This is not only true of what may be said to be remote from these bodies, but also of the very distance; which is interpos'd betwixt them; that being nothing but darkness, or the negation of light; without parts, without composition, invariable and indivisible. Now since this distance causes no perception different from what a blind man receives from his eyes, or what is convey'd to us in the darkest night, it must partake of the same properties: And as blindness and darkness afford us no ideas of extension, 'tis impossible that the dark and indistinguishable distance betwixt two bodies can ever produce that idea.

这是我们自然的和最熟悉的思维方式；但我们将通过稍加思考学会纠正这种思维方式。我们可以观察到，当两个物体出现在原来完全黑暗的地方时，唯一可以发现的变化是这两个物体的外观，其余的都和以前一样，是对光和每一个彩色或可见物体的完美否定。这不仅适用于离这些物体较远的东西，而且适用于它们之间的距离；它们之间只有黑暗，或对光的否定；没有部分，没有构成，是不变的，不可分割的。现在，既然这种距离造成的感知与盲人从他的眼睛中得到的感知，或在最黑暗的夜晚传达给我们的感知没有什么不同，它就必须具有相同的属性。由于失明和黑暗没有给我们带来任何延伸的概念，所以两个物体之间的黑暗和不可区分的距离不可能产生这种概念。

The sole difference betwixt an absolute darkness and the appearance of two or more visible luminous objects consists, as I said, in the objects themselves, and in the manner they affect our senses. The angles, which the rays of light flowing from them, form with each other; the motion that is requir'd in the eye, in its passage from one to the other; and the different parts of the organs, which are affected by them; these produce the only perceptions, from which we can judge of the distance. But as these perceptions are each of them simple and indivisible, they can never give us the idea of extension.

如我所说，绝对的黑暗与两个或多个可见的发光物体的出现之间的唯一区别在于这些物体本身，以及它们影响我们感官的方式。从这些物体流出的光线彼此形成的角度；眼睛在从一个物体到另一个物体的过程中所需要的运动；以及器官的不同部分受到的影响；这些产生了唯一的知觉，我们可以据此判断距离。但是，由于这些感觉都是简单的、不可分割的，它们永远不会给我们带来延伸的概念。

We may illustrate this by considering the sense of feeling, and the imaginary distance or interval interpos'd betwixt tangible or solid objects. I suppose two cases, viz. that of a man supported in the air, and moving his limbs to and fro, without meeting any thing tangible; and that of a man, who feeling something tangible, leaves it, and after a motion, of which he is sensible, perceives another tangible object; and I then ask, wherein consists the difference betwixt these two cases? No one will make any scruple to affirm, that it consists meerly in the perceiving those objects, and that the sensation, which arises from the motion, is in both cases the same: And as that sensation is not capable of conveying to us an idea of extension, when unaccompany'd with some other perception, it can no more give us that idea, when mix'd with the impressions of tangible objects; since that mixture produces no alteration upon it.

我们可以通过考虑感觉，以及有形或实体物体之间的想象距离或间隔来说明这一点。我假设有两种情况，即一个人支撑在空中，来回移动他的四肢，但没有遇到任何有形的东西；一个人感觉到有形的东西，离开了它，在运动之后，他感觉到了另一个有形的物体；然后我问，这两种情况之间的区别在哪里？没有人会不顾一切地断言，这仅仅在于对这些物体的感知，而由运动产生的感觉在这两种情况下都是一样的：既然这种感觉在没有其他感知的情况下无法向我们传达一种延伸的概念，那么当它与有形物体的印象混合在一起时，也无法给我们这种概念；因为这种混合不会对它产生改变。

But tho' motion and darkness, either alone, or attended with tangible and visible objects, convey no idea of a vacuum or extension without matter, yet they are the causes why we falsly imagine we can form such an idea. For there is a close relation betwixt that motion and darkness, and a real extension, or composition of visible and tangible objects. First, We may observe, that two visible objects appearing in the midst of utter darkness, affect the senses in the same manner, and form the same angle by the rays, which flow from them, and meet in the eye, as if the distance betwixt them were fill'd with visible objects, that give us a true idea of extension. The sensation of motion is likewise the same, when there is mating tangible interpos'd betwixt two bodies, as when we feel a compounded body, whose different parts are plac'd beyond each other.

但是，尽管运动和黑暗，无论是单独的，还是与有形的和可见的物体一起，都没有传达出没有物质的真空或延伸的概念，但它们是我们错误地想象我们可以形成这样一个概念的原因。因为这种运动和黑暗与真正的延伸或有形和无形物体的组成之间存在着密切的关系。首先，我们可以观察到，在一片漆黑中出现的两个可见物体，以同样的方式影响感官，并通过射线形成同样的角度，这些射线从它们那里流出来，并在眼睛里相遇，就像它们之间的距离充满了可见物体一样，这给我们一个真正的延伸概念。运动的感觉也是一样的，当两个物体之间存在着有形的交配时，就像我们感觉到一个复合体，它的不同部分被放置在彼此之外。

Secondly, We find by experience, that two bodies, which are so plac'd as to affect the senses in the same manner with two others, that have a certain extent of visible objects interpos'd betwixt them, are capable of receiving the same extent, without any sensible impulse or penetration, and without any change on that angle, under which they appear to the senses. In like manner, where there is one object, which we cannot feel after another without an interval, and the perceiving of that sensation we call motion in our hand or organ of sensation; experience shews us, that 'tis possible the same object may be felt with the same sensation of motion, along with the interpos'd impression of solid and tangible objects, attending the sensation. That is, in other words, an invisible and intangible distance may be converted into a visible and tangible one, without any change on the distant objects.

第二，我们根据经验发现，两个物体，如果它们的位置与另外两个物体的位置相同，对感官的影响也相同，它们之间有一定范围的可见物体，能够接受相同的范围，而没有任何感性的冲动或渗透，也没有任何角度的变化，在这种情况下，它们出现在感官上。同样，如果有一个物体，我们不能在另一个物体之后没有间隔地感觉到它，而我们的手或感觉器官对这种感觉的感知称为运动；经验告诉我们，同一物体有可能被感觉到同样的运动感觉，以及伴随这种感觉的固体和有形物体的印象。也就是说，换句话说，不可见的和无形的距离可以转化为可见的和有形的距离，而对遥远的物体没有任何改变。

Thirdly, We may observe, as another relation betwixt these two kinds of distance, that they have nearly the same effects on every natural phænomenon. For as all qualities, such as heat, cold, light, attraction, &c. diminish in proportion to the distance; there is but little difference observ'd, whether this distance be mark'd out by compounded and sensible objects, or be known only by the manner, in which the distant objects affect the senses.

第三，我们可以观察到，作为这两种距离之间的另一种关系，它们对每个自然现象的影响几乎都是一样的。因为所有的品质，如热、冷、光、吸引力等，都会随着距离的增加而减少；无论这种距离是由复合的、可感知的物体标示出来，还是仅由遥远的物体影响感官的方式来了解，都没有什么区别。

Here then are three relations betwixt that distance, which conveys the idea of extension, and that other, which is not fill'd with any colour'd or solid object. The distant objects affect the senses in the same manner, whether separated by the one distance or the other; the second species of distance is found capable of receiving the first; and they both equally diminish the force of every quality.

这里有三种关系，一种是传达延伸概念的距离，另一种是没有任何颜色或实体物体的距离。遥远的物体以同样的方式影响感官，不管是相隔一种距离还是另一种距离；第二种距离被发现能够接受第一种距离；它们都同样减少了每一种质量的力量。

These relations betwixt the two kinds of distance will afford us an easy reason, why the one has so often been taken for the other, and why we imagine we have an idea of extension without the idea of any object either of the sight or feeling. For we may establish it as a general maxim in this science of human nature, that wherever there is a close relation betwixt two ideas, the mind is very apt to mistake them, and in all its discourses and reasonings to use the one for the other. This phænomenon occurs on so many occasions, and is of such consequence, that I cannot forbear stopping a moment to examine its causes. I shall only premise, that we must distinguish exactly betwixt the phænomenon itself, and the causes, which I shall assign for it; and must not imagine from any uncertainty in the latter, that the former is also uncertain. The phænomenon may be real, tho' my explication be chimerical. The falshood of the one is no consequence of that of the other; tho' at the same time we may observe, that 'tis very natural for us to draw such a consequence; which is an evident instance of that very principle, which I endeavour to explain.

这两种距离之间的这些关系将为我们提供一个简单的理由，即为什么一个经常被当作另一个，以及为什么我们想象我们有一个延伸的概念，而没有任何视觉或感觉的对象的概念。因为我们可以把它作为这门人性科学的一般格言，即只要两个概念之间有密切的关系，头脑就很容易把它们搞错，并在其所有的讨论和推理中以一当百。这种现象发生在许多场合，而且具有如此大的影响，以至于我忍不住要停下来研究一下其原因。我只想说，我们必须准确区分现象本身和我为其指定的原因；不能因为后者的任何不确定性而认为前者也是不确定的。现象可能是真实的，尽管我的解释是虚构的。一个人的失败并不是另一个人的失败的结果；但同时我们可以看到，我们得出这样的结果是非常自然的；这正是我努力解释的那个原则的一个明显的例子。

When I receiv'd the relations of resemblance, contiguity and causation, as principles of union among ideas, without examining into their causes, 'twas more in prosecution of my first maxim, that we must in the end rest contented with experience, than for want of something specious and plausible, which I might have display'd on that subject. 'Twou'd have been easy to have made an imaginary dissection of the brain, and have shewn, why upon our conception of any idea, the animal spirits run into all the contiguous traces, and rouze up the other ideas, that are related to it. But tho' I have neglected any advantage, which I might have drawn from this topic in explaining the relations of ideas, I am afraid I must here have recourse to it, in order to account for the mistakes that arise from these relations. I shall therefore observe, that as the mind is endow'd with a power of exciting any idea it pleases; whenever it dispatches the spirits into that region of the brain, in which the idea is plac'd; these spirits always excite the idea, when they run into the proper traces, and rummage that cell, which belongs to the idea. But as their motion is seldom direct, and naturally turns a little to the one side or the other; for this reason the animal spirits, falling into the contiguous traces, present other related ideas in lieu of that, which the mind desir'd at first to survey. This change we are not always sensible of; but continuing still the same train of thought, make use of the related idea, which is presented to us, and employ it in our reasoning, as if it were the same with what we demanded. This is the cause of many mistakes and sophisms in philosophy; as will naturally be imagin'd, and as it wou'd be easy to show, if there was occasion.

当我接受了相似性、相邻性和因果性的关系，作为观念之间结合的原则，而没有研究它们的原因时，更多的是为了证明我的第一条格言，即我们最终必须满足于经验，而不是因为缺乏一些似是而非的东西，我本可以在这个问题上展示。我们可以很容易地对大脑进行假想的解剖，并说明为什么在我们对任何概念进行构思时，动物的精神会进入所有相邻的痕迹，并唤起其他与之相关的概念。但是，尽管我忽略了我在解释观念的关系时可能从这个话题中得到的任何好处，但我恐怕必须在这里求助于它，以解释这些关系所产生的错误。因此，我将观察到，由于心灵被赋予了激发任何它所喜欢的观念的能力；每当它把精神派遣到大脑的那个区域，而这个观念就安置在那里；这些精神总是激发这个观念，当它们跑到适当的地方，翻找属于这个观念的细胞。但是，由于它们的运动很少是直接的，而且自然会向一边或另一边转动；由于这个原因，动物的精神落入相邻的痕迹，呈现出其他相关的想法，以取代头脑最初想要调查的那个想法。我们并不总是能意识到这种变化；但我们仍然继续着同样的思路，利用呈现在我们面前的相关想法，并在我们的推理中使用它，就好像它与我们所要求的一样。这就是哲学中许多错误和诡辩的原因；人们自然会想到这一点，而且如果有机会的话，也很容易证明这一点。

Of the three relations above-mention'd that of resemblance is the most fertile source of error; and indeed there are few mistakes in reasoning, which do not borrow largely from that origin. Resembling ideas are not only related together, but the actions of the mind, which we employ in considering them, are so little different, that we are not able to distinguish them. This last circumstance is of great consequence; and we may in general observe, that wherever the actions of the mind in forming any two ideas are the same or resembling, we are very apt to confound these ideas, and take the one for the other. Of this we shall see many instances in the progress of this treatise. But tho' resemblance be the relation, which most readily produces a mistake in ideas, yet the others of causation and contiguity may also concur in the same influence. We might produce the figures of poets and orators, as sufficient proofs of this, were it as usual, as it is reasonable, in metaphysical subjects to draw our arguments from that quarter. But lest metaphysicians shou'd esteem this below their dignity, I shall borrow a proof from an observation, which may be made on most of their own discourses, viz. that 'tis usual for men to use words for ideas, and to talk instead of thinking in their reasonings. We use words for ideas, because they are commonly so closely connected, that the mind easily mistakes them. And this likewise is the reason, why we substitute the idea of a distance, which is not considered either as visible or tangible, in the room of extension, which is nothing but a composition of visible or tangible points dispos'd in a certain order. In causing this mistake there concur both the relations of causation and resemblance. As the first species of distance is found to be convertible into the second, 'tis in this respect a kind of cause; and the similarity of their manner of affecting the senses, and diminishing every quality, forms the relation of resemblance.

在上面提到的三种关系中，相似性是最容易产生错误的根源；事实上，推理中很少有不从这一根源出发的错误。相似的观念不仅联系在一起，而且我们在考虑这些观念时采用的思维方式差别很小，以至于我们无法将它们区分出来。这最后一个情况是非常重要的；我们可以看到，一般来说，只要思想在形成任何两个观念时的行动是相同的或相似的，我们就很容易混淆这些观念，并把一个当作另一个。在这篇论文的进展中，我们会看到很多这样的例子。但是，尽管相似是最容易在观念上产生错误的关系，但其他的因果关系和相邻关系也可能产生相同的影响。我们可以举出诗人和演说家的形象，作为这一点的充分证据，如果在形而上学的课题中，从那方面得出我们的论据，也是一样合理的。但为了避免形而上学者认为这低于他们的尊严，我将从他们自己的大部分论述中借用一个证据，即人们通常用语言来表达思想，在他们的推理中用谈话代替思考。我们用词来表达思想，是因为它们通常是紧密相连的，以至于头脑很容易将它们搞错。这也是为什么我们用距离的概念来代替延伸的概念的原因，因为距离既不被认为是可见的，也不被认为是有形的，而延伸只不过是由可见的或有形的点按一定顺序排列组成的。在造成这一错误的过程中，因果关系和相似关系同时存在。由于第一种距离被发现可以转化为第二种距离，因此在这方面是一种原因；而它们影响感官的方式的相似性，以及对每一种质量的削弱，构成了相似性的关系。

After this chain of reasoning and explication of my principles, I am now prepared to answer all the objections that have been offer'd, whether deriv'd from metaphysics or mechanics. The frequent disputes concerning a vacuum, or extension without matter, prove not the reality of the idea, upon which the dispute turns; there being nothing more common, than to see men deceive themselves in this particular; especially when by means of any close relation, there is another idea presented, which may be the occasion of their mistake.

在对我的原则进行了这一连串的推理和阐述之后，我现在准备回答所有被提出的反对意见，无论是从形而上学还是从机械学中得出的。关于真空或无物质的延伸的频繁争论，并不证明争论所依据的理念的真实性；没有什么比看到人们在这一点上欺骗自己更常见的了；特别是当通过任何密切的关系，有另一个理念的出现，这可能是他们错误的原因。

We may make almost the same answer to the second objection, deriv'd from the conjunction of the ideas of rest and annihilation. When every thing is annihilated in the chamber, and the walls continue immovable, the chamber must be conceiv'd much in the same manner as at present, when the air that fills it, is not an object of the senses. This annihilation leaves to the eye, that fictitious distance, which is discover'd by the different parts of the organ, that are affected, and by the degrees of light and shade; and to the feeling, that which consists in a sensation of motion in the hand, or other member of the body. In vain shou'd we search any farther. On whichever side we turn this subject, we shall find that these are the only impressions such an object can produce after the suppos'd annihilation; and it has already been remark'd, that impressions can give rise to no ideas, but to such as resemble them.

我们可以对第二个反对意见做出几乎相同的回答，这是从静止和湮灭这两个概念的结合中得出的。当房间里的每样东西都消失了，而墙壁继续保持不动，那么房间的概念就必须和现在一样，当填充在房间里的空气不是感官的对象时，它就会被想象成同样的方式。这种消失给眼睛留下了虚构的距离，这种距离是通过器官的不同部分受到影响以及光照和阴影的程度来发现的；给感觉留下的是手或身体其他部分的运动感觉。我们再去寻找也是徒劳的。无论我们把这个问题转向哪一边，我们都会发现，这些都是这样一个物体在假定的湮灭之后所能产生的唯一印象；而且我们已经说过，印象不能产生任何观念，只能产生与之相似的观念。

Since a body interpos'd betwixt two others may be suppos'd to be annihilated, without producing any change upon such as lie on each hand of it, 'tis easily conceiv'd, how it, may be created anew, and yet produce as little alteration. Now the motion of a body has much the same effect as its creation. The distant bodies are no more affected in the one case, than in the other. This suffices to satisfy the imagination, and proves there is no repugnance in such a motion. Afterwards experience comes in play to persuade us that two bodies, situated in the manner above-describ'd, have really such a capacity of receiving body betwixt them, and that there is no obstacle to the conversion of the invisible and intangible distance into one that is visible and tangible. However natural that conversation may seem, we cannot be sure it is practicable, before we have had experience of it.

既然一个介于两个物体之间的物体可以被认为是被消灭了，而不会对位于它两边的物体产生任何变化，那么就很容易想象，它是如何被重新创造出来的，但却产生同样少的变化。现在，一个物体的运动与它的创造有着同样的效果。在一种情况下，远处的物体不会比另一种情况下受到更多影响。这足以满足人们的想象力，并证明这种运动并不令人反感。之后，经验来说服我们，两个身体，以上面描述的方式，真的有这样的能力，接受他们之间的身体，没有障碍的无形和无形的距离转换为一个可见的和有形的。无论这种对话看起来多么自然，在我们有了经验之前，我们不能确定它是否可行。

Thus I seem to have answer'd the three objections above mention'd; tho' at the same time I am sensible, that few will be satisfy'd with these answers, but will immediately propose new objections and difficulties. 'Twill probably he said, that my reasoning makes nothing to the matter in hand, and that I explain only the manner in which objects affect the senses, without endeavouring to account for their real nature and operations. Tho' there be nothing visible or tangible interpos'd betwixt two bodies, yet we find by experience, that the bodies may be plac'd in the same manner, with regard to the eye, and require the same motion of the hand in passing from one to the other, as if divided by something visible and tangible. This invisible and intangible distance is also found by experience to contain a capacity of receiving body, or of becoming visible and tangible. Here is the whole of my system; and in no part of it have I endeavour'd to explain the cause, which separates bodies after this manner, and gives them a capacity of receiving others betwixt them, without any impulse or penetration.

这样，我似乎已经回答了上面提到的三个反对意见；但同时我也意识到，很少有人会对这些回答感到满意，而会立即提出新的反对意见和困难。他可能会说，我的推理对眼前的问题毫无意义，我只解释了物体影响感官的方式，而没有努力说明它们的真实性质和作用。尽管两个物体之间没有任何可见或有形的东西，但我们根据经验发现，就眼睛而言，这两个物体可以以同样的方式放置，并且在从一个物体到另一个物体时需要同样的手部动作，就像被可见和有形的东西分割一样。根据经验，这种不可见的和无形的距离也被发现含有接受身体的能力，或成为可见和有形的。这就是我的系统的全部内容；在其中的任何部分，我都没有努力解释以这种方式分开身体的原因，并使它们有能力接受它们之间的其他物体，而没有任何冲动或渗透。

I answer this objection, by pleading guilty, and by confessing that my intention never was to penetrate into the nature of bodies, or explain the secret causes of their operations. For besides that this belongs not to my present purpose, I am afraid, that such an enterprize is beyond the reach of human understanding, and that we can never pretend to know body otherwise than by those external properties, which discover themselves to the senses. As to those who attempt any thing farther, I cannot approve of their ambition, till I see, in some one instance at least, that they have met with success. But at present I content myself with knowing perfectly the manner in which objects affect my senses, and their connections with each other, as far as experience informs me of them. This suffices for the conduct of life; and this also suffices for my philosophy, which pretends only to explain the nature and causes of our perceptions, or impressions and ideas.

对于这种反对意见，我承认有罪，并承认我的目的从来都不是要深入了解身体的本质，或解释它们运作的秘密原因。因为除了这不属于我目前的目的之外，我担心这样的研究是人类理解力所不能及的，而且我们永远不能假装认识身体，而只能通过感官发现的那些外部属性。至于那些试图做更多事情的人，我不能赞同他们的野心，除非我看到，至少在某个例子中，他们获得了成功。但目前我只满足于完全了解物体影响我的感官的方式，以及它们之间的联系，只要经验告诉我这些。这对生活行为来说已经足够了；这对我的哲学来说也足够了，因为我的哲学只想解释我们的感知，或印象和观念的性质和原因。

I shall conclude this subject of extension with a paradox, which will easily be explain'd from the foregoing reasoning. This paradox is, that if you are pleas'd to give to the invisible and intangible distance, or in other words, to the capacity of becoming visible and tangible distance, the name of a vacuum, extension and matter are the same, and yet there is a vacuum. If you will not give it that name, motion is possible in a plenum, without any impulse in infinitum, without returning in a circle, and without penetration. But however we may express ourselves, we must always confess, that we have no idea of any real extension without filling it with sensible objects, and conceiving its parts as visible or tangible.

我将以一个悖论来结束这个关于延伸的话题，从前面的推理中很容易解释这个悖论。这个悖论是，如果你愿意给不可见的和无形的距离，或者换句话说，给成为可见的和有形的距离的能力，起一个真空的名字，那么延伸和物质是一样的，但却有一个真空。如果你不愿意给它这个名字，运动就有可能在一个羽状体中进行，没有任何冲动，在无限的范围内，没有返回的圈子，也没有渗透。但是，无论我们如何表达自己，我们必须始终承认，如果不以可感知的物体来填充它，不把它的各个部分设想为可见的或有形的，我们就对任何真正的扩展没有概念。

As to the doctrine, that time is nothing but the manner, in which some real objects exist; we may observe, that 'tis liable to the same objections as the similar doctrine with regard to extension. If it be a sufficient proof that we have the idea of a vacuum, because we dispute and reason concerning it; we must for the same reason have the idea of time without any changeable existence; since there is no subject of dispute more frequent and common. But that we really have no such idea, is certain. For whence shou'd it be deriv'd? Does it arise from an impression of sensation or of reflection? Point it out distinctly to us, that we may know its nature and qualities. But if you cannot point out any such impression, you may be certain you are mistaken, when you imagine you have any such idea.

至于说时间只不过是一些真实物体存在的方式的学说；我们可以注意到，这与关于延伸的类似学说一样，容易受到反对。如果这足以证明我们有一个真空的概念，因为我们对它有争议和推理；我们必须以同样的理由有一个没有任何变化的存在的时间概念；因为没有任何争议的主题更频繁和普遍。但是，我们确实没有这种想法，这是肯定的。因为它应该从何而来？它是由感觉的印象还是由思考的印象产生的？请向我们清楚地指出来，以便我们能知道它的性质和品质。但是，如果你不能指出任何这样的印象，你就可以肯定，当你想象你有任何这样的想法时，你是错的。

But tho' it be impossible to shew the impression, from which the idea of time without a changeable existence is deriv'd; yet we can easily point out those appearances, which make us fancy we have that idea. For we may observe, that there is a continual succession of perceptions in our mind; so that the idea of time being for ever present with us; when we consider a stedfast object at five-a-clock, and regard the same at six; we are apt to apply to it that idea in the same manner as if every moment were distinguish'd by a different position, or an alteration of the object. The first and second appearances of the object, being compar'd with the succession of our perceptions, seem equally remov'd as if the object had really chang'd. To which we may add, what experience shews us, that the object was susceptible of such a number of changes betwixt these appearances; as also that the unchangeable or rather fictitious duration has the same effect upon every quality, by encreasing or diminishing it, as that succession, which is obvious to the senses. From these three relations we are apt to confound our ideas, and imagine we can form the idea of a time and duration, without any change or succession.

但是，尽管不可能显示出没有变化存在的时间观念所产生的印象，但我们可以很容易地指出那些使我们认为我们有这种观念的表象。因为我们可以观察到，在我们的头脑中存在着持续不断的感知；因此，时间的概念永远存在于我们身上；当我们在五点时考虑一个固定的物体，在六点时考虑同一个物体；我们很可能以同样的方式将这个概念应用于它，就好像每一刻都有不同的位置，或者物体的变化。物体的第一次和第二次出现，与我们的感知的连续性相比较，似乎同样被移除，就像物体真的改变了一样。此外，我们还可以补充说，经验告诉我们，在这些表象之间，物体很容易发生如此多的变化；同样，不可改变的或相当虚构的持续时间，通过增加或减少它，对每一种质量都有同样的影响，这对感官来说是明显的。从这三种关系中，我们很容易混淆我们的观念，并想象我们可以形成一个没有任何变化或连续的时间和期限的概念。

 

Section 6. Of The Idea Of Existence, And Of External Existence

第 6 节。关于存在的概念和外部存在的概念

 

It may not be amiss, before we leave this subject, to explain the ideas of existence and of external existence; which have their difficulties, as well as the ideas of space and time. By this means we shall be the better prepar'd for the examination of knowledge and probability, when we understand perfectly all those particular ideas, which may enter into our reasoning.

在我们离开这个话题之前，解释一下存在和外部存在的概念可能不会有错；这和空间和时间的概念一样，都有其困难。通过这种方式，当我们完全理解所有这些可能进入我们推理的特殊观念时，我们将为知识和概率的研究做更好的准备。

There is no impression nor idea of any kind, of which we have any consciousness or memory, that is not conceiv'd as existent; and 'tis evident, that from this consciousness the most perfect idea and assurance of being is deriv'd. From hence we may form a dilemma, the most clear and conclusive that can be imagin'd, viz. that since we never remember any idea or impression without attributing existence to it, the idea of existence must either be deriv'd from a distinct impression, conjoin'd with every perception or object of our thought, or must be the very same with the idea of the perception or object.

在我们有任何意识或记忆的情况下，没有任何印象或想法不被认为是存在的；而且很明显，从这种意识中衍生出了最完美的存在观念和保证。因此，我们可以形成一个可以想象到的最清晰和最确定的难题，即：既然我们在记忆任何观念或印象时都没有将其归结为存在，那么存在的观念要么是从一个独特的印象中衍生出来的，与我们思想的每一个感知或对象结合在一起，要么必须与感知或对象的观念完全相同。

As this dilemma is an evident consequence of the principle, that every idea arises from a similar impression, so our decision betwixt the propositions of the dilemma is no more doubtful. So far from there being any distinct impression, attending every impression and every idea, that I do not think there are any two distinct impressions, which are inseparably conjoin'd. Tho' certain sensations may at one time be united, we quickly find they admit of a separation, and may be presented apart. And thus, tho' every impression and idea we remember be consider'd as existent, the idea of existence is not deriv'd from any particular impression.

由于这个难题是每一个观念都产生于类似的印象这一原则的明显后果，所以我们对这个难题的两个命题的决定也就不再有疑问了。每一个印象和每一个想法都有一个不同的印象，所以我认为不存在任何两个不同的印象，它们是不可分割地结合在一起的。尽管某些感觉可能在某一时刻结合在一起，但我们很快就会发现它们可以分开，并且可以分开呈现。因此，尽管我们记得的每一个印象和想法都被认为是存在的，但存在的想法并不是由任何特定的印象衍生出来的。

The idea of existence, then, is the very same with the idea of what we conceive to be existent. To reflect on any thing simply, and to reflect on it as existent, are nothing different from each other. That idea, when conjoin'd with the idea of any object, makes no addition to it. Whatever we conceive, we conceive to be existent. Any idea we please to form is the idea of a being; and the idea of a being is any idea we please to form.

那么，存在的概念与我们所设想的存在的概念是一样的。对任何事物的简单思考和对它的存在性的思考，彼此没有什么不同。这种想法，当与任何物体的想法结合在一起时，不会对其进行补充。无论我们设想的是什么，我们都设想它是存在的。我们愿意形成的任何观念都是一个存在的观念；而一个存在的观念就是我们愿意形成的任何观念。

Whoever opposes this, must necessarily point out that distinct impression, from which the idea of entity is deriv'd, and must prove, that this impression is inseparable from every perception we believe to be existent. This we may without hesitation conclude to be impossible.

无论谁反对这一点，都必须指出那个独特的印象，实体的概念就是从那里衍生出来的，而且必须证明，这个印象与我们认为是存在的每一个知觉是不可分割的。我们可以毫不犹豫地断定，这是不可能的。

Our foregoing11 reasoning concerning the distinction of ideas without any real difference will not here serve us in any stead. That kind of distinction is founded on the different resemblances, which the same simple idea may have to several different ideas. But no object can be presented resembling some object with respect to its existence, and different from others in the same particular; since every object, that is presented, must necessarily be existent.

我们前面提到的11关于没有任何实际差别的观念的区分的推理，在这里不会对我们有任何帮助。这种区分是建立在不同的相似性上的，同一个简单的概念可能与几个不同的概念有不同的相似性。但是，不可能有任何对象在其存在方面与某些对象相似，而在相同的细节上又与其他对象不同；因为每一个被提出的对象，都必须是存在的。

A like reasoning will account for the idea of external existence. We may observe, that 'tis universally allow'd by philosophers, and is besides pretty obvious of itself, that nothing is ever really present with the mind but its perceptions or impressions and ideas, and that external objects become known to us only by those perceptions they occasion. To hate, to love, to think, to feel, to see; all this is nothing but to perceive.

一个类似的推理将解释外部存在的概念。我们可以看到，哲学家们普遍认为，除了感知、印象和观念之外，没有任何东西真正存在于心灵之中，而外部物体只有通过它们引起的感知才能为我们所知。恨，爱，想，感觉，看；所有这些都不过是感知。

Now since nothing is ever present to the mind but perceptions, and since all ideas are deriv'd from something antecedently present to the mind; it follows, that 'tis impossible for us so much as to conceive or form an idea of any thing specifically different from ideas and impressions. Let us fix our attention out of ourselves as much as possible: Let us chace our imagination to the heavens, or to the utmost limits of the universe; we never really advance a step beyond ourselves, nor can conceive any kind of existence, but those perceptions, which have appear'd in that narrow compass. This is the universe of the imagination, nor have we any idea but what is there produc'd.

既然除了感知之外，没有任何东西会出现在心灵中，既然所有的观念都是从先前出现在心灵中的东西衍生出来的，那么，我们就不可能设想或形成与观念和印象具体不同的任何东西的想法。让我们尽可能地把我们的注意力从自己身上移开。让我们把我们的想象力引向天堂，或引向宇宙的最大极限；我们从未真正超越自己一步，也无法想象任何一种存在，只有那些出现在那个狭窄范围内的感知。这就是想象力的宇宙，除了那里产生的东西，我们也没有任何想法。

The farthest we can go towards a conception of external objects, when suppos'd specifically different from our perceptions, is to form a relative idea of them, without pretending to comprehend the related objects. Generally speaking we do not suppose them specifically different; but only attribute to them different relations, connections and durations. But of this more fully hereafter12.

当假定外部物体与我们的感知特别不同时，我们对外部物体的概念所能达到的最远程度是对它们形成一个相对的概念，而不是假装理解相关的物体。一般来说，我们不认为它们特别不同；而只是把不同的关系、联系和持续时间赋予它们。但关于这一点，下文会有更充分的说明12.

 

PART 3: OF KNOWLEDGE AND PROBABILITY

第三部分。知识与概率的关系

 

Section 1. Of Knowledge

第一节。关于知识

 

There are 13seven different kinds of philosophical relation, viz. resemblance, identity, relations of time and place, proportion in quantity or number, degrees in any quality, contrariety, and causation. These relations may be divided into two classes; into such as depend entirely on the ideas, which we compare together, and such as may be chang'd without any change in the ideas. 'Tis from the idea of a triangle, that we discover the relation of equality, which its three angles bear to two right ones; and this relation is invariable, as long as our idea remains the same. On the contrary, the relations of contiguity and distance betwixt two objects may be chang'd merely by an alteration of their place, without any change on the objects themselves or on their ideas; and the place depends on a hundred different accidents, which cannot be foreseen by the mind. 'Tis the same case with identity and causation. Two objects, tho' perfectly resembling each other, and even appearing in the same place at different times, may be numerically different: And as the power, by which one object produces another, is never discoverable merely from their idea, 'tis evident cause and effect are relations, of which we receive information from experience, and not from any abstract reasoning or reflection. There is no single phænomenon, even the most simple, which can be accounted for from the qualities of the objects, as they appear to us; or which we cou'd foresee without the help of our memory and experience.

哲学关系有 13有七种不同的哲学关系，即：相似性、同一性、时间和地点的关系、数量或数字的比例、任何质量的程度、对比性和因果关系。这些关系可以分为两类；一类是完全取决于我们一起比较的观念，另一类是在观念没有任何变化的情况下可以改变的关系。从三角形的概念中，我们发现了它的三个角与两个直角之间的平等关系；只要我们的概念保持不变，这种关系就是不变的。相反，两个物体之间的毗连关系和距离关系可能仅仅因为它们的位置改变而改变，而物体本身或它们的观念没有任何变化；而位置取决于一百种不同的意外情况，这不是头脑所能预见的。身份和因果关系的情况也是如此。两个物体虽然完全相似，甚至在不同的时间出现在同一个地方，但在数量上可能是不同的。由于一个物体产生另一个物体的力量，仅仅从它们的概念中是无法发现的，因此很明显，因果关系是我们从经验中得到的信息，而不是从任何抽象的推理或思考中得到的。没有一个现象，即使是最简单的现象，可以从物体的品质中得到解释，因为它们在我们面前出现；或者说，如果没有我们的记忆和经验的帮助，我们是可以预见的。

It appears, therefore, that of these seven philosophical relations, there remain only four, which depending solely upon ideas, can be the objects of knowledge and certainty. These four are resemblance, contrariety, degrees of quality, and proportions in quantity or number. Three of these relations are discoverable at first sight, and fall more properly under the province of intuition than demonstration. When any objects resemble each other, the resemblance will at first strike the eye, or rather the mind; and seldom requires a second examination. The case is the same with contrariety, and with the degrees of any quality. No one can once doubt but existence and non-existence destroy each other, and are perfectly incompatible and contrary. And tho' it be impossible to judge exactly of the degrees of any quality, such as colour, taste, heat, cold, when the difference betwixt them is very small; yet 'tis easy to decide, that any of them is superior or inferior to another, when their difference is considerable. And this decision we always pronounce at first sight, without any enquiry or reasoning.

因此，在这七种哲学关系中，似乎只剩下四种，它们完全取决于观念，可以成为知识和确定性的对象。这四种关系是：相似性、对比性、质量的程度和数量的比例。这些关系中的三个可以在第一时间发现，属于直觉的范畴，而不是证明。当任何物体彼此相似时，这种相似性会在第一时间击中眼睛，或者说是心灵；而且很少需要进行第二次检查。对比的情况也是如此，任何质量的程度也是如此。没有人会怀疑，存在和不存在是相互破坏的，是完全不相容和相反的。虽然不可能准确判断任何质量的程度，如颜色、味道、热度、冷度，当它们之间的差异很小时；但当它们之间的差异很大时，很容易决定它们中的任何一个比另一个高或低。我们总是在第一眼看到时就作出这种决定，而不需要进行任何调查或推理。

We might proceed, after the same manner, in fixing the proportions of quantity or number, and might at one view observe a superiority or inferiority betwixt any numbers, or figures; especially where the difference is very great and remarkable. As to equality or any exact proportion, we can only guess at it from a single consideration; except in very short numbers, or very limited portions of extension; which are comprehended in an instant, and where we perceive an impossibility of falling into any considerable error. In all other cases we must settle the proportions with some liberty, or proceed in a more artificial manner.

我们可以按照同样的方式来确定数量或数字的比例，并且可以从一个角度来观察任何数字或图形之间的优劣；特别是在差异非常大和显著的地方。至于平等或任何精确的比例，我们只能从单一的考虑中猜测它；除了在非常短的数字或非常有限的延伸部分中；这些数字是在瞬间被理解的，而且我们认为不可能落入任何相当大的错误。在所有其他情况下，我们必须自由地确定比例，或者以一种更人为的方式进行。

I have already observ'd, that geometry, or the art, by which we fix the proportions of figures; tho' it much excels, both in universality and exactness, the loose judgments of the senses and imagination; yet never attains a perfect precision and exactness. Its first principles are still drawn from the general appearance of the objects; and that appearance can never afford us any security, when we examine the prodigious minuteness of which nature is susceptible. Our ideas seem to give a perfect assurance, that no two right lines can have a common segment; but if we consider these ideas, we shall find, that they always suppose a sensible inclination of the two lines, and that where the angle they form is extremely small, we have no standard of a right line so precise as to assure us of the truth of this proposition. 'Tis the same case with most of the primary decisions of the mathematics. There remain, therefore, algebra and arithmetic as the only sciences, in which we can carry on a chain of reasoning to any degree of intricacy, and yet preserve a perfect exactness and certainty. We are possest of a precise standard, by which we can judge of the equality and proportion of numbers; and according as they correspond or not to that standard, we determine their relations, without any possibility of error. When two numbers are so combin'd, as that the one has always an unite answering to every unite of the other, we pronounce them equal; and 'tis for want of such a standard of equality in extension, that geometry can scarce be esteem'd a perfect and infallible science.

我已经注意到，几何学，或者说我们用来确定数字比例的艺术；虽然它在普遍性和精确性方面远远超过了感官和想象力的松散判断；但却从未达到完美的精确度和准确度。它的首要原则仍然是从物体的一般外观中得出的；而当我们研究自然界容易出现的惊人的细微差别时，这种外观永远无法给我们带来任何安全感。我们的想法似乎给了一个完美的保证，即没有两条直线能有一个共同的线段；但如果我们考虑这些想法，我们会发现，它们总是假定两条线有一个明显的倾斜，而且在它们形成的角度极小的情况下，我们没有一个如此精确的直线标准来保证这个命题的真实性。大多数数学的主要决定也是这样的情况。因此，代数和算术仍然是唯一的科学，在这些科学中，我们可以进行任何程度的复杂推理，但又能保持完美的精确性和确定性。我们拥有一个精确的标准，通过这个标准，我们可以判断数字的平等和比例；根据它们是否符合这个标准，我们确定它们的关系，没有任何错误的可能性。当两个数字如此结合时，一个总是有一个联合体与另一个的联合体相呼应，我们就宣布它们是相等的；正是因为缺少这样一个平等的扩展标准，几何学才很难被视为一门完美无缺的科学。

But here it may not be amiss to obviate a difficulty, which may arise from my asserting, that tho' geometry falls short of that perfect precision and certainty, which are peculiar to arithmetic and algebra, yet it excels the imperfect judgments of our senses and imagination. The reason why I impute any defect to geometry, is, because its original and fundamental principles are deriv' d merely from appearances; and it may perhaps be imagin'd, that this defect must always attend it, and keep it from ever reaching a greater exactness in the comparison of objects or ideas, than what our eye or imagination alone is able to attain. I own that this defect so far attends it, as to keep it from ever aspiring to a full certainty: But since these fundamental principles depend on the easiest and least deceitful appearances, they bestow on their consequences a degree of exactness, of which these consequences are singly incapable. 'Tis impossible for the eye to determine the angles of a chiliagon to be equal to 1996 right angles, or make any conjecture, that approaches this proportion; but when it determines, that right lines cannot concur; that we cannot draw more than one right line between two given points; its mistakes can never be of any consequence. And this is the nature and use of geometry, to run us up to such appearances, as, by reason of their simplicity, cannot lead us into any considerable error.

但是，在这里，我们不妨消除一个困难，这个困难可能来自于我的断言，即虽然几何学没有达到算术和代数所特有的那种完美的精确性和确定性，但它却比我们的感官和想象力的不完美判断要好。我之所以将任何缺陷归咎于几何学，是因为它的原始和基本原则仅仅是从表象中推导出来的；也许可以想象，这种缺陷必须始终伴随着它，并使它在比较物体或概念方面永远无法达到比我们的眼睛或想象力所能达到的更精确的程度。但由于这些基本原则取决于最简单和最不具欺骗性的表象，它们赋予其结果以一定程度的精确性，而这些结果是单独不能达到的。眼睛不可能确定一个斜角等于 1996 个直角，也不可能做出任何接近这一比例的猜测；但是当它确定直角线不可能同时出现，我们不可能在两个给定的点之间画出一条以上的直角线时，它的错误就不会有任何影响了。这就是几何学的性质和用途，它让我们看到这样的表象，由于它们的简单性，不会使我们陷入任何重大的错误。

I shall here take occasion to propose a second observation concerning our demonstrative reasonings, which is suggested by the same subject of the mathematics. 'Tis usual with mathematicians, to pretend, that those ideas, which are their objects, are of so refin'd and spiritual a nature, that they fall not under the conception of the fancy, but must be comprehended by a pure and intellectual view, of which the superior faculties of the soul are alone capable. The same notion runs thro' most parts of philosophy, and is principally made use of to explain our abstract ideas, and to shew how we can form an idea of a triangle, for instance, which shall neither be an isoceles nor scalenurn, nor be confin'd to any particular length and proportion of sides. 'Tis easy to see, why philosophers are so fond of this notion of some spiritual and refin'd perceptions; since by that means they cover many of their absurdities, and may refuse to submit to the decisions of clear ideas, by appealing to such as are obscure and uncertain. But to destroy this artifice, we need but reflect on that principle so oft insisted on, that all our ideas are copy'd from our impressions. For from thence we may immediately conclude, that since all impressions are clear and precise, the ideas, which are copy'd from them, must be of the same nature, and can never, but from our fault, contain any thing so dark and intricate. An idea is by its very nature weaker and fainter than an impression; but being in every other respect the same, cannot imply any very great mystery. If its weakness render it obscure, 'tis our business to remedy that defect, as much as possible, by keeping the idea steady and precise; and till we have done so, 'tis in vain to pretend to reasoning and philosophy.

在此，我想就我们的演示性推理提出第二点意见，这是由数学的同一主题提出的。数学家们通常认为，作为其对象的那些理念具有如此精炼和精神的性质，以至于它们不属于幻想的范畴，而必须由一种纯粹的智力观点来理解，只有灵魂的高级能力才能做到。同样的概念贯穿了哲学的大部分内容，主要用来解释我们的抽象概念，并说明我们如何形成一个三角形的概念，例如，它既不是等腰三角形，也不是鳞片形，也不限于任何特定的长度和边的比例。不难看出，为什么哲学家们如此喜欢这种关于精神和精炼的观念；因为通过这种方式，他们可以掩盖他们的许多荒谬之处，并且可以拒绝服从清晰观念的决定，而诉诸于那些模糊和不确定的观念。但要破除这种诡计，我们只需反思一下那个经常被坚持的原则，即我们所有的观念都是从我们的印象中复制的。因为从这里我们可以立即得出结论，既然所有的印象都是清晰而准确的，那么从印象中复制出来的观念就必须具有相同的性质，而且除了我们的错误之外，永远不可能包含任何如此黑暗和复杂的东西。观念就其本质而言，比印象更弱、更微弱；但在其他方面都是一样的，不可能意味着任何非常大的神秘性。如果它的弱点使它变得模糊不清，那么我们的任务就是尽可能地弥补这一缺陷，使理念保持稳定和精确；在我们这样做之前，假装推理和哲学是徒劳的。

 

Section 2. Of Probability; And Of The Idea Of Cause And Effect

第二节。概率；以及因果关系的概念

 

This is all I think necessary to observe concerning those four relations, which are the foundation of science; but as to the other three, which depend not upon the idea, and may be absent or present even while that remains the same, 'twill be proper to explain them more particularly. These three relations are identity, the situations in time and place, and causation.

关于这四种关系，我认为需要注意的就是这些，它们是科学的基础；但至于其他三种关系，它们不取决于理念，甚至在理念保持不变的情况下也可能不存在或存在，对它们进行更具体的解释将是恰当的。这三种关系是同一性、时间和地点的情况以及因果关系。

All kinds of reasoning consist in nothing but a companion, and a discovery of those relations, either constant or inconstant, which two or more objects bear to each other. This comparison we may make, either when both the objects are present to the senses, or when neither of them is present, or when only one. When both the objects are present to the senses along with the relation, we call this perception rather than reasoning; nor is there in this case any exercise of the thought, or any action, properly speaking, but a mere passive admission of the impressions thro' the organs of sensation. According to this way of thinking, we ought not to receive as reasoning any of the observations we may make concerning identity, and the relations of time and place; since in none of them the mind can go beyond what is immediately present to the senses, either to discover the real existence or the relations of objects. 'Tis only causation, which produces such a connexion, as to give us assurance from the existence or action of one object, that 'twas follow'd or preceded by any other existence or action; nor can the other two relations be ever made use of in reasoning, except so far as they either affect or are affected by it. There is nothing in any objects to perswade us, that they are either always remote or always contiguous; and when from experience and observation we discover, that their relation in this particular is invariable, we always conclude there is some secret cause, which separates or unites them. The same reasoning extends to identity. We readily suppose an object may continue individually the same, tho' several times absent from and present to the senses; and ascribe to it an identity, notwithstanding the interruption of the perception, whenever we conclude, that if we had kept our eye or hand constantly upon it, it wou'd have convey'd an invariable and uninterrupted perception. But this conclusion beyond the impressions of our senses can be founded only on the connexion of cause and effect; nor can we otherwise have any security, that the object is not chang'd upon us, however much the new object may resemble that which was formerly present to the senses. Whenever we discover such a perfect resemblance, we consider, whether it be common in that species of objects; whether possibly or probably any cause cou'd operate in producing the change and resemblance; and according as we determine concerning these causes and effects, we form our judgment concerning the identity of the object.

所有类型的推理都是由一个伙伴组成的，并发现两个或多个物体之间的那些关系，无论是恒定的还是不恒定的。我们可以在两个物体都存在于感官中时进行这种比较，也可以在它们都不存在或只有一个物体存在时进行这种比较。当两个物体都存在于感官中，并有这种关系时，我们称之为感知，而不是推理；在这种情况下，也没有任何思想的运动，或任何行动，正确地说，只是通过感觉器官被动地接受印象而已。根据这种思维方式，我们不应该把我们可能做出的关于特性以及时间和地点 关系的任何观察作为推理来接受；因为在这些观察中，思想不可能超越感官直接呈现的东西，也不可能发现物体的真实存在或关系。只有因果关系才会产生这样的联系，使我们从一个物体的存在或行动中得到保证，即它是由任何其他的存在或行动所跟随或引导的；在推理中也不能利用其他两种关系，除非它们影响或受其影响。在任何物体中都没有任何东西可以说服我们，它们要么总是遥远的，要么总是相邻的；当我们从经验和观察中发现，它们在这个方面的关系是不变的，我们总是得出结论，有一些秘密的原因，把它们分开或联合起来。同样的推理也延伸到了特性上。我们很容易认为，一个物体虽然多次不在感官上，但它可以单独保持不变；尽管感知被打断，但只要我们得出结论，如果我们的眼睛或手一直盯着它，它就会传达一个不变的和不间断的感知。但是，这种超越我们感官印象的结论只能建立在因果关系的基础上；否则，我们也不能有任何安全感，即物体没有在我们身上发生变化，无论新的物体多么类似于以前呈现在感官面前的物体。每当我们发现这种完美的相似性时，我们就会考虑它在该种物体中是否常见；是否可能或可能有任何原因会产生这种变化和相似性；根据我们对这些原因和效果的判断，我们就会形成我们对该物体身份的判断。

Here then it appears, that of those three relations, which depend not upon the mere ideas, the only one, that can be trac'd beyond our senses, and informs us of existences and objects, which we do not see or feel, is causation. This relation, therefore, we shall endeavour to explain fully before we leave the subject of the understanding.

这样看来，在这三种不依赖于单纯观念的关系中，唯一可以超越我们的感官，并告诉我们我们看不到或感觉不到的存在和对象的关系，就是因果关系。因此，在我们离开理解的主题之前，我们将努力充分解释这种关系。

To begin regularly, we must consider the idea of causation, and see from what origin it is deriv'd. 'Tis impossible to reason justly, without understanding perfectly the idea concerning which we reason; and 'tis impossible perfectly to understand any idea, without tracing it up to its origin, and examining that primary impression, from which it arises. The examination of the impression bestows a clearness on the idea; and the examination of the idea bestows a like clearness on all our reasoning.

为了有规律地开始，我们必须考虑因果关系的概念，看看它是从什么地方衍生出来的。如果不完全理解我们所推理的观念，就不可能进行公正的推理；如果不追溯到它的起源，不检查它所产生的那个主要印象，就不可能完全理解任何观念。对印象的研究使理念更加清晰；对理念的研究使我们所有的推理也同样清晰。

Let us therefore cast our eye on any two objects, which we call cause and effect, and turn them on all sides, in order to find that impression, which produces an idea of such prodigious consequence. At first sight I perceive, that I must not search for it in any of the particular qualities of the objects; since, which-ever of these qualities I pitch on, I find some object, that is not possest of it, and yet falls under the denomination of cause or effect. And indeed there is nothing existent, either externally or internally, which is not to be consider'd either as a cause or an effect; tho' 'tis plain there is no one quality, which universally belongs to all beings, and gives them a title to that denomination. The idea, then, of causation must be deriv'd from some relation among objects; and that relation we must now endeavour to discover. I find in the first place, that whatever objects are consider'd as causes or effects, are contiguous; and that nothing can operate in a time or place, which is ever so little remov'd from those of its existence. Tho' distant objects may sometimes seem productive of each other, they are commonly found upon examination to be link'd by a chain of causes, which are contiguous among themselves, and to the distant objects; and when in any particular instance we cannot discover this connexion, we still presume it to exist. We may therefore consider the relation of contiguity as essential to that of causation; at least may suppose it such, according to the general opinion, till we can find a more14 proper occasion to clear up this matter, by examining what objects are or are not susceptible of juxta-position and conjunction.

因此，让我们把目光投向任何两个我们称之为因果的物体，并把它们转到四面八方，以便找到那个产生如此巨大影响的想法的印象。第一眼我就发现，我不能在物体的任何特定品质中寻找它；因为无论我在这些品质中选择哪一种，我都会发现有些物体不具备这种品质，但却属于因或果的范畴。事实上，无论是外部还是内部，没有任何存在物不被视为因或果；但很明显，没有一种品质普遍属于所有的生命，并使它们有资格获得这一名称。那么，因果关系的概念必须来自物体之间的某种关系；而这种关系我们现在必须努力去发现。首先，我发现，无论什么物体被视为原因或效果，都是相邻的；没有什么东西可以在与它存在的时间或地点相距甚远的地方发挥作用。虽然遥远的物体有时看起来是相互产生的，但经过检查，它们通常被一连串的原因所连接，这些原因在它们之间以及与遥远的物体之间是相邻的；当在任何特定的情况下，我们不能发现这种联系，我们仍然假定它存在。因此，我们可以把毗连关系看作是因果关系的必要条件；至少可以根据一般的意见把它假定为这样，直到我们能找到一个更合适的场合来澄清这个问题。14在我们能够找到一个更合适的机会来澄清这个问题之前，我们要研究哪些对象是或不是容易发生联合定位和结合的。

The second relation I shall observe as essential to causes and effects, is not so universally acknowledge'd, but is liable to some controversy. 'Tis that of priority of time in the cause before the effect. Some pretend that 'tis not absolutely necessary a cause shou'd precede its effect; but that any object or action, in the very first moment of its existence, may exert its productive quality, and give rise to another object or action, perfectly co-temporary with itself. But beside that experience in most instances seems to contradict this opinion, we may establish the relation of priority by a kind of inference or reasoning. 'Tis an establish'd maxim both in natural and moral philosophy, that an object, which exists for any time in its full perfection without producing another, is not its sole cause; but is assisted by some other principle, which pushes it from its state of inactivity, and makes it exert that energy, of which it was secretly possest. Now if any cause may be perfectly co-temporary with its effect, 'tis certain, according to this maxim, that they must all of them be so; since any one of them, which retards its operation for a single moment, exerts not itself at that very individual time, in which it might have operated; and therefore is no proper cause. The consequence of this wou'd be no less than the destruction of that succession of causes, which we observe in the world; and indeed, the utter annihilation of time. For if one cause were co-temporary with its effect, and this effect with its effect, and so on, 'tis plain there wou'd be no such thing as succession, and all objects must be co-existent.

我将观察到的第二种关系，作为原因和结果的必要条件，并不是那么普遍地被承认，而是容易引起一些争论。这就是时间上的优先性，即因先于果。有些人认为，“并非绝对需要因先于果；但任何物体或行动，在其存在的最初时刻，就可以发挥其生产性，并产生另一个物体或行动，与自己完全同时。但是，除了经验在大多数情况下似乎与这一观点相矛盾之外，我们可以通过一种推论或推理来确定优先权的关系。在自然哲学和道德哲学中都有一条公认的格言，即一个物体在任何时候以其完全的完美状态存在而不产生另一个物体，并不是它唯一的原因；而是由其他一些原则协助，把它从其不活动的状态中推了出来，并使它发挥出它秘密拥有的能量。现在，如果任何原因都可能与它的效果完全同步，那么根据这条格言，可以肯定的是，它们都必须如此；因为其中任何一个原因，只要推迟了它的运作时间，就不会在它可能运作的那个个别时间内发挥自己的作用；因此，它不是适当的原因。这样做的后果将不亚于破坏我们在世界中观察到的原因的连续性；而且实际上是时间的彻底湮灭。因为如果一个原因与它的效果同时存在，而这个效果与它的效果同时存在，以此类推，很明显，就不会有所谓的继承，所有的物体都必须同时存在。

If this argument appear satisfactory, 'tis well. If not, I beg the reader to allow me the same liberty, which I have us'd in the preceding case, of supposing it such. For he shall find, that the affair is of no great importance.

如果这个论点看起来令人满意，那就好了。如果不是，我请读者允许我像在前面的案例中一样，自由地假设它是这样。因为他将发现，这件事并不十分重要。

Having thus discover'd or suppos'd the two relations of contiguity and succession to be essential to causes and effects, I find I am stopt short, and can proceed no farther in considering any single instance of cause and effect. Motion in one body is regarded upon impulse as the cause of motion in another. When we consider these objects with the utmost attention, we find only that the one body approaches the other; and that the motion of it precedes that of the other, but without any sensible interval. 'Tis in vain to rack ourselves with farther thought and reflection upon this subject. We can go no farther in considering this particular instance.

在发现或假定了连续和继承这两种对因果关系至关重要的关系之后，我发现我被挡住了，在考虑因果关系的任何一个例子时，我无法再继续下去。一个物体的运动被认为是另一个物体的运动的原因的冲动。当我们全神贯注地考虑这些物体时，我们只发现一个物体接近另一个物体；它的运动先于另一个物体的运动，但没有任何明显的间隔。在这个问题上进一步思考和反思是徒劳的。在考虑这个特殊的例子时，我们不能再走远了。

Shou'd any one leave this instance, and pretend to define a cause, by saying it is something productive of another, 'tis evident he wou'd say nothing. For what does he mean by production? Can he give any definition of it, that will not be the same with that of causation? If he can; I desire it may be produc'd. If he cannot; he here runs in a circle, and gives a synonymous term instead of a definition.

如果有人离开这个例子，假装给一个原因下定义，说它是另一个原因的产物，显然他什么也不会说。因为他所说的生产是什么意思？他能给它下一个与因果关系不一样的定义吗？如果他能，我希望它能被生产出来。如果他不能，他就在这里兜圈子，用一个同义词来代替定义。

Shall we then rest contented with these two relations of contiguity and succession, as affording a compleat idea of causation? By no means. An object may be contiguous and prior to another, without being consider'd as its cause. There is a necessary connexion to be taken into consideration; and that relation is of much greater importance, than any of the other two above-mention'd.

那么，我们是否应该满足于这两种相邻和相继的关系，认为它们提供了一个完整的因果关系的概念？绝不是这样。一个物体可能与另一个物体相邻，并且先于另一个物体，但不被认为是它的原因。有一种必要的联系需要考虑；这种关系比上面提到的其他两种关系都要重要得多。

Here again I turn the object on all sides, in order to discover the nature of this necessary connexion, and find the impression, or impressions, from which its idea may be deriv'd. When I cast my eye on the known qualities of objects, I immediately discover that the relation of cause and effect depends not in the least on them. When I consider their relations, I can find none but those of contiguity and succession; which I have already regarded as imperfect and unsatisfactory. Shall the despair of success make me assert, that I am here possest of an idea, which is not preceded by any similar impression? This wou'd be too strong a proof of levity and inconstancy; since the contrary principle has been already so firmly establish'd, as to admit of no farther doubt; at least, till we have more fully examin'd the present difficulty.

在这里，我再次把物体转向四面八方，以便发现这种必要的联系的性质，并找到它的概念可能来自的印象，或印象。当我把目光投向物体的已知品质时，我立即发现，因果关系丝毫不取决于它们。当我考虑它们的关系时，我只能找到那些相邻和相继的关系；我已经认为这些关系是不完善和不满意的。难道对成功的绝望会使我断言，我在这里拥有一个想法，而这个想法之前没有任何类似的印象？这将是轻率和不稳定的有力证明；因为相反的原则已经如此牢固地确立，以至于不允许有更多的怀疑；至少，在我们更充分地研究当前的困难之前。

We must, therefore, proceed like those, who being in search of any thing that lies conceal'd from them, and not finding it in the place they expected, beat about all the neighbouring fields, without any certain view or design, in hopes their good fortune will at last guide them to what they search for. 'Tis necessary for us to leave the direct survey of this question concerning the nature of that necessary connexion, which enters into our idea of cause and effect; and endeavour to find some other questions, the examination of which will perhaps afford a hint, that may serve to clear up the present difficulty. Of these questions there occur two, which I shall proceed to examine, viz.

因此，我们必须像那些人一样，在寻找他们所隐藏的任何东西时，如果在他们所期望的地方没有找到，就会在所有邻近的地方打转，没有任何明确的观点或设计，希望他们的好运气最终会引导他们找到他们所寻找的东西。我们有必要离开对这一问题的直接调查，该问题涉及到我们的因果观念中的必要联系的性质；并努力寻找一些其他问题，对这些问题的研究也许会提供一个提示，可能有助于清除目前的困难。在这些问题中，有两个问题，我将继续进行研究，即："为什么？

First, For what reason we pronounce it necessary, that every thing whose existence has a beginning, shou'd also have a cause?

首先，我们为什么说每一件事物的存在都有一个开始，就必须有一个原因？

Secondly, Why we conclude, that such particular causes must necessarily have such particular effects; and what is the nature of that inference we draw from the one to the other, and of the belief we repose in it?

第二，我们为什么会得出这样的结论，即这样的特殊原因必然会产生这样的特殊效果；我们从一个到另一个的推论的性质是什么，以及我们对它的信念是什么？

I shall only observe before I proceed any farther, that tho' the ideas of cause and effect be deriv'd from the impressions of reflection as well as from those of sensation, yet for brevity's sake, I commonly mention only the latter as the origin of these ideas; tho' I desire that whatever I say of them may also extend to the former. Passions are connected with their objects and with one another; no less than external bodies are connected together. The same relation, then, of cause and effect, which belongs to one, must be common to all of them.

在我进一步说明之前，我只想说，尽管因果观念既来自思考的印象，也来自感觉的印象，但为了简洁起见，我通常只提到后者作为这些观念的起源；尽管我希望我对它们所说的一切也能扩展到前者。激情与它们的对象和相互之间是有联系的；就像外在的身体被联系在一起一样。那么，属于一个人的相同的因果关系，一定是所有这些人所共有的。

 

Section 3. Why A Cause Is Always Necessary

第 3 节。为什么总是需要有一个原因

 

To begin with the first question concerning the necessity of a cause: 'Tis a general maxim in philosophy, that what-ever begins to exist, must have a cause of existence. This is commonly taken for granted in all reasonings, without any proof given or demanded 'Tis suppos'd to be founded on intuition, and to be one of those maxims, which tho' they may be deny'd with the lips, 'tis impossible for men in their hearts really to doubt of. But if we examine this maxim by the idea of knowledge above—explain'd, we shall discover in it no mark of any such intuitive certainty; but on the contrary shall find, that 'tis of a nature quite foreign to that species of conviction.

首先是关于原因的必要性的第一个问题。哲学上有一条普遍的格言，即凡是开始存在的东西，必定有其存在的原因。这在所有的推理中通常被认为是理所当然的，没有给出或要求任何证据。它被认为是建立在直觉的基础上，是那些虽然嘴上否认，但人们在心里不可能真正怀疑的格言之一。但是，如果我们用上面解释的知识概念来审视这条格言，我们就会发现它没有任何这种直觉上的确定性的标志；相反，我们会发现，它的性质与这种信念的种类完全不同。

All certainty arises from the comparison of ideas, and from the discovery of such relations as are unalterable, so long as the ideas continue the same. These relations are resemblance, proportions in quantity and number, degrees of any quality, and contrariety; none of which are imply'd in this proposition, Whatever has a beginning has also a cause of existence. That proposition therefore is not intuitively certain. At least any one, who wou'd assert it to be intuitively certain, must deny these to be the only infallible relations, and must find some other relation of that kind to be imply'd in it; which it will then be time enough to examine.

所有的确定性都来自于观念的比较，来自于发现这种关系，只要这些观念继续保持不变，就不会改变。这些关系是相似性、数量和数目的比例、任何质量的程度和反差；这些都不是这个命题所暗示的，即凡是有始有终的东西都有存在的原因。因此，这个命题在直觉上是不确定的。至少，任何断言它是直观确定的人，都必须否认这些是唯一无懈可击的关系，必须找到其中隐含的其他关系；然后才有足够的时间来研究。

But here is an argument, which proves at once, that the foregoing proposition is neither intuitively nor demonstrably certain. We can never demonstrate the necessity of a cause to every new existence, or new modification of existence, without shewing at the same time the impossibility there is, that any thing can ever begin to exist without some productive principle; and where the latter proposition cannot be prov'd, we must despair of ever being able to prove the former. Now that the latter proposition is utterly incapable of a demonstrative proof, we may satisfy ourselves by considering, that as all distinct ideas are separable from each other, and as the ideas of cause and effect are evidently distinct, 'twill be easy for us to conceive any object to be non-existent this moment, and existent the next, without conjoining to it the distinct idea of a cause or productive principle. The separation, therefore, of the idea of a cause from that of a beginning of existence, is plainly possible for the imagination; and consequently the actual separation of these objects is so far possible, that it implies no contradiction nor absurdity; and is therefore incapable of being refuted by any reasoning from mere ideas; without which 'tis impossible to demonstrate the necessity of a cause.

但这里有一个论据，它立即证明，上述命题既不是直观的，也不是明显的确定的。我们永远无法证明每一个新的存在或存在的新变化都必须有一个原因，而不同时说明任何事物在没有某种生产原则的情况下开始存在是不可能的；如果后一个命题无法证明，我们就必须对能够证明前一个命题感到绝望。既然后一个命题完全无法得到证明，我们可以通过考虑来满足自己，因为所有不同的观念都是可以相互分离的，而原因和结果的观念显然是不同的，我们很容易设想任何物体在这一刻是不存在的，在下一刻是存在的，而不需要把原因或生产原则的独特观念与它联系起来。因此，将原因的概念与存在的开始的概念分开，对想象力来说显然是可能的；因此，这些对象的实际分离是如此的可能，以至于它不意味着矛盾或荒谬；因此，不能被任何来自单纯概念的推理所驳倒；没有这些，就不可能证明原因的必要性。

Accordingly we shall find upon examination, that every demonstration, which has been produc'd for the necessity of a cause, is fallacious and sophistical. All the points of time and place,15 say some philosophers, in which we can suppose any object to begin to exist, are in themselves equal; and unless there be some cause, which is peculiar to one time and to one place, and which by that means determines and fixes the existence, it must remain in eternal suspence; and the object can never begin to be, for want of something to fix its beginning. But I ask; Is there any more difficulty in supposing the time and place to be fix'd without a cause, than to suppose the existence to be determin'd in that manner? The first question that occurs on this subject is always, whether the object shall exist or not: The next, when and where it shall begin to exist. If the removal of a cause be intuitively absurd in the one case, it must be so in the other: And if that absurdity be not clear without a proof in the one case, it will equally require one in the other. The absurdity, then, of the one supposition can never be a proof of that of the other; since they are both upon the same footing, and must stand or fall by the same reasoning.

因此，我们在研究后会发现，每一个证明，都是为了证明原因的必要性，都是谬误和诡辩。一些哲学家说，所有的时间点和地点，我们都可以假设任何物体在其中开始。15有些哲学家说，我们可以假定任何物体开始存在的所有时间和地点，本身都是平等的；除非有某种原因，是某个时间和地点所特有的，并且通过这种方式决定和固定了存在，否则它必须保持永恒的悬浮状态；物体永远不可能开始存在，因为没有东西来固定其开始。但我要问：假设时间和地点无缘无故地被固定下来，是否比假设存在以这种方式被决定更困难？在这个问题上出现的第一个问题总是，对象是否会存在。其次是，它将在 何时何地开始存在。如果在一种情况下消除原因在直觉上是荒谬的，那么在另一种情况下也一定是如此。如果这种荒谬性在一种情况下不需要证明就能明确，那么在另一种情况下同样需要证明。那么，一个假设的荒谬性永远不能成为另一个假设的证据；因为它们都在同一基础上，必须通过同样的推理才能成立或失败。

The second argument, 16 which I find us'd on this head, labours under an equal difficulty. Every thing, 'tis said, must have a cause; for if any thing wanted a cause, it wou'd produce itself; that is, exist before it existed; which is impossible. But this reasoning is plainly inconclusive; because it supposes, that in our denial of a cause we still grant what we expresly deny, vis. that there must be a cause; which therefore is taken to be the object itself; and that, no doubt, is an evident contradiction. But to say that any thing is produc'd, or to express myself more properly, comes into existence, without a cause, is not to affirm, that 'tis itself its own cause; but on the contrary in excluding all external causes, excludes a fortiori the thing itself which is created. An object, that exists absolutely without any cause, certainly is not its own cause; and when you assert, that the one follows from the other, you suppose the very point in question, and take it for granted, that 'tis utterly impossible any thing can ever begin to exist without a cause, but that upon the exclusion of one productive principle, we must still have recourse to another.

第二个论点。16我发现我们在这个问题上的第二个论点也遇到了同样的困难。据说，每件事情都必须有一个原因；因为如果任何事情需要一个原因，它就会产生自己；也就是说，在它存在之前就已经存在；这是不可能的。但这种推理显然是不确定的；因为它假定，在我们否认原因的时候，我们仍然承认我们明确否认的东西，即必须有一个原因；因此，它被认为是对象本身；毫无疑问，这是一个明显的矛盾。但是，说任何事物的产生，或者更恰当地说，没有原因的存在，并不是说它本身就是它自己的原因；相反，在排除所有外部原因时，更排除了被创造的事物本身。一个绝对没有任何原因而存在的物体，当然不是它自己的原因；当你断言，一个是由另一个引起的，你就假设了问题的关键，并认为这是理所当然的，任何事物都不可能在没有原因的情况下开始存在，但在排除了一个生产原则后，我们仍然必须求助于另一个。

'Tis exactly the same case with the 17third argument, which has been employ'd to demonstrate the necessity of a cause. Whatever is produc'd without any cause, is produc'd by nothing; or in other words, has nothing for its cause. But nothing can never be a cause, no more than it can be something, or equal to two right angles. By the same intuition, that we perceive nothing not to be equal to two right angles, or not to be something, we perceive, that it can never be a cause; and consequently must perceive, that every object has a real cause of its existence.

这与第三个论点的情况完全相同。17第三个论点也是如此，它被用来证明原因的必然性。凡是没有任何原因而产生的东西，都是由没有东西产生的；或者换句话说，没有东西作为它的原因。但是，“无” 永远不可能是一个原因，就像它不可能是一个东西，或者等于两个直角一样。根据同样的直觉，我们认为没有什么东西不等于两个直角，或者不是什么东西，我们就认为它永远不可能是一个原因；因此，我们必须认识到，每个物体都有其存在的真正原因。

I believe it will not be necessary to employ many words in shewing the weakness of this argument, after what I have said of the foregoing. They are all of them founded on the same fallacy, and are deriv'd from the same turn of thought. 'Tis sufficient only to observe, that when we exclude all causes we really do exclude them, and neither suppose nothing nor the object itself to be the causes of the existence; and consequently can draw no argument from the absurdity of these suppositions to prove the absurdity of that exclusion. If every thing must have a cause, it follows, that upon the exclusion of other causes we must accept of the object itself or of nothing as causes. But 'tis the very point in question, whether every thing must have a cause or not; and therefore, according to all just reasoning, it ought never to be taken for granted.

我相信，在我对前述论点说过之后，没有必要用很多话来说明这个论点的弱点。它们都是建立在同样的谬误之上的，都是由同样的思维方式衍生出来的。我们只需注意到，当我们排除所有的原因时，我们确实排除了它们，既没有假设任何东西，也没有假设对象本身是存在的原因；因此，不能从这些假设的荒谬性中得出任何论据来证明这种排除的荒谬性。如果每件事情都必须有一个原因，那么，在排除其他原因的情况下，我们必须接受物体本身或无物为原因。但这正是问题的关键所在，即每件事情是否必须有一个原因；因此，根据所有公正的推理，它永远不应该被认为是理所当然的。

They are still more frivolous, who say, that every effect must have a cause, because 'tis imply'd in the very idea of effect. Every effect necessarily pre-supposes a cause; effect being a relative term, of which cause is the correlative. But this does not prove, that every being must be preceded by a cause; no more than it follows, because every husband must have a wife, that therefore every man must be marry'd. The true state of the question is, whether every object, which begins to exist, must owe its existence to a cause; and this I assert neither to be intuitively nor demonstratively certain, and hope to have prov'd it sufficiently by the foregoing arguments.

更有甚者，他们说，每一个效果都必须有一个原因，因为这隐含在效果的概念中。每一个效果都必然以一个原因为前提；效果是一个相对的术语，而原因是其相关的。但这并不能证明每个存在都必须先有一个原因；就像因为每个丈夫都必须有一个妻子，所以每个男人都必须结婚一样。问题的真实情况是，是否每一个开始存在的物体都必须把它的存在归功于一个原因；我断言这一点既不是直观的，也不是证明的，我希望通过前面的论证充分地证明这一点。

Since it is not from knowledge or any scientific reasoning, that we derive the opinion of the necessity of a cause to every new production, that opinion must necessarily arise from observation and experience. The next question, then, shou'd naturally be, how experience gives rise to such a principle? But as I find it will be more convenient to sink this question in the following, Why we conclude, that such particular causes must necessarily have such particular effects, and why we form an inference from one to another? we shall make that the subject of our future enquiry. "Twill, perhaps, be found in the end, that the same answer will serve for both questions.

既然我们不是从知识或任何科学推理中得出每个新产品都必须有一个原因的观点，那么这个观点就必须从观察和经验中产生。那么，下一个问题自然是：经验是如何产生这种原则的？但我发现，把这个问题放在下面会更方便，即我们为什么会得出结论，认为这种特殊的原因必然会产生这种特殊的效果，以及我们为什么会形成从一个到另一个的推论？我们将把这个问题作为我们今后询问的主题。"也许最后会发现，两个问题的答案都是一样的。

 

Section 4. Of The Component Parts Of Our Reasonings Concerning Cause And Effect

第 4 节。我们关于因果关系的推理的组成部分

 

Tho' the mind in its reasonings from causes or effects carries its view beyond those objects, which it sees or remembers, it must never lose sight of them entirely, nor reason merely upon its own ideas, without some mixture of impressions, or at least of ideas of the memory, which are equivalent to impressions. When we infer effects from causes, we must establish the existence of these causes; which we have only two ways of doing, either by an immediate perception of our memory or senses, or by an inference from other causes; which causes again we must ascertain in the same manner, either by a present impression, or by an inference from their causes, and so on, till we arrive at some object, which we see or remember. 'Tis impossible for us to carry on our inferences in infinitum; and the only thing, that can stop them, is an impression of the memory or senses, beyond which there is no room for doubt or enquiry.

尽管心灵在从原因或效果进行推理时，其视野超越了它所看到或记住的那些对象，但它决不能完全忽视它们，也不能仅仅根据自己的观念进行推理，而不掺杂一些印象，或者至少是相当于印象的记忆中的观念。当我们从原因推断效果时，我们必须确定这些原因的存在；我们只有两种方法，要么通过我们的记忆或感官的直接感知，要么通过从其他原因的推断；这些原因我们又必须以同样的方式确定，要么通过当前的印象，要么通过从其原因的推断，如此反复，直到我们到达某个我们看到或记住的对象。我们不可能无休止地进行推论；唯一能阻止推论的是记忆或感官的印象，超出这个范围就没有怀疑或询问的余地。

To give an instance of this, we may chuse any point of history, and consider for what reason we either believe or reject it. Thus we believe that Cæsar was kill'd in the senate-house on the ides of March; and that because this fact is establish'd on the unanimous testimony of historians, who agree to assign this precise time and place to that event. Here are certain characters and letters present either to our memory or senses; which characters we likewise remember to have been us'd as the signs of certain ideas; and these ideas were either in the minds of such as were immediately present at that action, and receiv'd the ideas directly from its existence; or they were deriv'd from the testimony of others, and that again from another testimony, by a visible gradation, till we arrive at those who were eye-witnesses and spectators of the event. 'Tis obvious all this chain of argument or connexion of causes and effects, is at first founded on those characters or letters, which are seen or remember'd, and that without the authority either of the memory or senses our whole reasoning wou'd be chimerical and without foundation. Every link of the chain wou'd in that case hang upon another; but there wou'd not be any thing fix'd to one end of it, capable of sustaining the whole; and consequently there wou'd be no belief nor evidence. And this actually is the case with all hypothetical arguments, or reasonings upon a supposition; there being in them, neither any present impression, nor belief of a real existence.

为了举例说明这一点，我们可以选择历史上的任何一点，并考虑我们相信或拒绝它的理由是什么。因此，我们相信凯撒是在三月三日在元老院被杀的；这是因为这一事实是根据历史学家的一致证词确定的，他们一致认为这一事件的时间和地点是准确的。这里有一些字符和字母在我们的记忆或感官中出现；我们同样记得这些字符被用作某些想法的标志；而这些想法要么是在当时立即在场的人的头脑中，并从其存在中直接获得这些想法；要么是从其他人的证词中衍生出来的，然后又从另一个证词中衍生出来，通过一个明显的梯度，直到我们到达那些事件的目击者和观众。很明显，所有这条论证链或因果关系的联系，首先是建立在那些看到或记住的字符或字母上的，如果没有记忆或感官的权威，我们的整个推理将是虚构的，没有基础的。在这种情况下，链条上的每一个环节都会挂在另一个环节上；但不会有任何东西固定在它的一端，能够支撑整个链条；因此，不会有任何信念或证据。实际上，所有的假设性论证，或基于假设的推理都是这样的情况；其中既没有任何当前的印象，也没有对真实存在的信念。

I need not observe, that 'tis no just objection to the present doctrine, that we can reason upon our past conclusions or principles, without having recourse to those impressions, from which they first arose. For even supposing these impressions shou'd be entirely effac'd from the memory, the conviction they produc'd may still remain; and 'tis equally true, that all reasonings concerning causes and effects are originally deriv'd from some impression; in the same manner, as the assurance of a demonstration proceeds always from a comparison of ideas, tho' it may continue after the comparison is forgot.

我不需要指出，对于目前的学说，我们可以根据我们过去的结论或原则进行推理，而不必求助于它们最初产生的那些印象，这并不是正当的反对意见。因为即使这些印象完全从记忆中消失了，它们所产生的信念也可能仍然存在；同样正确的是，所有关于原因和结果的推理最初都来自于某种印象；以同样的方式，证明的保证总是来自于概念的比较，尽管它可能在比较被遗忘后继续存在。

Section 5. Of The Impressions Of The Senses And Memory

第 5 节。感官的印象和记忆

 

In this kind of reasoning, then, from causation, we employ materials, which are of a mix'd and heterogeneous nature, and which, however connected, are yet essentially different from each other. All our arguments concerning causes and effects consist both of an impression of the memory or senses, and of the idea of that existence, which produces the object of the impression, or is produc'd by it. Here therefore we have three things to explain, viz. First, The original impression. Secondly, The transition to the idea of the connected cause or effect. Thirdly, The nature and qualities of that idea.

那么，在这种推理中，从因果关系出发，我们所使用的材料是混合的、异质的，而且这些材料虽然有联系，但在本质上是相互不同的。我们所有关于因果关系的论证，都是由记忆或感官的印象，以及产生印象的对象或由其产生的那种存在的观念组成的。因此，在这里我们有三件事要解释，即：第一，原始印象。第二，过渡到相关的原因或效果的概念。第三，这个概念的性质和质量。

As to those impressions, which arise from the senses, their ultimate cause is, in my opinion, perfectly inexplicable by human reason, and 'twill always be impossible to decide with certainty, whether they arise immediately from the object, or are produc'd by the reative power of the mind, or are deriv'd from the author of our being. Nor is such a question any way material to our present purpose. We may draw inferences from the coherence of our perceptions, whether they be true or false; whether they represent nature justly, or be mere illusions of the senses.

至于那些从感官产生的印象，在我看来，它们的最终原因是人类的理性完全无法解释的，而且永远不可能肯定地决定它们是直接从物体中产生的，还是由心灵的反作用力产生的，或者是从我们存在的作者那里衍生出来的。这样的问题对我们目前的目的也没有任何意义。我们可以从我们的感知的一致性中得出推论，无论它们是真的还是假的；无论它们是公正地代表自然，还是仅仅是感官的幻觉。

When we search for the characteristic, which distinguishes the memory from the imagination, we must immediately perceive, that it cannot lie in the simple ideas it presents to us; since both these faculties borrow their simple ideas from the impressions, and can never go beyond these original perceptions. These faculties are as little distinguish'd from each other by the arrangement of their complex ideas. For tho' it be a peculiar property of the memory to preserve the original order and position of its ideas, while the imagination transposes and changes them, as it pleases; yet this difference is not sufficient to distinguish them in their operation, or make us know the one from the other; it being impossible to recal the past impressions, in order to compare them with our present ideas, and see whether their arrangement be exactly similar. Since therefore the memory is known, neither by the order of its complex ideas, nor the nature of its simple ones; it follows, that the difference betwixt it and the imagination lies in its superior force and vivacity. A man may indulge his fancy in feigning any past scene of adventures; nor wou'd there be any possibility of distinguishing this from a remembrance of a like kind, were not the ideas of the imagination fainter and more obscure.

当我们寻找区别记忆和想象力的特征时，我们必须立即意识到，它不可能在于它向我们展示的简单观念；因为这两种能力都是从印象中借用它们的简单观念，而且永远不能超越这些原始的感知。这些能力因其复杂观念的安排而彼此区别不大。因为尽管记忆力的一个特殊属性是保持其观念的原始顺序和位置，而想象力则随心所欲地转换和改变它们；但这种差异并不足以在它们的运作中加以区分，也不足以使我们知道它们之间的区别；我们不可能回顾过去的印象，以便将它们与我们现在的观念进行比较，看看它们的安排是否完全相似。因此，记忆既不是通过其复杂概念的顺序，也不是通过其简单概念的性质来认识的；因此，它与想象力的区别在于它的力量和活力更强。一个人可以放纵他的想象力，假装任何过去的冒险场景；如果不是想象力的观念更微弱、更模糊，也不可能将这与类似的记忆区分开来。

A painter, who intended to represent a passion or emotion of any kind, wou'd endeavour to get a sight of a person actuated by a like emotion, in order to enliven his ideas, and give them a force and vivacity superior to what is found in those, which are mere fictions of the imagination. The more recent this memory is, the clearer is the idea; and when after a long interval he would return to the contemplation of his object, he always finds its idea to be much decay'd, if not wholly obliterated. We are frequently in doubt concerning the ideas of the memory, as they become very weak and feeble; and are at a loss to determine whether any image proceeds from the fancy or the memory, when it is not drawn in such lively colours as distinguish that latter faculty. I think, I remember such an event, says one; but am not sure. A long tract of time has almost worn it out of my memory, and leaves me uncertain whether or not it be the pure offspring of my fancy.

一个画家，如果想表现任何一种激情或情感，就会努力去看一个被类似情感所驱动的人，以活跃他的思想，使之具有比那些仅仅是想象力的虚构的东西更强的力量和活泼性。这种记忆越新，想法就越清晰；而当他在很长时间的间隔后回到对他的目标的思考中时，他总是发现它的想法如果不是完全被抹去，也是非常衰弱的。我们经常对记忆中的概念产生怀疑，因为它们变得非常薄弱和无力；我们也不知道任何图像是来自于幻想还是记忆，因为它没有被画成生动的颜色，而这正是后者的特征。我想，我记得这样一个事件，有一个人说；但我不确定。漫长的时间几乎把它从我的记忆中磨灭了，让我无法确定它是否是我的幻想的纯粹产物。

And as an idea of the memory, by losing its force and vivacity, may degenerate to such a degree, as to be taken for an idea of the imagination; so on the other hand an idea of the imagination may acquire such a force and vivacity, as to pass for an idea of the memory, and counterfeit its effects on the belief and judgment. This is noted in the case of liars; who by the frequent repetition of their lies, come at last to believe and remember them, as realities; custom and habit having in this case, as in many others, the same influence on the mind as nature, and infixing the idea with equal force and vigour.

就像记忆中的一个概念，由于失去了它的力量和活力，可能会退化到这样的程度，以至于被当作想象中的一个概念；另一方面，想象中的一个概念也可能获得这样的力量和活力，以至于冒充记忆中的一个概念，并伪造它对信仰和判断的影响。这一点在说谎者的案例中可以看到；由于经常重复他们的谎言，他们最终相信并记住了这些谎言，就像现实一样；在这种情况下，习俗和习惯对心灵的影响和其他许多情况一样，并以同样的力量和活力注入了这种观念。

Thus it appears, that the belief or assent, which always attends the memory and senses, is nothing but the vivacity of those perceptions they present; and that this alone distinguishes them from the imagination. To believe is in this case to feel an immediate impression of the senses, or a repetition of that impression in the memory. 'Tis merely the force and liveliness of the perception, which constitutes the first act of the judgment, and lays the foundation of that reasoning, which we build upon it, when we trace the relation of cause and effect.

由此可见，始终伴随着记忆和感官的信念或同意，只不过是它们所呈现的那些感知的活力；而且，只有这一点才能将它们与想象区分开来。在这种情况下，相信就是感觉到感官的直接印象，或在记忆中重复这种印象。这仅仅是感知的力量和活力，它构成了判断的第一行为，并为推理奠定了基础，当我们追溯因果关系时，我们就建立在它上面。

 

Section 6. Of The Inference From The Impression To The Idea

第 6 节。从印象到理念的推论

 

'Tis easy to observe, that in tracing this relation, the inference we draw from cause to effect, is not deriv'd merely from a survey of these particular objects, and from such a penetration into their essences as may discover the dependence of the one upon the other. There is no object, which implies the existence of any other if we consider these objects in themselves, and never look beyond the ideas which we form of them. Such an inference wou'd amount to knowledge, and wou'd imply the absolute contradiction and impossibility of conceiving any thing different. But as all distinct ideas are separable, 'tis evident there can be no impossibility of that kind. When we pass from a present impression to the idea of any object, we might possibly have separated the idea from the impression, and have substituted any other idea in its room.

很容易观察到，在追踪这种关系时，我们从因到果所得出的推论，并不仅仅来自于对这些特定对象的调查，以及对其本质的深入了解，从而发现两者之间的依赖关系。如果我们只考虑这些对象本身，而不去看我们对它们形成的观念以外的东西，就没有任何对象意味着任何其他对象的存在。这样的推论就等于知识，就意味着绝对的矛盾和不可能设想出任何不同的东西。但是，由于所有不同的观念都是可以分离的，显然不可能存在这种不可能。当我们从现在的印象转到任何物体的观念时，我们可能已经把观念从印象中分离出来，用任何其他的观念来代替它。

'Tis therefore by experience only, that we can infer the existence of one object from that of another. The nature of experience is this. We remember to have had frequent instances of the existence of one species of objects; and also remember, that the individuals of another species of objects have always attended them, and have existed in a regular order of contiguity and succession with regard to them. Thus we remember to have seen that species of object we call flame, and to have felt that species of sensation we call heat. We likewise call to mind their constant conjunction in all past instances. Without any farther ceremony, we call the one cause and the other effect, and infer the existence of the one from that of the other. In all those instances, from which we learn the conjunction of particular causes and effects, both the causes and effects have been perceiv'd by the senses, and are remember'd: But in all cases, wherein we reason concerning them, there is only one perceiv'd or remember'd, and the other is supply'd in conformity to our past experience.

因此，只有通过经验，我们才能从一个物体的存在推断出另一个物体的存在。经验的本质是这样的。我们记得经常有一种物体存在的例子；也记得另一种物体的个体总是伴随着它们，并且以一种有规律的顺序存在，与它们相邻，相继存在。因此，我们记得看到过我们称之为火焰的那类物体，也记得感受过我们称之为热的那类感觉。我们也同样记得它们在过去的所有事例中不断地结合在一起。没有任何进一步的仪式，我们称一个为因，另一个为果，并从另一个的存在推断出一个的存在。在所有这些例子中，我们了解到特定的原因和结果的结合，原因和结果都是由感官感知的，并被记住了。但在所有情况下，当我们对它们进行推理时，只有一个被感知或记忆，而另一个是根据我们过去的经验提供的。

Thus in advancing we have insensibly discover'd a new relation betwixt cause and effect, when we least expected it, and were entirely employ'd upon another subject. This relation is their constant conjunction. Contiguity and succession are not sufficient to make us pronounce any two objects to be cause and effect, unless we perceive, that these two relations are preserv'd in several instances. We may now see the advantage of quitting the direct survey of this relation, in order to discover the nature of that necessary connexion, which makes so essential a part of it. There are hopes, that by this means we may at last arrive at our propos'd end; tho' to tell the truth, this new-discover'd relation of a constant conjunction seems to advance us but very little in our way. For it implies no more than this, that like objects have always been plac'd in like relations of contiguity and succession; and it seems evident, at least at first sight, that by this means we can never discover any new idea, and can only multiply, but not enlarge the objects of our mind. It may be thought, that what we learn not from one object, we can never learn from a hundred, which are all of the same kind, and are perfectly resembling in every circumstance. As our senses shew us in one instance two bodies, or motions, or qualities in certain relations of succession and contiguity; so our memory presents us only with a multitude of instances, wherein we always find like bodies, motions, or qualities in like relations. From the mere repetition of any past impression, even to infinity, there never will arise any new original idea, such as that of a necessary connexion; and the number of impressions has in this case no more effect than if we confin'd ourselves to one only. But tho' this reasoning seems just and obvious; yet as it wou'd be folly to despair too soon, we shall continue the thread of our discourse; and having found, that after the discovery of the constant conjunction of any objects, we always draw an inference from one object to another, we shall now examine the nature of that inference, and of the transition from the impression to the idea. Perhaps 'twill appear in the end, that the necessary connexion depends on the inference, instead of the inference's depending on the necessary connexion. Since it appears, that the transition from an impression present to the memory or senses to the idea of an object, which we call cause or effect, is founded on past experience, and on our remembrance of their constant conjunction, the next question is, Whether experience produces the idea by means of the understanding or of the imagination; whether we are determin'd by reason to make the transition, or by a certain association and relation of perceptions. If reason determin'd us, it wou'd proceed upon that principle, that instances, of which we have had no experience, must resemble those, of which we have had experience, and that the course of nature continues always uniformly the same. In order therefore to clear up this matter, let us consider all the arguments, upon which such a proposition may be suppos'd to be founded; and as these must be deriv' d either from knowledge or probability, let us cast our eye on each of these degrees of evidence, and see whether they afford any just conclusion of this nature.
