因此，在前进的过程中，我们不经意地发现了因果之间的一种新的关系，而这时我们最不愿意看到的是，我们完全在为另一个问题而努力。这种关系就是它们的不断结合。除非我们意识到这两种关系在不同的情况下都得到了保留，否则相邻和相继并不足以使我们宣布任何两个对象是因和果。我们现在可以看到放弃对这种关系的直接调查的好处，以便发现这种必要的联系的性质，这种联系是它的一个重要部分。人们希望，通过这种方式，我们最终可以达到我们提议的目的；尽管说实话，这种新发现的持续结合的关系似乎对我们的道路没有什么推动作用。因为它所暗示的不过是：相似的物体总是被放置在相似的毗连和继承关系中；而且，至少在第一眼看来，很明显，通过这种方式，我们永远无法发现任何新的想法，只能增加，而不能扩大我们思想的对象。可以认为，我们不能从一个物体中学到的东西，永远不能从一百个物体中学到，而这些物体都是同类的，在每一个方面都是完全相似的。正如我们的感官在一个例子中向我们展示了两个身体，或运动，或在某些连续和相邻的关系中的质量；所以我们的记忆只向我们展示了许多例子，在这些例子中，我们总是发现类似的身体，运动，或质量在类似的关系中。仅仅重复任何过去的印象，甚至重复到无穷大，都不会产生任何新的原始观念，如必然联系的观念；在这种情况下，印象的数量不会比我们只限于一个印象有更多的影响。尽管这个推理似乎是公正和明显的，但由于过早绝望是愚蠢的，我们将继续我们的讨论；在发现任何物体的持续结合之后，我们总是从一个物体推论到另一个物体，我们现在将研究这种推论的性质，以及从印象到概念的过渡。也许最后会发现，必要的联系取决于推论，而不是推论取决于必要的联系。既然看起来，从记忆或感官中的印象过渡到物体的观念，我们称之为因果，是建立在过去的经验上，以及我们对它们不断结合的记忆上，那么下一个问题是，经验是通过理解力还是想象力产生观念；我们是由理性决定过渡，还是由感知的某种联系和关系决定过渡。如果理性决定了我们，那么它就会根据这样的原则进行，即我们没有经验的事例必须与我们有经验的事例相似，而且自然界的进程总是一致的。因此，为了弄清这个问题，让我们考虑所有的论据，这样的命题可能被认为是有根据的；由于这些论据必须从知识或概率中推导出来，让我们把目光投向这些证据的每一个程度，看看它们是否提供了这种性质的任何公正结论。

Our foregoing method of reasoning will easily convince us, that there can be no demonstrative arguments to prove, that those instances, of which we have had no experience, resemble those, of which we have had experience. We can at least conceive a change in the course of nature; which sufficiently proves, that such a change is not absolutely impossible. To form a clear idea of any thing, is an undeniable argument for its possibility, and is alone a refutation of any pretended demonstration against it.

我们上述的推理方法将很容易使我们相信，不可能有示范性的论据来证明，那些我们没有经验的事例与我们有经验的事例相似。我们至少可以设想自然界的变化；这就充分证明，这种变化并非绝对不可能。对任何事物形成一个清晰的概念，就是对其可能性的一个不可否认的论证，也是对任何假装反对它的证明的唯一驳斥。

Probability, as it discovers not the relations of ideas, consider'd as such, but only those of objects, must in some respects be founded on the impressions of our memory and senses, and in some respects on our ideas. Were there no mixture of any impression in our probable reasonings, the conclusion wou'd be entirely chimerical: And were there no mixture of ideas, the action of the mind, in observing the relation, wou'd, properly speaking, be sensation, not reasoning. 'Tis therefore necessary, that in all probable reasonings there be something present to the mind, either seen or remember'd; and that from this we infer something connected with it, which is not seen nor remember'd.

概率，因为它发现的不是观念的关系，而只是对象的关系，所以在某些方面必须建立在我们的记忆和感官的印象上，在某些方面建立在我们的观念上。如果在我们可能的推理中没有任何印象的混合，那么这个结论就会完全是虚构的。如果没有观念的混合，那么在观察这种关系时，心灵的行动，正确地说，将是感觉，而不是推理。因此，在所有可能的推理中，必须有一些东西存在于头脑中，要么是看到的，要么是记住的；而且我们要从中推断出与之相关的东西，而这些东西是看不到也记不住的。

The only connexion or relation of objects, which can lead us beyond the immediate impressions of our memory and senses, is that of cause and effect; and that because 'tis the only one, on which we can found a just inference from one object to another. The idea of cause and effect is deriv'd from experience, which informs us, that such particular objects, in all past instances, have been constantly conjoin'd with each other: And as an object similar to one of these is suppos'd to be immediately present in its impression, we thence presume on the existence of one similar to its usual attendant. According to this account of things, which is, I think, in every point unquestionable, probability is founded on the presumption of a resemblance betwixt those objects, of which we have had experience, and those, of which we have had none; and therefore 'tis impossible, this presumption can arise from probability. The same principle cannot be both the cause and effect of another; and this is, perhaps, the only proposition concerning that relation, which is either intuitively or demonstratively certain.

唯一能引导我们超越我们的记忆和感官的直接印象的物体的联系或关系是因果关系；这是因为这是唯一的一个，我们可以根据它找到从一个物体到另一个物体的公正推断。因果的概念来自于经验，它告诉我们，在过去的所有事例中，这些特定的物体一直是相互关联的。由于与这些物体之一相似的物体被认为会立即出现在它的印象中，因此我们推测存在一个与它通常的伴随者相似的物体。根据这种说法，我认为在每一点上都是不容置疑的，概率是建立在对那些我们有经验的物体和那些我们没有经验的物体之间的相似性的推测之上的；因此，这种推测不可能从概率中产生。同一个原则不可能既是另一个原则的原因，又是另一个原则的结果；这也许是关于这种关系的唯一命题，它既是直观的，也是明显的确定。

Shou'd any one think to elude this argument; and without determining whether our reasoning on this subject be deriv'd from demonstration or probability, pretend that all conclusions from causes and effects are built on solid reasoning: I can only desire, that this reasoning may be produc'd, in order to be expos'd to our examination. It may, perhaps, be said, that after experience of the constant conjunction of certain objects, we reason in the following manner. Such an object is always found to produce another. 'Tis impossible it cou'd have this effect, if it was not endow'd with a power of production. The power necessarily implies the effect; and therefore there is a just foundation for drawing a conclusion from the existence of one object to that of its usual attendant. The past production implies a power: The power implies a new production: And the new production is what we infer from the power and the past production.

如果有人想避开这个论点，不确定我们在这个问题上的推理是来自证明还是概率，就假装所有来自因果的结论都建立在坚实的推理之上。我只能希望，这种推理可以被生产出来，以便暴露给我们检验。也许可以说，在经历了某些物体的不断结合之后，我们以如下方式推理。这样一个物体总是被发现产生另一个物体。如果它没有被赋予生产的能力，就不可能有这种效果。权力必然意味着效果；因此，从一个物体的存在到其通常的伴随物的存在得出结论是有根据的。过去的生产意味着一种力量：这种力量意味着一种新的生产。而新的生产是我们从权力和过去的生产中推断出来的。

'Twere easy for me to shew the weakness of this reasoning, were I willing to make use of those observations I have already made, that the idea of production is the same with that of causation, and that no existence certainly and demonstratively implies a power in any other object; or were it proper to anticipate what I shall have occasion to remark afterwards concerning the idea we form of power and efficacy. But as such a method of proceeding may seem either to weaken my system, by resting one part of it on another, or to breed a confusion in my reasoning, I shall endeavour to maintain my present assertion without any such assistance.

如果我愿意利用我已经提出的那些意见，即生产的概念与因果关系的概念是相同的，没有任何存在肯定地和明显地意味着任何其他物体的力量，那么我就很容易说明这种推理的弱点；或者，如果我愿意预见到我以后有机会对我们形成的力量和效力的概念进行评论，那么我就很容易说明。但是，由于这样的处理方法可能会削弱我的体系，因为它的一个部分依赖于另一个部分，或者在我的推理中滋生混乱，所以我将努力在没有任何帮助的情况下坚持我目前的论断。

It shall therefore be allow'd for a moment, that the production of one object by another in any one instance implies a power; and that this power is connected with its effect. But it having been already prov'd, that the power lies not in the sensible qualities of the cause; and there being nothing but the sensible qualities present to us; I ask, why in other instances you presume that the same power still exists, merely upon the appearance of these qualities? Your appeal to past experience decides nothing in the present case; and at the utmost can only prove, that that very object, which produc'd any other, was at that very instant endow'd with such a power; but can never prove, that the same power must continue in the same object or collection of sensible qualities; much less, that a like power is always conjoin'd with like sensible qualities. Shou'd it be said, that we have experience, that the same power continues united with the same object, and that like objects are endow'd with like powers, I wou'd renew my question, why from these experience we form any conclusion beyond those past instances, of which we have had experience. If you answer this question in the same manner as the preceding, your answer gives still occasion to a new question of the same kind, even in infinitum; which clearly proves, that the foregoing reasoning had no just foundation.

因此，我们应该允许，在任何一个例子中，一个物体由另一个物体产生意味着一种力量；而且这种力量与它的效果有关。但是，我们已经证明，这种力量并不在于原因的感性品质；除了我们所看到的感性品质之外，什么都没有；我问，为什么在其他情况下，你仅仅根据这些品质的出现，就推定同样的力量仍然存在？你对过去的经验的诉求在本案中没有任何决定意义；最多只能证明，那个产生了任何其他物体的物体在那一瞬间被赋予了这种力量；但永远不能证明，同样的力量必须继续存在于同一物体或感性品质的集合中；更不能证明，一种类似的力量总是与类似的感性品质结合在一起。如果有人说，我们有经验，同一力量继续与同一物体结合，而且类似的物体被赋予类似的力量，我就会再次提出我的问题，为什么从这些经验中我们要得出任何结论，而不是我们已经有经验的那些过去的例子。如果你对这个问题的回答和前面的一样，你的回答仍然会引起同样的新问题，甚至是无穷无尽的问题；这就清楚地证明，前面的推理是没有公正的基础。

Thus not only our reason fails us in the discovery of the ultimate connexion of causes and effects, but even after experience has inform'd us of their constant conjunction, 'tis impossible for us to satisfy ourselves by our reason, why we shou'd extend that experience beyond those particular instances, which have fallen under our observation. We suppose, but are never able to prove, that there must be a resemblance betwixt those objects, of which we have had experience, and those which lie beyond the reach of our discovery.

因此，不仅我们的理性无法发现因果的最终联系，而且即使在经验告诉我们它们的持续结合之后，我们也不可能通过我们的理性使自己满意，为什么我们应该把经验扩展到我们观察到的那些特殊的例子之外。我们假设，但永远无法证明，在那些我们有经验的物体和那些我们无法发现的物体之间，一定存在着相似性。

We have already taken notice of certain relations, which make us pass from one object to another, even tho' there be no reason to determine us to that transition; and this we may establish for a general rule, that wherever the mind constantly and uniformly makes a transition without any reason, it is influenc'd by these relations. Now this is exactly the present case. Reason can never shew us the connexion of one object with another, tho' aided by experience, and the observation of their constant conjunction in all past instances. When the mind, therefore, passes from the idea or impression of one object to the idea or belief of another, it is not determin'd by reason, but by certain principles, which associate together the ideas of these objects, and unite them in the imagination. Had ideas no more union in the fancy than objects seem to have to the understanding, we cou'd never draw any inference from causes to effects, nor repose belief in any matter of fact. The inference, therefore, depends solely on the union of ideas.

我们已经注意到了某些关系，这些关系使我们从一个对象转到另一个对象，即使没有任何理由决定我们进行这种转换；我们可以把这一点确立为一条普遍的规则，即凡是心灵在没有任何理由的情况下不断地、一致地进行转换，它都是受到这些关系的影响的。现在，这正是目前的情况。理性永远无法告诉我们一个物体与另一个物体的联系，尽管有经验的帮助，以及在所有过去的例子中观察到它们的不断结合。因此，当心灵从一个物体的观念或印象转到另一个物体的观念或信仰时，它不是由理性决定的，而是由某些原则决定的，这些原则把这些物体的观念联系在一起，并在想象中把它们结合起来。如果观念在想象中的结合不比物体在理解中的结合多，我们就不会从原因到结果得出任何推论，也不会在任何事实问题上保持信念。因此，这种推论完全取决于观念的结合。

The principles of union among ideas I have reduc'd to three general ones, and have asserted, that the idea or impression of any object naturally introduces the idea of any other object, that is resembling, contiguous to, or connected with it. These principles I allow to be neither the infallible nor the sole causes of an union among ideas. They are not the infallible causes. For one may fix his attention during some time on any one object without looking farther. They are not the sole causes. For the thought has evidently a very irregular motion in running along its objects, and may leap from the heavens to the earth, from one end of the creation to the other, without any certain method or order. But tho' I allow this weakness in these three relations, and this irregularity in the imagination; yet I assert that the only general principles, which associate ideas, are resemblance, contiguity and causation.

我把观念之间结合的原则简化为三个一般的原则，并断言，任何物体的观念或印象都会自然而然地引入任何其他物体的观念，即与之相似、相邻或相连的物体。我认为，这些原则既不是观念之间结合的可靠原因，也不是唯一原因。它们不是可靠的原因。因为一个人可以在一段时间内把他的注意力固定在任何一个物体上而不去看更远的地方。它们不是唯一的原因。因为思想在沿着它的对象运行时显然有一个非常不规则的运动，它可能从天上跳到地上，从创造的一端跳到另一端，没有任何特定的方法或秩序。但是，尽管我允许这三种关系中的这种弱点，以及想象力中的这种不规则性；但我断言，将思想联系起来的唯一一般原则是相似性、相邻性和因果关系。

There is indeed a principle of union among ideas, which at first sight may be esteem'd different from any of these, but will be found at the bottom to depend on the same origin. When ev'ry individual of any species of objects is found by experience to be constantly united with an individual of another species, the appearance of any new individual of either species naturally conveys the thought to its usual attendant. Thus because such a particular idea is commonly annex'd to such a particular word, nothing is requir'd but the hearing of that word to produce the correspondent idea; and 'twill scarce be possible for the mind, by its utmost efforts, to prevent that transition. In this case it is not absolutely necessary, that upon hearing such a particular sound, we shou'd reflect on any past experience, and consider what idea has been usually connected with the sound. The imagination of itself supplies the place of this reflection, and is so accustom'd to pass from the word to the idea, that it interposes not a moment's delay betwixt the hearing of the one, and the conception of the other.

观念之间确实有一个结合的原则，乍一看，它可能被认为与上述任何一个不同，但从根本上会发现它取决于同一个起源。当任何种类的物体的每一个个体都被经验发现与另一种类的个体经常结合在一起时，任何一个种类的新个体的出现都会自然而然地把这个想法传达给它的常客。因此，由于这样一个特定的想法通常与这样一个特定的词相联系，除了听到这个词就可以产生相应的想法；而且心灵几乎不可能通过其最大的努力来阻止这种转变。在这种情况下，我们没有必要在听到这种特定的声音时，反思过去的经验，并考虑通常与这种声音有关的想法。想象力本身就提供了这种思考的场所，并且习惯于从文字到概念，以至于它在听到一个声音和构想另一个声音之间没有片刻的延迟。

But tho' I acknowledge this to be a true principle of association among ideas, I assert it to be the very same with that betwixt the ideas of cause and effect, and to be an essential part in all our reasonings from that relation. We have no other notion of cause and effect, but that of certain objects, which have been always conjoin'd together, and which in all past instances have been found inseparable. We cannot penetrate into the reason of the conjunction. We only observe the thing itself, and always find that from the constant conjunction the objects acquire an union in the imagination. When the impression of one becomes present to us, we immediately form an idea of its usual attendant; and consequently we may establish this as one part of the definition of an opinion or belief, that 'tis an idea related to or associated with a present impression.

但是，尽管我承认这是概念之间关联的一个真正的原则，我断言它与因果概念之间的关联是一样的，并且是我们从这种关系中进行推理的一个基本部分。我们没有其他的因果概念，只有某些对象的概念，这些对象总是结合在一起，而且在过去的所有事例中都被发现是不可分割的。我们无法深入了解这种结合的原因。我们只观察事物本身，并且总是发现，从持续的结合中，这些物体在想象中获得了一种结合。当一个人的印象出现在我们面前时，我们就会立即形成一个关于其通常伴随者的想法；因此，我们可以将此作为意见或信仰定义的一部分，即 “它是一个与当前印象有关或相关的想法。

Thus tho' causation be a philosophical relation, as implying contiguity, succession, and constant conjunction, yet 'tis only so far as it is a natural relation, and produces an union among our ideas, that we are able to reason upon it, or draw any inference from it.

因此，尽管因果关系是一种哲学关系，因为它意味着连续性、继承性和持续的结合，但只有当它是一种自然关系，并在我们的观念中产生一种结合时，我们才能够对它进行推理，或从它得出任何推论。

 

Section 7. Of The Nature Of The Idea Or Belief

第 7 节。观念或信仰的性质

 

The idea of an object is an essential part pf the belief of it, but not the whole. We conceive many things, which we do not believe. In order then to discover more fully the nature of belief, or the qualities of those ideas we assent to, let us weigh the following considerations.

对一个物体的想法是对它的信念的一个重要部分，但不是全部。我们设想了许多事情，但我们并不相信。那么，为了更全面地发现信仰的本质，或者说我们所认同的那些观念的品质，让我们权衡一下以下的考虑。

'Tis evident, that all reasonings from causes or effects terminate in conclusions, concerning matter of fact; that is, concerning the existence of objects or of their qualities. 'Tis also evident, that the idea of existence is nothing different from the idea of any object, and that when after the simple conception of any thing we wou'd conceive it as existent, we in reality make no addition to or alteration on our first idea. Thus when we affirm, that God is existent, we simply form the idea of such a being, as he is represented to us; nor is the existence, which we attribute to him, conceiv'd by a particular idea, which we join to the idea of his other qualities, and can again separate and distinguish from them. But I go farther; and not content with asserting, that the conception of the existence of any object is no addition to the simple conception of it, I likewise maintain, that the belief of the existence joins no new ideas to those, which compose the idea of the object. When I think of God, when I think of him as existent, and when I believe him to be existent, my idea of him neither encreases nor diminishes. But as 'tis certain there is a great difference betwixt the simple conception of the existence of an object, and the belief of it, and as this difference lies not in the parts or composition of the idea, which we conceive; it follows, that it must lie in the manner, in which we conceive it.

显而易见，所有从原因或结果出发的推理都以关于事实问题的结论告终；也就是说，关于物体的存在或它们的质量。同样明显的是，存在的概念与任何物体的概念没有什么不同，当我们对任何事物有了简单的概念之后，就会认为它是存在的，实际上我们并没有对我们的第一个概念进行补充或改变。因此，当我们确认上帝是存在的时候，我们只是形成了这样一个存在的概念，就像他在我们面前表现出来的那样；我们归因于他的存在，也不是由一个特定的概念来构思的，我们把它与他其他品质的概念结合起来，并能再次与它们分开和区别。但我走得更远；我并不满足于断言，对任何物体的存在的概念都不是对它的简单概念的补充，我还坚持认为，对存在的信念不会把新的观念加入那些构成物体的观念的观念中。当我想到上帝的时候，当我认为他是存在的时候，当我相信他是存在的时候，我对他的想法既没有增加也没有减少。但可以肯定的是，在对一个物体存在的简单概念和对它的信仰之间存在着巨大的差异，而这种差异并不在于我们所设想的概念的部分或组成；因此，它必须在于我们设想它的方式。

Suppose a person present with me, who advances propositions, to which I do not assent, that Cæsar dy'd in his bed, that silver is more fusible than lead, or mercury heavier than gold; 'tis evident, that notwithstanding my incredulity, I clearly understand his meaning, and form all the same ideas, which he forms. My imagination is endow'd with the same powers as his; nor is it possible for him to conceive any idea, which I cannot conceive; or conjoin any, which I cannot conjoin. I therefore ask, Wherein consists the difference betwixt believing and disbelieving any proposition? The answer is easy with regard to propositions, that are prov'd by intuition or demonstration. In that case, the person, who assents, not only conceives the ideas according to the proposition, but is necessarily determin'd to conceive them in that particular manner, either immediately or by the interposition of other ideas. Whatever is absurd is unintelligible; nor is it possible for the imagination to conceive any thing contrary to a demonstration. But as in reasonings from causation, and concerning matters of fact, this absolute necessity cannot take place, and the imagination is free to conceive both sides of the question, I still ask, Wherein consists the difference betwixt incredulity and belief? since in both cases the conception of the idea is equally possible and requisite.

假设有一个人和我在一起，他提出了我不同意的主张，说凯撒死在床上，银比铅更易熔，水银比金更重；很明显，尽管我难以置信，但我清楚地理解他的意思，并形成他所形成的所有相同的想法。我的想象力和他的想象力是一样的；他也不可能构思出任何我无法构思的想法，或者连接任何我无法连接的想法。因此我问，相信和不相信任何命题的区别在哪里？对于那些通过直觉或证明来证明的命题，答案很简单。在这种情况下，同意的人不仅按照命题设想了观念，而且必然决定以这种特定的方式设想它们，或者立即设想，或者通过其他观念的介入。荒谬的东西是不可理解的；想象力也不可能设想出任何与证明相反的东西。但在因果关系的推理中，以及在有关事实的问题上，这种绝对的必然性是不可能发生的，想象力可以自由地设想问题的两面，我还是要问，难以置信和相信之间的区别在哪里？因为在这两种情况下，对观念的设想是同样可能和必要的。

'Twill not be a satisfactory answer to say, that a person, who does not assent to a proposition you advance; after having conceiv'd the object in the same manner with you; immediately conceives it in a different manner, and has different ideas of it. This answer is unsatisfactory; not because it contains any falsehood, but because it discovers not all the truth. 'Tis confest, that in all cases, wherein we dissent from any person, we conceive both sides of the question; but as we can believe only one, it evidently follows, that the belief must make some difference betwixt that conception to which we assent, and that from which we dissent. We may mingle, and unite, and separate, and confound, and vary our ideas in a hundred different ways; but 'till there appears some principle, which fixes one of these different situations, we have in reality no opinion: And this principle, as it plainly makes no addition to our precedent ideas, can only change the manner of our conceiving them.

如果说一个不同意你提出的主张的人，在以与你相同的方式构思对象之后，立即以不同的方式构思它，对它有不同的想法，这不是一个令人满意的答案。这个答案并不令人满意；不是因为它包含任何错误，而是因为它没有发现所有的真理。可以肯定的是，在所有情况下，当我们不同意任何人的观点时，我们对问题的两面都有概念；但由于我们只能相信一个，显然，在我们同意的概念和我们不同意的概念之间，信仰必须有一些区别。我们可以以一百种不同的方式混合、联合、分离、混淆和改变我们的观念；但 “除非出现某种原则，将这些不同情况中的一种固定下来，否则我们实际上没有意见。而这一原则，由于它显然没有对我们先前的观念进行补充，只能改变我们对它们的设想方式。

All the perceptions of the mind are of two kinds, viz. impressions and ideas, which differ from each other only in their different degrees of force and vivacity. Our ideas are copy'd from our impressions, and represent them in all their parts. When you wou'd any way vary the idea of a particular object, you can only encrease or diminish its force and vivacity. If you make any other change on it, it represents a different object or impression. The case is the same as in colours. A particular shade of any colour may acquire a new degree of liveliness or brightness without any other variation. But when you produce any other variation, 'tis no longer the same shade or colour. So that as belief does nothing but vary the manner, in which we conceive any object, it can only bestow on our ideas an additional force and vivacity. An opinion, therefore, or belief may be most accurately defin'd, A lively idea related to or associated with a present impression18.

心灵的所有感知都有两种，即印象和观念，它们之间的区别只在于它们的力量和活力的不同程度。我们的观念是从我们的印象中复制出来的，并在它们的所有部分中代表它们。当你想以任何方式改变一个特定对象的观念时，你只能增加或减少它的力量和活力。如果你对它做任何其他的改变，它就会代表一个不同的物体或印象。这种情况与颜色的情况是一样的。任何颜色的一个特定色调都可能获得一种新的活力或亮度，而不需要任何其他变化。但是，当你产生任何其他的变化时，它就不再是同一个色调或颜色了。因此，由于信仰除了改变我们对任何物体的概念的方式外，它只能赋予我们的想法以额外的力量和活力。因此，观点或信仰可以被最准确地定义为：与当前印象有关或相关的生动的想法18.

Here are the heads of those arguments, which lead us to this conclusion. When we infer the existence of an object from that of others, some object must always be present either to the memory or senses, in order to be the foundation of our reasoning; since the mind cannot run up with its inferences in infinitum. Reason can never satisfy us that the existence of any one object does ever imply that of another; so that when we pass from the impression of one to the idea or belief of another, we are not determin'd by reason, but by custom or a principle of association. But belief is somewhat more than a simple idea. 'Tis a particular manner of forming an idea: And as the same idea can only be vary'd by a variation of its degrees of force and vivacity; it follows upon the whole, that belief is a lively idea produc'd by a relation to a present impression, according to the foregoing definition.

以下是那些导致我们得出这一结论的论据的标题。当我们从一个物体的存在推断出其他物体的存在时，一些物体必须始终存在于记忆或感官中，以便成为我们推理的基础；因为头脑不可能无休止地进行推理。理性永远不能使我们确信任何一个对象的存在都意味着另一个对象的存在；因此，当我们从一个对象的印象转到另一个对象的想法或信念时，我们不是由理性决定的，而是由习惯或联想的原则决定的。但信仰不仅仅是一个简单的概念。它是一种形成观念的特殊方式。由于同一观念只能通过其力量和活力程度的变化而变化；从整体上看，根据上述定义，信仰是通过与当前印象的关系而产生的一种生动的观念。

This definition will also be found to be entirely conformable to every one's feeling and experience. Nothing is more evident, than that those ideas, to which we assent, are more strong, firm and vivid, than the loose reveries of a castle builder. If one person sits down to read a book as a romance, and another as a true history, they plainly receive

这个定义也会被发现完全符合每个人的感觉和经验。最明显的莫过于，我们所认同的那些观念，比城堡建造者的松散遐想更加强烈、坚定和生动。如果一个人坐下来把一本书当作罗曼蒂克来读，而另一个人则把它当作真实的历史来读，他们就会清楚地收到

the same ideas, and in the same order; nor does the incredulity of the one, and the belief of the other hinder them from putting the very same sense upon their author. His words produce the same ideas in both; tho' his testimony has not the same influence on them. The latter has a more lively conception of all the incidents. He enters deeper into the concerns of the persons: represents to himself their actions, and characters, and friendships, and enmities: He even goes so far as to form a notion of their features, and air, and person. While the former, who gives no credit to the testimony of the author, has a more faint and languid conception of all these particulars; and except on account of the style and ingenuity of the composition, can receive little entertainment from it.

同样的想法，同样的顺序；一个人的难以置信，另一个人的相信，也不妨碍他们把同样的意义放在他们的作者身上。他的话语在两人身上产生了同样的想法；尽管他的证词对他们的影响并不相同。后者对所有的事件有一个更生动的概念。他更深入地了解这些人的情况：向自己描述他们的行为和性格，以及友谊和敌意。他甚至还对他们的特征、气质和性格形成了概念。而前者不相信作者的证词，对所有这些细节都有一个更模糊和无精打采的概念；除非是由于作品的风格和独创性，否则无法从中得到什么乐趣。

 

Section 8. Of The Causes Of Belief

第 8 节。信仰的原因

 

Having thus explain'd the nature of belief; and shewn that it consists in a lively idea related to a present impression; let us now proceed to examine from what principles it is deriv'd, and what bestows the vivacity on the idea.

在这样解释了信仰的本质之后，并证明它是由一个与当前印象相关的活泼的想法组成的；现在让我们继续研究它是由什么原则衍生出来的，是什么赋予了这个想法以活力。

I wou'd willingly establish it as a general maxim in the science of human nature, that when any impression becomes present to us, it not only transports the mind to such ideas as are related to it, but likewise communicates to them a share of its force and vivacity. All the operations of the mind depend in a great measure on its disposition, when it performs them; and according as the spirits are more or less elevated, and the attention more or less fix'd, the action will always have more or less vigour and vivacity. When therefore any object is presented, which elevates and enlivens the thought, every action, to which the mind applies itself, will be more strong and vivid, as long as that disposition continues. Now 'tis evident the continuance of the disposition depends entirely on the objects, about which the mind is employ'd; and that any new object naturally gives a new direction to the spirits, and changes the disposition; as on the contrary, when the mind fixes constantly on the same object, or passes easily and insensibly along related objects, the disposition has a much longer duration. Hence it happens, that when the mind is once inliven'd by a present impression, it proceeds to form a more lively idea of the related objects, by a natural transition of the disposition from the one to the other. The change of the objects is so easy, that the mind is scarce sensible of it, but applies itself to the conception of the related idea with all the force and vivacity it acquir'd from the present impression.

我愿意把它确立为人性科学中的一般格言，即当任何印象出现在我们面前时，它不仅把思想带到与之相关的观念中，而且还把它的一部分力量和活力传递给它们。心灵的所有活动在很大程度上取决于它在进行这些活动时的态度；根据精神或多或少的提升，注意力或多或少的固定，行动总是有或多或少的活力和生机。因此，当有任何对象出现，使思想得到提升和活跃时，只要这种倾向继续下去，思想所运用的每一个行动都会更加有力和生动。很明显，这种倾向的持续完全取决于思想所关注的对象；任何新的对象都会给精神带来新的方向，并改变这种倾向；相反，当思想不断地固定在同一个对象上，或者轻松而不经意地沿着相关的对象前进时，这种倾向的持续时间会更长。因此，当心灵一旦被当前的印象所激发，它就会对相关的对象形成一个更生动的概念，通过处置方式从一个对象自然过渡到另一个对象。对象的变化是如此容易，以至于头脑几乎感觉不到它的存在，而是用它从当前印象中获得的所有力量和活力来构思相关概念。

If in considering the nature of relation, and that facility of transition, which is essential to it, we can satisfy ourselves concerning the reality of this phænomenon, 'tis well: But I must confess I place my chief confidence in experience to prove so material a principle. We may, therefore, observe, as the first experiment to our present purpose, that upon the appearance of the picture of an absent friend, our idea of him is evidently inliven'd by the resemblance, and that every passion, which that idea occasions, whether of joy or sorrow, acquires new force and vigour. In producing this effect there concur both a relation and a present impression. Where the picture bears him no resemblance, or at least was not intended for him, it never so much as conveys our thought to him: And where it is absent, as well as the person; tho' the mind may pass from the thought of the one to that of the other; it feels its idea to be rather weaken'd than inliven'd by that transition. We take a pleasure in viewing the picture of a friend, when 'tis set before us; but when 'tis remov'd, rather choose to consider him directly, than by reflexion in an image, which is equally distant and obscure.

如果在考虑关系的性质和过渡的便利性时，也就是在考虑关系的本质时，我们可以对这种现象的真实性感到满意，那就好了。但我必须承认，我对证明如此重要的原则，主要信赖经验。因此，我们可以观察到，作为我们目前目的的第一个实验，当一个不在的朋友的照片出现时，我们对他的想法显然因相似而活跃起来，而且这种想法引起的每一种激情，无论是快乐还是悲伤，都会获得新的力量和活力。在产生这种效果时，同时存在着一种关系和一种现在的印象。如果这幅画与他没有相似之处，或者至少不是为他准备的，那么它就不会把我们的想法传达给他。如果没有他，也没有他的人，虽然思想可以从一个人的思想转到另一个人的思想，但它觉得它的想法会因为这种转变而被削弱，而不是活跃。当朋友的画像摆在我们面前时，我们会很高兴地观看；但当画像被移开时，我们宁愿选择直接考虑他，而不是通过反射在一个同样遥远和模糊的图像中。

The ceremonies of the Roman Catholic religion may be consider'd as experiments of the same nature. The devotees of that strange superstition usually plead in excuse of the mummeries, with which they are upbraided, that they feel the good effect of those external motions, and postures, and actions, in inlivening their devotion, and quickening their fervour, which otherwise wou'd decay away, if directed entirely to distant and immaterial objects. We shadow out the objects of our faith, say they, in sensible types and images, and render them more present to us by the immediate presence of these types, than 'tis possible for us to do, merely by an intellectual view and contemplation. Sensible objects have always a greater influence on the fancy than any other; and this influence they readily convey to those ideas, to which they are related, and which they resemble. I shall only infer from these practices, and this reasoning, that the effect of resemblance in inlivening the idea is very common; and as in every case a resemblance and a present impression must concur, we are abundantly supply'd with experiments to prove the reality of the foregoing principle.

罗马天主教的仪式可以被认为是同样性质的实验。这种奇怪的迷信的信徒们通常为他们被指责的默默无闻的行为辩解说，他们感到这些外部的动作、姿势和行动有很好的效果，使他们的虔诚之心更加活跃，使他们的热情更加高涨，否则，如果完全针对遥远的、非物质的对象，这种热情就会消退。他们说，我们在感性的类型和图像中看到了我们信仰的对象，并通过这些类型的直接存在使它们在我们面前更有存在感，这比我们仅仅通过智力的观察和思考是不可能做到的。感性的物体对想象力的影响总是比其他任何物体都大；这种影响很容易传达给那些与之相关的、与之相似的观念。我只想从这些实践和这个推理中推断出，相似性对活跃思想的影响是非常普遍的；由于在每一种情况下，相似性和当前的印象必须同时存在，我们有大量的实验来证明上述原则的真实性。

We may add force to these experiments by others of a different kind, in considering the effects of contiguity, as well as of resemblance. 'Tis certain, that distance diminishes the force of every idea, and that upon our approach to any object; tho' it does not discover itself to our senses; it operates upon the mind with an influence that imitates an immediate impression. The thinking on any object readily transports the mind to what is contiguous; but 'tis only the actual presence of an object that transports it with a superior vivacity. When I am a few miles from home, whatever relates to it touches me more nearly than when I am two hundred leagues distant; tho' even at that distance the reflecting on any thing in the neighbourhood of my friends and family naturally produces an idea of them. But as in this latter case, both the objects of the mind are ideas; notwithstanding there is an easy transition betwixt them; that transition alone is not able to give a superior vivacity to any of the ideas, for want of some immediate impression.

我们可以通过其他不同类型的实验来增加这些实验的力度，考虑相邻和相似的影响。可以肯定的是，距离会减弱每一个想法的力量，而且在我们接近任何物体时都会减弱；尽管它不会被我们的感官所发现；它对心灵的影响是模仿直接印象的。对任何物体的思考都很容易将头脑转移到邻近的事物上；但只有物体的实际存在才会使它具有更强的活力。当我离家几英里时，任何与之有关的东西都会比我在 200 英里以外的地方更接近我；即使在那么远的地方，对我的朋友和家人附近的任何东西进行思考，也会自然产生对他们的印象。但在后一种情况下，头脑中的两个对象都是观念；尽管它们之间有一个容易的过渡；但由于缺乏一些直接的印象，仅仅这种过渡并不能给任何观念带来更多的活力。

No one can doubt but causation has the same influence as the other two relations of resemblance and contiguity. Superstitious people are fond of the relicts of saints and holy men for the same reason that they seek after types and images, in order to inliven their devotion, and give them a more intimate and strong conception of those exemplary lives, which they desire to imitate. Now 'tis evident, one of the best relicks a devotee cou'd procure, wou'd be the handy work of a saint; and if his cloaths and furniture are ever to be consider'd in this light, 'tis because they were once at his disposal, and were mov'd and affected by him; in which respect they are to be consider'd as imperfect effects, and as connected with him by a shorter chain of consequences than any of those, from which we learn the reality of his existence. This phænomenon clearly proves, that a present impression with a relation of causation may enliven any idea, and consequently produce belief or assent, according to the precedent definition of it.

没有人会怀疑，因果关系与其他两种相似和相邻关系具有同样的影响。迷信的人喜欢圣徒和圣人的遗物，原因与他们寻求类型和图像一样，是为了使他们的奉献更加生动，并使他们对那些他们想要模仿的模范生活有一个更亲密和强烈的概念。现在很明显，一个信徒所能获得的最好的遗物之一，就是圣人的得意之作；如果他的衣着和家具永远要从这个角度来考虑，那是因为它们曾经由他支配，并被他移动和影响过；在这方面，它们应被视为不完美的效果，而且与他的联系比那些我们从他的存在中得知的后果链更短。这个现象清楚地证明，一个具有因果关系的现存印象可以使任何想法活跃起来，并因此产生信仰或同意，根据它的先例定义。

But why need we seek for other arguments to prove, that a present impression with a relation or transition of the fancy may inliven any idea, when this very instance of our reasonings from cause and effect will alone suffice to that purpose? 'Tis certain we must have an idea of every matter of fact, which we believe. 'Tis certain, that this idea arises only from a relation to a present impression. 'Tis certain, that the belief super-adds nothing to the idea, but only changes our manner of conceiving it, and renders it more strong and lively. The present conclusion concerning the influence of relation is the immediate consequence of all these steps; and every step appears to me sure and infallible. There enters nothing into this operation of the mind but a present impression, a lively idea, and a relation or association in the fancy betwixt the impression and idea; so that there can be no suspicion of mistake.

但是，我们为什么要寻找其他的论据来证明，当我们从因果关系中推理出的这个例子就足以达到这个目的的时候，现在的印象与幻想的关系或过渡可以使任何观念得到启发？可以肯定的是，我们必须对我们所相信的每一个事实问题有一个想法。可以肯定的是，这种观念只是从与当前印象的关系中产生的。可以肯定的是，信仰并没有给观念带来任何好处，而只是改变了我们对它的理解方式，并使它变得更加强烈和生动。目前关于关系的影响的结论是所有这些步骤的直接结果；在我看来，每一个步骤都是肯定和无懈可击的。在心灵的这种运作中，除了一个当前的印象、一个活泼的想法，以及印象和想法之间在幻想中的关系或联想之外，没有任何东西会进入心灵；因此，不可能有错误的怀疑。

In order to put this whole affair in a fuller light, let us consider it as a question in natural philosophy, which we must determine by experience and observation. I suppose there is an object presented, from which I draw a certain conclusion, and form to myself ideas, which I am said to believe or assent to. Here 'tis evident, that however that object, which is present to my senses, and that other, whose existence I infer by reasoning, may be thought to influence each other by their particular powers or qualities; yet as the phænomenon of belief, which we at present examine, is merely internal, these powers and qualities, being entirely unknown, can have no hand in producing it. 'Tis the present impression, which is to be consider'd as the true and real cause of the idea, and of the belief which attends it. We must therefore endeavour to discover by experiments the particular qualities, by which 'tis enabled to produce so extraordinary an effect.

为了更全面地了解这整个事件，让我们把它看作是自然哲学中的一个问题，我们必须通过经验和观察来确定。我假设有一个物体出现，我从中得出某种结论，并形成自己的想法，据说我相信或同意这些想法。这里很明显，无论我的感官所看到的那个物体和我通过推理推断出的那个物体的存在，都可以被认为是通过它们特定的力量或品质来相互影响的；但是，由于我们目前所研究的信仰现象只是内在的，这些力量和品质是完全未知的，不可能对其产生影响。现在的印象才是思想和伴随它的信仰的真正和真正的原因。因此，我们必须努力通过实验来发现特定的品质，通过这些品质，它能够产生如此非凡的效果。

First then I observe, that the present impression has not this effect by its own proper power and efficacy, and when consider'd alone, as a single perception, limited to the present moment. I find, that an impression, from which, on its first appearance, I can draw no conclusion, may afterwards become the foundation of belief, when I have had experience of its usual consequences. We must in every case have observ'd the same impression in past instances, and have found it to be constantly conjoin'd with some other impression. This is confirm'd by such a multitude of experiments, that it admits not of the smallest doubt.

首先，我观察到，目前的印象并不是通过其自身的力量和功效而产生的，当单独考虑时，作为一种单一的感知，仅限于目前的时刻。我发现，一个印象，在它第一次出现时，我不能得出任何结论，但当我对其通常的后果有了经验之后，它可能成为信仰的基础。在每一种情况下，我们都必须在过去的事例中观察到同样的印象，并发现它经常与其他一些印象联系在一起。这一点已被大量的实验所证实，以至于不允许有丝毫的怀疑。

From a second observation I conclude, that the belief which attends the present impression, and is produc'd by a number of past impressions and conjunctions; that this belief, I say, arises immediately, without any new operation of the reason or imagination. Of this I can be certain, because I never am conscious of any such operation, and find nothing in the subject, on which it can be founded. Now as we call every thing custom, which proceeds from a past repetition, without any new reasoning or conclusion, we may establish it as a certain truth, that all the belief, which follows upon any present impression, is deriv'd solely from that origin. When we are accustom'd to see two impressions conjoin'd together, the appearance or idea of the one immediately carries us to the idea of the other.

根据第二项观察，我得出结论：伴随着当前印象的信念，是由一些过去的印象和联结产生的；我说，这种信念是立即产生的，没有任何新的理性或想象力的操作。这一点我可以肯定，因为我从来没有意识到任何这样的操作，也没有在这个主题中发现任何可以作为其基础的东西。现在，由于我们把每一件从过去的重复中产生的、没有任何新的推理或结论的事情称为习惯，我们可以把它作为一个确定的事实来确定，即所有的信仰，在任何现在的印象中产生的，都完全来自于这种起源。当我们习惯于看到两个印象结合在一起时，一个印象的出现或想法会立即让我们产生另一个印象。

Being fully satisfy'd on this head, I make a third set of experiments, in order to know, whether any thing be requisite, beside the customary transition, towards the production of this phænomenon of belief. I therefore change the first impression into an idea; and observe, that tho' the customary transition to the correlative idea still remains, yet there is in reality no belief nor persuasion. A present impression, then, is absolutely requisite to this whole operation; and when after this I compare an impression with an idea, and find that their only difference consists in their different degrees of force and vivacity, I conclude upon the whole, that belief is a more vivid and intense conception of an idea, proceeding from its relation to a present impression.

在这一点上我很满意，于是我又做了第三组实验，以了解在产生这种信仰现象的过程中，除了习惯性的过渡之外，是否还有其他必要的东西。因此，我把第一印象变成了一个观念；并且观察到，尽管向相关观念的惯常过渡仍然存在，但实际上并没有信仰或说服力。因此，整个过程绝对需要一个现在的印象；当我把印象和观念进行比较后，发现它们唯一的区别在于它们的力量和活力程度不同，我得出的结论是，总的来说，信仰是对一个观念更生动、更强烈的概念，源于它与现在印象的关系。

Thus all probable reasoning is nothing but a species of sensation. 'Tis not solely in poetry and music, we must follow our taste and sentiment, but likewise in philosophy. When I am convinc'd of any principle, 'tis only an idea, which strikes more strongly upon me. When I give the preference to one set of arguments above another, I do nothing but decide from my feeling concerning the superiority of their influence. Objects have no discoverable connexion together; nor is it from any other principle but custom operating upon the imagination, that we can draw any inference from the appearance of one to the existence of another.

因此，所有可能的推理都不过是感觉的一个种类。不仅仅是在诗歌和音乐中，我们必须遵循我们的品味和情感，在哲学中也是如此。当我对任何原则深信不疑时，这只是一种想法，它对我的冲击力更强。当我优先选择一套论据而不是另一套时，我所做的只是根据我对其影响的优越性的感觉来决定。物体之间没有任何可以发现的联系；除了习惯对想象力的影响外，我们也不能从一个物体的外观推断出另一个物体的存在，这不是任何其他原则。

'Twill here be worth our observation, that the past experience, on which all our judgments concerning cause and effect depend, may operate on our mind in such an insensible manner as never to be taken notice of, and may even in some measure be unknown to us. A person, who stops short in his journey upon meeting a river in his way, foresees the consequences of his proceeding forward; and his knowledge of these consequences is convey'd to him by past experience, which informs him of such certain conjunctions of causes and effects. But can we think, that on this occasion he reflects on any past experience, and calls to remembrance instances, that he has seen or heard of, in order to discover the effects of water on animal bodies? No surely; this is not the method in which he proceeds in his reasoning. The idea of sinking is so closely connected with that of water, and the idea of suffocating with that of sinking, that the mind makes the transition without the assistance of the memory. The custom operates before we have time for reflection. The objects seem so inseparable, that we interpose not a moment's delay in passing from the one to the other. But as this transition proceeds from experience, and not from any primary connexion betwixt the ideas, we must necessarily acknowledge, that experience may produce a belief and a judgment of causes and effects by a secret operation, and without being once thought of. This removes all pretext, if there yet remains any, for asserting that the mind is convinc'd by reasoning of that principle, that instances of which we have no experience, must necessarily resemble those, of which we have. For we here find, that the understanding or imagination can draw inferences from past experience, without reflecting on it; much more without forming any principle concerning it, or reasoning upon that principle.

这里值得我们注意的是，我们所有关于因果关系的判断所依赖的过去的经验，可能以一种不为人知的方式作用于我们的头脑，以至于从未被注意到，甚至在某种程度上可能不为我们所知。一个人在旅途中遇到河流就会停下脚步，他预见到了自己前进的后果；他对这些后果的认识是由过去的经验传达给他的，这些经验告诉他这种特定的因果关系的组合。但我们能认为，在这个场合，他反思过去的任何经验，并唤起他所看到或听到的例子，以发现水对动物身体的影响？当然不是；这不是他进行推理的方法。下沉的概念与水的概念密切相关，窒息的概念与下沉的概念密切相关，以至于头脑在没有记忆的帮助下完成了过渡。在我们有时间进行思考之前，这种习惯就已经开始了。这些对象似乎是如此密不可分，以至于我们在从一个对象转到另一个对象时没有片刻的延迟。但是，由于这种转变来自于经验，而不是来自于观念之间的任何主要联系，我们必须承认，经验可能会通过秘密的操作，在没有想到的情况下，产生对原因和结果的信念和判断。这就消除了所有的借口，如果还有任何借口的话，那就是断言心灵被推理说服的原则，即我们没有经验的事例，必然与我们有经验的事例相似。因为我们在这里发现，理解力或想象力可以从过去的经验中得出推论，而不需要对它进行反思；更不需要对它形成任何原则，或根据该原则进行推理。

In general we may observe, that in all the most establish'd and uniform conjunctions of causes and effects, such as those of gravity, impulse, solidity, &c., the mind never carries its view expressly to consider any past experience: Tho' in other associations of objects, which are more rare and unusual, it may assist the custom and transition of ideas by this reflection. Nay we find in some cases, that the reflection produces the belief without the custom; or more properly speaking, that the reflection produces the custom in an oblique and artificial manner. I explain myself. 'Tis certain, that not only in philosophy, but even in common life, we may attain the knowledge of a particular cause merely by one experiment, provided it be made with judgment, and after a careful removal of all foreign and superfluous circumstances. Now as after one experiment of this kind, the mind, upon the appearance either of the cause or the effect, can draw an inference concerning the existence of its correlative; and as a habit can never be acquir'd merely by one instance; it may be thought, that belief cannot in this case be esteem'd the effect of custom. But this difficulty will vanish, if we consider, that tho' we are here suppos'd to have had only one experiment of a particular effect, yet we have many millions to convince us of this principle; that like objects, plac'd in like circumstances, will always produce like effects; and as this principle has establish'd itself by a sufficient custom, it bestows an evidence and firmness on any opinion, to which it can be apply'd. The connexion of the ideas is not habitual after one experiment; but this connexion is comprehended under another principle, that is habitual; which brings us back to our hypothesis. In all cases we transfer our experience to instances, of which we have no experience, either expressly or tacitly, either directly or indirectly.

一般来说，我们可以观察到，在所有最成熟和最统一的因果关系中，如重力、冲力、坚固性等，头脑从未明确地考虑过任何过去的经验。虽然在其他更罕见和不寻常的物体关联中，它可以通过这种思考来帮助习惯和观念的转变。但我们发现，在某些情况下，反思产生了信仰，而没有习惯；或者更恰当地说，反思以一种斜的和人为的方式产生了习惯。我自己解释一下。可以肯定的是，不仅在哲学中，甚至在普通生活中，我们都可以通过一次实验来获得对某一特定原因的认识，只要它是经过判断的，并在仔细清除了所有外来和多余的情况之后。现在，经过这样的一次实验，头脑中出现了原因或结果，就可以推断出其相关因素的存在；由于一种习惯不可能仅仅通过一个例子就能获得；人们可能会认为，在这种情况下，信仰不能被视为习惯的结果。但是，如果我们考虑到，虽然我们在这里被认为只有一个特定效果的实验，但是我们有无数个例子来说服我们相信这个原则；相似的物体，放在相似的环境中，总是会产生相似的效果；由于这个原则已经通过足够的习惯建立了自己，它赋予了任何意见以证据和坚定性，它可以被应用于此。观念的联系在一次实验之后并不是习惯性的；但这种联系被包含在另一个原则之下，那就是习惯性的；这使我们回到了我们的假设。在所有情况下，我们都会把我们的经验转移到我们没有经验的实例上，无论是明确的还是默示的，无论是直接的还是间接的。

I must not conclude this subject without observing, that 'tis very difficult to talk of the operations of the mind with perfect propriety and exactness; because common language has seldom made any very nice distinctions among them, but has generally call'd by the same term all such as nearly resemble each other. And as this is a source almost inevitable of obscurity and confusion in the author; so it may frequently give rise to doubts and objections in the reader, which otherwise he wou'd never have dream'd of. Thus my general position, that an opinion or belief is nothing but a strong and lively idea deriv'd from a present impression related to it, may be liable to the following objection, by reason of a little ambiguity in those words strong and lively. It may be said, that not only an impression may give rise to reasoning, but that an idea may also have the same influence; especially upon my principle, that all our ideas are deriv'd from correspondent impressions. For suppose I form at present an idea, of which I have forgot the correspondent impression, I am able to conclude from this idea, that such an impression did once exist; and as this conclusion is attended with belief, it may be ask'd, from whence are the qualities of force and vivacity deriv'd, which constitute this belief? And to this I answer very readily, from the present idea. For as this idea is not here consider'd as the representation of any absent object, but as a real perception in the mind, of which we are intimately conscious, it must be able to bestow on whatever is related to it the same quality, call it firmness, or solidity, or force, or vivacity, with which the mind reflects upon it, and is assur'd of its present existence. The idea here supplies the place of an impression, and is entirely the same, so far as regards our present purpose.

在结束这个话题之前，我必须指出，要完全恰当和准确地谈论心灵的运作是非常困难的；因为普通的语言很少对它们进行很好的区分，而是通常用同一个词来称呼所有几乎相似的东西。由于这几乎不可避免地造成了作者的晦涩和混乱；因此，它可能经常引起读者的怀疑和反对，否则他做梦都想不到。因此，我的一般立场，即一个观点或信仰只不过是由与之相关的当前印象衍生出来的一个强烈而生动的想法，可能会受到以下反对意见的影响，原因是在这些强烈和生动的词语中存在着一点模糊不清。可以说，不仅印象可以引起推理，而且观念也可以产生同样的影响；特别是根据我的原则，即我们所有的观念都是由相应的印象衍生出来的。因为假设我现在形成了一个观念，而我却忘记了相应的印象，我就能从这个观念中得出结论，这种印象曾经存在过；由于这个结论伴随着信念，人们可能会问，构成这种信念的力量和活力的品质是从哪里来的？对于这个问题，我很容易回答，从现在的观念出发。因为这个观念在这里不是被视为任何不存在的物体的表象，而是被视为我们密切意识到的心灵中的真实感知，它必须能够赋予与之相关的任何事物以同样的品质，称之为坚定性、牢固性、力量 或活力，而心灵正是以这种品质来反映它，并保证它现在的存在。在这里，观念代替了印象，而且就我们目前的目的而言，观念是完全相同的。

Upon the same principles we need not be surpriz'd to hear of the remembrance of an idea; that is, of the idea of an idea, and of its force and vivacity superior to the loose conceptions of the imagination. In thinking of our past thoughts we not only delineate out the objects, of which we were thinking, but also conceive the action of the mind in the meditation, that certain je-ne-scai-quoi, of which 'tis impossible to give any definition or description, but which every one sufficiently understands. When the memory offers an idea of this, and represents it as past, 'tis easily conceiv'd how that idea may have more vigour and firmness, than when we think of a past thought, of which we have no remembrance.

根据同样的原则，我们不需要惊讶地听到对一个想法的记忆；也就是说，对一个想法的想法，以及它的力量和活力优于想象力的松散概念。在思考我们过去的想法时，我们不仅勾勒出我们所想的对象，而且还设想出冥想中的思维行动，即某种 “我”的想法，对它不可能给出任何定义或描述，但每个人都能充分理解它。当记忆提供了一个想法，并把它表现为过去，'很容易想象，这个想法可能比我们想到一个过去的想法时更有活力和坚定性，因为我们对它没有记忆。

After this any one will understand how we may form the idea of an impression and of an idea, and how we may believe the existence of an impression and of an idea.

在这之后，任何人都会明白我们是如何形成一个印象和一个想法的，以及我们是如何相信一个印象和一个想法的存在的。

 

Section 9. Of The Effects Of Other Relations And Other Habits

第 9 节。其他关系和其他习惯的影响

 

However convincing the foregoing arguments may appear, we must not rest contented with them, but must turn the subject on every side, in order to find some new points of view, from which we may illustrate and confirm such extraordinary, and such fundamental principles. A scrupulous hesitation to receive any new hypothesis is so laudable a disposition in philosophers, and so necessary to the examination of truth, that it deserves to be comply'd with, and requires that every argument be produc'd, which may tend to their satisfaction, and every objection remov'd, which may stop them in their reasoning.

无论上述论据看起来多么有说服力，我们都不能满足于这些论据，而必须从各个角度来看待这个问题，以便找到一些新的观点，从这些观点中我们可以说明和证实这些非凡的基本原则。对于接受任何新的假设，哲学家们都有一种值得称道的态度，对于真理的检验也是如此的必要，以至于它值得被遵守，并要求提出每一个可能使他们满意的论据，消除每一个可能阻止他们推理的异议。

I have often observ'd, that, beside cause and effect, the two relations of resemblance and contiguity, are to be consider'd as associating principles of thought, and as capable of conveying the imagination from one idea to another. I have also observ'd, that when of two objects connected together by any of these relations, one is immediately present to the memory or senses, not only the mind is convey'd o its co-relative by means of the associating principle; but likewise conceives it with an additional force and vigour, by the united operation of that principle, and of the present impression. All this I have observ'd, in order to confirm by analogy, my explication of our judgments concerning cause and effect. But this very argument may perhaps, be turn'd against me, and instead of a confirmation of my hypothesis, may become an objection to it. For it may be said, that if all the parts of that hypothesis be true, viz. that these three species of relation are deriv'd from the same principles; that their effects in in forcing and inlivening our ideas are the same; and that belief is nothing but a more forcible and vivid conception of an idea; it shou'd follow, that that action of the mind may not only be deriv'd from the relation of cause and effect, but also from those of contiguity and resemblance. But as we find by experience, that belief arises only from causation, and that we can draw no inference from one object to another, except they be corrected by this relation, we may conclude, that there is some error in that reasoning, which leads us into such difficulties.

我经常注意到，除了因果关系外，相似和相邻这两种关系应被视为思想的联想原则，并能将想象力从一个概念传递到另一个概念。我还注意到，当由这些关系连接在一起的两个物体中，有一个立即出现在记忆或感官中时，不仅思想通过联想原则被传递到它的共同关系上，而且还通过该原则和当前印象的联合运作，以一种额外的力量和活力来构想它。我所观察到的这一切，是为了通过类比证实我对我们关于因果关系判断的解释。但这一论点也许会被用来反对我，而不是证实我的假设，反而会成为对它的反对。因为可以说，如果这个假设的所有部分都是真实的，即 这三种关系是由相同的原则衍生出来的；它们在强迫和活跃我们的观念方面的效果是相同的；信仰只不过是对一个观念的更有力和生动的概念；那就应该说，心灵的行动不仅可以由因果关系衍生出来，也可以由相邻和相似的关系衍生出来。但我们通过经验发现，信念只产生于因果关系，而且我们无法从一个物体推论到另一个物体，除非它们被这种关系所纠正，因此我们可以得出结论，这种推理存在一些错误，导致我们陷入这种困境。

This is the objection; let us now consider its solution. 'Tis evident, that whatever is present to the memory, striking upon the mind with a vivacity, which resembles an immediate impression, must become of considerable moment in all the operations of the mind, and must easily distinguish itself above the mere fictions of the imagination. Of these impressions or ideas of the memory we form a kind of system, comprehending whatever we remember to have been present, either to our internal perception or senses; and every particular of that system join'd, to the present impressions, we are pleas'd to call a reality. But the mind stops not here. For finding, that with this system of perceptions, there is another connected by custom, or if you will, by the relation of cause or effect, it proceeds to the consideration of their ideas; and as it feels that 'tis in a manner necessarily determin'd to view these particular ideas, and that the custom or relation, by which it is determin'd, admits not of the least change, it forms them into a new system, which it likewise dignifies with the title of realities. The first of these systems is the object of the memory and senses; the second of the judgment.

这就是反对意见；现在让我们考虑其解决办法。很明显，凡是存在于记忆中的东西，以一种活泼的方式冲击着心灵，类似于一种直接的印象，在心灵的所有活动中必须变得相当重要，而且必须很容易地将自己区别于单纯的想象力的虚构。记忆中的这些印象或想法，我们形成了一种系统，包括我们记忆中的任何东西，无论是对我们的内部感知或感官而言，都是存在的；而这个系统的每一个细节，与现在的印象相结合，我们都乐意称之为现实。但思想并没有在这里停止。因为它发现，在这个感知系统的基础上，还有另一个系统通过习俗，或者如果你愿意的话，通过因果关系联系在一起，它就开始考虑它们的观念；由于它觉得自己在某种程度上必然要看待这些特殊的观念，而它所决定的习俗或关系不允许有任何改变，它就把它们组成一个新的系统，它也同样把这个系统冠以现实的称号。这些系统中的第一个是记忆和感官的对象；第二个是判断的对象。

'Tis this latter principle which peoples the world, and brings us acquainted with such existences, as by their removal in time and place, lie beyond the reach of the senses and memory. By means of it I paint the universe in my imagination, and fix my attention on any part of it I please. I form an idea of Rome, which I neither see nor remember; but which is connected with such impressions as I remember to have received from the conversation and books of travellers and historians. This idea of Rome I place in a certain situation on the idea of an object, which I call the globe. I join to it the conception of a particular government, and religion, and manners. I look backward and consider its first foundation; its several revolutions, successes, and misfortunes. All this, and every thing else, which I believe, are nothing but ideas; tho' by their force and settled order, arising from custom and the relation of cause and effect, they distinguish themselves from the other ideas, which are merely the offspring of the imagination.

正是这后一种原则，让我们认识了世界，并使我们认识了这些存在，因为它们在时间和地点上的差异，是感官和记忆所不能企及的。通过它，我在我的想象中描绘宇宙，并将我的注意力固定在我喜欢的任何部分。我形成了一个罗马的概念，我既没有看到也没有记住；但它与我记得从旅行者和历史学家的谈话和书籍中得到的印象有关。我把这个罗马的概念放在一个物体概念的某个位置上，我称之为地球。我把一个特定的政府、宗教和礼仪的概念与它结合起来。我向后看，考虑它最初的基础；它的几次革命、成功和不幸。所有这一切，以及我所相信的其他一切，都不过是观念；但由于它们的力量和固定的秩序，由习俗和因果关系产生，它们与其他观念不同，后者只是想象力的产物。

As to the influence of contiguity and resemblance, we may observe, that if the contiguous and resembling object be comprehended in this system of realities, there is no doubt but these two relations will assist that of cause and effect, and infix the related idea with more force in the imagination. This I shall enlarge upon presently. Mean while I shall carry my observation a step farther, and assert, that even where the related object is but feign'd, the relation will serve to enliven the idea, and encrease its influence. A poet, no doubt, will be the better able to form a strong description of the Elysian fields, that he prompts his imagination by the view of a beautiful meadow or garden; as at another time he may by his fancy place himself in the midst of these fabulous regions, that by the feign'd contiguity he may enliven his imagination.

至于毗连和相似的影响，我们可以注意到，如果毗连和相似的物体被包含在这个现实的系统中，毫无疑问，这两种关系将协助因果关系，并在想象力中注入相关的想法，使其更有力量。这一点我将在下文中详细说明。同时，我将把我的观察再往前推进一步，并断言，即使相关的对象只是假装的，这种关系也将有助于活跃思想，增强其影响力。毫无疑问，如果一个诗人通过欣赏美丽的草地或花园来激发他的想象力，那么他就能更好地形成对极乐世界的强烈描述；就像在另一个时候，他可以通过幻想将自己置于这些神话般的地区之中，通过假装的相邻关系来活跃他的想象力。

But tho' I cannot altogether exclude the relations of resemblance and contiguity from operating on the fancy in this manner, 'tis observable that, when single, their influence is very feeble and uncertain. As the relation of cause and effect is requisite to persuade us of any real existence, so is this persuasion requisite to give force to these other relations. For where upon the appearance of an impression we not only feign another object, but likewise arbitrarily, and of our mere good-will and pleasure give it a particular relation to the impression, this can have but a small effect upon the mind; nor is there any reason, why, upon the return of the same impression, we shou'd be determin'd to place the same object in the same relation to it. There is no manner of necessity for the mind to feign any resembling and contiguous objects; and if it feigns such, there is as little necessity for it always to confine itself to the same, without any difference or variation. And indeed such a fiction is founded on so little reason, that nothing but pure caprice can determine the mind to form it; and that principle being fluctuating and uncertain, 'tis impossible it can ever operate with any considerable degree of force and constancy. The mind forsees and anticipates the change; and even from the very first instant feels the looseness of its actions, and the weak hold it has of its objects. And as this imperfection is very sensible in every single instance, it still encreases by experience and observation, when we compare the several instances we may remember, and form a general rule against the reposing any assurance in those momentary glimpses of light, which arise in the imagination from a feign'd resemblance and contiguity.

但是，尽管我不能完全排除相似性和相邻性的关系以这种方式作用于幻想，但可以看到，在单一的情况下，其影响是非常微弱和不确定的。由于因果关系是说服我们相信任何真实存在的必要条件，这种说服力也是赋予这些其他关系力量的必要条件。因为当一个印象出现时，我们不仅假装另一个物体，而且还任意地，仅仅出于我们的善意和快乐，赋予它与印象的特定关系，这对心灵的影响很小；也没有任何理由，为什么在同一印象返回时，我们会决定将同一物体置于与之相同的关系中。心灵没有必要假装任何相似和相邻的物体；如果它假装如此，它也没有必要总是局限于相同的物体，没有任何区别或变化。事实上，这种虚构是建立在如此少的理由之上的，除了纯粹的任性之外，没有任何东西可以决定心灵的形成；而这种原则是波动的和不确定的，它不可能以任何相当程度的力量和恒定来运作。心灵预见到并预料到这种变化；甚至从一开始就感觉到它的行动的松散性，以及它对它的对象的薄弱控制。由于这种不完美在每一个实例中都是非常明显的，当我们比较我们可能记得的几个实例时，这种不完美仍然在增加，并形成了一个一般的规则，反对在那些瞬间的闪光中寄予任何保证，这些闪光在想象中是由假装的相似性和连续性引起的。

The relation of cause and effect has all the opposite advantages. The objects it presents are fixt and unalterable. The impressions of the memory never change in any considerable degree; and each impression draws along with it a precise idea, which takes its place in the imagination, as something solid and real, certain and invariable. The thought is always determin'd to pass from the impression to the idea, and from that particular impression to that particular idea, without any choice or hesitation.

因果关系具有所有相反的优点。它所呈现的对象是固定的和不可改变的。记忆中的印象永远不会有任何程度的改变；每一个印象都伴随着一个精确的想法，它在想象中占据了位置，成为坚实而真实的、确定而不变的东西。思想总是被确定为从印象到想法，从特定的印象到特定的想法，没有任何选择或犹豫。

But not content with removing this objection, I shall endeavour to extract from it a proof of the present doctrine. Contiguity and resemblance have an effect much inferior to causation; but still have some effect, and augment the conviction of any opinion, and the vivacity of any conception. If this can be prov'd in several new instances, beside what we have already observ'd, 'twill be allow'd no inconsiderable argument, that belief is nothing but a lively idea related to a present impression.

但我并不满足于消除这种反对意见，我将努力从它那里提取目前学说的证据。毗连和相似的效果比因果关系要差得多；但仍有一定的效果，能增强任何观点的说服力和任何概念的生动性。如果这一点能在几个新的例子中得到证明，除了我们已经观察到的情况之外，这将被允许作为一个不小的论据，即信仰只不过是与当前印象相关的一个生动的想法。

To begin with contiguity; it has been remark'd among the Mahometans as well as Christians, that those pilgrims, who have seen Mecca or the Holy Land are ever after more faithful and zealous believers, than those who have not had that advantage. A man, whose memory presents him with a lively image of the Red-Sea, and the Desert, and Jerusalem, and Galilee, can never doubt of any miraculous events, which are related either by Moses or the Evangelists. The lively idea of the places passes by an easy transition to the facts, which are suppos'd to have been related to them by contiguity, and encreases the belief by encreasing the vivacity of the conception. The remembrance of these fields and rivers has the same influence on the vulgar as a new argument; and from the same causes.

首先是毗连性；马赫曼人和基督徒都说，那些朝圣者，如果见过麦加或圣地，就会比那些没有这种优势的人更加忠实和热心地信仰。一个人，如果他的记忆中出现了红海、沙漠、耶路撒冷 和加利利的生动形象，就不会怀疑摩西或福音书中提到的任何神奇事件。对这些地方的生动印象很容易过渡到事实，这些事实被认为是与它们有关联的，并通过提高概念的生动性来增加信仰。对这些田野和河流的记忆对普通人的影响与新的论点相同；而且是出于同样的原因。

We may form a like observation concerning resemblance. We have remark'd, that the conclusion, which we draw from a present object to its absent cause or effect, is never founded on any qualities, which we observe in that object, consider'd in itself; or, in other words, that 'tis impossible to determine. otherwise than by experience, what will result from any phænomenon, or what has preceded it. But tho' this be so evident in itself, that it seem'd not to require any proof; yet some philosophers have imagin'd that there is an apparent cause for the communication of motion, and that a reasonable man might immediately infer the motion of one body from the impulse of another, without having recourse to any past observation. That this opinion is false will admit of an easy proof. For if such an inference may be drawn merely from the ideas of body, of motion, and of impulse, it must amount to a demonstration, and must imply the absolute impossibility of any contrary supposition. Every effect, then, beside the communication of motion, implies a formal contradiction; and 'tis impossible not only that it can exist, but also that it can be conceiv'd. But we may soon satisfy ourselves of the contrary, by forming a clear and consistent idea of one body's moving upon another, and of its rest immediately upon the contact; or of its returning back in the same line, in which it came; or of its annihilation; or circular or elliptical motion: and in short, of an infinite number of other changes, which we may suppose it to undergo. These suppositions are all consistent and natural; and the reason, why we imagine the communication of motion to be more consistent and natural not only than those suppositions, but also than any other natural effect, is founded on the relation of resemblance betwixt the cause and effect, which is here united to experience, and binds the objects in the closest and most intimate manner to each other, so as to make us imagine them to be absolutely inseparable. Resemblance, then, has the same or a parallel influence with experience; and as the only immediate effect of experience is to associate our ideas together, it follows, that all belief arises from the association of ideas, according to my hypothesis.

关于相似性，我们可以形成类似的观察。我们已经说过，我们从一个现在的物体得出的结论，到它不存在的原因或效果，从来都是建立在我们观察到的该物体的任何品质之上，考虑到它本身；或者，换句话说，除了经验之外，不可能确定任何现象会产生什么结果，或者它之前有什么。但是，尽管这本身是如此明显，以至于它似乎不需要任何证明；但一些哲学家想象，运动的交流有一个明显的原因，一个理智的人可以立即从另一个物体的冲动中推断出一个物体的运动，而不必求助于任何过去的观察。这种观点是错误的，这一点很容易得到证明。因为如果这种推论可以仅仅从身体、运动和冲力的概念中得出，它就必须相当于一个证明，并且必须意味着任何相反的假设是绝对不可能的。那么，除了运动的交流之外，每一个效果都意味着形式上的矛盾；不仅它不可能存在，而且它也不可能被设想出来。但是，我们很快就可以通过形成一个清晰而一致的概念，即一个物体在另一个物体上运动，并在接触后立即静止；或按它来时的路线返回；或它的湮灭；或圆周或椭圆运动；以及总之，我们可以假设它经历的无数其他变化。这些假设都是一致的和自然的；而我们为什么认为运动的交流不仅比这些假设更一致和自然，而且比任何其他自然效果更一致和自然，原因是建立在原因和结果之间的相似关系上，这种关系在这里与经验结合在一起，以最紧密和最亲密的方式将对象联系在一起，从而使我们认为它们是绝对不可分割的。那么，相似性与经验具有相同或平行的影响；由于经验的唯一直接效果是将我们的观念联系在一起，因此，根据我的假设，所有的信仰都是由观念的联系产生的。

'Tis universally allow'd by the writers on optics, that the eye at all times sees an equal number of physical points, and that a man on the top of a mountain has no larger an image presented to his senses, than when he is cooped up in the narrowest court or chamber. 'Tis only by experience that he infers the greatness of the object from some peculiar qualities of the image; and this inference of the judgment he confounds with sensation, as is common on other occasions. Now 'tis evident, that the inference of the judgment is here much more lively than what is usual in our common reasonings, and that a man has a more vivid conception of the vast extent of the ocean from the image he receives by the eye, when he stands on the top of the high promontory, than merely from hearing the roaring of the waters. He feels a more sensible pleasure from its magnificence; which is a proof of a more lively idea: And he confounds his judgment with sensation; which is another proof of it. But as the inference is equally certain and immediate in both cases, this superior vivacity of our conception in one case can proceed from nothing but this, that in drawing an inference from the sight, beside the customary conjunction, there is also a resemblance betwixt the image and the object we infer; which strengthens the relation, and conveys the vivacity of the impression to the related idea with an easier and more natural movement.

光学作者普遍认为，眼睛在任何时候看到的物理点都是相等的，一个人在山顶上看到的图像并不比他被关在最狭窄的庭院或房间里时大。只是根据经验，他从图像的某些特殊品质中推断出物体的伟大；这种推断的判断他与感觉相混淆，这在其他场合很常见。现在很明显，这里的判断推论比我们常见的推理要生动得多，当一个人站在高高的岬角上时，他从眼睛接收到的图像中对海洋的广袤有了更生动的概念，而不仅仅是听到水的咆哮。他从海洋的壮丽中感受到更多的感官愉悦；这证明了他有一个更生动的想法。他把他的判断与感觉混为一谈；这是另一个证据。但是，由于推论在两种情况下都是同样确定和直接的，我们的概念在一种情况下的这种优越的活泼性只能来自于此，即在从视觉中得出推论时，除了惯常的联系之外，在图像和我们推论的对象之间还有一种相似性；这加强了这种关系，并将印象的活泼性以一种更容易和更自然的运动传达给相关概念。

No weakness of human nature is more universal and conspicuous than what we commonly call Credulity, or a too easy faith in the testimony of others; and this weakness is also very naturally accounted for from the influence of resemblance. When we receive any matter of fact upon human testimony, our faith arises from the very same origin as our inferences from causes to effects, and from effects to causes; nor is there any thing but our experience of the governing principles of human nature, which can give us any assurance of the veracity of men. But tho' experience be the true standard of this, as well as of all other judgments, we seldom regulate ourselves entirely by it; but have a remarkable propensity to believe whatever is reported, even concerning apparitions, enchantments, and prodigies, however contrary to daily experience and observation. The words or discourses of others have an intimate connexion with certain ideas in their mind; and these ideas have also a connexion with the facts or objects, which they represent. This latter connexion is generally much over-rated, and commands our assent beyond what experience will justify; which can proceed from nothing beside the resemblance betwixt the ideas and the facts. Other effects only point out their causes in an oblique manner; but the testimony of men does it directly, and is to be consider'd as an image as well as an effect. No wonder, therefore, we are so rash in drawing our inferences from it, and are less guided by experience in our judgments concerning it, than in those upon any other subject.

人类本性中最普遍、最明显的弱点莫过于我们通常所说的 “轻信”（Credulity），或对他人的证词过于轻易地相信；这种弱点也可以很自然地从相似性的影响中得到解释。当我们根据人的证词接受任何事实时，我们的信仰与我们从因到果、从果到因的推论的起源相同；除了我们对人性的主导原则的经验，也没有任何东西可以让我们对人的真实性有任何保证。但是，尽管经验是这个问题以及所有其他判断的真正标准，我们却很少完全按照它来规范自己；而是有一种显著的倾向，即相信任何报道，甚至是关于幽灵、魔法和神迹的报道，不管它们如何与日常经验和观察相悖。别人的话语或谈话与他们心中的某些想法有密切的联系；这些想法也与他们所代表的事实或物体有联系。这后一种联系通常被高估了，并使我们的同意超出了经验所能证明的范围；除了观念和事实之间的相似性之外，没有任何其他原因可以产生。其他的效果只是以一种间接的方式指出它们的原因；但人的证词却直接指出了原因，并被视为一种形象，也是一种效果。因此，难怪我们在从中得出推论时如此轻率，而且在有关它的判断中比在任何其他问题上的判断都更少受到经验的指导。

As resemblance, when conjoin'd with causation, fortifies our reasonings; so the want of it in any very great degree is able almost entirely to destroy them. Of this there is a remarkable instance in the universal carelessness and stupidity of men with regard to a future state, where they show as obstinate an incredulity, as they do a blind credulity on other occasions. There is not indeed a more ample matter of wonder to the studious, and of regret to the pious man, than to observe the negligence of the bulk of mankind concerning their approaching condition; and 'tis with reason, that many eminent theologians have not scrupled to affirm, that tho' the vulgar have no formal principles of infidelity, yet they are really infidels in their hearts, and have nothing like what we can call a belief of the eternal duration of their souls. For let us consider on the one hand what divines have display'd with such eloquence concerning the importance of eternity; and at the same time reflect, that tho' in matters of rhetoric we ought to lay our account with some exaggeration, we must in this case allow, that the strongest figures are infinitely inferior to the subject: And after this let us view on the other hand the prodigious security of men in this particular: I ask, if these people really believe what is inculcated on them, and what they pretend to affirm; and the answer is obviously in the negative. As belief is an act of the mind arising from custom, 'tis not strange the want of resemblance shou'd overthrow what custom has establish'd, and diminish the force of the idea, as much as that latter principle encreases it. A future state is so far remov'd from our comprehension, and we have so obscure an idea of the manner, in which we shall exist after the dissolution of the body, that all the reasons we can invent, however strong in themselves, and however much assisted by education, are never able with slow imaginations to surmount this difficulty, or bestow a sufficient authority and force on the idea. I rather choose to ascribe this incredulity to the faint idea we form of our future condition, deriv'd from its want of resemblance to the present life, than to that deriv'd from its remoteness. For I observe, that men are every where concern'd about what may happen after their death, provided it regard this world; and that there are few to whom their name, their family, their friends, and their country are in any period of time entirely indifferent.

当相似性与因果关系结合在一起时，会加强我们的推理；因此，在任何非常大的程度上缺乏相似性，都能几乎完全摧毁它们。关于这一点，在人们对未来状态的普遍粗心和愚蠢中，有一个显著的例子，他们在那里表现出顽固的难以置信，就像他们在其他场合表现出盲目的轻信一样。确实没有比观察大多数人对他们即将到来的状况的忽视更让研究者感到惊奇，让虔诚的人感到遗憾的事情了；这也是有道理的，许多知名的神学家不惮于肯定，虽然俗人没有正式的不忠原则，但他们心里确实是不忠的，没有任何我们可以称之为对他们灵魂的永恒的信仰。因为让我们一方面考虑一下神学家们对永恒的重要性所做的雄辩；同时反思一下，虽然在修辞方面我们应该夸大其词，但在这种情况下，我们必须承认，最有力的数字都远远不如主题。在这之后，我们再来看看人们在这方面的惊人的安全感。我问，这些人是否真的相信向他们灌输的东西，以及他们假装肯定的东西；而答案显然是否定的。由于信仰是由习俗产生的一种思想行为，因此，缺乏相似性就会推翻习俗所建立的东西，并削弱思想的力量，就像后一原则所增加的那样，这并不奇怪。未来的状态与我们的理解力相去甚远，我们对身体解体后的存在方式的想法是如此模糊，以至于我们所能发明的所有理由，无论本身多么强大，无论教育多么有帮助，都无法用缓慢的想象力来克服这一困难，或赋予这一想法以足够的权威和力量。我宁愿把这种难以置信归因于我们对未来状况的微弱想法，因为它与现在的生活缺乏相似性，而不是因为它的遥远性。因为我注意到，人们在任何地方都关心他们死后可能发生的事情，只要它与这个世界有关；而且很少有人对自己的名字、家人、朋友和国家在任何时期都完全漠不关心。

And indeed the want of resemblance in this case so entirely destroys belief, that except those few, who upon cool reflection on the importance of the subject, have taken care by repeated meditation to imprint in their minds the arguments for a future state, there scarce are any, who believe the immortality of the soul with a true and establish'd judgment; such as is deriv'd from the testimony of travellers and historians. This appears very conspicuously wherever men have occasion to compare the pleasures and pains, the rewards and punishments of this life with those of a future; even tho' the case does not concern themselves, and there is no violent passion to disturb their judgment. The Roman Catholicks are certainly the most zealous of any sect in the christian world; and yet you'll find few among the more sensible people of that communion, who do not blame the Gunpowder-treason, and the massacre of St. Bartholomew, as cruel and barbarous, tho' projected or executed against those very people, whom without any scruple they condemn to eternal and infinite punishments. All we can say in excuse for this inconsistency is, that they really do not believe what they affirm concerning a future state; nor is there any better proof of it than the very inconsistency.

事实上，在这种情况下，缺乏相似性完全破坏了信仰，除了那些对这个问题的重要性进行冷静思考，并通过反复冥想将未来状态的论据印在脑海中的少数人之外，几乎没有人相信灵魂的不朽，并有一个真实和确定的判断；如从旅行者和历史学家的证词中得出的结论。只要人们有机会将今生的快乐和痛苦、奖赏和惩罚与未来的快乐和痛苦进行比较，这种情况就会非常明显；即使这种情况与他们自己无关，也没有激烈的激情来干扰他们的判断。罗马天主教徒当然是基督教世界中最热心的教派；但你会发现，在该教派中比较理智的人中，很少有人不指责火药案和圣巴塞洛缪的屠杀是残忍和野蛮的，尽管他们是针对那些被他们毫无顾忌地谴责为永恒和无限的惩罚的人而策划或执行的。对于这种不一致，我们只能说，他们真的不相信他们所宣称的未来国家；也没有比这种不一致更好的证据了。

We may add to this a remark; that in matters of religion men take a pleasure in being terrify'd, and that no preachers are so popular, as those who excite the most dismal and gloomy passions. In the common affairs of life, where we feel and are penetrated with the solidity of the subject, nothing can be more disagreeable than fear and terror; and 'tis only in dramatic performances and in religious discourses, that they ever give pleasure. In these latter cases the imagination reposes itself indolently on the idea; and the passion, being soften'd by the want of belief in the subject, has no more than the agreeable effect of enlivening the mind, and fixing the attention.

我们可以补充一句；在宗教问题上，人们以被吓倒为乐，没有哪个传教士会像那些激起最可怕和最阴暗的激情的人那样受欢迎。在普通的生活事务中，当我们感受到并渗透到主题的稳固性时，没有什么比恐惧和恐怖更令人不快的了；只有在戏剧表演和宗教演讲中，它们才会给人带来快乐。在后一种情况下，想象力不由自主地寄托在思想上；而激情由于对主题缺乏信心而变得软弱，除了活跃思想和固定注意力的愉快效果外，并没有其他作用。

The present hypothesis will receive additional confirmation, if we examine the effects of other kinds of custom, as well as of other relations. To understand this we must consider, that custom, to which I attribute all belief and reasoning, may operate upon the mind in invigorating an idea after two several ways. For supposing that in all past experience we have found two objects to have been always conjoin'd together, 'tis evident, that upon the appearance of one of these objects in an impression, we must from custom make an easy transition to the idea of that object, which usually attends it; and by means of the present impression and easy transition must conceive that idea in a stronger and more lively manner, than we do any loose floating image of the fancy.

如果我们研究一下其他种类的习俗以及其他关系的影响，目前的假设将得到更多的证实。为了理解这一点，我们必须考虑到，我把所有的信仰和推理都归功于习俗，它可能以两种不同的方式在头脑中运作，使一个想法变得更有活力。假设在过去的所有经验中，我们发现两个物体总是结合在一起，那么很明显，当这些物体中的一个出现在印象中时，我们必须从习惯中轻松过渡到那个物体的想法，这通常伴随着它；并且通过目前的印象和轻松的过渡，我们必须以更强大和更生动的方式设想那个想法，而不是我们做任何松散的浮动图像的幻想。

But let us next suppose, that a mere idea alone, without any of this curious and almost artificial preparation, shou'd frequently make its appearance in the mind, this idea must by degrees acquire a facility and force; and both by its firm hold and easy introduction distinguish itself from any new and unusual idea. This is the only particular, in which these two kinds of custom agree; and if it appear, that their effects on the judgment are similar and proportion able, we may certainly conclude, that the foregoing explication of that faculty is satisfactory. But can we doubt of this agreement in their influence on the judgment, when we consider the nature and effects of education?

但是，让我们接下来假设，一个单纯的想法，在没有任何这种奇怪的、几乎是人为的准备的情况下，经常在头脑中出现，这个想法一定会逐渐获得一种便利和力量；并通过它的牢固性和容易引入，将自己与任何新的和不寻常的想法区分开来。这是这两种习惯唯一一致的地方；如果它们对判断力的影响相似且相称，我们当然可以得出结论，上述对这种能力的解释是令人满意的。但是，当我们考虑到教育的性质和影响时，我们能怀疑它们对判断力的影响是否一致吗？

All those opinions and notions of things, to which we have been accustom'd from our infancy, take such deep root, that 'tis impossible for us, by all the powers of reason and experience, to eradicate them; and this habit not only approaches in its influence, but even on many occasions prevails over that which arises from the constant and inseparable union of causes and effects. Here we must not be contented with saying, that the vividness of the idea produces the belief: We must maintain that they are individually the same.

所有那些我们从婴儿时期就已经习惯的观点和概念，都深深地扎下了根，以至于我们不可能通过所有的理性和经验的力量来根除它们；这种习惯不仅在影响上接近，甚至在很多情况下都胜过了因果关系的持续和不可分割的结合所产生的影响。在这里，我们不能满足于说，思想的生动性产生了信仰。我们必须坚持认为，它们各自都是相同的。

The frequent repetition of any idea infixes it in the imagination; but cou'd never possibly of itself produce belief; if that act of the mind was, by the original constitution of our natures, annex'd only to a reasoning and comparison of ideas. Custom may lead us into some false comparison of ideas. This is the utmost effect we can conceive of it. But 'tis certain it cou'd never supply the place of that comparison, nor produce any act of the mind, which naturally belong'd to that principle.

频繁地重复任何观念，都会把它注入想象力；但这种重复本身不可能产生信仰；如果根据我们天性的原始结构，心灵的这种行为只附属于对观念的推理和比较。习惯可能会使我们陷入一些错误的观念比较中。这是我们所能想象到的最大的效果。但可以肯定的是，它永远无法提供这种比较的位置，也无法产生任何自然属于该原则的心灵行为。

A person, that has lost a leg or an arm by amputation, endeavours for a long time afterwards to serve himself with them. After the death of any one, 'tis a common remark of the whole family, but especially of the servants, that they can scarce believe him to be dead, but still imagine him to be in his chamber or in any other place, where they were accustom'd to find him. I have often heard in conversation, after talking of a person, that is any way celebrated, that one, who has no acquaintance with him, will say, I have never seen such-a-one, but almost fancy I have; so often have I heard talk of him. All these are parallel instances.

一个人如果因为截肢而失去了一条腿或一条胳膊，那么在之后的很长一段时间里都会努力用它们来为自己服务。一个人死后，全家人，特别是仆人们常说，他们几乎不相信他已经死了，而是想象他还在自己的房间或其他地方，他们习惯于在那里找到他。我经常在谈话中听到，在谈及一个人时，一个与他不相识的人说，我从来没有见过这样的人，但几乎以为我见过；我经常听到关于他的谈话。所有这些都是平行的例子。

If we consider this argument from education in a proper light, 'twill appear very convincing; and the more so, that 'tis founded on one of the most common phænomena, that is any where to be met with. I am persuaded, that upon examination we shall find more than one half of those opinions, that prevail among mankind, to be owing to education, and that the principles, which are thus implicitly embrac'd, over-ballance those, which are owing either to abstract reasoning or experience. As liars, by the frequent repetition of their lies, come at last to remember them; so the judgment, or rather the imagination, by the like means, may have ideas so strongly imprinted on it, and conceive them in so full a light, that they may operate upon the mind in the same manner with those, which the senses, memory or reason present to us.

如果我们从适当的角度来考虑这个来自教育的论点，它就会显得非常有说服力；而且更有说服力的是，它是建立在一个最常见的现象上的，这在任何地方都是可以见到的。我相信，经过研究，我们会发现，在人类普遍存在的那些观点中，有一半以上是由于教育造成的，而那些隐含在其中的原则，比那些由于抽象推理或经验而产生的原则更为重要。就像骗子通过经常重复他们的谎言，最终记住了他们；所以判断力，或者说想象力，通过类似的手段，可以在它身上留下如此强烈的印记，并在如此充分的光线下想象它们，以至于它们可以以与感官、记忆或理性呈现给我们的相同方式作用于头脑。

But as education is an artificial and not a natural cause, and as its maxims are frequently contrary to reason, and even to themselves in different times and places, it is never upon that account recogniz'd by philosophers; tho' in reality it be built almost on the same foundation of custom and repetition as our reasonings from causes and effects19.

但是，由于教育是一种人为的而不是自然的原因，由于它的格言经常与理性相悖，甚至在不同的时间和地点与自己相悖，所以它从来没有因此而被哲学家所承认；尽管实际上它几乎建立在与我们的因果推理一样的习惯和重复的基础上19.

 

Section 10. Of The Influence Of Belief

第 10 节。信仰的影响

 

But tho' education be disclaim'd by philosophy, as a fallacious ground of assent to any opinion, it prevails nevertheless in the world, and is the cause why all systems are apt to be rejected at first as new and unusual. This perhaps will be the fate of what I have here advanc'd concerning belief, and tho' the proofs I have produc'd appear to me perfectly conclusive, I expect not to make many proselytes to my opinion. Men will scarce ever be persuaded, that effects of such consequence can flow from principles, which are seemingly so inconsiderable, and that the far greatest part of our reasonings, with all our actions and passions, can be deriv'd from nothing but custom and habit. To obviate this objection, I shall here anticipate a little what wou'd more properly fall under our consideration afterwards, when we come to treat of the passions and the sense of beauty.

但是，尽管教育被哲学否定，认为是同意任何观点的错误理由，但它仍然在世界范围内盛行，这也是所有体系一开始就被认为是新的和不寻常的而被拒绝的原因。这也许就是我在这里提出的关于信仰的命运，虽然我提出的证据在我看来是完全确凿的，但我希望不会有很多人接受我的观点。人们很少会被说服，认为如此重要的效果可以从看似微不足道的原则中产生，而且我们的推理，以及我们所有的行动和激情，最大的部分可以从习俗和习惯中产生。为了避免这种反对意见，我将在这里预测一下以后我们在讨论激情和美感时更应该考虑的问题。

There is implanted in the human mind a perception of pain and pleasure, as the chief spring and moving principle of all its actions. But pain and pleasure have two ways of making their appearance in the mind; of which the one has effects very different from the other. They may either appear in impression to the actual feeling, or only in idea, as at present when I mention them. 'Tis evident the induence of these upon our actions is far from being equal. Impressions always actuate the soul, and that in the highest degree; but 'tis not every idea which has the same efect. Nature has proceeded with caution in this case, and seems to have carefully avoided the inconveniences of two extremes. Did impressions alone influence the will, we should every moment of our lives be subject to the greatest calamities; because, tho' we foresaw their approach, we should not be provided by nature with any principle of action, which might impel us to avoid them. On the other hand, did every idea influence our actions, our condition would not be much mended. For such is the unsteadiness and activity of thought, that the images of every thing, especially of goods and evils, are always wandering in the mind; and were it mov'd by every idle conception of this kind, it would never enjoy a moment's peace and tranquillity.

在人的头脑中植入了对痛苦和快乐的感知，作为其所有行为的主要源泉和运动原则。但是，痛苦和快乐有两种方式在头脑中出现；其中一种的效果与另一种非常不同。它们可以在实际的感觉中出现，也可以只在观念中出现，就像我现在提到它们时一样。很明显，这些东西对我们的行为的诱导作用是不一样的。印象总是激励着灵魂，而且是最高程度的激励；但并不是每一种观念都有同样的效果。大自然在这种情况下谨慎行事，似乎已经小心翼翼地避免了两个极端的不便之处。如果仅仅是印象影响意志，我们在生活中每时每刻都会遭受最大的灾难；因为尽管我们预见到了它们的到来，但自然界并没有为我们提供任何行动原则，以促使我们避免这些灾难。另一方面，如果每个想法都能影响我们的行动，我们的状况也不会得到很大的改善。因为思想的不稳定和活跃，每件事情的形象，特别是货物和罪恶的形象，总是在头脑中游荡；如果它被这种闲置的概念所推动，它将永远不会享受片刻的和平和安宁。

Nature has, therefore, chosen a medium, and has neither bestow'd on every idea of good and evil the power of actuating the will, nor yet has entirely excluded them from this influence. Tho' an idle fiction has no efficacy, yet we find by experience, that the ideas of those objects, which we believe either are or will be existent, produce in a lesser degree the same effect with those impressions, which are immediately present to the senses and perception. The effect, then, of belief is to raise up a simple idea to an equality with our impressions, and bestow on it a like influence on the passions. This effect it can only have by making an idea approach an impression in force and vivacity. For as the different degrees of force make all the original difference betwixt an impression and an idea, they must of consequence be the source of all the differences in the effects of these perceptions, and their removal, in whole or in part, the cause of every new resemblance they acquire. Wherever we can make an idea approach the impressions in force and vivacity, it will likewise imitate them in its influence on the mind; and vice versa, where it imitates them in that influence, as in the present case, this must proceed from its approaching them in force and vivacity. Belief, therefore, since it causes an idea to imitate the effects of the impressions, must make it resemble them in these qualities, and is nothing but a more vivid and intense conception of any idea.
