This, then, may both serve as an additional argument for the present system, and may give us a notion after what manner our reasonings from causation are able to operate on the will and passions.

因此，大自然选择了一种媒介，既没有赋予每个善恶观念以驱动意志的力量，也没有完全排除它们的影响。虽然空洞的虚构没有效力，但我们通过经验发现，那些我们相信存在或将要存在的对象的观念，与那些立即呈现在感官和知觉中的印象产生的影响程度较低。那么，信仰的效果就是把一个简单的观念提升到与我们的印象平等的地位，并赋予它对激情的类似影响。这种效果只有通过使一个观念在力量和活力上接近印象才能产生。因为力的不同程度造成了印象和观念之间的所有原始差异，因此它们必然是这些感知效果的所有差异的来源，而它们的全部或部分消除则是它们获得的每一个新的相似性的原因。只要我们能使一个观念在力量和活力上接近印象，它就会在对心灵的影响上同样模仿它们；反之亦然，如果它在这种影响上模仿它们，如在目前的情况下，这一定是由于它在力量和活力上接近它们。因此，信仰既然会使一个观念模仿印象的效果，就一定会使它在这些品质上与它们相似，而且只不过是对任何观念的 更生动和强烈的概念。那么，这既可以作为本系统的一个补充论据，也可以给我们一个概念，即我们从因果关系出发的推理能够以何种方式对意志和激情进行操作。

As belief is almost absolutely requisite to the exciting our passions, so the passions in their turn are very favourable to belief; and not only such facts as convey agreeable emotions, but very often such as give pain, do upon that account become more readily the objects of faith and opinion. A coward, whose fears are easily awaken'd, readily assents to every account of danger he meets with; as a person of a sorrowful and melancholy disposition is very credulous of every thing, that nourishes his prevailing passion. When any affecting object is presented, it gives the alarm, and excites immediately a degree of its proper passion; especially in persons who are naturally inclined to that passion. This emotion passes by an easy transition to the imagination; and diffusing itself over our idea of the affecting object, makes us form that idea with greater force and vivacity, and consequently assent to it, according to the precedent system. Admiration and surprize have the same effect as the other passions; and accordingly we may observe, that among the vulgar, quacks and projectors meet with a more easy faith upon account of their magnificent pretensions, than if they kept themselves within the bounds of moderation. The first astonishment, which naturally attends their miraculous relations, spreads itself over the whole soul, and so vivifies and enlivens the idea, that it resembles the inferences we draw from experience. This is a mystery, with which we may be already a little acquainted, and which we shall have farther occasion to be let into in the progress of this treatise.

由于信仰对于激发我们的激情几乎是绝对必要的，所以激情反过来也非常有利于信仰；不仅是那些传递令人愉快的情绪的事实，而且往往是那些给人带来痛苦的事实，因此更容易成为信仰和意见的对象。一个懦夫，他的恐惧很容易被唤醒，很容易同意他遇到的每一个关于危险的说法；就像一个性格忧郁的人对每一件滋养他的激情的事情都非常相信。当任何有影响的物体出现时，它就会发出警报，并立即激起某种程度的适当激情；尤其是在那些天生就有这种激情的人身上。这种情绪很容易过渡到想象力；并扩散到我们对影响对象的想法上，使我们以更大的力量和活力形成这种想法，并因此根据先例系统对它表示赞同。钦佩和惊奇与其他激情有同样的效果；因此我们可以看到，在庸俗的人中，庸医和预测者因其华丽的装腔作势而更容易得到人们的信任，而如果他们把自己保持在适度的范围内的话。自然而然地伴随着他们的神奇关系的第一份惊奇，遍布整个灵魂，并如此生动和活泼的想法，它类似于我们从经验中得出的推论。这是一个奥秘，我们可能已经有点了解了，在本论文的进展中，我们将有更多的机会了解它。

After this account of the influence of belief on the passions, we shall find less difficulty in explaining its effects on the imagination, however extraordinary they may appear. 'Tis certain we cannot take pleasure in any discourse, where our judgment gives no assent to those images which are presented to our fancy. The conversation of those, who have acquir'd a habit of lying, tho' in affairs of no moment, never gives any satisfaction; and that because those ideas they present to us, not being attended with belief, make no impression upon the mind. Poets themselves, tho' liars by profession, always endeavour to give an air of truth to their fictions; and where that is totally neglected, their performances, however ingenious, will never be able to afford much pleasure. In short, we may observe, that even when ideas have no manner of influence on the will and passions, truth and reality are still requisite, in order to make them entertaining to the imagination.

在说明了信仰对激情的影响之后，我们将发现在解释它对想象力的影响时就不那么困难了，无论它们看起来多么不寻常。可以肯定的是，如果我们的判断力不同意呈现在我们想象中的那些图像，我们就无法在任何谈话中获得快乐。那些已经养成说谎习惯的人的谈话，尽管在无关紧要的事情上，也不会让人感到满意；这是因为他们呈现给我们的那些想法，并不带有信仰，不会在头脑中留下印象。诗人自己，虽然以说谎为职业，但总是努力使他们的虚构有一种真实感；如果完全忽略了这一点，他们的表演，无论多么巧妙，都不会给人带来多少乐趣。总之，我们可以看到，即使思想对意志和激情没有任何影响，真实和现实仍然是必要的，以便使它们对想象力具有娱乐性。

But if we compare together all the phænomena that occur on this head, we shall find, that truth, however necessary it may seem in all works of genius, has no other effect than to procure an easy reception for the ideas, and to make the mind acquiesce in them with satisfaction, or at least without reluctance. But as this is an effect, which may easily be supposed to flow from that solidity and force, which, according to my system, attend those ideas that are establish'd by reasonings from causation; it follows, that all the influence of belief upon the fancy may be explained from that system. Accordingly we may observe, that wherever that influence arises from any other principles beside truth or reality, they supply its place, and give an equal entertainment to the imagination. Poets have form'd what they call a poetical system of things, which tho' it be believ'd neither by themselves nor readers, is commonly esteem'd a sufficient foundation for any fiction. We have been so much accustom'd to the names of Mars, Jupiter, Venus, that in the same manner as education infixes any opinion, the constant repetition of these ideas makes them enter into the mind ith facility, and prevail upon the fancy, without influencing the judgment. In like manner tragedians always borrow their fable, or at least the names of their principal actors, from some known passage in history; and that not in order to deceive the spectators; for they will frankly confess, that truth is not in any circumstance inviolably observed; but in order to procure a more easy reception into the imagination for those extraordinary events, which they represent. But this is a precaution, which is not required of comic poets, whose personages and incidents, being of a more familiar kind, enter easily into the conception, and are received without any such formality, even tho' at first sight they be known to be fictitious, and the pure offspring of the fancy.

但是，如果我们把发生在这个问题上的所有现象放在一起比较，我们就会发现，无论真理在所有天才作品中是多么必要，它的作用也不过是为了使思想容易被接受，并使头脑满意地或至少不勉强地默认它们。但是，既然这是一种效果，就很容易被认为是来自于那种稳固性和力量，而根据我的体系，这种稳固性和力量是伴随着那些通过因果关系的推理而确立的观念的；因此，信仰对幻想的所有影响都可以从这个体系中得到解释。因此，我们可以看到，凡是这种影响来自真理或现实之外的任何其他原则，它们都能提供其位置，并给想象力以同样的娱乐。诗人已经形成了他们所谓的诗意的事物体系，虽然他们自己和读者都不相信，但普遍认为这是任何虚构的充分基础。我们已经习惯了火星、木星、金星的名字，就像教育为任何观点打上标签一样，这些想法的不断重复使它们顺利地进入大脑，并在幻想中占上风，而不影响判断。同样，悲剧演员总是从历史上的某些已知段落中借用他们的寓言，或者至少借用他们的主要演员的名字；这并不是为了欺骗观众；因为他们会坦率地承认，在任何情况下，真理都不是不可侵犯的；而是为了使他们所表现的那些特殊事件更容易被想象力接受。但这是一种预防措施，喜剧诗人不需要这样做，他们的人物和事件都是比较熟悉的，很容易进入人们的概念，不需要任何形式就能接受，即使一开始就知道是虚构的，是纯粹的幻想的产物。

This mixture of truth and falshood in the fables of tragic poets not only serves our present purpose, by shewing, that the imagination can be satisfy'd without any absolute belief or assurance; but may in another view be regarded as a very strong confirmation of this system. 'Tis evident, that poets make use of this artifice of borrowing the names of their persons, and the chief events of their poems, from history, in order to procure a more easy reception for the whole, and cause it to make a deeper impression on the fancy and affections. The several incidents of the piece acquire a kind of relation by being united into one poem or representation; and if any of these incidents be an object of belief, it bestows a force and vivacity on the others, which are related to it. The vividness of the first conception diffuses itself along the relations, and is convey'd, as by so many pipes or canals, to every idea that has any communication with the primary one. This, indeed, can never amount to a perfect assurance; and that because the union among the ideas is, in a manner, accidental: But still it approaches so near, in its influence, as may convince us, that they are deriv'd from the same origin. Belief must please the imagination by means of the force and vivacity which attends it; since every idea, which has force and vivacity, is found to be agreeable to that faculty.

悲剧诗人的寓言中这种真假混杂的现象，不仅有助于我们目前的目的，说明想象力可以在没有任何绝对信仰或保证的情况下得到满足；而且从另一个角度看，可以被视为对这一制度的有力证实。很明显，诗人利用了这种从历史中借用他们的人名和他们诗歌中的主要事件的伎俩，以便使整个作品更容易被接受，并使其在想象力和情感上留下更深刻的印象。作品中的几个事件通过结合成一首诗或表现形式而获得一种关系；如果这些事件中的任何一个是信仰的对象，它就会给与它有关的其他事件带来一种力量和活力。第一个概念的生动性沿着这些关系扩散开来，并像通过许多管道或运河一样，被输送到与主要概念有任何联系的每一个概念。这的确不可能达到完美的保证；这是因为观念之间的结合在某种程度上是偶然的：但它的影响仍然如此接近，以至于可以使我们相信，它们是来自同一源头的。信仰必须通过伴随它的力量和活力来取悦想象力；因为每一个有力量和活力的观念都会被发现是符合这种能力的。

To confirm this we may observe, that the assistance is mutual betwixt the judgment and fancy, as well as betwixt the judgment and passion; and that belief not only gives vigour to the imagination, but that a vigorous and strong imagination is of all talents the most proper to procure belief and authority. 'Tis difficult for us to withold our assent from what is painted out to us in all the colours of eloquence; and the vivacity produc'd by the fancy is in many cases greater than that which arises from custom and experience. We are hurried away by the lively imagination of our author or companion; and even he himself is often a victim to his own fire and genius.

为了证实这一点，我们可以观察到，判断力和想象力之间的协助，以及判断力和激情之间的协助是相互的；信仰不仅给想象力带来活力，而且一个充满活力和强大的想象力是所有才能中最适合获得信仰和权威的。我们很难不同意那些以各种雄辩的色彩向我们展示的东西；在许多情况下，想象力所产生的活力比从习俗和经验中产生的活力更大。我们被我们的作者或同伴的生动的想象力所驱使；甚至他自己也常常是他自己的火焰和天才的受害者。

Nor will it be amiss to remark, that as a lively imagination very often degenerates into madness or folly, and bears it a great resemblance in its operations; so they influence the judgment after the same manner, and produce belief from the very same principles. When the imagination, from any extraordinary ferment of the blood and spirits, acquires such a vivacity as disorders all its powers and faculties, there is no means of distinguishing betwixt truth and falshood; but every loose fiction or idea, having the same influence as the impressions of the memory, or the conclusions of the judgment, is receiv'd on the same footing, and operates with equal force on the passions. A present impression and a customary transition are now no longer necessary to inliven our ideas. Every chimera of the brain is as vivid and intense as any of those inferences, which we formerly dignify'd with the name of conclusions concerning matters of fact, and sometimes as the present impressions of the senses.

我们也可以说，由于活泼的想象力经常退化为疯狂或愚蠢，并且在其运作中与之非常相似；所以它们以同样的方式影响判断力，并从同样的原则产生信仰。当想象力因血液和精神的异常发酵而获得如此的活力，使其所有的力量和能力失调时，就没有办法区分真理和谬误；但每一个松散的虚构或想法，都具有与记忆的印象或判断的结论相同的影响，都在同样的基础上被接受，并以同样的力量作用于激情。现在，为了活跃我们的思想，已经不再需要现有的印象和习惯性的过渡。大脑的每一个幻觉都和那些推论一样生动和强烈，我们以前把这些推论冠以关于事实问题的结论之名，有时还冠以感官的现有印象。

We may observe the same effect of poetry in a lesser degree; only with this difference, that the least reflection dissipates the illusions of poetry, and places the objects in their proper light. 'Tis however certain, that in the warmth of a poetical enthusiasm, a poet has a counterfeit belief, and even a kind of vision of his objects: And if there be any shadow of argument to support this belief; nothing contributes more to his full conviction than a blaze of poetical figures and images, which have their effect upon the poet himself, as well as upon his readers.

我们可以在较小的程度上观察到诗歌的相同效果；只是有一点不同，那就是最起码的反思会驱散诗歌的幻觉，并将对象置于其适当的光线中。然而，可以肯定的是，在诗歌的热情中，诗人有一种虚假的信念，甚至对他的对象有一种幻觉。如果有任何论据支持这种信念，那么没有什么比诗意的数字和图像的光芒更有助于他的充分信念，这些数字和图像对诗人本人和他的读者都有影响。

 

Section 11. Of The Probability Of Chances

第 11 节。机会的概率

 

But in order to bestow on this system its full force and evidence, we must carry our eye from it a moment to consider its consequences, and explain from the same principles some other species of reasoning, which are deriv'd from the same origin.

但是，为了赋予这个系统以充分的力量和证据，我们必须把目光从它身上移开，考虑它的后果，并从同样的原则解释其他一些推理的种类，这些推理是由同一来源衍生出来的。

Those philosophers, who have divided human reason into knowledge and probability, and have defin'd the first to be that evidence, which arises from the comparison of ideas, are oblig'd to comprehend all our arguments from causes or effects under the general term of probability. But tho' every one be free to use his terms in what sense he pleases; and accordingly in the precedent part of this discourse, I have follow'd this method of expression; 'tis however certain, that in common discourse we readily affirm, that many arguments from causation exceed probability, and may be receiv'd as a superior kind of evidence. One wou'd appear ridiculous, who wou'd say, that 'tis only probable the sun will rise to-morrow, or that all men must dye; tho' 'tis plain we have no further assurance of these facts, than what experience affords us. For this reason, 'twould perhaps be more convenient, in order at once to preserve the common signification of words, and mark the several degrees of evidence, to distinguish human reason into three kinds, viz. that from knowledge, from proofs, and from probabilities. By knowledge, I mean the assurance arising from the comparison of ideas. By proofs, those arguments, which are deriv'd from the relation of cause and effect, and which are entirely free from doubt and uncertainty. By probability, that evidence, which is still attended with uncertainty. 'Tis this last species of reasoning, I proceed to examine.

那些把人类理性分为知识和概率的哲学家们，把第一种定义为从观念的比较中产生的证据，他们不得不把我们从原因或结果中得出的所有论据都归入概率这个总称之下。但是，尽管每个人都可以自由地在他喜欢的意义上使用他的术语；因此，在本论述的前一部分，我遵循了这种表达方法；然而，可以肯定的是，在普通的论述中，我们很容易肯定，许多因果关系的论据超过了概率，可以作为一种高级的证据来接受。如果有人说 “太阳明天可能会升起”，或者 “所有的人都会变老”，那就显得很可笑了；虽然我们对这些事实没有进一步的保证，但经验却给了我们。由于这个原因，为了同时保持词语的共同含义，并标明证据的不同程度，将人类的理性分为三种，即来自知识、来自证明和来自概率的理性，也许会更加方便。我所说的知识，是指从观念的比较中产生的保证。所谓证明，是指那些从因果关系中得出的、完全没有疑问和不确定性的论据。所谓概率，是指那些仍有不确定性的证据。我接下来要研究的就是这最后一种推理。

Probability or reasoning from conjecture may be divided into two kinds, viz. that which is founded on chance, and that which arises from causes. We shall consider each of these in order.

概率或猜想的推理可分为两种，即建立在机会上的推理和产生于原因的推理。我们将依次考虑这两种情况。

The idea of cause and effect is deriv'd from experience, which presenting us with certain objects constantly conjoin'd with each other, produces such a habit of surveying them in that relation, that we cannot without a sensible violence survey them in any other. On the other hand, as chance is nothing real in itself; and, properly speaking, is merely the negation of a cause, its influence on the mind is contrary to that of causation; and 'tis essential to it, to leave the imagination perfectly indifferent, either to consider the existence or non-existence of that object, which is regarded as contingent. A cause traces the way to our thought, and in a manner forces us to survey such certain objects, in such certain relations. Chance can only destroy this determination of the thought, and leave the mind in its native situation of indifference; in which, upon the absence of a cause, 'tis instantly re-instated.

因果关系的概念是由经验派生出来的，它使我们看到某些物体不断地相互联系，产生了在这种关系中观察它们的习惯，以至于我们不能不以一种感觉上的暴力来观察它们的任何其他关系。另一方面，由于偶然性本身并不真实；正确地说，它只是对原因的否定，它对心灵的影响与因果关系相反；对它来说，让想象力完全无动于衷，要么考虑那个被视为偶然的对象的存在或不存在，是至关重要的。一个原因为我们的思想指明了方向，并以某种方式迫使我们在这种特定的关系中考察这种特定的对象。偶然性只能破坏思想的这种决定性，并使思想处于其原始的冷漠状态；在这种情况下，一旦没有原因，就会立即重新恢复过来。

Since therefore an entire indifference is essential to chance, no one chance can possibly be superior to another, otherwise than as it is compos'd of a superior number of equal chances. For if we affirm that one chance can, after any other manner, be superior to another, we must at the same time affirm, that there is something, which gives it the superiority, and determines the event rather to that side than the other: That is, in other words, we must allow of a cause, and destroy the supposition of chance; which we had before establish'd. A perfect and total indifference is essential to chance, and one total indifference can never in itself be either superior or inferior to another. This truth is not peculiar to my system, but is acknowledge'd by every one, that forms calculations concerning chances.

因此，既然整个冷漠对机会来说是必不可少的，那么没有一个机会可能优于另一个，除非它是由数量众多的同等机会组成的。因为如果我们确认一个机会可以以任何其他方式优于另一个机会，我们就必须同时确认，有某种东西赋予它优势，并决定了事件宁可偏向那一方而不是另一方。也就是说，换句话说，我们必须允许有一个原因，并破坏我们之前建立的关于机会的假设。一个完美的、完全的冷漠对机会来说是必不可少的，而一个完全的冷漠本身永远不会比另一个冷漠优越或低劣。这一真理并不是我的体系所特有的，而是每个人都承认的，因为他们对机会进行了计算。

And here 'tis remarkable, that tho' chance and causation be directly contrary, yet 'tis impossible for us to conceive this combination of chances, which is requisite to render one hazard superior to another, without supposing a mixture of causes among the chances, and a conjunction of necessity in some particulars, with a total indifference in others. Where nothing limits the chances, every notion, that the most extravagant fancy can form, is upon a footing of equality; nor can there be any circumstance to give one the advantage above another. Thus unless we allow, that there are some causes to make the dice fall, and preserve their form in their fall, and lie upon some one of their sides, we can form no calculation concerning the laws of hazard. But supposing these causes to operate, and supposing likewise all the rest to be indifferent and to be determin'd by chance, 'tis easy to arrive at a notion of a superior combination of chances. A dye, that has four sides mark'd with a certain number of spots, and only two with another, affords us an obvious and easy instance of this superiority. The mind is here limited by the causes to such a precise number and quality of the events; and at the same time is undetermin'd in its choice of any particular event.

这里值得注意的是，尽管机会和因果关系是直接相反的，但我们不可能设想这种机会的组合，这是使一种危险优于另一种危险所必需的，而不需要假定机会中的原因混合，以及在某些特定情况下的必然性与其他情况下的完全漠不关心。在没有任何限制机会的地方，最奢侈的幻想所能形成的每一个概念都是建立在平等的基础上的；也不可能有任何情况使一个人比另一个人更有优势。因此，除非我们允许有一些原因使骰子落下，并在落下的过程中保持其形状，且位于其中的某一面，否则我们就无法计算出危险的规律。但是，假设这些原因在起作用，同时假设所有其他的原因都是无所谓的，都是由机会决定的，那么就很容易得出一个关于机会的卓越组合的概念。一块染料，四面有一定数量的斑点，而只有两面有另一种斑点，为我们提供了这种优越性的一个明显而容易的例子。在这里，思想被原因限制在事件的精确数量和质量上；同时，在选择任何特定事件时也是不确定的。

Proceeding then in that reasoning, wherein we have advanc'd three steps; that chance is merely the negation of a cause, and produces a total indifference in the mind; that one negation of a cause and one total indifference can never be superior or inferior to another; and that there must always be a mixture of causes among the chances, in order to be the foundation of any reasoning: We are next to consider what effect a superior combination of chances can have upon the mind, and after what manner it influences our judgment and opinion. Here we may repeat all the same arguments we employ'd in examining that belief, which arises from causes; and may prove after the same manner, that a superior number of chances produces our assent neither by demonstration nor probability. 'Tis indeed evident, that we can never by the comparison of mere ideas make any discovery, which can be of consequence in this affair, and that 'tis impossible to prove with certainty, that any event must fall on that side where there is a superior number of chances. To suppose in this case any certainty, were to overthrow what we have establish'd concerning the opposition of chances, and their perfect equality and indifference.

然后继续推理，其中我们已经推进了三个步骤；机会只是对一个原因的否定，并在头脑中产生一种完全的冷漠；对一个原因的否定和一种完全的冷漠永远不可能优于或劣于另一个原因；在机会中必须始终有一个混合的原因，以便成为任何推理的基础。我们接下来要考虑的是，机会的高级组合会对人的思想产生什么影响，以及它以何种方式影响我们的判断和意见。在这里，我们可以重复所有我们在研究由原因产生的信念时所使用的相同论据；并且可以以同样的方式证明，机会的数量越多，就越不能通过证明或概率来产生我们的同意。这的确很明显，我们永远无法通过单纯的观念比较来做出任何发现，这在这件事上是有意义的，而且不可能肯定地证明，任何事件都必须落在机会较多的那一方。在这种情况下，假设有任何确定性，就等于推翻了我们所确立的关于机会的对立，以及它们的完全平等和冷漠。

Shou'd it be said, that tho' in an opposition or chances 'tis impossible to determine with certainty, on which side the event will fall, yet we can pronounce with certainty, that 'tis more likely and probable, 'twill be on that side where there is a superior number of chances, than where there is an inferior: Shou'd this be said, I wou'd ask, what is here meant by likelihood and probability? The likelihood and probability of chances is a superior number of equal chances; and consequently when we say 'tis likely the event will fall on the side, which is superior, rather than on the inferior, we do no more than affirm, that where there is a superior number of chances there is actually a superior, and where there is an inferior there is an inferior; which are identical propositions, and of no consequence. The question is, by what means a superior number of equal chances operates upon the mind, and produces belief or assent; since it appears, that 'tis neither by arguments deriv'd from demonstration, nor from probability.

是否可以这样说，虽然在一个对立或机会中，我们不可能确定事件将落在哪一边，但我们可以肯定地宣布，“更有可能、更有可能的是，机会多的那一边将比机会少的那一边更有可能出现。既然这样说，我想问，这里的可能性和概率是什么意思？机会的可能性和概率是指同等机会的优势数量；因此，当我们说” 事件有可能落在优势的一方，而不是落在劣势的一方 "时，我们不过是确认，有优势数量的地方实际上就有优势，有劣势的地方就有劣势；这是相同的命题，没有任何意义。问题是，同等机会的上等数量是通过什么方式作用于人的心灵，并产生信仰或同意；因为看来，这既不是通过证明的论据，也不是通过概率的论据。

In order to clear up this difficulty, we shall suppose a person to take a dye, form'd after such a manner as that four of its sides are mark'd with one figure, or one number of spots, and two with another; and to put this dye into the box with an intention of throwing it: 'Tis plain, he must conclude the one figure to be more probable than the other, and give the preference to that which is inscrib'd on the greatest number of sides. He in a manner believes, that this will lie uppermost; tho' still with hesitation and doubt, in proportion to the number of chances, which are contrary: And according as these contrary chances diminish, and the superiority encreases on the other side, his belief acquires new degrees of stability and assurance. This belief arises from an operation of the mind upon the simple and limited object before us; and therefore its nature will be the more easily discover'd and explain'd. We have nothing but one single dye to contemplate, in order to comprehend one of the most curious operations of the understanding.

为了弄清这个难题，我们要假设一个人拿着一种染料，它的四条边上刻着一个图形，或一个数目的斑点，两条边上刻着另一个图形；然后把这种染料放进盒子里，打算把它扔出去。很明显，他必须断定一个图形比另一个图形更有可能，并优先考虑刻在最多边上的那个图形。在某种程度上，他相信这个图形会在最上面；尽管他仍然犹豫不决，怀疑与相反的机会的数量成正比。当这些相反的机会减少，而另一边的优势增加时，他的信念就获得了新的稳定和保证。这种信念来自于对我们面前这个简单而有限的对象的思维运作；因此，它的性质将更容易被发现和解释。为了理解理解力最奇特的操作之一，我们只需考虑一个单一的染料就可以了。

This dye form'd as above, contains three circumstances worthy of our attention. First, Certain causes, such as gravity, solidity, a. cubical figure, &c. which determine it to fall, to preserve its form in its fall, and to turn up one of its sides. Secondly, A certain number of sides, which are suppos'd indifferent. Thirdly, A certain figure, inscrib'd on each side. These three particulars form the whole nature of the dye, so far as relates to our present purpose; and consequently are the only circumstances regarded by the mind in its forming a judgment concerning the result of such a throw. Let us, therefore, consider gradually and carefully what must be the influence of these circumstances on the thought and imagination.

如上所述，这个染料的形状包含了三个值得我们注意的情况。首先，某些原因，如重力、坚固性、立方体等，决定了它会坠落，在坠落过程中保持其形状，并翻起其中的一个面。第二，有一定数量的边，这些边被认为是无所谓的。第三，每个面都刻有某种图形。这三个细节构成了染料的全部性质，只要与我们目前的目的有关；因此，这也是人们在对这种投掷的结果作出判断时唯一考虑的情况。因此，让我们逐步仔细考虑这些情况对思想和想象力的影响是什么。

First, We have already observ'd, that the mind is determin'd by custom to pass from any cause to its effect, and that upon the appearance of the one, 'tis almost impossible for it not to form an idea of the other. Their constant conjunction in past instances has produc'd such a habit in the mind, that it always conjoins them in its thought, and infers the existence of the one from that of its usual attendant. When it considers the dye as no longer supported by the box, it cannot without violence regard it as suspended in the air; but naturally places it on the table, and views it as turning up one of its sides. This is the effect of the intermingled causes, which are requisite to our forming any calculation concerning chances.

首先，我们已经注意到，人们的思想是由习惯决定的，从任何原因到它的结果，一旦出现一个，几乎不可能不形成另一个的想法。在过去的例子中，它们不断地结合在一起，在头脑中形成了这样一种习惯，以至于它总是把它们连在一起思考，并从其通常的伴随者推断出一个人的存在。当它认为染料不再由盒子支撑时，它就不能不认为它是悬浮在空气中的；而是自然地把它放在桌子上，把它看成是翻开它的一个面。这就是混合原因的结果，这对我们形成任何有关机会的计算都是必要的。

Secondly, 'Tis suppos'd, that tho' the dye be necessarily determin'd to fall, and turn up one of its sides, yet there is nothing to fix the particular side, but that this is determin'd entirely by chance. The very nature and essence of chance is a negation of causes, and the leaving the mind in a perfect indifference among those events, which are suppos'd contingent. When therefore the thought is determin'd by the causes to consider the dye as falling and turning up one of its sides, the chances present all these sides as equal, and make us consider every one of them, one after another, as alike probable and possible. The imagination passes from the cause, viz. the throwing of the dye, to the effect, viz. the turning up one of the six sides; and feels a kind of impossibility both of stopping short in the way, and of forming any other idea. But as all these six sides are incompatible, and the dye cannot turn up above one at once, this principle directs us not to consider all of them at once as lying uppermost; which we look upon as impossible: Neither does it direct us with its entire force to any particular side; for in that case this side wou'd be consider'd as certain and inevitable; but it directs us to the whole six sides after such a manner as to divide its force equally among them. We conclude in general, that some one of them must result from the throw: We run all of them over in our minds: The determination of the thought is common to all; but no more of its force falls to the share of any one, than what is suitable to its proportion with the rest. 'Tis after this manner the original impulse, and consequently the vivacity of thought, arising from the causes, is divided and split in pieces by the intermingled chances.

其次，我们认为，尽管染料必然会落下，并翻起其中一面，但没有任何东西可以固定特定的一面，而这完全是由机会决定的。机会的性质和本质是对原因的否定，并使思想在那些被认为是偶然的事件中处于完全的冷漠状态。因此，当思想被原因所决定，认为染料落下并翻起它的一个面时，机会把所有这些面都呈现为平等的，并使我们把它们中的每一个，一个接一个，视为同样的可能和可能。想象力从原因（即染料的投掷）到结果（即六面中的一面翻起）；并感到一种不可能，既不可能在路上停下来，也不可能形成任何其他想法。但是，由于所有这六个面都是不相容的，而且染料不可能一下子翻到一个以上，这个原则指导我们不要一下子把所有的面都看成是最上面的；我们认为这是不可能的。它也没有把它的全部力量指向任何一个特定的面；因为在这种情况下，这个面会被认为是确定的和不可避免的；但它指导我们以这样一种方式将它的力量平均分配到整个六面。总的来说，我们得出的结论是，其中的某一个必须是投掷的结果。我们在脑海中反复思考所有这些问题。思想的决定是共同的；但它的力量除了适合于它与其他部分的比例之外，没有更多的力量属于任何一个人的份额。就是这样，最初的冲动，以及由此产生的思想的活力，从各种原因中产生，被混合的机会分割成碎片。

We have already seen the influence of the two first qualities of the dye, viz. the causes, and the number and indifference of the sides, and have learn'd how they give an impulse to the thought, and divide that impulse into as many parts as there are unites in the number of sides. We must now consider the effects of the third particular, viz. the figures inscrib'd on each side. 'Tis evident that where several sides have the same figure inscrib'd on them, they must concur in their influence on the mind, and must unite upon one image or idea of a figure all those divided impulses, that were dispers'd over the several sides, upon which that figure is inscrib'd. Were the question only what side will be turn'd up, these are all perfectly equal, and no one cou'd ever have any advantage above another. But as the question is concerning the figure, and as the same figure is presented by more than one side; 'tis evident, that the impulses belonging to all these sides must re-unite in that one figure, and become stronger and more forcible by the union. Four sides are suppos'd in the present case to have the same figure inscrib'd on them, and two to have another figure. The impulses of the former are, therefore, superior to those of the latter. But as the events are contrary, and 'tis impossible both these figures can be turn'd up; the impulses likewise become contrary, and the inferior destroys the superior, as far as its strength goes. The vivacity of the idea is always proportionable to the degrees of the impulse or tendency to the transition; and belief is the same with the vivacity of the idea, according to the precedent doctrine.

我们已经看到了染料的前两个特质的影响，即 原因以及边的数量和冷漠，并且已经了解到它们是如何给思想带来冲动，并将这种冲动分成与边的数量相同的多个部分。我们现在必须考虑第三种情况的影响，即每条边上所刻的数字。很明显，如果几个面都刻有相同的图形，它们对心灵的影响必然是一致的，而且必须把所有分散在几个面上的、刻有该图形的、分裂的冲动统一到一个图形的形象或概念上。如果问题仅仅是哪一面会被翻起，那么这些都是完全平等的，没有任何一方会比另一方有任何优势。但是，由于问题是关于图形的，而同一个图形是由多个面来呈现的；显然，属于所有这些面的冲动必须在这一个图形中重新结合，并通过结合变得更加强大和有力。在本例中，有四个面被假定为刻有同一个图形，有两个面被假定为另一个图形。因此，前者的冲动优于后者的冲动。但是，由于事件是相反的，而且这两个图形不可能被翻转起来；冲动也同样变得相反，而且就其力量而言，劣等的破坏了高等的。思想的活力总是与过渡时期的冲动或倾向的程度成比例；根据先例学说，信仰与思想的活力是一样的。

 

Section 12. Of The Probability Of Causes

第 12 节。关于原因的概率

 

What I have said concerning the probability of chances can serve to no other purpose, than to assist us in explaining the probability of causes; since 'tis commonly allow'd by philosophers, that what the vulgar call chance is nothing but a secret and conceal'd cause. That species of probability, therefore, is what we must chiefly examine.

我所说的关于机会的概率，除了帮助我们解释原因的概率外，别无他用；因为哲学家们通常认为，俗人所说的机会不过是一种秘密的、隐蔽的原因。因此，这种可能性是我们必须主要研究的。

The probabilities of causes are of several kinds; but are all deriv'd from the same origin, viz. the association of ideas to a present impression. As the habit, which produces the association, arises from the frequent conjunction of objects, it must arrive at its perfection by degrees, and must acquire new force from each instance, that falls under our observation. The first instance has little or no force: The second makes some addition to it: The third becomes still more sensible; and 'tis by these slow steps, that our judgment arrives at a full assurance. But before it attains this pitch of perfection, it passes thro' several inferior degrees, and in all of them is only to be esteem'd a presumption or probability. The gradation, therefore, from probabilities to proofs is in many cases insensible; and the difference betwixt these kinds of evidence is more easily perceiv'd in the remote degrees, than in the near and contiguous.

原因的可能性有好几种；但都是从同一源头衍生出来的，即观念与当前印象的联系。由于产生联想的习惯来自于物体的频繁结合，它必须逐步达到完美，并且必须从我们观察到的每个实例中获得新的力量。第一个例子很少或没有力量。第二个例子使它得到一些补充。第三次变得更有意义；正是通过这些缓慢的步骤，我们的判断力才达到了充分的保证。但在达到这个完美的程度之前，它要经过几个较低的等级，而且在所有这些等级中都只能被视为一种推测或可能性。因此，从可能性到证明的分级在很多情况下是不明显的；这些证据之间的差异在遥远的程度上比在接近和相邻的程度上更容易被察觉。

'Tis worthy of remark on this occasion, that tho' the species of probability here explain'd be the first in order, and naturally takes place before any entire proof can exist, yet no one, who is arriv'd at the age of maturity, can any longer be acquainted with it. 'Tis true, nothing is more common than for people of the most advanc'd knowledge to have attain'd only an imperfect experience of many particular events; which naturally produces only an imperfect habit and transition: But then we must consider, that the mind, having form'd another observation concerning the connexion of causes and effects, gives new force to its reasoning from that observation; and by means of it can build an argument on one single experiment, when duly prepar'd and examin'd. What we have found once to follow from any object, we conclude will for ever follow from it; and if this maxim be not always built upon as certain, 'tis not for want of a sufficient number of experiments, but because we frequently meet with instances to the contrary; which leads us to the second species of probability, where there is a contrariety in our experience and observation.

在此值得一提的是，虽然这里解释的概率种类是最早的，而且自然发生在任何完整的证明之前，但没有人，在成熟的年龄，可以再熟悉它了。诚然，没有什么比最先进的知识的人对许多特定的事件只获得了不完善的经验更常见的了；这自然只产生了不完善的习惯和过渡。但是，我们必须考虑到，头脑在形成了对因果关系的另一种观察后，会从这种观察中给它的推理带来新的力量；并且通过它，在适当的准备和检查后，可以在一个单一的实验上建立一个论点。如果这句格言并不总是建立在确定的基础上，那不是因为缺乏足够数量的实验，而是因为我们经常遇到相反的例子；这使我们进入了第二种可能性，即在我们的经验和观察中存在着矛盾。

'Twou'd be very happy for men in the conduct of their lives and actions, were the same objects always conjoin'd together, and we had nothing to fear but the mistakes of our own judgment, without having any reason to apprehend the uncertainty of nature. But as 'tis frequently found, that one observation is contrary to another, and that causes and effects follow not in the same order, of which we have had experience, we are oblig'd to vary our reasoning on account of this uncertainty, and take into consideration the contrariety of events. The first question, that occurs on this head, is concerning the nature and causes of the contrariety.

如果同样的目标总是结合在一起，而我们除了自己判断的错误之外没有什么可担心的，没有任何理由去担心自然界的不确定性，那么人们在生活和行动中就会非常高兴。但是，我们经常发现，一个观察结果与另一个观察结果相反，而且原因和结果不是按照我们所经历的同一顺序进行的，因此，我们不得不根据这种不确定性来改变我们的推理，并考虑到事件的反常性。在这个问题上出现的第一个问题，是关于矛盾的性质和原因。

The vulgar, who take things according to their first appearance, attribute the uncertainty of events to such an uncertainty in the causes, as makes them often fail of their usual influence, tho' they meet with no obstacle nor impediment in their operation. But philosophers observing, that almost in every part of nature there is contain'd a vast variety of springs and principles, which are hid, by reason of their minuteness or remoteness, find that 'tis at least possible the contrariety of events may not proceed from any contingency in the cause, but from the secret operation of contrary causes. This possibility is converted into certainty by farther observation, when they remark, that upon an exact scrutiny, a contrariety of effects always betrays a contrariety of causes, and proceeds from their mutual hindrance and opposition. A peasant can give no better reason for the stopping of any clock or watch than to say, that commonly it does not go right: But an artizan easily perceives, that the same force in the spring or pendulum has always the same influence on the wheels; but fails of its usual effect, perhaps by reason of a grain of dust, which puts a stop to the whole movement. From the observation of several parallel instances, philosophers form a maxim, that the connexion betwixt all causes and effects is equally necessary, and that its seeming uncertainty in some instances proceeds from the secret opposition of contrary causes.

俗人根据事物的最初表象，把事件的不确定性归因于原因的不确定性，使它们经常不能发挥其通常的影响，尽管它们在运行中没有遇到任何障碍或阻碍。但哲学家们观察到，自然界的每一个部分几乎都包含着各种各样的源泉和原理，由于它们的微小或遥远而被隐藏起来，他们发现，"事件的反常性至少有可能不是来自原因中的任何偶然性，而是来自相反原因的秘密运作。这种可能性通过进一步的观察转化为确定性，当他们指出，经过精确的检查，结果的反差总是暴露了原因的反差，并且来自它们的相互阻碍和反对。一个农民对于任何时钟或手表的停顿，除了说它通常走得不对之外，没有更好的理由。但是，一个艺术家很容易看出，弹簧或钟摆中的相同力量对轮子的影响始终是相同的；但由于一粒灰尘的存在，使整个运动停顿下来，从而失去了其通常的效果。哲学家们从对几个平行例子的观察中形成了一条格言，即所有的原因和结果之间的联系都是同样必要的，而在某些情况下，其看似不确定的原因是由于相反的原因的秘密对抗。

But however philosophers and the vulgar may differ in their explication of the contrariety of events, their inferences from it are always of the same kind, and founded on the same principles. A contrariety of events in the past may give us a kind of hesitating belief for the future after two several ways. First, By producing an imperfect habit and transition from the present impression to the related idea. When the conjunction of any two objects is frequent, without being entirely constant, the mind is determin'd to pass from one object to the other; but not with so entire a habit, as when the union is uninterrupted, and all the instances we have ever met with are uniform and of a piece. We End from common experience, in our actions as well as reasonings, that a constant perseverance in any course of life produces a strong inclination and tendency to continue for the future; tho' there are habits of inferior degrees of force, proportion'd to the inferior degrees of steadiness and uniformity in our conduct.

但是，无论哲学家和普通人在解释事件的反差方面如何不同，他们从中得出的推论总是同类的，并建立在相同的原则之上。过去事件的反差可以通过两种方式给我们一种对未来的犹豫不决的信念。首先，通过产生一种不完美的习惯和过渡，从现在的印象到相关的想法。当任何两个对象的结合是频繁的，而不是完全恒定的，头脑就会被确定为从一个对象转到另一个对象；但不会像结合是不间断的，而且我们曾经遇到的所有例子都是统一的，是一个整体的时候，有如此完整的习惯。在我们的行动和推理中，我们从常见的经验中得知，在任何生活过程中的持续坚持都会产生一种强烈的倾向和趋势，以便在未来继续下去；尽管有些习惯的力量程度较低，与我们行为中的稳定和统一程度较低相称。

There is no doubt but this principle sometimes takes place, and produces those inferences we draw from contrary phænomena; tho' I am persuaded, that upon examination we shall not find it to be the principle, that most commonly influences the mind in this species of reasoning. When we follow only the habitual determination of the mind, we make the transition without any reflection, and interpose not a moments delay betwixt the view of one object and the belief of that, which is often found to attend it. As the custom depends not upon any deliberation, it operates immediately, without allowing any time for reflection. But this method of proceeding we have but few instances of in our probable reasonings; and even fewer than in those, which are deriv'd from the uninterrupted conjunction of objects. In the former species of reasoning we commonly take knowingly into consideration the contrariety of past events; we compare the different sides of the contrariety, and carefully weigh the experiments, which we have on each side: Whence we may conclude, that our reasonings of this kind arise not directly from the habit, but in an oblique manner; which we must now endeavour to explain.

毫无疑问，这一原则有时会发生，并产生我们从相反的现象中得出的那些推论；尽管我相信，经过检查，我们不会发现它是在这种推理中最常影响心灵的原则。当我们只遵循头脑中的习惯性决定时，我们会在没有任何思考的情况下进行转换，并且在看到一个物体和相信那个物体之间没有片刻的延迟，而这是经常发现的。由于这种习惯不取决于任何考虑，它立即发挥作用，不允许有任何思考的时间。但是，在我们可能的推理中，这种进行方式的例子很少；甚至比那些从对象的不间断结合中得出的推理还要少。在前一种推理中，我们通常明知故犯地考虑到过去事件的反差；我们比较反差的不同方面，并仔细权衡我们在每一方面的实验。因此，我们可以得出结论，我们的这种推理不是直接从习惯中产生的，而是以一种间接的方式产生的；我们现在必须努力解释这一点。

'Tis evident, that when an object is attended with contrary effects, we judge of them only by our past experience, and always consider those as possible, which we have observ'd to follow from it. And as past experience regulates our judgment concerning the possibility of these effects, so it does that concerning their probability; and that effect, which has been the most common, we always esteem the most likely. Here then are two things to be consider'd, viz. the reasons which determine us to make the past a standard for the future, and the manner how we extract a single judgment from a contrariety of past events.

很明显，当一个物体伴随着相反的效果时，我们只根据我们过去的经验来判断它们，并且总是认为那些我们观察到的可能的效果是由它产生的。由于过去的经验制约着我们对这些影响的可能性的判断，所以它也制约着对其可能性的判断；最常见的影响，我们总是认为是最可能的。这里有两件事需要考虑，即决定我们将过去作为未来标准的原因，以及我们如何从过去的各种事件中提取一个单一的判断。

First we may observe, that the supposition, that the future resembles the past, is not founded on arguments of any kind, but is deriv'd entirely from habit, by which we are determin'd to expect for the future the same train of objects, to which we have been accustom'd. This habit or determination to transfer the past to the future is full and perfect; and consequently the first impulse of the imagination in this species of reasoning is endow'd with the same qualities.

首先，我们可以看到，未来与过去相似的假设不是建立在任何种类的论据上，而是完全来自于习惯，根据这种习惯，我们决定对未来期待与我们已经习惯的对象相同。这种将过去转移到未来的习惯或决心是充分和完美的；因此，在这种推理中，想象力的第一冲动也被赋予了同样的品质。

But, secondly, when in considering past experiments we find them of a contrary nature, this determination, tho' full and perfect in itself, presents us with no steady object, but offers us a number of disagreeing images in a certain order and proportion. The first impulse, therefore, is here broke into pieces, and diffuses itself over all those images, of which each partakes an equal share of that force and vivacity, that is deriv'd from the impulse. Any of these past events may again happen; and we judge, that when they do happen, they will be mix'd in the same proportion as in the past.

但是，第二，当我们在考虑过去的实验时，发现它们具有相反的性质，这种决定，虽然本身是充分和完美的，但向我们展示的不是稳定的目标，而是按照一定的顺序和比例向我们提供一些不一致的图像。因此，第一个冲动在这里被分解成了碎片，并扩散到所有的图像上，其中每个图像都有同等的力量和活力，这是从冲动中衍生出来的。这些过去的事件中的任何一个都可能再次发生；而且我们判断，当它们真的发生时，它们将以与过去相同的比例混合。

If our intention, therefore, be to consider the proportions of contrary events in a great number of instances, the images presented by our past experience must remain in their first form, and preserve their first proportions. Suppose, for instance, I have found by long observation, that of twenty ships, which go to sea, only nineteen return. Suppose I see at present twenty ships that leave the port: I transfer my past experience to the future, and represent to myself nineteen of these ships as returning in safety, and one as perishing. Concerning this there can be no difficulty. But as we frequently run over those several ideas of past events, in order to form a judgment concerning one single event, which appears uncertain; this consideration must change the first form of our ideas, and draw together the divided images presented by experience; since 'tis to it we refer the determination of that particular event, upon which we reason. Many of these images are suppos'd to concur, and a superior number to concur on one side. These agreeing images unite together, and render the idea more strong and lively, not only than a mere fiction of the imagination, but also than any idea, which is supported by a lesser number of experiments. Each new experiment is as a new stroke of the pencil, which bestows an additional vivacity on the colours, without either multiplying or enlarging the figure. This operation of the mind has been so fully explain'd in treating of the probability of chance, that I need not here endeavour to render it more intelligible. Every past experiment may be consider'd as a kind of chance; it being uncertain to us, whether the object will exist comformable to one experiment or another: And for this reason every thing that has been said on the one subject is applicable to both. Thus upon the whole, contrary experiments produce an imperfect belief, either by weakening the habit, or by dividing and afterwards joining in different parts, that perfect habit, which makes us conclude in general, that instances, of which we have no experience, must necessarily resemble those of which we have.

因此，如果我们的目的是考虑大量事例中相反事件的比例，我们过去的经验所呈现的图像必须保持其最初的形式，并保持其最初的比例。例如，假设我通过长期观察发现，在二十艘出海的船只中，只有十九艘返回。假设我现在看到有二十艘船离开港口。我把我过去的经验转移到未来，并对自己说，这些船中有 19 艘是安全返回的，有一艘是灭亡的。关于这一点，不会有什么困难。但是，由于我们经常翻阅过去事件的几种想法，以便对一个看起来不确定的单一事件作出判断；这种考虑必须改变我们想法的第一种形式，并将经验所呈现的分裂的图像汇集在一起；因为我们是根据它来确定那个特定事件的，我们据此进行推理。这些图像中的许多都被认为是一致的，而更多的是一致的一面。这些一致的形象结合在一起，使这个想法更加强烈和生动，不仅比单纯的想象力的虚构，而且比任何由较少数量的实验支持的想法。每一个新的实验就像铅笔的一个新的笔触，它给颜色带来了额外的活力，而没有增加或扩大图形。心灵的这种运作在论述偶然性的概率时已经有了充分的解释，我不需要在这里努力使它更容易理解。过去的每一个实验都可以被看作是一种机会；对我们来说，不确定物体的存在是否符合一个实验的要求。由于这个原因，在一个主题上所说的每一件事都适用于两个主题。因此，总的来说，相反的实验会产生一种不完美的信念，或者是通过削弱习惯，或者是通过分割，然后在不同的部分结合起来，这种完美的习惯使我们一般地得出结论，即我们没有经验的例子，必然与我们有经验的例子相似。

To justify still farther this account of the second species of probability, where we reason with knowledge and reflection from a contrariety of past experiments, I shall propose the following considerations, without fearing to give offence by that air of subtilty, which attends them. Just reasoning ought still, perhaps, to retain its force, however subtile; in the same manner as matter preserves its solidity in the air, and fire, and animal spirits, as well as in the grosser and more sensible forms.

为了进一步证明第二种可能性的说法，即我们从过去的实验对比中用知识和思考进行推理，我将提出以下考虑，而不必担心因这些考虑所带来的狡猾的空气而引起冒犯。公正的推理也许仍应保持其力量，无论多么微妙；就像物质在空气、火和动物精神中以及在更粗大和更感性的形式中保持其稳固性一样。

First, We may observe, that there is no probability so great as not to allow of a contrary possibility; because otherwise 'twou'd cease to be a probability, and wou'd become a certainty. That probability of causes, which is most extensive, and which we at present examine, depends on a contrariety of experiments; and 'tis evident an experiment in the past proves at least a possibility for the future.

首先，我们可以看到，没有任何概率大到不允许有相反的可能性；因为否则的话，这就不再是一种概率，而会成为一种确定性。我们目前所研究的最广泛的原因的概率，取决于各种实验的对比；显然，过去的实验至少证明了未来的可能性。

Secondly, The component parts of this possibility and probability are of the same nature, and differ in number only, but not in kind. It has been observ'd, that all single chances are entirely equal, and that the only circumstance, which can give any event, that is contingent, a superiority over another, is a superior number of chances. In like manner, as the uncertainty of causes is discover'd by experience, which presents us with a view of contrary events, 'tis plain, that when we transfer the past to the future, the known to the unknown, every past experiment has the same weight, and that 'tis only a superior number of them, which can throw the ballance on any side. The possibility, therefore, which enters into every reasoning of this kind, is compos'd of parts, which are of the same nature both among themselves, and with those, that compose the opposite probability.

第二，这种可能性和概率的组成部分具有相同的性质，只在数量上有区别，但在种类上没有区别。据观察，所有单一的机会都是完全平等的，唯一能使任何事件（即偶然事件）优于另一事件的情况，是机会的数量更多。同样，由于原因的不确定性是由经验发现的，它向我们展示了相反的事件，因此很明显，当我们把过去转移到未来，把已知转移到未知时，每一个过去的实验都有相同的分量，只有它们的数量多，才能把天平放在任何一边。因此，进入这种推理的可能性是由各部分组成的，这些部分在它们之间以及与构成相反的可能性的部分具有相同的性质。

Thirdly, We may establish it as a certain maxim, that in all moral as well as natural phænomena, wherever any cause consists of a number of parts, and the effect encreases or diminishes, according to the variation of that number, the effect, properly speaking, is a compounded one, and arises from the union of the several effects, that proceed from each part of the cause. Thus because the gravity of a body encreases or diminishes by the encrease or diminution of its parts, we conclude that each part contains this quality and contributes to the gravity of the whole. The absence or presence of a part of the cause is attended with that of a proportionable part of the effect. This connexion or constant conjunction sufficiently proves the one part to be the cause of the other. As the belief, which we have of any event, encreases or diminishes according to the number of chances or past experiments, 'tis to be consider'd as a compounded effect, of which each part arises from a proportionable number of chances or experiments.

第三，我们可以把它确定为一条格言，即在所有道德和自然现象中，凡是任何原因由若干部分组成，而结果根据该数字的变化而增加或减少，正确地说，该结果是一个复合的结果，是由原因的每一部分产生的若干效果的结合。因此，由于一个物体的重力因其各部分的增加或减少而增加或减少，我们得出结论，每个部分都包含这种质量，并对整个物体的重力有所贡献。原因的一个部分的缺失或存在与结果的一个相应部分的缺失或存在相伴随。这种联系或持续的结合足以证明这一部分是另一部分的原因。由于我们对任何事件的信念是根据机会或过去的实验的数量而增加或减少的，因此应将其视为一种复合效应，其中的每一部分都是由相应数量的机会或实验产生的。

Let us now join these three observations, and see what conclusion we can draw from them. To every probability there is an opposite possibility. This possibility is compos'd of parts, that are entirely of the same nature with those of the probability; and consequently have the same influence on the mind and understanding. The belief, which attends the probability, is a compounded effect, and is form'd by the concurrence of the several effects, which proceed from each part of the probability. Since therefore each part of the probability contributes to the production of the belief, each part of the possibility must have the same influence on the opposite side; the nature of these parts being entirely the same. The contrary belief, attending the possibility, implies a view of a certain object, as well as the probability does an opposite view. In this particular both these degrees of belief are alike. The only manner then, in which the superior number of similar component parts in the one can exert its influence, and prevail above the inferior in the other, is by producing a stronger and more lively view of its object. Each part presents a particular view; and all these views uniting together produce one general view, which is fuller and more distinct by the greater number of causes or principles, from which it is deriv'd.

现在让我们把这三个观察结合起来，看看我们能从中得出什么结论。每个可能性都有一个相反的可能性。这种可能性是由一些部分组成的，这些部分的性质与可能性的性质完全相同；因此对头脑和理解力有同样的影响。伴随着概率而来的信念是一种复合效应，是由概率的每一部分所产生的几种效应共同构成的。因此，既然可能性的每一部分都有助于信念的产生，那么可能性的每一部分都必须对反面产生同样的影响；这些部分的性质是完全一样的。与之相反的信念，在可能性的作用下，意味着对某一对象的看法，就像概率对一个相反的看法一样。在这一点上，这两种程度的信念是相同的。那么，在一个人中，类似的组成部分的优势数量能够发挥其影响，并在另一个人中战胜劣势的唯一方式，就是对其对象产生更强烈和更生动的看法。每个部分都提出了一个特殊的观点；而所有这些观点结合在一起，产生了一个总的观点，由于它是由更多的原因或原则衍生出来的，所以它更充分和更鲜明。

The component parts of the probability and possibility, being alike in their nature, must produce like effects; and the likeness of their effects consists in this, that each of them presents a view of a particular object. But tho' these parts be alike in their nature, they are very different in their quantity and number; and this difference must appear in the effect as well as the similarity. Now as the view they present is in both cases full and entire, and comprehends the object in all its parts, 'tis impossible that in this particular there can be any difference; nor is there any thing but a superior vivacity in the probability, arising from the concurrence of a superior number of views, which can distinguish these effects.

概率和可能性的组成部分在性质上是相同的，因此必须产生相似的效果；它们的效果的相似性在于，它们中的每一个都呈现出对一个特定对象的看法。但是，尽管这些部分在性质上是相同的，它们在数量上却有很大的不同；这种不同必须出现在效果上，也出现在相似性上。现在，由于它们所呈现的景象在两种情况下都是完整的，并且包含了物体的所有部分，所以在这一点上不可能有任何区别；也不可能有任何东西，而只是在概率上有更大的活力，这是因为有更多的景象同时存在，才能区分出这些效果。

Here is almost the same argument in a different light. All our reasonings concerning the probability of causes are founded on the transferring of past to future. The transferring of any past experiment to the future is sufficient to give us a view of the object; whether that experiment be single, or combin'd with others of the same kind; whether it be entire, or oppos'd by others of a contrary kind. Suppose, then, it acquires both these qualities of combination and opposition, it loses not upon that account its former power of presenting a view of the object, but only concurs with and opposes other experiments, that have a like influence. A question, therefore, may arise concerning the manner both of the concurrence and opposition. As to the concurrence, there is only the choice left betwixt these two hypotheses. First, That the view of the object, occasion'd by the transference of each past experiment, preserves itself entire, and only multiplies the number of views. Or, secondly, That it runs into the other similar and correspondent views, and gives them a superior degree of force and vivacity. But that the first hypothesis is erroneous, is evident from experience, which informs us, that the belief, attending any reasoning, consists in one conclusion, not in a multitude of similar ones, which wou'd only distract the mind, and in many cases wou'd be too numerous to be comprehended distinctly by any finite capacity. It remains, therefore, as the only reasonable opinion, that these similar views run into each other, and unite their forces; so as to produce a stronger and clearer view, than what arises from any one alone. This is the manner, in which past experiments concur, when they are transfer'd to any future event. As to the manner of their opposition, 'tis evident, that as the contrary views are incompatible with each other, and 'tis impossible the object can at once exist conformable to both of them, their influence becomes mutually destructive, and the mind is determin'd to the superior only with that force, which remains after subtracting the inferior.

这里几乎是同一论点的另一种体现。我们所有关于原因概率的推理都是建立在把过去转移到未来的基础上的。将任何过去的实验转移到未来，就足以让我们对对象有一个看法；不管这个实验是单一的，还是与其他同类实验相结合的；不管它是完整的，还是与其他同类实验相反的。那么，假设它获得了这些组合和反对的品质，它并不因此而失去它以前对物体的看法的能力，而只是与具有类似影响的其他实验相配合和反对。因此，可能会出现一个关于结合和反对的方式的问题。关于一致，只剩下在这两种假设之间的选择。第一，对物体的看法，由过去每个实验的转移所引起的，保留了自己的全部，而只是增加了看法的数量。或者，第二，它与其他类似的和相应的观点相联系，并使它们具有更高的力量和活力。但第一种假设是错误的，这一点从经验中可以看出，任何推理所产生的信念都是由一个结论组成的，而不是由许多类似的结论组成的，这些结论只会分散人们的注意力，而且在许多情况下，由于数量太多，任何有限的能力都无法清楚地理解。因此，唯一合理的观点是，这些类似的观点相互碰撞，并将它们的力量结合起来；从而产生一个比任何一个单独产生的观点更强大、更清晰的观点。这就是过去的实验在转移到任何未来的事件中时所采用的方式。至于它们的对立方式，很明显，由于相反的观点是互不相容的，而且对象不可能同时符合它们两个的要求，它们的影响就变成了相互破坏，而头脑中只有在减去劣势后剩下的力量才会被确定为优势。

I am sensible how abstruse all this reasoning must appear to the generality of readers, who not being accustom'd to such profound reflections on the intellectual faculties of the mind, will be apt to reject as chimerical whatever strikes not in with the common receiv'd notions, and with the easiest and most obvious principles of philosophy. And no doubt there are some pains requir'd to enter into these arguments; tho' perhaps very little are necessary to perceive the imperfection of every vulgar hypothesis on this subject, and the little light, which philosophy can yet afford us in such sublime and such curious speculations. Let men be once fully perswaded of these two principles, That there is nothing in any object, consider'd in itself, which can afford us a reason for drawing a conclusion beyond it; and, That even after the observation of the frequent or constant conjunction of objects, we have no reason to draw any inference concerning any object beyond those of which we have had experience; I say, let men be once fully convinc'd of these two principles, and this will throw them so loose from all common systems, that they will make no difficulty of receiving any, which may appear the most extraordinary. These principles we have found to be sufficiently convincing, even with regard to our most certain reasonings from causation: But I shall venture to affirm, that with regard to these conjectural or probable reasonings they still acquire a new degree of evidence.

我意识到，对于广大读者来说，所有这些推理必须显得多么深奥，他们不习惯于对心灵的智力进行如此深刻的反思，很容易把不符合普遍接受的概念和最简单、最明显的哲学原则的东西当作是虚构的。毫无疑问，进入这些争论需要一些痛苦；但也许只需要很少的痛苦就能看出这个问题上每一个庸俗假设的不完善，以及哲学在这种崇高和这种奇怪的猜测中所能提供给我们的一点光亮。让人们充分认识到这两个原则，即任何物体本身没有任何东西可以让我们得出超越它的结论；以及即使在观察了物体的频繁或持续结合之后，我们也没有理由就任何物体得出超越我们经验的推论；我说，让人们充分认识到这两个原则，这将使他们从所有普通系统中摆脱出来，以至于他们将不难接受任何可能看起来最不寻常的东西。我们发现这些原则有足够的说服力，甚至对我们最确定的因果关系的推理也是如此。但我要大胆地说，对于这些猜想的或可能的推理，它们仍然获得了新的证据程度。

First, 'Tis obvious, that in reasonings of this kind, 'tis not the object presented to us, which, consider'd in itself, affords us any reason to draw a conclusion concerning any other object or event. For as this latter object is suppos'd uncertain, and as the uncertainty is deriv'd from a conceal'd contrariety of causes in the former, were any of the causes plac'd in the known qualities of that object, they wou'd no longer be conceal'd, nor wou'd our conclusion be uncertain.

首先，很明显，在这种推理中，向我们提出的对象本身并不能为我们提供任何理由来得出有关任何其他对象或事件的结论。因为后一个对象被认为是不确定的，而这种不确定是由前一个对象中隐藏的各种原因引起的，如果任何一个原因被置于该对象的已知品质中，它们就不会再被隐藏，我们的结论也不会不确定。

But, secondly, 'tis equally obvious in this species of reasoning, that if the transference of the past to the future were founded merely on a conclusion of the understanding, it cou'd never occasion any belief or assurance. When we transfer contrary experiments to the future, we can only repeat these contrary experiments with their particular proportions; which cou'd not produce assurance in any single event, upon which we reason, unless the fancy melted together all those images that concur, and extracted from them one single idea or image, which is intense and lively in proportion to the number of experiments from which it is deriv'd, and their superiority above their antagonists. Our past experience presents no determinate object; and as our belief, however faint, fixes itself on a determinate object, 'tis evident that the belief arises not merely from the transference of past to future, but from some operation of the fancy conjoin'd with it. This may lead us to conceive the manner, in which that faculty enters into all our reasonings.

但是，第二，在这种推理中，同样明显的是，如果把过去转移到未来仅仅建立在理解力的结论上，它永远不会产生任何信念或保证。当我们把相反的实验转移到未来时，我们只能以它们的特定比例重复这些相反的实验；这不可能在我们推理的任何单一事件中产生保证，除非幻想把所有这些同时出现的图像融为一体，并从它们中提取出一个单一的想法或图像，这种想法或图像的强烈和生动程度与它所衍生的实验的数量以及它们高于其对手的优势成比例。我们过去的经验没有呈现出确定的对象；而我们的信念，无论多么微弱，都将自己固定在一个确定的对象上，显然，这种信念的产生不仅仅是来自过去对未来的转移，而是来自与之相联系的某种幻想的运作。这可以使我们想象出这种能力进入我们所有推理的方式。

I shall conclude this subject with two reflections, which may deserve our attention. The first may be explain'd after this manner. When the mind forms a reasoning concerning any matter of fact, which is only probable, it casts its eye backward upon past experience, and transferring it to the future, is presented with so many contrary views of its object, of which those that are of the same kind uniting together, and running into one act of the mind, serve to fortify and inliven it. But suppose that this multitude of views or glimpses of an object proceeds not from experience, but from a voluntary act of the imagination; this effect does not follow, or at least, follows not in the same degree. For tho' custom and education produce belief by such a repetition, as is not deriv'd from experience, yet this requires a long tract of time, along with a very frequent and undersign'd repetition. In general we may pronounce, that a person, who wou'd 20voluntarily repeat any idea in his mind, tho' supported by one past experience, wou'd be no more inclin'd to believe the existence of its object, than if he had contented himself with one survey of it. Beside the effect of design; each act of the mind, being separate and independent, has a separate influence, and joins not its force with that of its fellows. Not being united by any common object, producing them, they have no relation to each other; and consequently make no transition or union of forces. This phænomenon we shall understand better afterwards.

我将以两个值得我们注意的思考来结束这个话题。第一个问题可以这样解释。当人们对任何事实形成推理时，这只是一种可能性，它将目光投向过去的经验，并将其转移到未来，呈现出许多关于其目标的相反观点，其中那些同类的观点结合在一起，并流入心灵的一个行为，有助于加强和活跃它。但是，假设对一个物体的多种看法或瞥见不是来自于经验，而是来自于想象力的自愿行为；这种效果就不会出现，或者至少不会在同样的程度上出现。因为尽管习惯和教育通过这样的重复来产生信仰，而不是来自于经验，但这需要很长的时间，以及非常频繁和低调的重复。一般来说，我们可以说，一个人，如果他愿意 20一个人如果自愿重复他心中的任何想法，尽管有过去的经验支持，也不会比他满足于对它的一次调查而更倾向于相信其对象的存在。除了设计的效果之外，心灵的每一个行为都是独立的，有单独的影响，并不与其他行为的力量结合。由于没有任何共同的对象来产生它们，它们彼此之间没有任何关系；因此，没有任何力量的过渡或结合。这个现象我们以后会更好地理解。

My second reflection is founded on those large probabilities, which the mind can judge of, and the minute differences it can observe betwixt them. When the chances or experiments on one side amount to ten thousand, and on the other to ten thousand and one, the judgment gives the preference to the latter, upon account of that superiority; tho' 'tis plainly impossible for the mind to run over every particular view, and distinguish the superior vivacity of the image arising from the superior number, where the difference is so inconsiderable. We have a parallel instance in the affections. 'Tis evident, according to the principles above mention'd, that when an object produces any passion in us, which varies according to the different quantity of the object; I say, 'tis evident, that the passion, properly speaking, is not a simple emotion, but a compounded one, of a great number of weaker passions, deriv'd from a view of each part of the object. For otherwise 'twere impossible the passion shou'd encrease by the encrease of these parts. Thus a man, who desires a thousand pound, has in reality a thousand or more desires, which uniting together, seem to make only one passion; tho' the composition evidently betrays itself upon every alteration of the object, by the preference he gives to the larger number, if superior only by an unite. Yet nothing can be more certain, than that so small a difference wou'd not be discernible in the passions, nor cou'd render them distinguishable from each other. The difference, therefore, of our conduct in preferring the greater number depends not upon our passions, but upon custom, and general rules. We have found in a multitude of instances, that the augmenting the numbers of any sum augments the passion, where the numbers are precise and the difference sensible. The mind can perceive from its immediate feeling, that three guineas produce a greater passion than two; and this it transfers to larger numbers, because of the resemblance; and by a general rule assigns to a thousand guineas, a stronger passion than to nine hundred and ninety nine. These general rules we shall explain presently.

我的第二个思考是建立在那些大的概率上的，心灵可以判断的，以及它可以观察到的它们之间的微小差异。当一方的机会或实验达到一万个，另一方的机会或实验达到一万零一个时，由于后者的优越性，判断力就会优先考虑后者；尽管 “头脑显然不可能跑遍每一个特定的观点，并区分出由优越的数量所产生的图像的优越活力，而这种差异是如此微不足道。我们在情感方面有一个类似的例子。根据上面提到的原则，很明显，当一个物体在我们身上产生任何激情时，这种激情会根据物体的不同数量而变化；我说，很明显，这种激情，正确地说，不是一种简单的情感，而是一种复合的情感，由大量较弱的激情组成，从物体的每个部分衍生而来。因为否则的话，激情不可能随着这些部分的增加而增加。因此，一个渴望得到一千英镑的人，实际上有一千或更多的欲望，这些欲望结合在一起，似乎只构成一种激情；尽管这种成分在对象的每一次改变中都明显地暴露出来，因为他对较大的数量给予了优先考虑，如果只是通过结合来提高的话。然而，没有什么能比这更肯定的了，这么小的差别在激情中是看不出来的，也不可能使它们彼此区分开来。因此，我们在选择人数较多的人方面的行为差异，不是取决于我们的激情，而是取决于习俗和一般规则。我们在许多例子中发现，在数字精确和差异明显的情况下，增加任何总数的数字都会增加激情。心灵可以从它的直接感觉中察觉到，三基尼比两基尼产生更大的激情；由于相似性，它将这种激情转移到更大的数字上；根据一般规则，对一千基尼的激情比对九百九十九的激情更强烈。我们将在下文中解释这些一般规则。

But beside these two species of probability, which are deriv'd from an imperfect experience and from contrary causes, there is a third arising from Analogy, which differs from them in some material circumstances. According to the hypothesis above explain'd all kinds of reasoning from causes or effects are founded on two particulars, viz. the constant conjunction of any two objects in all past experience, and the resemblance of a present object to any one of them. The effect of these two particulars is, that the present object invigorates and inlivens the imagination; and the resemblance, along with the constant union, conveys this force and vivacity to the related idea; which we are therefore said to believe, or assent to. If you weaken either the union or resemblance, you weaken the principle of transition, and of consequence that belief, which arises from it. The vivacity of the first impression cannot be fully convey'd to the related idea, either where the conjunction of their objects is not constant, or where the present impression does not perfectly resemble any of those, whose union we are accustom'd to observe. In those probabilities of chance and causes above explain'd, 'tis the constancy of the union, which is diminish'd; and in the probability deriv'd from analogy, 'tis the resemblance only, which is affected. Without some degree of resemblance, as well as union, 'tis impossible there can be any reasoning: but as this resemblance admits of many different degrees, the reasoning becomes proportionally more or less firm and certain. An experiment loses of its force, when transfer'd to instances, which are not exactly resembling; tho' 'tis evident it may still retain as much as may be the foundation of probability, as long as there is any resemblance remaining.

但是，除了这两种从不完美的经验和相反的原因中得出的可能性之外，还有第三种从类比中产生的可能性，它在某些物质条件下与它们不同。根据上面解释的假设，所有从原因或效果出发的推理都建立在两个细节上，即在所有过去的经验中任何两个对象的持续结合，以及现在的对象与其中任何一个的相似性。这两个特点的作用是，现在的物体使想象力活跃起来；而相似性，加上持续的结合，将这种力量和活力传递给相关的想法；因此，我们被说成是相信，或同意。如果你削弱了结合或相似性，你就削弱了过渡原则，以及由此产生的信念。第一印象的活力不能完全传达给相关的想法，要么是在它们的对象的结合不是恒定的情况下，要么是在目前的印象与我们习惯于观察的那些结合不完全相似的情况下。在上面解释的那些机会和原因的概率中，减少的是结合的恒定性；而在从类比中得出的概率中，影响的只是相似性。如果没有某种程度的相似和结合，就不可能有任何推理：但由于这种相似可以有许多不同的程度，推理就会相应地变得更加坚定和确定。当一个实验被转移到不完全相似的实例上时，它就失去了力量；但很明显，只要还有任何相似之处，它仍然可以尽可能多地保留可能性的基础。

 

Section 13. Of Unphilosophical Probability

第 13 节。非哲学性的概率

 

All these kinds of probability are receiv'd by philosophers, and allow'd to be reasonable foundations of belief and opinion. But there are others, that are deriv'd from the same principles, tho' they have not had the good fortune to obtain the same sanction. The first probability of this kind may be accounted for thus. The diminution of the union, and of the resemblance, as above explained, diminishes the facility of the transition, and by that means weakens the evidence; and we may farther observe, that the same diminution of the evidence will follow from a diminution of the impression, and from the shading of those colours, under which it appears to the memory or senses. The argument, which we found on any matter of fact we remember, is more or less convincing, according as the fact is recent or remote; and tho' the difference in these degrees of evidence be not receiv'd by philosophy as solid and legitimate; because in that case an argument must have a different force to day, from what it shall have a month hence; yet notwithstanding the opposition of philosophy, 'tis certain, this circumstance has a considerable influence on the understanding, and secretly changes the authority of the same argument, according to the different times, in which it is propos'd to us. A greater force and vivacity in the impression naturally conveys a greater to the related idea; and 'tis on the degrees of force and vivacity, that the belief depends, according to the foregoing system.

所有这些可能性都被哲学家们接受，并被认为是信仰和观点的合理基础。但是，还有一些概率是由同样的原则推导出来的，尽管它们没有幸运地获得同样的认可。这方面的第一个可能性可以这样解释。如上所述，结合和相似性的减弱，减少了过渡的便利性，并通过这种方式削弱了证据；我们还可以进一步观察到，证据的同样减弱将来自于印象的减弱，以及那些颜色的阴影，在这种情况下，它出现在记忆或感官中。我们在记忆中发现的任何事实的论据，都会根据事实的近期或远期而或多或少地具有说服力；尽管这些证据程度的差异不被哲学认为是坚实和合法的；因为在这种情况下，一个论据今天的力量与一个月后的力量肯定是不同的；然而，尽管有哲学的反对，可以肯定的是，这种情况对理解有相当大的影响，并根据不同时期向我们提出的同一论据，秘密地改变它的权威。印象中的力量和活力越大，自然会给相关的观念带来越大的影响；而根据前述体系，信仰取决于力量和活力的程度。

There is a second difference, which we may frequently observe in our degrees of belief and assurance, and which never fails to take place, tho' disclaimed by philosophers. An experiment, that is recent and fresh in the memory, affects us more than one that is in some measure obliterated; and has a superior influence on the judgment, as well as on the passions. A lively impression produces more assurance than a faint one; because it has more original force to communicate to the related idea, which thereby acquires a greater force and vivacity. A recent observation has a like effect; because the custom and transition is there more entire, and preserves better the original force in the communication. Thus a drunkard, who has seen his companion die of a debauch, is struck with that instance for some time, and dreads a like accident for himself: But as the memory of it decays away by degrees, his former security returns, and the danger seems less certain and real. I add, as a third instance of this kind, that tho' our reasonings from proofs and from probabilities be considerably different from each other, yet the former species of reasoning often degenerates insensibly into the latter, by nothing but the multitude of connected arguments. 'Tis certain, that when an inference is drawn immediately from an object, without any intermediate cause or effect, the conviction is much stronger, and the persuasion more lively, than when the imagination is carry'd thro' a long chain of connected arguments, however infallible the connexion of each link may be esteem'd. 'Tis from the original impression, that the vivacity of all the ideas is deriv'd, by means of the customary transition of the imagination; and 'tis evident this vivacity must gradually decay in proportion to the distance, and must lose somewhat in each transition. Sometimes this distance has a greater influence than even contrary experiments wou'd have; and a man may receive a more lively conviction from a probable reasoning, which is close and immediate, than from a long chain of consequences, tho' just and conclusive in each part. Nay 'tis seldom such reasonings produce any conviction; and one must have a very strong and firm imagination to preserve the evidence to the end, where it passes thro' so many stages.

还有一个区别，我们可以在我们的信仰和保证的程度中经常观察到，虽然哲学家们不承认，但这种区别从未发生过。一个最近的、记忆犹新的实验比一个在某种程度上被遗忘的实验对我们的影响更大；而且对判断力和激情的影响也更大。一个生动的印象比一个微弱的印象产生更多的保证；因为它有更多的原始力量传达给相关的想法，从而获得更大的力量和活力。最近的观察也有类似的效果；因为那里的习惯和过渡更完整，而且在交流中更好地保留了原始力量。因此，一个酒鬼，如果看到他的同伴死于酗酒，就会在一段时间内对这个例子感到震惊，并害怕自己发生类似的事故。但随着记忆的逐渐消失，他又恢复了以前的安全感，危险也就显得不那么确定和真实了。我补充说，作为这种情况的第三个例子，尽管我们从证据和概率中进行的推理有很大的不同，但前一种推理往往会不经意地退化成后一种推理，原因无非是众多的关联论据。可以肯定的是，当一个推论是立即从一个对象中得出的，没有任何中间的原因或效果，其说服力要比想象力通过一长串相连的论据时强得多，无论每个环节的联系如何被认为是无懈可击的。所有思想的活力都来自于原始印象，通过想象力的习惯性转换；很明显，这种活力会随着距离的增加而逐渐减弱，并且在每次转换中都会有所损失。有时这种距离的影响甚至比相反的实验还要大；一个人可能从一个近在咫尺的可能推理中得到更生动的信念，而不是从一长串的后果中得到，尽管每一部分都是公正和确凿的。不，这种推理很少能产生任何信念；人们必须有非常强大和坚定的想象力，才能将证据保存到最后，因为它经历了这么多阶段。

But here it may not be amiss to remark a very curious phænomenon, which the present subject suggests to us. 'Tis evident there is no point of ancient history, of which we can have any assurance, but by passing thro' many millions of causes and effects, and thro' a chain of arguments of almost an immeasurable length. Before the knowledge of the fact cou'd come to the first historian, it must be convey'd thro' many mouths; and after it is committed to writing, each new copy is a new object, of which the connexion with the foregoing is known only by experience and observation. Perhaps, therefore, it may be concluded from the precedent reasoning, that the evidence of all ancient history must now be lost; or at least, will be lost in time, as the chain of causes encreases, and runs on to a greater length. But as it seems contrary to common sense to think, that if the republic of letters, and the art of printing continue on the same footing as at present, our posterity, even after a thousand ages, can ever doubt if there has been such a man as Julius Cæsar; this may be consider'd as an objection to the present system. If belief consisted only in a certain vivacity, convey'd from an original impression, it wou'd decay by the length of the transition, and must at last be utterly extinguish'd: And vice versa, if belief on some occasions be not capable of such an extinction; it must be something different from that vivacity.

但在这里，我们不妨说说目前这个问题给我们带来的一个非常奇怪的现象。很明显，在古代历史中，没有任何一点是我们可以确信的，除非是通过数百万个因果关系，以及通过几乎不可估量的论证链。在第一个历史学家了解到这一事实之前，它必须通过许多人的嘴来传达；在它被写成文字之后，每一个新的副本都是一个新的对象，它与前述内容的联系只有通过经验和观察才能知道。因此，也许可以从前面的推理中得出结论，所有古代历史的证据现在必须消失；或者至少会随着时间的推移而消失，因为原因链在不断增加，而且长度也在不断增加。但是，如果字母共和国和印刷术继续保持目前的状态，我们的后人即使在一千多年后也会怀疑是否有朱利叶斯·凯撒这样的人，这种想法似乎有悖于常理；这可以被视为对目前制度的反对。如果信仰只包括从原始印象中传递出来的某种活力，它就会因过渡期的长短而衰败，最后必须彻底消亡。反之亦然，如果信仰在某些情况下不具备这种消亡的能力，它就必须是与这种活力不同的东西。

Before I answer this objection I shall observe, that from this topic there has been borrow'd a very celebrated argument against the Christian Religion; but with this difference, that the connexion betwixt each link of the chain in human testimony has been there suppos'd not to go beyond probability, and to be liable to a degree of doubt and uncertainty. And indeed it must be confest, that in this manner of considering the subject, (which however is not a true one) there is no history or tradition, but what must in the end lose all its force and evidence. Every new probability diminishes the original conviction; and however great that conviction may be suppos'd, 'tis impossible it can subsist under such reiterated diminutions. This is true in general; tho' we shall find 21afterwards, that there is one very memorable exception, which is of vast consequence in the present subject of the understanding.

在回答这个反对意见之前，我想说的是，从这个话题中，有一个非常有名的反对基督教的论据；但有一点不同的是，人类证词中的每一个环节之间的联系在那里被认为是不超过概率的，并有可能受到一定程度的怀疑和不确定性。事实上，必须承认，在这种考虑问题的方式中，（然而这并不是一个真实的方式），没有历史或传统，但最终必须失去所有的力量和证据。每一个新的可能性都会削弱原来的信念；无论这种信念有多大，它都不可能在这种反复的削弱下继续存在下去。这在一般情况下是真的；尽管我们会发现 21之后，我们会发现，有一个非常令人难忘的例外，它对目前的理解主题具有重大影响。

Mean while to give a solution of the preceding objection upon the supposition, that historical evidence amounts at first to an entire proof; let us consider, that tho' the links are innumerable, that connect any original fact with the present impression, which is the foundation of belief; yet they are all of the same kind, and depend on the fidelity of Printers and Copists. One edition passes into another, and that into a third, and so on, till we come to that volume we peruse at present. There is no variation in the steps. After we know one, we know all of them; and after we have made one, we can have no scruple as to the rest. This circumstance alone preserves the evidence of history, and will perpetuate the memory of the present age to the latest posterity. If all the long chain of causes and effects, which connect any past event with any volume of history, were compos'd of parts different from each other, and which 'twere necessary for the mind distinctly to conceive, 'tis impossible we shou'd preserve to the end any belief or evidence. But as most of these proofs are perfectly resembling, the mind runs easily along them, jumps from one part to another with facility, and forms but a confus'd and general notion of each link. By this means a long chain of argument, has as little effect in diminishing the original vivacity, as a much shorter wou'd have, if compos'd of parts, which were different from each other, and of which each requir'd a distinct consideration.

在对前面的反对意见进行解答的同时，假设历史证据首先相当于一个完整的证据；让我们考虑一下，尽管连接任何原始事实和当前印象的环节数不胜数，这是信仰的基础；但它们都是同类的，并且取决于印刷商和复印商的忠诚度。一个版本进入另一个版本，另一个版本进入第三个版本，以此类推，直到我们现在看到的这一卷。这些步骤中没有任何变化。当我们知道一个版本后，我们就知道所有的版本；当我们做了一个版本后，我们就可以毫不顾忌地去做其他的。只有这种情况才能保留历史的证据，并将当代的记忆延续到最近的后世。如果将任何过去的事件与任何一卷历史联系起来的所有长长的因果链，都是由彼此不同的部分组成的，而这些部分是必须由头脑来明确设想的，那么我们就不可能将任何信仰或证据保留到最后。但是，由于这些证明中的大多数都是完全相似的，所以人们的思维很容易沿着它们运行，很容易从一个部分跳到另一个部分，并对每个环节形成一个混乱的和一般的概念。通过这种方式，一长串的论证在减少原来的活力方面所起的作用，就像短得多的论证一样，如果由不同的部分组成，而且每个部分都需要单独考虑的话。

A fourth unphilosophical species of probability is that deriv'd from general rules, which we rashly form to ourselves, and which are the source of what we properly call Prejudice. An Irishman cannot have wit, and a Frenchman cannot have solidity; for which reason, tho' the conversation of the former in any instance be visibly very agreeable, and of the latter very judicious, we have entertain'd such a prejudice against them, that they must be dunces or fops in spite of sense and reason. Human nature is very subject to errors of this kind; and perhaps this nation as much as any other.

第四种非哲学的概率是由一般规则衍生出来的，我们轻率地对自己形成了这些规则，这也是我们正确地称之为偏见的来源。一个爱尔兰人不可能有智慧，一个法国人不可能有稳重；由于这个原因，尽管前者的谈话在任何情况下都明显地非常令人满意，而后者也非常明智，但我们对他们产生了这样一种偏见，认为他们一定是傻瓜或笨蛋，尽管有理智和理性。人性是很容易犯这种错误的；也许这个国家和其他国家一样。

Shou'd it be demanded why men form general rules, and allow them to influence their judgment, even contrary to present observation and experience, I shou'd reply, that in my opinion it proceeds from those very principles, on which all judgments concerning causes and effects depend. Our judgments concerning cause and effect are deriv'd from habit and experience; and when we have been accustom'd to see one object united to another, our imagination passes from the first to the second, by a natural transition, which precedes reflection, and which cannot be prevented by it. Now 'tis the nature of custom not only to operate with its full force, when objects are presented, that are exactly the same with those to which we have been accustom'd; but also to operate in an inferior degree, when we discover such as are similar; and tho' the habit loses somewhat of its force by every difference, yet 'tis seldom entirely destroy'd, where any considerable circumstances remain the same. A man, who has contracted a custom of eating fruit by the use of pears or peaches, will satisfy himself with melons, where he cannot find his favourite fruit; as one, who has become a drunkard by the use of red wines, will be carried almost with the same violence to white, if presented to him. From this principle I have accounted for that species of probability, deriv'd from analogy, where we transfer our experience in past instances to objects which are resembling, but are not exactly the same with those concerning which we have had experience. In proportion as the resemblance decays, the probability diminishes; but still has some force as long as there remain any traces of the resemblance.

如果有人问为什么人们会形成一般的规则，并允许它们影响他们的判断，甚至与目前的观察和经验相反，我会回答说，在我看来，这正是从这些原则出发的，所有关于原因和结果的判断都是基于此。我们对因果的判断来自于习惯和经验；当我们习惯于看到一个物体与另一个物体结合在一起时，我们的想象力就会从第一个物体转移到第二个物体，这是一种自然的过渡，它先于思考，而且不能被思考所阻止。现在，习惯的本质不仅是在出现与我们所习惯的对象完全相同的物体时发挥其全部力量；而且在我们发现类似的物体时，也会在较低的程度上发挥作用；尽管习惯会因每一次的不同而失去一些力量，但在任何相当大的情况保持不变时，很少会被完全摧毁。一个因吃梨或桃子而养成吃水果习惯的人，如果找不到他喜欢的水果，就会用瓜子来满足自己；就像一个因喝红葡萄酒而成为酒鬼的人，如果给他喝白葡萄酒，他几乎会以同样的速度喝下去。根据这一原则，我解释了从类比中得出的那种可能性，即我们把过去的经验转移到与我们有经验的对象相似，但不完全相同的对象上。随着相似性的减弱，概率也随之减弱；但只要还存在相似性的痕迹，就仍有一些力量。

This observation we may carry farther; and may remark, that tho' custom be the foundation of all our judgments, yet sometimes it has an effect on the imagination in opposition to the judgment, and produces a contrariety in our sentiments concerning the same object. I explain myself. In almost all kinds of causes there is a complication of circumstances, of which some are essential, and others superfluous; some are absolutely requisite to the production of the effect, and others are only conjoin'd by accident. Now we may observe, that when these superfluous circumstances are numerous, and remarkable, and frequently conjoin'd with the essential, they have such an influence on the imagination, that even in the absence of the latter they carry us on to the conception of the usual effect, and give to that conception a force and vivacity, which make it superior to the mere fictions of the fancy. We may correct this propensity by a reflection on the nature of those circumstances; but 'tis still certain, that custom takes the start, and gives a biass to the imagination.

我们可以进一步观察；可以说，尽管习俗是我们所有判断的基础，但有时它对想象力的影响与判断相反，并在我们对同一对象的情感中产生矛盾。我自己解释一下。在几乎所有种类的原因中，都有一些复杂的情况，其中有些是必要的，有些是多余的；有些是产生结果的绝对必要条件，有些只是偶然结合起来的。现在我们可以看到，当这些多余的情况很多，而且很突出，并经常与必要的情况结合在一起时，它们对想象力有很大的影响，甚至在没有后者的情况下，它们也会把我们带到通常效果的概念中去，并给这种概念以力量和活力，使它比单纯的幻想的虚构要好。我们可以通过对这些情况的性质进行反思来纠正这种倾向；但仍然可以肯定的是，习俗是开始，并为想象力提供了一个偏向。

To illustrate this by a familiar instance, let us consider the case of a man, who being hung out from a high tower in a cage of iron cannot forbear trembling, when he surveys the precipice below him, tho' he knows himself to be perfectly secure from falling, by his experience of the solidity of the iron, which supports him; and tho' the ideas of fall and descent, and harm and death, be deriv'd solely from custom and experience. The same custom goes beyond the instances, from which it is deriv'd, and to which it perfectly corresponds; and influences his ideas of such objects as are in some respect resembling, but fall not precisely under the same rule. The circumstances of depth and descent strike so strongly upon him, that their influence cannot be destroy'd by the contrary circumstances of support and solidity, which ought to give him a perfect security. His imagination runs away with its object, and excites a passion proportion'd to it. That passion returns back upon the imagination and inlivens the idea; which lively idea has a new influence on the passion, and in its turn augments its force and violence; and both his fancy and affections, thus mutually supporting each other, cause the whole to have a very great influence upon him.

为了用一个熟悉的例子来说明这一点，让我们考虑一个人的情况，他被吊在一个高塔的铁笼子里，当他看到下面的悬崖时，忍不住颤抖起来，尽管他知道自己是完全安全的，不会掉下去，因为他对支撑他的铁的坚固性有经验；尽管坠落和下降、伤害和死亡的观念完全来自习俗和经验。同样的习俗超越了它所衍生的、与之完全对应的实例；并且影响了他对那些在某些方面与之相似、但不完全属于同一规则的物体的想法。深度和下降的情况对他的影响如此强烈，以至于他们的影响不能被相反的支持和稳固的情况所破坏，而这些情况应该给他一个完美的安全感。他的想象力与它的目标背道而驰，并激发出与之相称的激情。这种激情又回到了想象力上，并使思想活跃起来；这种活跃的思想对激情产生了新的影响，反过来又增加了它的力量和暴力；他的幻想和情感，这样相互支持，使整个人对他产生了非常大的影响。

But why need we seek for other instances, while the present subject of [philosophical]22 probabilities offers us so obvious an one, in the opposition betwixt the judgment and imagination arising from these effects of custom? According to my system, all reasonings are nothing but the effects of custom; and custom has no influence, but by in livening the imagination, and giving us a strong conception of any object. It may, therefore, be concluded, that our judgment and imagination can never be contrary, and that custom cannot operate on the latter faculty after such a manner, as to render it opposite to the former. This difficulty we can remove after no other manner, than by supposing the influence of general rules. We shall afterwards take notice of some general rules, by which we ought to regulate our judgment concerning causes and effects; and these rules are form'd on the nature of our understanding, and on our experience of its operations in the judgments we form concerning objects. By them we learn to distinguish the accidental circumstances from the efficacious causes; and when we find that an effect can be produc'd without the concurrence of any particular circumstance, we conclude that that circumstance makes not a part of the efficacious cause, however frequently conjoin'd with it. But as this frequent conjunction necessarily makes it have some effect on the imagination, in spite of the opposite conclusion from general rules, the opposition of these two principles produces a contrariety in our thoughts, and causes us to ascribe the one inference to our judgment, and the other to our imagination. The general rule is attributed to our judgment; as being more extensive and constant. The exception to the imagination; as being more capricious and uncertain.

但是，我们为什么要寻找其他的例子，而目前的哲学主题为我们提供了如此明显的例子。22而现在的哲学概率主题为我们提供了一个如此明显的例子，即由习俗的这些影响所产生的判断力和想象力之间的对抗？根据我的体系，所有的推理都不过是习俗的影响；而习俗除了活跃想象力，让我们对任何物体有强烈的概念外，没有任何影响。因此，可以得出这样的结论：我们的判断力和想象力不可能是相反的，而且习俗不可能以这样的方式对后者的能力产生影响，使其与前者相反。除了假设一般规则的影响外，我们无法以其他方式来消除这一困难。我们随后会注意到一些一般规则，我们应该根据这些规则来规范我们对因果关系的判断；这些规则是根据我们理解力的性质，以及我们在对物体进行判断时的经验形成的。通过这些规则，我们学会了区分偶然的情况和有效的原因；当我们发现一个效果可以在没有任何特定情况下产生时，我们就会得出结论，该情况不属于有效的原因，不管它是如何频繁地与之结合的。但是，由于这种频繁的结合必然使它对想象力产生一些影响，尽管从一般规则得出的结论是相反的，这两个原则的对立在我们的思想中产生了矛盾，使我们把一个推论归于我们的判断，另一个归于我们的想象力。一般的规则被归于我们的判断力；因为它更广泛，更恒定。而想象力则是例外，因为它更加反复无常和不确定。
