Thus our general rules are in a manner set in opposition to each other. When an object appears, that resembles any cause in very considerable circumstances, the imagination naturally carries us to a lively conception of the usual effect, tho' the object be different in the most material and most efficacious circumstances from that cause. Here is the first influence of general rules. But when we take a review of this act of the mind, and compare it with the more general and authentic operations of the understanding, we find it to be of an irregular nature, and destructive of all the most establish'd principles of reasonings; which is the cause of our rejecting it. This is a second influence of general rules, and implies the condemnation of the former. Sometimes the one, sometimes the other prevails, according to the disposition and character of the person. The vulgar are commonly guided by the first, and wise men by the second. Mean while the sceptics may here have the pleasure of observing a new and signal contradiction in our reason, and of seeing all philosophy ready to be subverted by a principle of human nature, and again sav'd by a new direction of the very same principle. The following of general rules is a very unphilosophical species of probability; and yet 'tis only by following them that we can correct this, and all other unphilosophical probabilities.

因此，我们的一般规则在某种程度上是相互对立的。当一个物体出现，并且在非常大的情况下与任何原因相似时，想象力自然会使我们对通常的效果产生生动的概念，尽管该物体在最实质和最有效的情况下与该原因不同。这就是一般规则的第一个影响。但是，当我们审视心灵的这一行为，并将其与理解力的更一般和更真实的操作相比较时，我们发现它具有不规则的性质，并破坏了所有最成熟的推理原则；这就是我们拒绝它的原因。这是一般规则的第二个影响，意味着对前者的谴责。根据人的性情和性格，有时这一种，有时那一种占上风。庸人通常以第一种方式为指导，而智者则以第二种方式为指导。怀疑论者在这里可以很高兴地看到我们的理性中有一个新的、明显的矛盾，看到所有的哲学都准备被人性的一个原则所颠覆，又被同一个原则的一个新的方向所拯救。遵循一般规则是一种非常不符合哲学的概率；然而，只有通过遵循这些规则，我们才能纠正这种概率，以及所有其他不符合哲学的概率。

Since we have instances, where general rules operate on the imagination even contrary to the judgment, we need not be surpriz'd to see their effects encrease, when conjoin'd with that latter faculty, and to observe that they bestow on the ideas they present to us a force superior to what attends any other. Every one knows, there is an indirect manner of insinuating praise or blame, which is much less shocking than the open flattery or censure of any person. However he may communicate his sentiments by such secret insinuations, and make them known with equal certainty as by the open discovery of them, 'tis certain that their influence is not equally strong and powerful. One who lashes me with conceal'd strokes of satire, moves not my indignation to such a degree, as if he flatly told me I was a fool and coxcomb; tho' I equally understand his meaning, as if he did. This difference is to be attributed to the influence of general rules.

既然我们有实例表明，一般规则对想象力的作用甚至与判断力相反，那么我们就不必惊奇地看到，当它们与后一种能力结合在一起时，它们的作用就会增强，并注意到它们给我们提出的想法赋予了一种比任何其他能力更强的力量。每个人都知道，有一种间接的方式来暗示赞美或指责，这比公开的奉承或指责任何人都要少得多。无论他如何通过这种秘密的影射来传达他的情感，并以同样的确定性使之与公开的发现相提并论，"可以肯定的是，其影响并不同样强烈和有力。一个人用隐蔽的讽刺笔触抽打我，不会像他直截了当地告诉我我是个傻瓜和笨蛋那样引起我的愤怒；尽管我同样明白他的意思，就像他明白一样。这种差异应归因于一般规则的影响。

Whether a person openly abuses me, or slyly intimates his contempt, in neither case do I immediately perceive his sentiment or opinion; and 'tis only by signs, that is, by its effects, I become sensible of it. The only difference, then, betwixt these two cases consists in this, that in the open discovery of his sentiments he makes use of signs, which are general and universal; and in the secret-intimation employs such as are more singular and uncommon. The effect of this circumstance is, that the imagination, in running from the present impression to the absent idea, makes the transition with greater facility, and consequently conceives the object with greater force, where the connexion is common and universal, than where it is more rare and particular. Accordingly we may observe, that the open declaration of our sentiments is call'd the taking off the mask, as the secret intimation of our opinions is said to be the veiling of them. The difference betwixt an idea produc'd by a general connexion, and that arising from a particular one is here compar'd to the difference betwixt an impression and an idea. This difference in the imagination has a suitable effect on the passions; and this effect is augmented by another circumstance. A secret intimation of anger or contempt shews that we still have some consideration for the person, and avoid the directly abusing him. This makes a conceal'd satire less disagreeable; but still this depends on the same principle. For if an idea were not more feeble, when only intimated, it wou'd never be esteem'd a mark of greater respect to proceed in this method than in the other.

无论一个人是公开辱骂我，还是狡猾地暗示他的蔑视，在这两种情况下，我都不会立即察觉到他的情绪或观点；只有通过迹象，即通过其效果，我才会感觉到它。那么，这两种情况之间的唯一区别在于，在公开发现他的情绪时，他使用的是一般的和普遍的迹象；而在秘密暗示中，他使用的是更奇特和不常见的迹象。这种情况的影响是，想象力在从现在的印象到不存在的想法的过程中，会更方便地进行转换，因此，在联系是普通和普遍的情况下，比在更罕见和特殊的情况下，会更有力地构想出目标。因此，我们可以看到，公开宣布我们的情感被称为摘下面具，就像秘密暗示我们的观点被说成是对它们的遮掩。由一般联系产生的想法和由特定联系产生的想法之间的区别，在这里被比作印象和想法之间的区别。这种想象力上的差异对激情有适当的影响；而这种影响又因另一种情况而增加。愤怒或蔑视的秘密暗示表明，我们仍然对这个人有一些考虑，避免直接辱骂他。这使得隐蔽的讽刺不那么令人不快；但这仍然取决于同一原则。因为如果一个想法在暗示的时候不是更微弱的话，那么用这种方法比用另一种方法进行就不会被认为是更大的尊重。

Sometimes scurrility is less displeasing than delicate satire, because it revenges us in a manner for the injury at the very time it is committed, by affording us a just reason to blame and contemn the person, who injures us. But this phænomenon likewise depends upon the same principle. For why do we blame all gross and injurious language, unless it be, because we esteem it contrary to good breeding and humanity? And why is it contrary, unless it be more shocking than any delicate satire? The rules of good-breeding condemn whatever is openly disobliging, and gives a sensible pain and confusion to those, with whom we converse. After this is once establish'd, abusive language is universally blam'd, and gives less pain upon account of its coarseness and incivility, which render the person despicable, that employs it. It becomes less disagreeable, merely because originally it is more so; and 'tis more disagreeable, because it affords an inference by general and common rules, that are palpable and undeniable.

有时，无赖比精致的讽刺更令人不快，因为它在伤害发生时就以某种方式报复了我们，为我们提供了责备和谴责伤害我们的人的正当理由。但这一现象也同样取决于同一原则。因为我们为什么要指责所有粗暴和伤害性的语言，除非是我们认为它违反了良好的教养和人性？除非它比任何微妙的讽刺更令人震惊，否则为什么它是违背的呢？良好教养的规则谴责任何公开的不体面的东西，并给那些与我们交谈的人带来明显的痛苦和混乱。一旦确立了这一点，辱骂性的语言就会受到普遍的指责，而且由于其粗俗和不礼貌，使使用它的人变得卑鄙，从而减少了痛苦。它变得不那么令人讨厌了，只是因为它本来就比较讨厌；而它更令人讨厌，是因为它通过一般和普通的规则提供了一种推论，而这种推论是明显的和不可否认的。

To this explication of the different influence of open and conceal'd flattery or satire, I shall add the consideration of another phænomenon, which is analogous to it. There are many particulars in the point of honour both of men and women, whose violations, when open and avow'd, the world never excuses, but which it is more apt to overlook, when the appearances are sav'd, and the transgression is secret and conceal'd. Even those, who know with equal certainty, that the fault is committed, pardon it more easily, when the proofs seem in some measure oblique and equivocal, than when they are direct and undeniable. The same idea is presented in both cases, and, properly speaking, is equally assented to by the judgment; and yet its influence is different, because of the different manner, in which it is presented. Now if we compare these two cases, of the open and conceal'd violations of the laws of honour, we shall find, that the difference betwixt them consists in this, that in the first case the sign, from which we infer the blameable action, is single, and suffices alone to be the foundation of our reasoning and judgment; whereas in the latter the signs are numerous, and decide little or nothing when alone and unaccompany'd with many minute circumstances, which are almost imperceptible. But 'tis certainly true, that any reasoning is always the more convincing, the more single and united it is to the eye, and the less exercise it gives to the imagination to collect all its parts, and run from them to the correlative idea, which forms the conclusion. The labour of the thought disturbs the regular progress of the sentiments, as we shall observe presently. The idea strikes not on us with such vivacity; and consequently has no such influence on the passion and imagination.

在阐述了公开和隐蔽的奉承或讽刺的不同影响之后，我还要考虑另一个与之相似的现象。在男人和女人的荣誉问题上，有许多细节，当他们的违法行为被公开宣布时，世界不会原谅他们，但当表面上被拯救，而违法行为被秘密隐藏时，他们更容易忽视。即使是那些同样肯定地知道犯有过错的人，当证据在某种程度上似乎是斜的和含糊的时候，也比直接和不可否认的时候更容易原谅它。在这两种情况下，都提出了同样的观点，而且，正确地说，同样得到了判决的认可；但由于提出的方式不同，其影响也不同。现在，如果我们比较这两种情况，即公开和隐蔽地违反荣誉法的情况，我们会发现，它们之间的区别在于：在第一种情况下，我们据以推断应受谴责的行为的迹象是单一的，仅此就足以成为我们推理和判断的基础；而在第二种情况下，迹象是众多的，当单独和没有与许多细微的情况相伴，几乎无法决定什么。但是，毫无疑问，任何推理总是越有说服力，对眼睛来说越是单一和统一的，越是不需要想象力去收集它的所有部分，并从它们跑到相关的想法，从而形成结论。思想的劳作扰乱了情感的正常发展，我们将在下文中看到这一点。思想对我们的冲击没有那么大，因此对激情和想象力没有那么大的影响。

From the same principles we may account for those observations of the Cardinal de Retz, that there are many things, in which the world wishes to be deceiv'd; and that it more easily excuses a person in acting than in talking contrary to the decorum of his profession and character.. A fault in words is commonly more open and distinct than one in actions, which admit of many palliating excuses, and decide not so clearly concerning the intention and views of the actor.

根据同样的原则，我们可以解释雷兹枢机主教的那些意见，即有许多事情，世界希望被欺骗；而且，它更容易原谅一个人的行为，而不是违反其职业和性格的礼仪的谈话。言语上的过错通常比行动上的过错更公开、更明显，因为行动上的过错可以有很多缓和的借口，而且对行为人的意图和观点的判断也不那么明确。

Thus it appears upon the whole, that every kind of opinion or judgment, which amounts not to knowledge, is deriv'd entirely from the force and vivacity of the perception, and that these qualities constitute in the mind, what we call the belief of the existence of any object. This force and this vivacity are most conspicuous in the memory; and therefore our confidence in the veracity of that faculty is the greatest imaginable, and equals in many respects the assurance of a demonstration. The next degree of these qualities is that deriv'd from the relation of cause and effect; and this too is very great, especially when the conjunction is found by experience to be perfectly constant, and when the object, which is present to us, exactly resembles those, of which we have had experience. But below this degree of evidence there are many others, which have an influence on the passions and imagination, proportion'd to that degree of force and vivacity, which they communicate to the ideas. 'Tis by habit we make the transition from cause to effect; and 'tis from some present impression we borrow that vivacity, which we diffuse over the correlative idea. But when we have not observ'd a sufficient number of instances, to produce a strong habit; or when these instances are contrary to each other; or when the resemblance is not exact; or the present impression is faint and obscure; or the experience in some measure obliterated from the memory; or the connexion dependent on a long chain of objects; or the inference deriv'd from general rules, and yet not conformable to them: In all these cases the evidence diminishes by the diminution of the force and in tenseness of the idea. This therefore is the nature of the judgment and probability.

因此，从整体上看，每一种不属于知识的意见或判断，都完全来自于感知的力量和活力，而这些品质在头脑中构成了我们所说的对任何物体存在的信念。这种力量和活力在记忆中最为明显；因此，我们对这种能力的真实性的信心是可以想象的最大的，在许多方面等同于证明的保证。这些品质的下一个程度是由因果关系派生出来的；这也是非常大的，特别是当经验发现这种结合是完全恒定的，以及当呈现在我们面前的对象与我们有经验的对象完全相似的时候。但是，在这种程度的证据之下，还有许多其他的证据，它们对激情和想象力的影响，与它们传递给观念的力量和活力的程度成正比。我们是通过习惯来实现从因到果的过渡的；我们是从一些当前的印象中借来的活力，我们把它散布在相关的想法上。但是，当我们没有观察到足够多的实例，以产生强烈的习惯时；或者当这些实例彼此相反时；或者当相似性不确切时；或者目前的印象是微弱和模糊的；或者经验在某种程度上从记忆中被抹去了；或者这种联系取决于一长串的对象；或者推论来自一般规则，但又不符合它们。在所有这些情况下，证据都会因思想的力量和紧张程度的减弱而减少。因此，这就是判断和概率的本质。

What principally gives authority to this system is, beside the undoubted arguments, upon which each part is founded, the agreement of these parts, and the necessity of one to explain another. The belief, which attends our memory, is of the same nature with that, which is deriv'd from our judgments: Nor is there any difference betwixt that judgment, which is deriv'd from a constant and uniform connexion of causes and effects, and that which depends upon an interrupted and uncertain. 'Tis indeed evident, that in all determinations, where the mind decides from contrary experiments, 'tis first divided within itself, and has an inclination to either side in proportion to the number of experiments we have seen and remember. This contest is at last determin'd to the advantage of that side, where we observe a superior number of these experiments; but still with a diminution of force in the evidence correspondent to the number of the opposite experiments. Each possibility, of which the probability is compos'd, operates separately upon the imagination; and 'tis the larger collection of possibilities, which at last prevails, and that with a force proportionable to its superiority. All these phænomena lead directly to the precedent system; nor will it ever be possible upon any other principles to give a satisfactory and consistent explication of them. Without considering these judgments as the effects of custom on the imagination, we shall lose ourselves in perpetual contradiction and absurdity.

除了每个部分所依据的毋庸置疑的论据之外，这个体系的主要权威在于这些部分的一致，以及一个部分解释另一个部分的必要性。伴随着我们的记忆而产生的信念，与我们的判断而产生的信念具有相同的性质。从恒定而统一的因果关系中得出的判断，与取决于间断而不确定的判断，两者之间也没有任何区别。的确很明显，在所有的决定中，当心灵从相反的实验中作出决定时，它首先在自己内部分裂，并根据我们所看到和记住的实验的数量而倾向于任何一方。这种争论最后被确定为对我们观察到的这些实验数量较多的那一方有利；但证据中的力量仍会随着相反的实验数量而减少。每一种可能性，即概率的组成，都分别作用于想象力；而最终占上风的是更大的可能性集合，其力量与它的优势成正比。所有这些现象都直接导致了先例系统；根据任何其他原则，也不可能对它们作出令人满意和一致的解释。如果不把这些判断看作是习俗对想象力的影响，我们就会在永恒的矛盾和荒谬中迷失自己。

 

Section 14. Of The Idea Of Necessary Connexion

第 14 节。关于必要的联系的概念

 

Having thus explain'd the manner, in which we reason beyond our immediate impressions, and conclude that such particular causes must have such particular effects; we must now return upon our footsteps to examine that question, which first occur'd to us, and which we dropt in our way, viz. What is our idea of necessity, when we say that two objects are necessarily connected together. Upon this head I repeat what I have often had occasion to observe, that as we have no idea, that is not deriv'd from an impression, we must find some impression, that gives rise to this idea of necessity, if we assert we have really such an idea. In order to this I consider, in what objects necessity is commonly suppos'd to lie; and finding that it is always ascrib'd to causes and effects, I turn my eye to two objects suppos'd to be plac'd in that relation; and examine them in all the situations, of which they are susceptible. I immediately perceive, that they are contiguous in time and place, and that the object we call cause precedes the other we call effect. In no one instance can I go any farther, nor is it possible for me to discover any third relation betwixt these objects. I therefore enlarge my view to comprehend several instances; where I find like objects always existing in like relations of contiguity and succession. At first sight this seems to serve but little to my purpose. The reflection on several instances only repeats the same objects; and therefore can never give rise to a new idea. But upon farther enquiry I find, that the repetition is not in every particular the same, but produces a new impression, and by that means the idea, which I at present examine. For after a frequent repetition, I find, that upon the appearance of one of the objects, the mind is determin'd by custom to consider its usual attendant, and to consider it in a stronger light upon account of its relation to the first object. 'Tis this impression, then, or determination, which affords me the idea of necessity.

在这样解释了我们如何超越我们的直接印象进行推理，并得出这样的特殊原因必须产生这样的特殊效果的结论之后，我们现在必须回到我们的脚步，来研究那个最初发生在我们身上的、我们在路上掉下来的问题，即：当我们说两个物体必然联系在一起时，我们的必然性概念是什么 。 在这个问题上，我重复了我经常观察到的情况，即由于我们没有不是由印象派生出来的观念，如果我们断言我们真的有这样一个观念，我们就必须找到一些印象，以引起这种必然性的观念。为了达到这个目的，我考虑了一下，人们通常认为必然性存在于哪些物体中；发现它总是被赋予原因和结果，我把目光转向两个被认为处于这种关系中的物体；并在它们可能出现的所有情况下对它们进行检查。我立即意识到，它们在时间和地点上是相邻的，而且我们称之为因的对象先于我们称之为果的对象。在任何一种情况下，我都不能走得更远，也不可能发现这些对象之间的任何第三种关系。因此，我把我的观点扩大到包括几个实例；在这些实例中，我发现类似的对象总是以类似的相邻和相继关系存在。乍一看，这似乎对我的目的没有什么作用。对几个例子的思考只是重复相同的对象，因此永远不会产生新的想法。但经过进一步的调查，我发现，这种重复并不是在每一个细节上都是相同的，而是产生了一种新的印象，并通过这种方式产生了我现在要研究的想法。因为在频繁的重复之后，我发现，当其中一个物体出现时，人们的头脑会因习惯而决定考虑其通常的伴随物，并因其与第一个物体的关系而考虑其更强的光线。那么，正是这种印象，或者说决定，给我带来了必然性的概念。

I doubt not but these consequences will at first sight be receiv'd without difficulty, as being evident deductions from principles, which we have already establish'd, and which we have often employ'd in our reasonings. This evidence both in the first principles, and in the deductions, may seduce us unwarily into the conclusion, and make us imagine it contains nothing extraordinary, nor worthy of our curiosity. But tho' such an inadvertence may facilitate the reception of this reasoning, 'twill make it be the more easily forgot; for which reason I think it proper to give warning, that I have just now examin'd one of the most sublime questions in philosophy, viz. that concerning the power and efficacy of causes; where all the sciences seem so much interested. Such a warning will naturally rouze up the attention of the reader, and make him desire a more full account of my doctrine, as well as of the arguments, on which it is founded. This request is so reasonable, that I cannot refuse complying with it; especially as I am hopeful that these principles, the more they are examin'd, will acquire the more force and evidence.

我不怀疑，这些结果乍一看会毫无困难地被接受，因为它们是从我们已经确立的、并且在我们的推理中经常使用的原则中明显推导出来的。这种证据，无论是在最初的原则中，还是在推论中，都可能不经意地引诱我们进入结论，并使我们认为它没有什么特别之处，也不值得我们好奇。但是，尽管这样的疏忽可能有助于我们接受这种推理，但也会使我们更容易忘记它；为此，我认为应该提出警告，我刚刚研究了哲学中最崇高的问题之一，即关于原因的力量和效力的问题；所有科学似乎都对这个问题很感兴趣。这样的警告自然会引起读者的注意，并使他希望对我的学说以及它所依据的论据有一个更全面的说明。这个要求是如此合理，以至于我不能拒绝满足它；尤其是我希望这些原则，越是被研究，就越能获得力量和证据。

There is no question, which on account of its importance, as well as difficulty, has caus'd more disputes both among antient and modern philosophers, than this concerning the efficacy of causes, or that quality which makes them be followed by their effects. But before they enter'd upon these disputes, methinks it wou'd not have been improper to have examin'd what idea we have of that efficacy, which is the subject of the controversy. This is what I find principally wanting in their reasonings, and what I shall here endeavour to supply.

在古代和现代的哲学家中，没有一个问题因为其重要性和难度而引起更多的争论，那就是关于原因的效力，或者说使它们被其结果所追随的那种品质。但在他们进入这些争论之前，我想如果能研究一下我们对这一功效的看法，也就是争论的主题，也不会有什么不妥。这就是我发现他们的推理中主要缺乏的东西，而我将在此努力提供。

I begin with observing that the terms of efficacy, agency, power, force, energy, necessity, connexion, and productive quality, are all nearly synonymous; and therefore 'tis an absurdity to employ any of them in defining the rest. By this observation we reject at once all the vulgar definitions, which philosophers have given of power and efficacy; and instead of searching for the idea in these definitions, must look for it in the impressions, from which it is originally deriv'd. If it be a compound idea, it must arise from compound impressions. If simple, from simple impressions.

我首先指出，功效、机构、权力、力量、能量、必要性、联系和生产质量等术语几乎都是同义词；因此，用其中任何一个术语来定义其余术语都是荒谬的。通过这一观察，我们立即拒绝了哲学家们对权力和效力的所有庸俗定义；与其在这些定义中寻找概念，不如在它最初衍生的印象中寻找它。如果它是一个复合的概念，它必须从复合的印象中产生。如果是简单的，就是从简单的印象中产生的。

I believe the most general and most popular explication of this matter, is to say, 23 that finding from experience, that there are several new productions in matter, such as the motions and variations of body, and concluding that there must somewhere be a power capable of producing them, we arrive at last by this reasoning at the idea of power and efficacy. But to be convinc'd that this explication is more popular than philosophical, we need but reflect on two very obvious principles. First, That reason alone can never give rise to any original idea, and secondly, that reason, as distinguish'd from experience, can never make us conclude, that a cause or productive quality is absolutely requisite to every beginning of existence. Both these considerations have been sufficiently explain'd; and therefore shall not at present be any farther insisted on.

我相信，对这一问题的最普遍和最流行的解释是说。23从经验中发现，在物质中存在一些新的产物，如身体的运动和变化，并得出结论，在某处必须有一种能够产生这些产物的力量，我们通过这种推理最后得出了力量和功效的概念。但是，为了让人相信这种解释是流行的而不是哲学的，我们只需要思考两个非常明显的原则。第一，仅凭理性永远不会产生任何原创性的想法，第二，理性与经验的区别，永远不能使我们得出结论，即每一个存在的开始都绝对需要一个原因或生产性的质量。这两点已经得到了充分的解释；因此，目前不应继续坚持下去。

I shall only infer from them, that since reason can never give rise to the idea of efficacy, that idea must be deriv'd from experience, and from some particular instances of this efficacy, which make their passage into the mind by the common channels of sensation or reflection. Ideas always represent their objects or impressions; and vice versa, there are some objects necessary to give rise to every idea. If we pretend, therefore, to have any just idea of this efficacy, we must produce some instance, wherein the efficacy is plainly discoverable to the mind, and its operations obvious to our consciousness or sensation. By the refusal of this, we acknowledge, that the idea is impossible and imaginary; since the principle of innate ideas, which alone can save us from this dilemma, has been already refuted, and is now almost universally rejected in the learned world. Our present business, then, must be to find some natural production, where the operation and efficacy of a cause can be clearly conceiv'd and comprehended by the mind, without any danger of obscurity or mistake.

我只想从它们中推断出，既然理性永远不可能产生功效的概念，那么这种概念就必须从经验和这种功效的某些特定实例中获得，这些实例通过感觉或思考的普通渠道进入心灵。观念总是代表它们的对象或印象；反之亦然，有一些对象是产生每个观念所必需的。因此，如果我们假装对这种效力有任何公正的看法，我们就必须提出一些例子，在这些例子中，这种效力对心灵来说是明显可以发现的，其作用对我们的意识或感觉来说也是明显的。如果拒绝这样做，我们就承认，这种想法是不可能的，是虚构的；因为只有先天观念的原则才能把我们从这种困境中解救出来，它已经被驳倒了，而且现在在学术界几乎被普遍拒绝。那么，我们目前的任务必须是找到一些自然的产物，在那里，一个原因的运作和效力可以被头脑清楚地设想和理解，而没有任何模糊或错误的危险。

In this research we meet with very little encouragement from that prodigious diversity, which is found in the opinions of those philosophers, who have pretended to explain the secret force and energy of causes24. There are some, who maintain, that bodies operate by their substantial form; others, by their accidents or qualities; several, by their matter and form; some, by their form and accidents; others, by certain virtues and faculties distinct from all this. All these sentiments again are mix'd and vary'd in a thousand different ways; and form a strong presumption, that none of them have any solidity or evidence. and that the supposition of an efficacy in any of the known qualities of matter is entirely without foundation. This presumption must encrease upon us, when we consider, that these principles of substantial forms, and accidents, and faculties, are not in reality any of the known properties of bodies, but are perfectly unintelligible and inexplicable. For 'tis evident philosophers wou'd never have had recourse to such obscure and uncertain principles had they met with any satisfaction in such as are clear and intelligible; especially in such an affair as this, which must be an object of the simplest understanding, if not of the senses. Upon the whole, we may conclude, that 'tis impossible in any one instance to shew the principle, in which the force and agency of a cause is plac'd; and that the most refin'd and most vulgar understandings are equally at a loss in this particular. If any one think proper to refute this assertion, he need not put himself to the trouble of inventing any long reasonings; but may at once shew us an instance of a cause, where we discover the power or operating principle. This defiance we are oblig'd frequently to make use of as being almost the only means of proving a negative in philosophy.

在这项研究中，我们几乎没有从那些哲学家的意见中得到什么鼓励，这些哲学家假装解释原因的秘密力量和能量，他们的意见也是如此。24. 有一些人坚持认为，身体的运作是通过它们的实质形式；另一些人则是通过它们的意外或质量；一些人则是通过它们的物质和形式；一些人则是通过它们的形式和意外；另一些人则是通过与所有这些不同的某些美德和能力。所有这些观点又以千变万化的方式混合在一起，并形成了一个强有力的假设，即它们都没有任何坚实的证据，而且在任何已知的物质质量中假设功效是完全没有根据的。当我们考虑到这些实质性的形式、事故和能力的原则实际上并不是身体的任何已知属性，而是完全无法理解和无法解释的时候，这种推测必须在我们身上得到加强。因为显而易见，如果哲学家们对清晰易懂的原则感到满意，他们就不会求助于这种晦涩难懂的原则；尤其是在这样一个问题上，如果不是感官的问题，也必须是最简单的理解的对象。总的来说，我们可以得出这样的结论：在任何一个例子中，都不可能说明一个原因的力量和作用的原理；在这个问题上，最精致的和最庸俗的理解力都是一样的。如果有人认为应该反驳这一论断，他不需要费力地编造任何冗长的推理；而是可以立即向我们展示一个原因的例子，在那里我们发现了力量或作用原理。我们不得不经常使用这种抗辩，因为这几乎是哲学中证明否定的唯一手段。

The small success, which has been met with in all the attempts to fix this power, has at last oblig'd philosophers to conclude, that the ultimate force and efficacy of nature is perfectly unknown to us, and that 'tis in vain we search for it in all the known qualities of matter. In this opinion they are almost unanimous; and 'tis only in the inference they draw from it, that they discover any difference in their sentiments. For some of them, as the Cartesians in particular, having establish'd it as a principle, that we are perfectly acquainted with the essence of matter, have very naturally inferr'd, that it is endow'd with no efficacy, and that 'tis impossible for it of itself to communicate motion, or produce any of those effects, which we ascribe to it. As the essence of matter consists in extension, and as extension implies not actual motion, but only mobility; they conclude, that the energy, which produces the motion, cannot lie in the extension.

所有试图确定这种力量的努力都取得了小小的成功，最后迫使哲学家们得出结论，自然界的最终力量和功效对我们来说是完全未知的，我们在所有已知的物质质量中寻找它是徒劳的。在这个观点上，他们几乎是一致的；只是在他们从中得出的推论中，他们才发现自己的情感有任何不同。因为他们中的一些人，特别是笛卡尔派，在确立了我们完全了解物质的本质这一原则后，很自然地推断出，物质没有任何功效，而且它本身不可能传递运动，也不可能产生我们归因于它的任何效果。由于物质的本质是延伸，而延伸并不意味着实际的运动，而只是流动性；他们的结论是，产生运动的能量不可能存在于延伸之中。

This conclusion leads them into another, which they regard as perfectly unavoidable. Matter, say they, is in itself entirely unactive, and depriv' d of any power, by which it may produce, or continue, or communicate motion: But since these effects are evident to our senses, and since the power, that produces them, must be plac'd somewhere, it must lie in the Deity, or that divine being, who contains in his nature all excellency and perfection. 'Tis the deity, therefore, who is the prime mover of the universe, and who not only first created matter, and gave it it's original impulse, but likewise by a continu'd exertion of omnipotence, supports its existence, and successively bestows on it all those motions, and configurations, and qualities, with which it is endow'd.

这个结论将他们引向另一个结论，他们认为这个结论是完全不可避免的。他们说，物质本身是完全没有活性的，而且被剥夺了任何可以产生、持续或传递运动的力量。但是，既然这些效果对我们的感官来说是显而易见的，而且既然产生这些效果的力量必须放在某个地方，那么它必须在神性中，或者在那个神圣的存在中，他的本性中包含了所有的卓越和完美。因此，神是宇宙的主要推动者，他不仅首先创造了物质，给了它最初的动力，而且还通过不断地发挥全能，支持它的存在，并相继赋予它所有的运动、构造和品质，这是它被赋予的。

This opinion is certainly very curious, and well worth our attention; but 'twill appear superfluous to examine it in this place, if we reflect a moment on our present purpose in taking notice of it. We have establish'd it as a principle, that as all ideas are deriv'd from impressions, or some precedent perceptions, 'tis impossible we can have any idea of power and efficacy, unless some instances can be produc'd, wherein this power is perceiv'd to exert itself. Now as these instances can never be discover'd in body, the Cartesians, proceeding upon their principle of innate ideas, have had recourse to a supreme spirit or deity, whom they consider as the only active being in the universe, and as the immediate cause of every alteration in matter. But the principle of innate ideas being allow'd to be false, it follows, that the supposition of a deity can serve us in no stead, in accounting for that idea of agency, which we search for in vain in all the objects, which are presented to our senses, or which we are internally conscious of in our own minds. For if every idea be deriv'd from an impression, the idea of a deity proceeds from the same origin; and if no impression, either of sensation or reflection, implies any force or efficacy, 'tis equally impossible to discover or even imagine any such active principle in the deity. Since these philosophers, therefore, have concluded, that matter cannot be endow'd with any efficacious principle, because 'tis impossible to discover in it such a principle; the same course of reasoning shou'd determine them to exclude it from the supreme being. Or if they estem that opinion absurd and impious, as it really is, I shall tell them how they may avoid it; and that is, by concluding from the very first, that they have no adequate idea of power or efficacy in any object; since neither in body nor spirit, neither in superior nor inferior natures, are they able to discover one single instance of it.

这个观点当然非常有趣，很值得我们注意；但如果我们思考一下我们现在注意它的目的，就会发现在这个地方研究它是多余的。我们已经把它确立为一项原则，即由于所有的观念都来自于印象，或者一些先验的感知，所以我们不可能有任何关于力量和效力的观念，除非能够产生一些实例，在这些实例中，这种力量被感知到发挥其作用。现在，由于这些实例在身体中永远无法发现，笛卡尔派根据他们的先天观念原则，不得不求助于一个最高的精神或神灵，他们认为他是宇宙中唯一活跃的存在，也是物质中每一个变化的直接原因。但是，既然先天观念的原则被认为是错误的，那么，关于神性的假设就不能为我们提供任何帮助，以说明我们在所有呈现给我们感官的物体中，或者在我们自己的头脑中内在意识到的物体中徒劳无功地寻找这种作用的观念。因为如果每个观念都来自于印象，那么神性的观念也来自于同样的起源；如果没有任何印象，无论是感觉还是思考，都意味着任何力量或效力，那么同样不可能在神性中发现或甚至想象出任何这样的活动原则。因此，既然这些哲学家已经得出结论，物质不可能被赋予任何有效的原则，因为不可能在其中发现这样的原则；同样的推理过程应该决定他们把它从最高的存在中排除。如果他们认为这种观点是荒谬和不敬的，因为它确实如此，我将告诉他们如何避免它；那就是，从一开始就得出结论，他们在任何物体中都没有足够的权力或效力的概念；因为无论是在身体还是精神，无论是在高级还是低级的性质，他们都无法发现它的一个实例。

The same conclusion is unavoidable upon the hypothesis of those, who maintain the efficacy of second causes, and attribute a derivative, but a real power and energy to matter. For as they confess, that this energy lies not in any of the known qualities of matter, the difficulty still remains concerning the origin of its idea. If we have really an idea of power, we may attribute power to an unknown quality: But as 'tis impossible, that that idea can be deriv'd from such a quality, and as there is nothing in known qualities, which can produce it; it follows that we deceive ourselves, when we imagine we are possest of any idea of this kind, after the manner we commonly understand it. All ideas are deriv'd from, and represent impressions. We never have any impression, that contains any power or efficacy. We never therefore have any idea of power.

同样的结论在那些坚持第二原因的功效，并将一种派生的、但真正的力量和能量归于物质的人的假设中是不可避免的。因为他们承认，这种能量并不存在于任何已知的物质品质中，所以关于其观念的起源，困难仍然存在。如果我们真的有一个力量的概念，我们可以把力量归于一个未知的质量。但是，由于这种观念不可能从这种质量中衍生出来，而且在已知的质量中没有任何东西可以产生这种观念；因此，当我们想象我们拥有这种观念的时候，我们是在欺骗自己，按照我们通常的理解方式。所有的观念都是由印象派生出来的，并代表印象。我们从来没有任何印象，包含任何权力或效力。因此，我们从来没有任何权力的概念。

It has been establish'd as a certain principle, that general or abstract ideas are nothing but individual ones taken in a certain light, and that, in effecting on any object, 'tis as impossible to exclude from our thought all particular degrees of quantity and quality as from the real nature of things. If we be possest, therefore, of any idea of power in general, we must also be able to conceive some particular species of it; and as power cannot subsist alone, but is always regarded as an attribute of some being or existence, we must be able to place this power in some particular being, and conceive that being as endow'd with a real force and energy, by which such a particular effect necessarily results from its operation. We must distinctly and particularly conceive the connexion betwixt the cause and effect, and be able to pronounce, from a simple view of the one, that it must be follow'd or preceded by the other. This is the true manner of conceiving a particular power in a particular body: and a general idea being impossible without an individual; where the latter is impossible, 'tis certain the former can never exist. Now nothing is more evident, than that the human mind cannot form such an idea of two objects, as to conceive any connexion betwixt them, or comprehend distinctly that power or efficacy, by which they are united. Such a connexion wou'd amount to a demonstration, and wou'd imply the absolute impossibility for the one object not to follow, or to be conceiv'd not to follow upon the other: Which kind of connexion has already been rejected in all cases. If any one is of a contrary opinion, and thinks he has attain'd a notion of power in any particular object, I desire he may point out to me that object. But till I meet with such-a-one, which I despair of, I cannot forbear concluding, that since we can never distinctly conceive how any particular power can possibly reside in any particular object, we deceive ourselves in imagining we can form any such general idea.

作为一项确定的原则，一般的或抽象的观念只不过是在某种意义上的个别观念，而且在对任何物体施加影响时，不可能从我们的思想中排除所有数量和质量的特定程度，就像从事物的真实性质中排除一样。因此，如果我们拥有关于一般力量的任何概念，我们也必须能够设想出它的某些特定种类；由于力量不能单独存在，而总是被视为某种存在或存在的属性，我们必须能够将这种力量置于某种特定的存在之中，并设想该存在被赋予一种真正的力量和能量，通过它的运作必然产生这样一种特定的效果。我们必须明确地、特别地构想出原因和结果之间的联系，并且能够从一个简单的观点中宣布，它必须由另一个跟随或在前。这就是在一个特定的身体中设想一种特定的力量的真正方式：没有个体就不可能有一般的想法；如果后者不可能，那么可以肯定前者就永远不会存在。现在最明显的是，人的头脑无法对两个物体形成这样的概念，以至于无法想象它们之间的任何联系，也无法清楚地理解它们所结合的力量或效力。这种联系相当于一种证明，并意味着一个物体绝对不可能不跟随，或被认为不跟随另一个物体。这种联系在所有情况下都已被拒绝。如果有人持相反意见，认为他在任何特定对象中达到了权力的概念，我希望他能向我指出那个对象。但是，在我遇到这样的人之前（我对这一点感到绝望），我不能不得出这样的结论：既然我们永远无法明确地设想任何特定的权力如何可能存在于任何特定的物体中，那么我们想象我们能够形成任何这样的一般概念就是自欺欺人。

Thus upon the whole we may infer, that when we talk of any being, whether of a superior or inferior nature, as endow'd with a power or force, proportion'd to any effect; when we speak of a necessary connexion betwixt objects, and suppose, that this connexion depends upon an efficacy or energy, with which any of these objects are endow'd; in all these expressions, so applied, we have really no distinct meaning, and make use only of common words, without any clear and determinate ideas. But as 'tis more probable, that these expressions do here lose their true meaning by being wrong apply'd, than that they never have any meaning; 'twill be proper to bestow another consideration on this subject, to see if possibly we can discover the nature and origin of those ideas, we annex to them.

因此，总的来说，我们可以推断，当我们谈论任何存在，无论其性质是高是低，都被赋予了某种力量，与任何效果相称；当我们谈论物体之间的必然联系，并假设这种联系取决于这些物体中的任何一个被赋予的功效或能量；在所有这些表达中，如此应用，我们实际上没有明确的意义，只是使用了普通的词汇，没有任何清晰和确定的想法。但是，由于这些表达方式由于被错误地应用而失去了它们的真正含义，这比它们从来没有任何含义更有可能；我们应该对这个问题进行另一种考虑，看看我们是否可以发现我们附在它们身上的那些想法的性质和来源。

Suppose two objects to be presented to us, of which the one is the cause and the other the effect; 'tis plain, that from the simple consideration of one, or both these objects we never shall perceive the tie, by which they are united, or be able certainly to pronounce, that there is a connexion betwixt them. 'Tis not, therefore, from any one instance, that we arrive at the idea of cause and effect, of a necessary connexion of power, of force, of energy, and of efficacy. Did we never see any but particular conjunctions of objects, entirely different from each other, we shou'd never be able to form any such ideas.

假设有两个物体呈现在我们面前，其中一个是因，另一个是果；很明显，从对其中一个或两个物体的简单考虑中，我们永远不会察觉到它们之间的联系，或者能够肯定地宣布它们之间存在着一种联系。因此，我们不是从任何一个实例中得出因果关系的概念，得出权力、力量、能量和功效的必然联系。如果我们从来没有看到过任何物体的特殊结合，而且彼此完全不同，我们就永远无法形成任何这样的想法。

But again; suppose we observe several instances, in which the same objects are always conjoin'd together, we immediately conceive a connexion betwixt them, and begin to draw an inference from one to another. This multiplicity of resembling instances, therefore, constitutes the very essence of power or connexion, and is the source, from which the idea of it arises. In order, then, to understand the idea of power, we must consider that multiplicity; nor do I ask more to give a solution of that difficulty, which has so long perplex'd us. For thus I reason. The repetition of perfectly similar instances can never alone give rise to an original idea, different from what is to be found in any particular instance, as has been observ'd, and as evidently follows from our fundamental principle, that all ideas are copy'd from impressions.

但是，如果我们观察到几个例子，在这些例子中，相同的物体总是结合在一起，我们就会立即构想出它们之间的联系，并开始从一个推论到另一个。因此，这种相似实例的多重性构成了力量或联系的本质，也是它的概念产生的根源。那么，为了理解权力的概念，我们必须考虑这种多重性；我也不要求对这个长期困扰我们的难题给予解决。因为我是这样推理的。正如人们所观察到的，以及从我们的基本原则中明显得出的结论，即所有的观念都是从印象中复制出来的，完全相似的事例的重复永远不会单独产生一个不同于任何特定事例的原始观念。

Since therefore the idea of power is a new original idea, not to be found in any one instance, and which yet arises from the repetition of several instances, it follows, that the repetition alone has not that effect, but must either discover or produce something new, which is the source of that idea.

因此，既然权力的观念是一个新的原始观念，在任何一个实例中都找不到，而它又是从几个实例的重复中产生的，那么，仅靠重复就没有这种效果，而必须发现或产生新的东西，这就是这种观念的来源。

Did the repetition neither discover nor produce any thing new, our ideas might be multiply'd by it, but wou'd not be enlarg'd above what they are upon the observation of one single instance. Every enlargement, therefore, (such as the idea of power or connexion) which arises from the multiplicity of similar instances, is copy'd from some effects of the multiplicity, and will be perfectly understood by understanding these effects. Wherever we find any thing new to be discover'd or produc'd by the repetition, there we must place the power, and must never look for it in any other object.

如果这种重复既没有发现也没有产生任何新的东西，我们的想法可能会因此而增多，但不会比观察一个单一实例时的想法更多。因此，每一个从类似实例的多重性中产生的扩大（如力量或联系的概念），都是从多重性的某些影响中复制出来的，并通过理解这些影响而得到完美的理解。只要我们发现有任何新的东西可以通过重复来发现或产生，我们就必须把力量放在那里，而决不能在任何其他物体中寻找它。

But 'tis evident, in the first place, that the repetition of like objects in like relations of succession and contiguity discovers nothing new in any one of them; since we can draw no inference from it, nor make it a subject either of our demonstrative or probable reasonings; 25 as has been already prov'd. Nay suppose we cou'd draw an inference, 'twou'd be of no consequence in the present case; since no kind of reasoning can give rise to a new idea, such as this of power is; but wherever we reason, we must antecedently be possest of clear ideas, which may be the objects of our reasoning. The conception always precedes the understanding; and where the one is obscure, the other is uncertain; where the one fails, the other must fail also.

但显而易见的是，首先，在相似的连续和毗连关系中重复相似的物体，在其中任何一个物体中都没有发现新的东西；因为我们不能从中得出任何推论，也不能使它成为我们证明性或可能性推理的主题。25正如已经证明的那样。即使我们能得出推论，在目前的情况下也没有什么意义；因为任何一种推理都不可能产生新的观念，比如这种力量；但无论我们在哪里推理，我们都必须先拥有明确的观念，这可能是我们推理的对象。概念总是先于理解；当一个人模糊不清时，另一个人也不确定；当一个人失败时，另一个人也一定失败。

Secondly, 'Tis certain that this repetition of similar objects in similar situations produces nothing new either in these objects, or in any external body. For 'twill readily be allow'd, that the several instances we have of the conjunction of resembling causes and effects are in themselves entirely independent, and that the communication of motion, which I see result at present from the shock of two billiard-balls, is totally distinct from that which I saw result from such an impulse a twelve-month ago. These impulses have no influence on each other. They are entirely divided by time and place; and the one might have existed and communicated motion, tho' the other never had been in being.

第二，可以肯定的是，类似物体在类似情况下的这种重复，在这些物体或任何外部物体中都不会产生新的东西。因为我们很容易被允许，我们所拥有的几个类似的原因和效果的结合的例子本身是完全独立的，而且我现在看到的由两个台球的冲击所产生的运动交流，与我在 12 个月前看到的由这种冲动所产生的运动交流是完全不同的。这些冲动对彼此没有影响。它们完全被时间和地点所分割；一个可能已经存在并传达了运动，而另一个却从未存在过。

There is, then, nothing new either discover'd or produc'd in any objects by their constant conjunction, and by the uninterrupted resemblance of their relations of succession and contiguity. But 'tis from this resemblance, that the ideas of necessity, of power, and of efficacy, are deriv'd. These ideas, therefore, represent not any thing, that does or can belong to the objects, which are constantly conjoin'd. This is an argument, which, in every view we can examine it, will be found perfectly unanswerable. Similar instances are still the first source of our idea of power or necessity; at the same time that they have no influence by their similarity either on each other, or on any external object. We must therefore, tum ourselves to some other quarter to seek the origin of that idea.

那么，在任何物体中，通过它们的不断结合，以及通过它们的连续和毗连关系的不间断的相似性，没有任何新的发现或产生。但正是从这种相似性中，衍生出了必然性、权力和效力的观念。因此，这些观念并不代表任何确实或可能属于对象的东西，而这些对象是不断结合在一起的。这是一个论点，从任何角度来看，我们都会发现它是完全无法回答的。类似的例子仍然是我们关于力量或必然性的想法的第一个来源；同时，它们的相似性对彼此或对任何外部对象都没有影响。因此，我们必须到其他地方去寻找这种观念的来源。

Tho' the several resembling instances, which give rise to the idea of power, have no influence on each other, and can never produce any new quality in the object, which can be the model of that idea, yet the observation of this resemblance produce a new impression in the mind, which is its real model. For after we have observ'd the resemblance in a sufficient number of instances, we immediately feel a determination of the mind to pass from one object to its usual attendant, and to conceive it in a stronger light upon account of that relation. This determination is the only effect of the resemblance; and therefore must be the same with power or efficacy, whose idea is deriv'd from the resemblance. The several instances of resembling conjunctions leads us into the notion of power and necessity. These instances are in themselves totally distinct from each other, and have no union but in the mind, which observes them, and collects their ideas. Necessity, then, is the effect of this observation, and is nothing but an internal impression of the mind, or a determination to carry our thoughts from one object to another. Without considering it in this view, we can never arrive at the most distant notion of it, or be able to attribute it either to external or internal objects, to spirit or body, to causes or effects.

虽然引起权力观念的几个相似的例子对彼此没有任何影响，也不可能在物体中产生任何新的质量，这可以成为该观念的模型，但对这种相似性的观察会在头脑中产生新的印象，这就是它的真正模型。因为当我们在足够多的例子中观察到这种相似性后，我们会立即感觉到心灵的决心，从一个物体转移到它通常的随从，并根据这种关系以更强的光线来设想它。这种决心是相似性的唯一效果；因此必须与权力或效力相同，其概念是由相似性衍生的。相似的连接词的几个例子使我们进入权力和必要性的概念。这些例子本身是完全不同的，除了在观察它们并收集它们的想法的头脑中，它们没有任何结合。那么，必然性就是这种观察的结果，它只不过是心灵的一种内部印象，或者是把我们的思想从一个对象带到另一个对象的决心。如果不从这个角度来考虑它，我们就永远无法得出它最遥远的概念，也无法把它归于外部或内部物体，归于精神或身体，归于原因或结果。

The necessary connexion betwixt causes and effects is the foundation of our inference from one to the other. The foundation of our inference is the transition arising from the accustom'd union. These are, therefore, the same.

原因和结果之间的必要联系是我们从一个到另一个的推论的基础。我们推论的基础是由习惯的结合产生的过渡。因此，这些都是相同的。

The idea of necessity arises from some impression. There is no impression convey'd by our senses, which can give rise to that idea. It must, therefore, be deriv'd from some internal impression, or impression of reflection. There is no internal impression, which has any relation to the present business, but that propensity, which custom produces, to pass from an object to the idea of its usual attendant. This therefore is the essence of necessity. Upon the whole, necessity is something, that exists in the mind, not in objects; nor is it, possible for us ever to form the most distant idea of it, consider'd as a quality in bodies. Either we have no idea of necessity, or necessity is nothing but that determination of the thought to pass from causes to effects and from effects to causes, according to their experience'd union.

必然性的观念产生于某种印象。我们的感官所传达的印象，并不能产生这种观念。因此，它必须来自于某种内部印象，或者是思考的印象。没有任何内部印象与目前的业务有任何关系，只有习惯所产生的倾向，即从一个对象转移到其通常伴随的想法。因此，这就是必然性的本质。总的来说，必然性是存在于头脑中的东西，而不是存在于物体中的东西；我们也不可能把它看作是身体中的一种品质，形成最遥远的概念。要么我们没有必然性的概念，要么必然性不过是思想根据其经验的结合从原因到结果，从结果到原因的决定。

Thus as the necessity, which makes two times two equal to four, or three angles of a triangle equal to two right ones, lies only in the act of the understanding, by which we consider and compare these ideas; in like manner the necessity or power, which unites causes and effects, lies in the determination of the mind to pass from the one to the other. The efficacy or energy of causes is neither plac'd in the causes themselves, nor in the deity, nor in the concurrence of these two principles; but belongs entirely to the soul, which considers the union of two or more objects in all past instances. 'Tis here that the real power of causes is plac'd, along with their connexion and necessity.

因此，正如使二乘以二等于四，或使三角形的三个角等于两个直角的必然性，只在于我们考虑和比较这些观念的理解力；同样，使原因和结果结合起来的必然性或力量，也在于心灵决定从一个到另一个。原因的效力或能量既不存在于原因本身，也不存在于神灵，更不存在于这两个原则的结合；而是完全属于灵魂，它在所有过去的事例中考虑两个或更多对象的结合。正是在这里，原因的真正力量与它们的联系和必然性一起被放置在这里。

I am sensible, that of all the paradoxes, which I have had, or shall hereafter have occasion to advance in the course of this treatise, the present one is the most violent, and that 'tis merely by dint of solid proof and reasoning I can ever hope it will have admission, and overcome the inveterate prejudices of mankind. Before we are reconcil'd to this doctrine, how often must we repeat to ourselves, that the simple view of any two objects or actions, however related, can never give us any idea of power, or of a connexion betwixt them: that this idea arises from the repetition of their union: that the repetition neither discovers nor causes any thing in the objects, but has an influence only on the mind, by that customary transition it produces: that this customary transition is, therefore, the same with the power and necessity; which are consequently qualities of perceptions, not of objects, and are internally felt by the soul, and not perceiv'd externally in bodies? There is commonly an astonishment attending every thing extraordinary; and this astonishment changes immediately into the highest degree of esteem or contempt, according as we approve or disapprove of the subject. I am much afraid, that tho' the foregoing reasoning appears to me the shortest and most decisive imaginable; yet with the generality of readers the biass of the mind will prevail, and give them a prejudice against the present doctrine.

我意识到，在我已经或将来有机会在这篇论文中提出的所有悖论中，目前这个悖论是最猛烈的，而且我只是通过坚实的证明和推理，才希望它能得到承认，并克服人类顽固的偏见。在我们接受这一理论之前，我们必须经常向自己重复，对任何两个物体或行动的简单看法，无论它们之间如何关联，都不能给我们带来任何力量或它们之间的联系的概念：这种概念来自于它们的重复结合。重复既没有发现也没有导致物体中的任何东西，而只是通过它所产生的习惯性过渡对心灵产生影响：因此，这种习惯性过渡与力量和必然性是一样的；因此，它们是感知的品质，而不是物体的品质，是由灵魂内在感受到的，而不是在身体上外部感知到的？每一件不寻常的事情通常都会有一种惊奇；这种惊奇会立即变成最高程度的尊敬或蔑视，这取决于我们对该主题的认可或不认可。我很担心，尽管上述推理在我看来是可以想象的最简短和最果断的，但对广大读者来说，头脑中的偏见会占上风，并使他们对目前的学说产生偏见。

This contrary biass is easily accounted for. 'Tis a common observation, that the mind has a great propensity to spread itself on external objects, and to conjoin with them any internal impressions, which they occasion, and which always make their appearance at the same time that these objects discover themselves to the senses. Thus as certain sounds and smells are always found to attend certain visible objects, we naturally imagine a conjunction, even in place, betwixt the objects and qualities, tho' the qualities be of such a nature as to admit of no such conjunction, and really exist no where. But of this more fully 26hereafter. Mean while 'tis sufficient to observe, that the same propensity is the reason, why we suppose necessity and power to lie in the objects we consider, not in our mind, that considers them; notwithstanding it is not possible for us to form the most distant idea of that quality, when it is not taken for the determination of the mind, to pass from the idea of an object to that of its usual attendant.

这种相反的倾向是很容易解释的。一个常见的现象是，人的思想有很大的倾向性，会把自己分散在外部物体上，并把它们与任何内部印象联系起来，而这些印象总是在这些物体被感官发现的同时出现的。因此，由于某些声音和气味总是伴随着某些可见的物体，我们自然会想象物体和质量之间有一种结合，甚至是在地方上，尽管这些质量的性质不允许有这种结合，而且实际上不存在。但关于这一点，更全面的 26的更多内容，请见下文。尽管我们不可能对质量形成最遥远的概念，但如果不把它作为心灵的决定因素，就不可能从物体的概念转移到其通常的伴随物。

But tho' this be the only reasonable account we can give of necessity, the contrary notion is so riveted in the mind from the principles above-mention'd, that I doubt not but my sentiments will be treated by many as extravagant and ridiculous. What! the efficacy of causes lie in the determination of the mind! As if causes did not operate entirely independent of the mind, and wou'd not continue their operation, even tho' there was no mind existent to contemplate them, or reason concerning them. Thought may well depend on causes for its operation, but not causes on thought. This is to reverse the order of nature, and make that secondary, which is really primary. To every operation there is a power proportion'd; and this power must be plac'd on the body, that operates. If we remove the power from one cause, we must ascribe it to another: But to remove it from all causes, and bestow it on a being, that is no ways related to the cause or effect, but by perceiving them, is a gross absurdity, and contrary to the most certain principles of human reason.

但是，尽管这是我们能给出的关于必然性的唯一合理解释，但从上面提到的原则来看，相反的概念在人们的头脑中是如此的牢固，以至于我不怀疑我的观点会被许多人视为奢侈和可笑。什么！原因的效力在于心灵的决定！？仿佛原因的运作并不完全独立于思想，即使没有思想存在来思考它们，或对它们进行推理，它们也不会继续运作。思想的运作很可能依赖于原因，但原因不依赖于思想。这是在颠倒自然界的次序，使真正的主要的东西成为次要的东西。每一个操作都有一个相应的力量；而这个力量必须放在操作的身体上。如果我们把力量从一个原因中移除，我们必须把它归于另一个原因。但是，把它从所有的原因中移除，并把它赋予一个与原因或结果没有任何关系的存在，而只是通过感知它们，这是一个严重的荒谬，并且违背了人类理性的最确定原则。

I can only reply to all these arguments, that the case is here much the same, as if a blind man shou'd pretend to find a great many absurdities in the supposition, that the colour of scarlet is not the same with the sound of a trumpet, nor light the same with solidity. If we have really no idea of a power or efficacy in any object, or of any real connexion betwixt causes and effects, 'twill be to little purpose to prove, that an efficacy is necessary in all operations. We do not understand our own meaning in talking so, but ignorantly confound ideas, which are entirely distinct from each other. I am, indeed, ready to allow, that there may be several qualities both in material and immaterial objects, with which we are utterly unacquainted; and if we please to call these power or efficacy, 'twill be of little consequence to the world. But when, instead of meaning these unknown qualities, we make the terms of power and efficacy signify something, of which we have a clear idea, and which is incompatible with those objects, to which we apply it, obscurity and error begin then to take place, and we are led astray by a false philosophy. This is the case, when we transfer the determination of the thought to external objects, and suppose any real intelligible connexion betwixt them; that being a quality, which can only belong to the mind that considers them.

对于所有这些论点，我只能回答说，这里的情况是一样的，就好像一个盲人假装在假设中发现了许多荒谬之处，即大红的颜色与喇叭的声音不一样，光与固体也不一样。如果我们真的不知道任何物体的力量或功效，或者不知道因果之间的任何真正联系，那么证明功效在所有行动中都是必要的，就没有什么意义了。我们这样说并不理解自己的意思，而是无知地混淆了彼此完全不同的概念。我确实愿意承认，在物质和非物质的物体中，可能有一些我们完全不了解的品质；如果我们愿意把这些品质称为力量或功效，那对世界就没有什么影响了。但是，当我们不是指这些未知的品质，而是让权力和效力这两个词表示一些我们有明确概念的东西，而这些东西与我们所适用的对象不相容时，就会开始出现模糊和错误，我们就会被错误的哲学引入歧途。当我们把思想的决定权转移到外部物体上，并假设它们之间有任何真正可理解的联系时，情况就是这样；那是一种品质，只能属于考虑它们的头脑。

As to what may be said, that the operations of nature are independent of our thought and reasoning, I allow it; and accordingly have observ'd, that objects bear to each other the relations of contiguity and succession; that like objects may be observ'd in several instances to have like relations; and that all this is independent of, and antecedent to the operations of the understanding. But if we go any farther, and ascribe a power or necessary connexion to these objects; this is what we can never observe in them, but must draw the idea of it from what we feel internally in contemplating them. And this I carry so far, that I am ready to convert my present reasoning into an instance of it, by a subtility, which it will not be difficult to comprehend.

至于有人说，自然界的运作是独立于我们的思想和推理的，我承认这一点；因此，我观察到，物体之间有相邻和相继的关系；在一些情况下，类似的物体可能被观察到有类似的关系；所有这些都是独立于理解力的运作，并且是在理解力的运作之前。但如果我们走得更远，把一种力量或必要的联系归于这些物体；这就是我们永远无法在它们身上观察到的东西，而必须从我们在思考它们时的内在感受中得出它的概念。这一点我已经说得很清楚了，以至于我准备把我现在的推理转化为一个例子，通过一个巧妙的方法，这不难理解。

When any object is presented to us, it immediately conveys to the mind a lively idea of that object, which is usually found to attend it; and this determination of the mind forms the necessary connexion of these objects. But when we change the point of view, from the objects to the perceptions; in that case the impression is to be considered as the cause, and the lively idea as the effect; and their necessary connexion is that new determination, which we feel to pass from the idea of the one to that of the other. The uniting principle among our internal perceptions is as unintelligible as that among external objects, and is not known to us any other way than by experience. Now the nature and effects of experience have been already sufficiently examin'd and explain'd. It never gives us any insight into the internal structure or operating principle of objects, but only accustoms the mind to pass from one to another.

当任何物体呈现在我们面前时，它立即向头脑传达了一个关于该物体的活泼的想法，这通常被认为是伴随着它的；而头脑的这种确定形成了这些物体的必要联系。但是，当我们改变观点，从对象到知觉；在这种情况下，印象应被视为原因，而活泼的想法是结果；它们的必要联系是新的决定，我们感到从一个的想法到另一个的想法的转变。我们的内部知觉之间的结合原则与外部物体之间的结合原则一样，是无法理解的，而且除了经验之外，我们没有任何其他方法可以知道。现在，经验的性质和效果已经得到了充分的研究和解释。它从来没有让我们洞察到物体的内部结构或运行原理，而只是让心灵习惯于从一个到另一个。

'Tis now time to collect all the different parts of this reasoning, and by joining them together form an exact definition of the relation of cause and effect, which makes the subject of the present enquiry. This order wou'd not have been excusable, of first examining our inference from the relation before we had explain'd the relation itself, had it been possible to proceed in a different method. But as the nature of the relation depends so much on that of the inference, we have been oblig'd to advance in this seemingly preposterous manner, and make use of terms before we were able exactly to define them, or fix their meaning. We shall now correct this fault by giving a precise definition of cause and effect.

现在是时候收集这一推理的所有不同部分，并通过将它们结合起来，形成对因果关系的准确定义，这也是本次调查的主题。如果有可能以不同的方法进行的话，在我们解释关系本身之前，首先审查我们从关系中的推论，这种顺序是不可原谅的。但是，由于关系的性质在很大程度上取决于推论的性质，我们不得不以这种看似荒谬的方式前进，并在我们能够准确定义术语或确定其含义之前使用这些术语。现在我们要纠正这个错误，给因果关系下一个准确的定义。

There may two definitions be given of this relation, which are only different, by their presenting a different view of the same object, and making us consider it either as a philosophical or as a natural relation; either as a comparison of two ideas, or as an association betwixt them. We may define a cause to be 'An object precedent and contiguous to another, and where all the objects resembling the former are plac'd in like relations of precedence and contiguity to those objects, that resemble the latter.' If this definition be esteem'd defective, because drawn from objects foreign to the cause, we may substitute this other definition in its place, viz. 'A cause is an object precedent and contiguous to another, and so united with it, that the idea of the one determines the mind to form the idea of the other, and the impression of the one to form a more lively idea of the other.' Shou'd this definition also be rejected for the same reason, I know no other remedy, than that the persons, who express this delicacy, should substitute a juster definition in its place. But for my part I must own my incapacity for such an undertaking. When I examine with the utmost accuracy those objects, which are commonly denominated causes and effects, I find, in considering a single instance, that the one object is precedent and contiguous to the other; and in enlarging my view to consider several instances, I find only, that like objects are constantly plac'd in like relations of succession and contiguity. Again, when I consider the influence of this constant conjunction, I perceive, that such a relation can never be an object of reasoning, and can never operate upon the mind, but by means of custom, which determines the imagination to make a transition from the idea of one object to that of its usual attendant, and from the impression of one to a more lively idea of the other. However extraordinary these sentiments may appear, I think it fruitless to trouble myself with any farther enquiry or reasoning upon the subject, but shall repose myself on them as on establish'd maxims.

对这种关系可以有两个定义，它们的不同之处在于对同一对象提出了不同的看法，并使我们把它看作是一种哲学关系或自然关系；或者看作是两个概念的比较，或者看作是它们之间的一种联系。我们可以把原因定义为：“一个物体在另一个物体之前并与之相邻，而且所有与前者相似的物体都与后者相似的物体有相似的优先权和相邻关系。如果这个定义被认为是有缺陷的，因为它来自于与原因无关的物体，我们可以用另一个定义来代替它，即：'原因是一个物体在另一个物体之前并与之相邻，并且与之结合，一个物体的概念决定了心灵形成另一个物体的概念，一个物体的印象形成另一个物体的更生动的概念。如果这个定义也因为同样的原因被拒绝，我不知道还有什么补救办法，只能让表达这种微妙的人用一个更公正的定义来代替它。但就我而言，我必须承认我没有能力做这样的工作。当我以最准确的方式研究那些通常被称为原因和结果的对象时，我发现，在考虑一个例子时，一个对象是先于另一个对象的，并与之相邻；而当我扩大视野考虑几个例子时，我只发现，类似的对象不断被置于类似的继承和相邻关系中。此外，当我考虑到这种不断结合的影响时，我意识到，这种关系永远不会成为推理的对象，也永远不会作用于心灵，而是通过习惯的方式，决定想象力从一个物体的概念过渡到其通常的伴随物，从一个物体的印象过渡到另一个物体的更生动的概念。无论这些观点看起来多么不寻常，我认为在这个问题上进行任何进一步的调查或推理都是徒劳的，而应该把自己放在这些既定的格言上。

'Twill only be proper, before we leave this subject, to draw some corollaries from it, by which we may remove several prejudices and popular errors, that have very much prevail'd in philosophy. First, We may learn from the foregoing doctrine, that all causes are of the same kind, and that in particular there is no foundation for that distinction, which we sometimes make betwixt efficient causes, and causes sine qua non; or betwixt efficient causes, and formal, and material, and exemplary, and final causes. For as our idea of efficiency is deriv'd from the constant conjunction of two objects, wherever this is observ'd, the cause is efficient; and where it is not, there can never be a cause of any kind. For the same reason we must reject the distinction betwixt cause and occasion, when suppos'd to signify any thing essentially different from each other. If constant conjunction be imply'd in what we call occasion, 'tis a real cause. If not, 'tis no relation at all, and cannot give rise to any argument or reasoning.

在我们离开这个话题之前，只需从它那里得出一些推论，通过这些推论，我们可以消除哲学中非常普遍的一些偏见和流行的错误。首先，我们可以从上述学说中了解到，所有的原因都是同类的，特别是我们有时在有效原因和必要条件的原因之间所做的区分是没有根据的；或者在有效原因和形式的、物质的、模范的和最终的原因之间所做的区分是没有根据的。因为我们的效率观念是由两个物体的不断结合而来，只要观察到这一点，原因就是有效的；而如果不是这样，就不可能有任何形式的原因。出于同样的原因，我们必须拒绝区分原因和场合，因为这意味着任何本质上不同的东西。如果在我们所谓的场合中隐含着恒定的结合，那么它就是一个真正的原因。如果不是，就根本没有关系，也不能引起任何论证或推理。

Secondly, The same course of reasoning will make us conclude, that there is but one kind of necessity, as there is but one kind of cause, and that the common distinction betwixt moral and physical necessity is without any foundation in nature. This clearly appears from the precedent explication of necessity. 'Tis the constant conjunction of objects, along with the determination of the mind, which constitutes a physical necessity: And the removal of these is the same thing with chance. As objects must either be conjoin'd or not, and as the mind must either be determin'd or not to pass from one object to another, 'tis impossible to admit of any medium betwixt chance and an absolute necessity. In weakening this conjunction and determination you do not change the nature of the necessity; since even in the operation of bodies, these have different degrees of constancy and force, without producing a different species of that relation.

第二，同样的推理过程将使我们得出结论，即只有一种必然性，就像只有一种原因一样，道德和物理必然性之间的共同区别在自然界中没有任何基础。这一点从前面对必然性的解释中可以清楚地看出。物体的不断结合，加上心灵的决定，构成了物理上的必然性。而消除这些是与机会相同的事情。由于物体必须结合或不结合，由于心灵必须决定或不决定从一个物体到另一个物体，所以不可能承认在机会和绝对必然性之间有任何媒介。在削弱这种结合和决定时，你并没有改变必然性的性质；因为即使在身体的运作中，这些都有不同程度的恒定性和力量，而没有产生这种关系的不同种类。

The distinction, which we often make betwixt power and the exercise of it, is equally without foundation.

我们经常在权力和行使权力之间做出区分，这同样是没有根据的。

Thirdly, We may now be able fully to overcome all that repugnance, which 'tis so natural for us to entertain against the foregoing reasoning, by which we endeavour'd to prove, that the necessity of a cause to every beginning of existence is not founded on any arguments either demonstrative or intuitive. Such an opinion will not appear strange after the foregoing definitions. If we define a cause to be an object precedent and contiguous to another, and where all the objects resembling the former are plac'd in a like relation of priority and contiguity to those objects, that resemble the latter; we may easily conceive, that there is no absolute nor metaphysical necessity, that every beginning of existence shou'd be attended with such an object. If we define a cause to be, An object precedent and contiguous to another, and so united with it in the imagination, that the idea of the one determines the mind to form the idea of the other, and the impression of the one to form a more lively idea of the other; we shall make still less difficulty of assenting to this opinion. Such an influence on the mind is in itself perfectly extraordinary and incomprehensible; nor can we be certain of its reality, but from experience and observation.

第三，我们现在可以完全克服我们对前述推理的反感，因为我们在前述推理中努力证明，每一个存在的开始都必须有一个原因，这不是建立在任何证明性或直观性的论据上。在前面的定义之后，这样的观点不会显得奇怪。如果我们把原因定义为一个先于另一个物体并与之相邻的物体，并且所有与前者相似的物体都与后者相似的物体有类似的优先和相邻关系；我们可以很容易地设想，没有绝对的或形而上学的必然性，即每一个存在的开始都应该有这样一个物体存在。如果我们把原因定义为：一个物体在另一个物体之前，与之相邻，并在想象中与之结合，以至于一个物体的观念决定了心灵形成另一个物体的观念，一个物体的印象形成了另一个物体的更生动的观念；我们同意这一观点的难度就会降低。这种对心灵的影响本身就是非常特别和不可理解的；除了经验和观察，我们也无法确定其真实性。

I shall add as a fourth corollary, that we can never have reason to believe that any object exists, of which we cannot form an idea. For as all our reasonings concerning existence are deriv'd from causation, and as all our reasonings concerning causation are deriv'd from the experience'd conjunction of objects, not from any reasoning or reflection, the same experience must give us a notion of these objects, and must remove all mystery from our conclusions. This is so evident, that 'twou'd scarce have merited our attention, were it not to obviate certain objections of this kind, which might arise against the following reasonings concerning matter and substance. I need not observe, that a full knowledge of the object is not requisite, but only of those qualities of it, which we believe to exist.

我将补充第四个推论，即我们永远没有理由相信任何我们无法形成概念的物体存在。因为我们所有关于存在的推理都来自于因果关系，而我们所有关于因果关系的推理都来自于物体的经验结合，而不是来自于任何推理或思考，同样的经验必须给我们一个关于这些物体的概念，并且必须从我们的结论中消除所有的神秘感。这一点非常明显，如果不是为了避免可能出现的某些反对意见，我们根本不值得注意，因为这些反对意见可能会对下面关于物质和实质的推理产生影响。我不需要指出，对物体的全面了解是不需要的，只需要了解我们认为存在的那些品质。

 

Section 15. Rules By Which To Judge Of Causes And Effects

第 15 节。判断原因和影响的规则

 

According to the precedent doctrine, there are no objects, which by the mere survey, without consulting experience, we can determine to be the causes of any other; and no objects, which we can certainly determine in the same manner not to be the causes. Any thing may produce any thing. Creation, annihilation, motion, reason, volition; all these may arise from one another, or from any other object we can imagine. Nor will this appear strange, if we compare two principles explain'd above, that the constant conjunction of objects determines their causation, and27 that properly speaking, no objects are contrary to each other, but existence and non-existance. Where objects are not contrary, nothing hinders them from having that constant conjunction, on which the relation of cause and effect totally depends. Since therefore 'tis possible for all objects to become causes or effects to each other, it may be proper to fix some general rules, by which we may know when they really are so.

根据先例学说，没有任何物体，我们可以通过单纯的调查，不需要咨询经验，就可以确定是任何其他物体的原因；也没有任何物体，我们肯定可以以同样的方式确定不是原因。任何事物都可以产生任何事物。创造、湮灭、运动、理性、意志；所有这些都可能产生于彼此，或产生于我们可以想象的任何其他物体。如果我们比较上面解释的两个原则，这也不会显得奇怪，即物体的不断结合决定了它们的因果关系，以及27正确地说，除了存在和不存在之外，没有任何物体是彼此相反的。在物体不相反的情况下，没有什么能阻止它们有这种持续的结合，而因果关系完全取决于此。因此，既然所有的物体都有可能成为彼此的原因或效果，那么就应该确定一些一般的规则，通过这些规则我们可以知道它们何时真的是这样。

1. The cause and effect must be contiguous in space and time.

1. 因果关系在空间和时间上必须是连续的。

2. The cause must be prior to the effect.

2. 原因必须先于结果。

3. There must be a constant union betwixt the cause and effect. 'Tis chiefly this quality, that constitutes the relation.

3. 原因和结果之间必须有一个持续的结合。构成这种关系的主要是这种品质。

4. The same cause always produces the same effect, and the same effect never arises but from the same cause. This principle we derive from experience, and is the source of most of our philosophical reasonings. For when by any clear experiment we have discover'd the causes or effects of any phænomenon, we immediately extend our observation to every phænomenon of the same kind, without waiting for that constant repetition, from which the first idea of this relation is deriv'd.

4. 同样的原因总是产生同样的效果，而同样的效果除了来自同样的原因之外，永远不会产生。这一原则是我们从经验中得出的，也是我们大多数哲学推理的来源。因为当我们通过任何明确的实验发现了任何现象的原因或影响时，我们会立即将我们的观察扩展到每一个同类现象，而不需要等待不断的重复，这种关系的第一个概念就是从这种重复中产生的。

5. There is another principle, which hangs upon this, viz. that where several different objects produce the same effect, it must be by means of some quality, which we discover to be common amongst them. For as like effects imply like causes, we must always ascribe the causation to the circumstance, wherein we discover the resemblance.

5. 在此基础上还有一个原则，即当几个不同的物体产生相同的效果时，它一定是通过我们发现它们之间共同的某种品质来实现的。由于相似的效果意味着相似的原因，我们必须始终将因果关系归于我们发现相似的情况。

6. The following principle is founded on the same reason. The difference in the effects of two resembling objects must proceed from that particular, in which they differ. For as like causes always produce like effects, when in any instance we find our expectation to be disappointed, we must conclude that this irregularity proceeds from some difference in the causes.

6. 下面的原则也是建立在同样的理由上。两个相似的物体在效果上的差异必须来自于它们不同的那部分。因为相似的原因总是产生相似的效果，当我们在任何情况下发现我们的期望落空时，我们必须得出结论，这种不规则性是由原因中的某些差异引起的。

7. When any object encreases or diminishes with the encrease or diminution of its cause, 'tis to be regarded as a compounded effect, deriv'd from the union of the several different effects, which arise from the several different parts of the cause. The absence or presence of one part of the cause is here suppos'd to be always attended with the absence or presence of a proportionable part of the effect. This constant conjunction sufficiently proves, that the one part is the cause of the other. We must, however, beware not to draw such a conclusion from a few experiments; A certain degree of heat gives pleasure; if you diminish that heat, the pleasure diminishes; but it does not follow, that if you augment it beyond a certain degree, the pleasure will likewise augment; for we find that it degenerates into pain.

7. 当任何物体随着其原因的增加或减少而增加或减少时，应将其视为一种复合效应，它是由原因的几个不同部分产生的几个不同效应的结合而产生的。原因的一个部分的缺失或存在，在这里被认为总是伴随着效果的一个相应部分的缺失或存在。这种持续的结合足以证明，这一部分是另一部分的原因。然而，我们必须注意不要从一些实验中得出这样的结论；一定程度的热会给人带来快乐；如果你减少这种热，快乐就会减少；但这并不意味着，如果你增加它超过一定程度，快乐也会同样增加；因为我们发现，它将退化为痛苦。

8. The eighth and last rule I hall take notice of is, that an object, which exists for any time in its full perfection without any effect, is not the sole cause of that effect, but requires to be assisted by some other principle, which may forward its influence and operation. For as like effects necessarily follow from like causes, and in a contiguous time and place, their separation for a moment shews, that these causes are compleat ones.

8. 我所注意到的第八条也是最后一条规则是，一个物体在任何时候以其完全的完美存在而没有任何效果，并不是该效果的唯一原因，而是需要得到其他一些原则的帮助，以促进其影响和运作。因为类似的效果必然来自于类似的原因，而且是在相邻的时间和地点，它们暂时的分离表明，这些原因是完整的。

Here is all the Logic I think proper to employ in my reasoning; and perhaps even this was not very necessary, but might have been supply'd by the natural principles of our understanding. Our scholastic headpieces and logicians shew no such superiority above the mere vulgar in their reason and ability, as to give us any inclination to imitate them in delivering a long system of rules and precepts to direct our judgment, in philosophy. All the rules of this nature are very easy in their invention, but extremely difficult in their application; and even experimental philosophy, which seems the most natural and simple of any, requires the utmost stretch of human judgment. There is no phænomenon in nature, but what is compounded and modify'd by so many different circumstances, that in order to arrive at the decisive point, we must carefully separate whatever is superfluous, and enquire by new experiments, if every particular circumstance of the first experiment was essential to it. These new experiments are liable to a discussion of the same kind; so that the utmost constancy is requir'd to make us persevere in our enquiry, and the utmost sagacity to choose the right way among so many that present themselves. If this be the case even in natural philosophy, how much more in moral, where there is a much greater complication of circumstances, and where those views and sentiments, which are essential to any action of the mind, are so implicit and obscure, that they often escape our strictest attention, and are not only unaccountable in their causes, but even unknown in their existence? I am much afraid, lest the small success I meet with in my enquiries will make this observation bear the air of an apology rather than of boasting.

这就是我认为在我的推理中应该采用的所有逻辑；也许这也不是非常必要的，而是可以由我们理解的自然原则来提供。我们的学者头头和逻辑学家在他们的理性和能力方面并没有显示出比普通人更高的优越性，以至于让我们倾向于模仿他们，在哲学中提出一长串的规则和戒律来指导我们的判断。所有这种性质的规则在发明上都很容易，但在应用上却极其困难；甚至实验哲学，这个看起来最自然和最简单的东西，也需要人类判断力的最大延伸。自然界中没有任何现象，而是由许多不同的情况组成和修改的，为了达到决定性的一点，我们必须小心翼翼地把多余的东西分开，并通过新的实验询问第一次实验的每一个特定情况是否对它至关重要。这些新的实验有可能引起同样的讨论；因此，需要最大的恒心来使我们坚持不懈地进行调查，并需要最大的智慧来在如此多的实验中选择正确的方法。如果在自然哲学中都是这样，那么在道德哲学中就更不用说了，因为那里的情况要复杂得多，而且那些对心灵的任何行动都至关重要的观点和情绪是如此隐晦和模糊，以至于它们常常逃脱我们最严格的关注，不仅无法解释其原因，甚至不知道其存在？我很害怕，怕我在调查中取得的微小成功会使我的这一意见带有歉意而不是自夸的意味。

If any thing can give me security in this particular, 'twill be the enlarging the sphere of my experiments as much as possible; for which reason it may be proper in this place to examine the reasoning faculty of brutes, as well as that of human creatures.

如果有什么东西能在这方面给我带来安全感，那就是尽可能地扩大我的实验范围；为此，在这个地方研究畜生的推理能力和人类的推理能力可能是合适的。

 

Section 16. Of The Reason Of Animals

第 16 节。关于动物的理由

 

Next to the ridicule of denying an evident truth, is that of taking much pains to defend it; and no truth appears to me more evident, than that beasts are endow'd with thought and reason as well as men. The arguments are in this case so obvious, that they never escape the most stupid and ignorant.

除了否认一个明显的真理的嘲笑之外，还有费尽心思为其辩护的嘲笑；在我看来，没有什么真理比野兽和人一样具有思想和理性更明显了。在这种情况下，论据是如此明显，以至于最愚蠢和最无知的人都无法逃脱。

We are conscious, that we ourselves, in adapting means to ends, are guided by reason and design, and that 'tis not ignorantly nor casually we perform those actions, which tend to self-preservation, to the obtaining pleasure, and avoiding pain. When therefore we see other creatures, in millions of instances, perform like actions, and direct them to like ends, all our principles of reason and probability carry us with an invincible force to believe the existence of a like cause. 'Tis needless in my opinion to illustrate this argument by the enumeration of particulars. The smallest attention will supply us with more than are requisite. The resemblance betwixt the actions of animals and those of men is so entire in this respect, that the very first action of the first animal we shall please to pitch on, will afford us an incontestable argument for the present doctrine.

我们意识到，我们自己在使手段与目的相适应时，是由理性和设计指导的，而且我们并非无知或随意地采取那些行动，以利于自我保护，获得快乐，避免痛苦。因此，当我们看到其他生物在数以百万计的例子中做出类似的行为，并将它们引向类似的目的时，我们所有的理性和概率原则就会以一种不可战胜的力量让我们相信存在着类似的原因。在我看来，没有必要通过列举具体事例来说明这一论点。我们只要稍加注意，就能得到更多必要的信息。在这方面，动物的行动和人的行动之间的相似性是如此之大，以至于我们要讨论的第一种动物的第一个行动就能为目前的学说提供一个无可争议的论据。

This doctrine is as useful as it is obvious, and furnishes us with a kind of touchstone, by which we may try every system in this species of philosophy. 'Tis from the resemblance of the external actions of animals to those we ourselves perform, that we judge their internal likewise to resemble ours; and the same principle of reasoning, carry'd one step farther, will make us conclude that since our internal actions resemble each other, the causes, from which they are deriv'd, must also be resembling. When any hypothesis, therefore, is advanc'd to explain a mental operation, which is common to men and beasts, we must apply the same hypothesis to both; and as every true hypothesis will abide this trial, so I may venture to affirm, that no false one will ever be able to endure it. The common defect of those systems, which philosophers have employ'd to account for the actions of the mind, is, that they suppose such a subtility and refinement of thought, as not only exceeds the capacity of mere animals, but even of children and the common people in our own species; who are notwithstanding susceptible of the same emotions and affections as persons of the most accomplish'd genius and understanding. Such a subtility is a clear proof of the falshood, as the contrary simplicity of the truth, of any system.

这个学说既有用又明显，为我们提供了一种试金石，我们可以据此检验这种哲学的每一个体系。正是由于动物的外部行为与我们自己的行为相似，我们才判断它们的内部行为与我们的内部行为相似；同样的推理原则，再往前走一步，就会使我们得出结论，既然我们的内部行为彼此相似，那么它们所产生的原因也一定是相似的。因此，当任何假说被提出来解释人和动物所共有的心理活动时，我们必须将同样的假说应用于两者；由于每个真正的假说都能经受住这种考验，所以我可以大胆地说，没有一个假说能够经受住这种考验。哲学家们用来解释思想行为的那些系统的共同缺陷是，他们假定思想的微妙性和精致性，不仅超过了单纯的动物的能力，甚至超过了我们这个物种中的儿童和普通人的能力；尽管如此，他们还是有可能拥有与最有天赋和理解力的人一样的情感和情操。这样的微妙性清楚地证明了任何系统的虚假性，就像真理的相反简单性一样。

Let us therefore put our present system concerning the nature of the understanding to this decisive trial, and see whether it will equally account for the reasonings of beasts as for these of the human species.

因此，让我们把我们目前关于理解力的性质的系统放在这个决定性的试验中，看看它是否能同样解释野兽的推理和人类的推理。

Here we must make a distinction betwixt those actions of animals, which are of a vulgar nature, and seem to be on a level with their common capacities, and those more extraordinary instances of sagacity, which they sometimes discover for their own preservation, and the propagation of their species. A dog, that avoids fire and precipices, that shuns strangers, and caresses his master, affords us an instance of the first kind. A bird, that chooses with such care and nicety the place and materials of her nest, and sits upon her eggs for a due time, and in a suitable season, with all the precaution that a chymist is capable of in the most delicate projection, furnishes us with a lively instance of the second.

在这里，我们必须区分动物的那些行为，这些行为具有粗俗的性质，似乎与它们的普通能力持平，而那些更特殊的智慧实例，它们有时为了保护自己和繁殖自己的物种而发现。一只狗，避开火和悬崖，避开陌生人，爱抚它的主人，为我们提供了第一类的例子。一只鸟，如此小心谨慎地选择它的巢穴的位置和材料，在适当的时间和适当的季节坐在她的蛋上，在最微妙的投射中，以一个糜烂者所能做到的所有预防措施，为我们提供了一个生动的第二种例子。

As to the former actions, I assert they proceed from a reasoning, that is not in itself different, nor founded on different principles, from that which appears in human nature. 'Tis necessary in the first place, that there be some impression immediately present to their memory or senses, in order to be the foundation of their judgment. From the tone of voice the dog infers his master's anger, and foresees his own punishment. From a certain sensation affecting his smell, he judges his game not to be far distant from him.

至于以前的行为，我断言它们来自于一种推理，这种推理本身并没有什么不同，也没有建立在不同的原则上，与人类本性中出现的推理不同。首先，必须有一些印象立即呈现在他们的记忆或感官中，以便成为他们判断的基础。狗从说话的语气中推断出主人的愤怒，并预感到对自己的惩罚。根据影响其嗅觉的某种感觉，它判断其猎物离它不远了。

Secondly, The inference he draws from the present impression is built on experience, and on his observation of the conjunction of objects in past instances. As you vary this experience, he varies his reasoning. Make a beating follow upon one sign or motion for some time, and afterwards upon another; and he will successively draw different conclusions, according to his most recent experience.

第二，他从现在的印象中得出的推论是建立在经验上的，是建立在他对过去事例中物体结合的观察上的。当你改变这种经验时，他也会改变他的推理。让一个人在一个标志或运动上跳动一段时间，然后在另一个标志或运动上跳动；他就会根据他最近的经验连续得出不同的结论。

Now let any philosopher make a trial, and endeavour to explain that act of the mind, which we call belief and give an account of the principles, from which it is deriv'd, independent of the influence of custom on the imagination, and let his hypothesis be equally applicable to beasts as to the human species; and after he has done this, I promise to embrace his opinion. But at the same time I demand as an equitable condition, that if my system be the only one, which can answer to all these terms, it may be receiv'd as entirely satisfactory and convincing. And that 'tis the only one, is evident almost without any reasoning. Beasts certainly never perceive any real connexion among objects. 'Tis therefore by experience they infer one from another. They can never by any arguments form a general conclusion, that those objects, of which they have had no experience, resemble those of which they have. 'Tis therefore by means of custom alone, that experience operates upon them. All this was sufficiently evident with respect to man. But with respect to beasts there cannot be the least suspicion of mistake; which must be own'd to be a strong confirmation, or rather an invincible proof of my system.

现在，让任何一位哲学家进行试验，努力解释我们称之为信仰的心灵行为，并说明它所依据的原则，不受习俗对想象力的影响，而且让他的假设同样适用于野兽和人类；在他做完这些之后，我保证会接受他的意见。但同时，我要求作为一个公平的条件，如果我的体系是唯一一个能够满足所有这些条件的体系，它可以被认为是完全令人满意和令人信服的。而这是唯一的一种，几乎不需要任何推理就可以看出。动物当然不会察觉到物体之间有任何真正的联系。因此，它们是通过经验来推断一个又一个的。它们不可能通过任何论据形成一个一般性的结论，即那些它们没有经验的物体与它们有经验的物体相似。因此，只有通过习俗，经验才会对他们产生作用。这一切对人来说是足够明显的。但对于野兽，却不能有丝毫错误的怀疑；这必须被认为是对我的体系的有力证实，或者说是一个不可战胜的证明。

Nothing shews more the force of habit in reconciling us to any phænomenon, than this, that men are not astonish'd at the operations of their own reason, at the same time, that they admire the instinct of animals, and find a difficulty in explaining it, merely because it cannot be reduc'd to the very same principles. To consider the matter aright, reason is nothing but a wonderful and unintelligible instinct in our which carries us along a certain train of ideas, and endows them with particular qualities, according to their particular situations and relations. This instinct, 'tis true, arises from past observation and experience; but can any one give the ultimate reason, why past experience and observation produces such an effect, any more than why nature alone shou'd produce it? Nature may certainly produce whatever can arise from habit: Nay, habit is nothing but one of the principles of nature, and derives all its force from that origin.

没有什么比这更能说明习惯在使我们与任何现象相协调方面的力量了，即人们对自己的理性的运作并不感到惊讶，同时，他们对动物的本能感到钦佩，并认为难以解释它，只是因为它不能被归结为同样的原则。正确地考虑这个问题，理性不过是我们的一种奇妙的、难以理解的本能，它带着我们沿着一定的思路走，并根据它们的特殊情况和关系，赋予它们特殊的品质。诚然，这种本能来自于过去的观察和经验；但有谁能给出最终的理由，为什么过去的经验和观察会产生这样的效果，而不是只有自然界才会产生这样的效果？自然当然可以产生任何可以从习惯中产生的东西。不，习惯只不过是自然的原则之一，它的所有力量都来自于自然。

 

PART 4: OF THE SCEPTICAL AND OTHER SYSTEMS OF PHILOSOPHY

第四部分：关于怀疑论和其他哲学体系

 

Section 1. Of Scepticism With Regard To Reason

第一节。关于理性的怀疑论

 

In all demonstrative sciences the rules are certain and infallible; but when we apply them, our fallible and uncertain faculties are very apt to depart from them, and fall into error. We must, therefore, in every reasoning form a new judgment, as a check or controul on our first judgment or belief; and must enlarge our view to comprehend a kind of history of all the instances, wherein our understanding has deceiv'd us, compar'd with those, wherein its testimony was just and true. Our reason must be consider'd as a kind of cause, of which truth is the natural effect; but such-a-one as by the irruption of other causes, and by the inconstancy of our mental powers, may frequently be prevented. By this means all knowledge degenerates into probability; and this probability is greater or less, according to our experience of the veracity or deceitfulness of our understanding, and according to the simplicity or intricacy of the question.

在所有论证科学中，规则是确定的和无懈可击的；但当我们应用它们时，我们易变的和不确定的能力很容易偏离它们，并陷入错误。因此，我们必须在每次推理中形成一个新的判断，作为对我们第一个判断或信仰的检查或反驳；必须扩大我们的视野，以包括一种历史，即我们的理解力欺骗了我们的所有事例，与那些它的证词是公正和真实的事例进行比较。我们的理性必须被视为一种原因，而真理是这种原因的自然结果；但由于其他原因的干扰，以及我们精神力量的不稳定，这种原因可能经常被阻止。通过这种方式，所有的知识都退化为可能性；这种可能性或大或小，取决于我们对自己理解力的真实性或欺骗性的经验，也取决于问题的简单性或复杂性。

There is no Algebraist nor Mathematician so expert in his science, as to place entire confidence in any truth immediately upon his discovery of it, or regard it as any thing, but a mere probability. Every time he runs over his proofs, his confidence encreases; but still more by the approbation of his friends; and is rais'd to its utmost perfection by the universal assent and applauses of the learned world. Now 'tis evident, that this gradual encrease of assurance is nothing but the addition of new probabilities, and is deriv'd from the constant union of causes and effects, according to past experience and observation.

没有一个代数学家或数学家在他的科学中如此专业，以至于在发现任何真理时立即对其抱有完全的信心，或将其视为任何东西，而仅仅是一种概率。每当他仔细研究他的证明时，他的信心就会增加；但由于他的朋友的认可，他的信心就会增加；并且由于学问界的普遍赞同和掌声，他的信心就会达到最完美的程度。现在很明显，这种信心的逐渐增强只不过是新的可能性的增加，是根据过去的经验和观察，从原因和结果的不断结合中得到的。

In accompts of any length or importance, Merchants seldom trust to the infallible certainty of numbers for their security; but by the artificial structure of the accompts, produce a probability beyond what is deriv'd from the skill and experience of the accomptant. For that is plainly of itself some degree of probability; tho' uncertain and variable, according to the degrees of his experience and length of the accompt. Now as none will maintain, that our assurance in a long numeration exceeds probability, I may safely affirm, that there scarce is any proposition concerning numbers, of which we can have a fuller security.
