For 'tis easily possible, by gradually diminishing the numbers, to reduce the longest series of addition to the most simple question, which can be form'd, to an addition of two single numbers; and upon this supposition we shall find it impracticable to shew the precise limits of knowledge and of probability, or discover that particular number, at which the one ends and the other begins. But knowledge and probability are of such contrary and disagreeing natures, that they cannot well run insensibly into each other, and that because they will not divide, but must be either entirely present, or entirely absent. Besides, if any single addition were certain, every one wou'd be so, and consequently the whole or total sum; unless the whole can be different from all its parts. I had almost said, that this was certain; but I reflect, that it must reduce itself, as well as every other reasoning, and from knowledge degenerate into probability.

在任何长度或重要性的交易中，商人很少相信数字的无误确定性来保证他们的安全；而是通过交易的人为结构，产生一种超越交易员的技能和经验的可能性。因为这本身就是某种程度的概率；尽管根据他的经验程度和伴奏的长短，是不确定的和可变的。既然没有人坚持认为我们对长数的保证超过了概率，我可以肯定地说，很少有关于数字的命题，我们可以有更充分的保证。因为通过逐渐减少数字，很容易将最长的加法系列减少到最简单的问题，可以形成两个单一数字的加法；在这种假设下，我们会发现显示知识和概率的精确界限是不切实际的，或者发现那个特定的数字，在那里一个结束，另一个开始。但是，知识和概率的性质是如此的相反和不一致，以至于它们不可能不约而同地相互影响，这是因为它们不会分裂，而必须要么完全存在，要么完全不存在。此外，如果任何一个加数都是确定的，那么每一个加数都是如此，因此整体或总和也是如此；除非整体能与它的所有部分不同。我几乎说过，这是确定的；但我想，它必须像其他推理一样缩小自己，从知识退化为概率。

Since therefore all knowledge resolves itself into probability, and becomes at last of the same nature with that evidence, which we employ in common life, we must now examine this latter species of reasoning, and see on what foundation it stands.

因此，既然所有的知识都会转化为概率，并最终与我们在日常生活中使用的证据具有相同的性质，那么我们现在就必须研究这后一种推理，看看它的基础是什么。

In every judgment, which we can form concerning probability, as well as concerning knowledge, we ought always to correct the first judgment, deriv'd from the nature of the object, by another judgment, deriv'd from the nature of the understanding. 'Tis certain a man of solid sense and long experience ought to have, and usually has, a greater assurance in his opinions, than one that is foolish and ignorant, and that our sentiments have different degrees of authority, even with ourselves, in proportion to the degrees of our reason and experience. In the man of the best sense and longest experience, this authority is never entire; since even such-a-one must be conscious of many errors in the past, and must still dread the like for the future. Here then arises a new species of probability to correct and regulate the first, and fix its just standard and proportion. As demonstration is subject to the controul of probability, so is probability liable to a new correction by a reflex act of the mind, wherein the nature of our understanding, and our reasoning from the first probability become our objects.

在我们能够形成的关于概率以及关于知识的每一个判断中，我们总是应该用另一个从理解力的本质中得出的判断来纠正从对象的本质中得出的第一个判断。可以肯定的是，一个有坚实理智和长期经验的人应该比一个愚蠢和无知的人对他的观点有更大的把握，而且我们的情感有不同程度的权威，即使对我们自己来说，也与我们的理智和经验的程度成比例。在最有理智和最有经验的人身上，这种权威永远不会是完全的；因为即使是这样的人，也必须意识到过去的许多错误，而且还必须担心未来会出现类似的问题。因此，这里出现了一种新的可能性，以纠正和规范第一种可能性，并确定其公正的标准和比例。正如证明受到概率的制约一样，概率也有可能通过心灵的反射行为得到新的修正，在这里，我们理解的性质和我们从第一种概率中进行的推理成为我们的目标。

Having thus found in every probability, beside the original uncertainty inherent in the subject, a new uncertainty deriv'd from the weakness of that faculty, which judges, and having adjusted these two together, we are oblig'd by our reason to add a new doubt deriv'd from the possibility of error in the estimation we make of the truth and fidelity of our faculties. This is a doubt, which immediately occurs to us, and of which, if we wou'd closely pursue our reason, we cannot avoid giving a decision. But this decision, tho' it shou'd be favourable to our preceding judgment, being founded only on probability, must weaken still further our first evidence, and must itself be weaken'd by a fourth doubt of the same kind, and so on in infinitum; till at last there remain nothing of the original probability, however great we may suppose it to have been, and however small the diminution by every new uncertainty. No finite Object can subsist under a decrease repeated in infinitum; and even the vastest quantity, which can enter into human imagination, must in this manner be reduc'd to nothing. Let our first belief be never so strong, it must infallibly perish by passing thro' so many new examinations, of which each diminishes somewhat of its force and vigour. When I reflect on the natural fallibility of my judgment, I have less confidence in my opinions, than when I only consider the objects concerning which I reason; and when I proceed still farther, to turn the scrutiny against every successive estimation I make of my faculties, all the rules of logic require a continual diminution, and at last a total extinction of belief and evidence.

这样一来，在每一种可能性中，除了主题中固有的不确定性之外，还发现了一种新的不确定性，这种不确定性是由判断能力的弱点引起的，在将这两种能力调整到一起之后，我们不得不通过我们的理性来增加一种新的怀疑，这种怀疑是由我们对我们能力的真理和忠诚度的估计中可能出现的错误引起的。这是一个立即发生在我们身上的疑问，如果我们仔细追寻我们的理性，我们就不能不对它作出一个决定。但是这个决定，尽管它应该有利于我们以前的判断，因为它只是建立在概率的基础上，必须进一步削弱我们的第一个证据，而且它本身必须被第四个同类的怀疑所削弱，如此循环往复；直到最后，原来的概率没有了，不管我们可能认为它有多大，也不管每一个新的不确定性的减少有多小。任何有限的物体都不可能在无限重复的减少中存在；即使是人类想象力中最庞大的数量，也必须以这种方式被减少到一无所有。让我们的第一个信念永远不会如此强大，它一定会因为经历了这么多新的检验而消亡，而每一次检验都会在一定程度上削弱它的力量和活力。当我思考我的判断力的自然缺陷时，我对我的观点的信心就会比我只考虑我推理的对象时要少；当我更进一步，把审查转向反对我对我的能力所作的每一个连续的估计时，所有的逻辑规则都要求不断地减少，最后完全消灭信仰和证据。

Shou'd it here be ask'd me, whether I sincerely assent to this argument, which I seem to take such pains to inculcate, and whether I be really one of those sceptics, who hold that all is uncertain, and that our judgment is not in my thing possest of any measures of truth and falshood; I shou'd reply, that this question is entirely superfluous, and that neither I, nor any other person was ever sincerely and constantly of that opinion. Nature, by an absolute and uncontroulable necessity has determin'd us to judge as well as to breathe and feel; nor can we any more forbear viewing certain objects in a stronger and fuller light, upon account of their customary connexion with a present impression, than we can hinder ourselves from thinking as long as we are awake, or seeing the surrounding bodies, when we turn our eyes towards them in broad sunshine. Whoever has taken the pains to refute the cavils of this total scepticism, has really disputed without an antagonist, and endeavour'd by arguments to establish a faculty, which nature has antecedently implanted in the mind, and render'd unavoidable.

如果在这里有人问我，我是否真诚地同意这个我似乎不厌其烦地灌输的论点，以及我是否真的是那些怀疑论者之一，他们认为一切都不确定，我们的判断在我这里不具备任何真理和虚假的措施；我应该回答，这个问题完全是多余的，我和任何其他人都没有真诚地和持续地持有这种观点。大自然以一种绝对的、不可违背的必要性决定了我们既要判断，又要呼吸和感觉；我们也不能因为某些物体与当前印象的习惯性联系而不以更强、更全面的眼光来看待它们，就像我们在清醒时能阻止自己思考，或在广阔的阳光下把眼睛转向周围的物体时，能阻止自己看到它们。不管是谁不厌其烦地驳斥这种完全怀疑论的责难，都是在没有对手的情况下进行争论，并努力通过论证来确立一种能力，这种能力是大自然事先植入心灵的，是不可避免的。

My intention then in displaying so carefully the arguments of that fantastic sect, is only to make the reader sensible of the truth of my hypothesis, that all our reasonings concerning causes and effects are deriv'd from nothing but custom; and that belief is more properly an act of the sensitive, than of the cogitative part of our natures. I have here prov'd, that the very same principles, which make us form a decision upon any subject, and correct that decision by the consideration of our genius and capacity, and of the situation of our mind, when we examin'd that subject; I say, I have prov'd, that these same principles, when carry'd farther, and apply'd to every new reflex judgment, must, by continually diminishing the original evidence, at last reduce it to nothing, and utterly subvert all belief and opinion. If belief, therefore, were a simple act of the thought, without any peculiar manner of conception, or the addition of a force and vivacity, it must infallibly destroy itself, and in every case terminate in a total suspense of judgment. But as experience will sufficiently convince any one, who thinks it worth while to try, that tho' he can find no error in the foregoing arguments, yet he still continues to believe, and think, and reason as usual, he may safely conclude, that his reasoning and belief is some sensation or peculiar manner of conception, which 'tis impossible for mere ideas and reflections to destroy.

那么，我如此仔细地展示那个梦幻般的教派的论点，只是为了让读者了解我的假设的真实性，即我们所有关于因果关系的推理都是来自于习惯，而信仰更应该是我们天性中敏感而非思考的部分的行为。我在这里证明，正是这些原则，使我们在任何问题上形成决定，并通过考虑我们的天才和能力，以及我们的思想状况来纠正这一决定，当我们审查该问题时；我说，我已经证明，这些相同的原则，当进一步进行，并应用于每一个新的反射判断时，必须通过不断减少原始证据，最后将其减少到没有，并彻底颠覆所有的信仰和意见。因此，如果信仰是一种简单的思想行为，没有任何特殊的构思方式，也没有增加一种力量和活力，它必然会自我毁灭，并在每一种情况下以判断的完全悬置而告终。但是，经验足以使任何认为值得一试的人相信，尽管他在上述论点中找不到错误，但他仍然像往常一样继续相信、思考和推理，他可以安全地得出结论，他的推理和信仰是某种感觉或特殊的构思方式，而单纯的想法和思考是不可能破坏的。

But here, perhaps, it may be demanded, how it happens, even upon my hypothesis, that these arguments above explain'd produce not a total suspense of judgment, and after what manner the mind ever retains a degree of assurance in any subject? For as these new probabilities, which by their repetition perpetually diminish the original evidence, are founded on the very same principles, whether of thought or sensation, as the primary judgment, it may seem unavoidable, that in either case they must equally subvert it, and by the opposition, either of contrary thoughts or sensations, reduce the mind to a total uncertainty. I suppose, there is some question propos'd to me, and that after revolving over the impressions of my memory and senses, and carrying my thoughts from them to such objects, as are commonly conjoin'd with them, I feel a stronger and more forcible conception on the one side, than on the other. This strong conception forms my first decision. I suppose, that afterwards I examine my judgment itself, and observing from experience, that 'tis sometimes just and sometimes erroneous, I consider it as regulated by contrary principles or causes, of which some lead to truth, and some to error; and in balancing these contrary causes, I diminish by a new probability the assurance of my first decision. This new probability is liable to the same diminution as the foregoing, and so on, in infinitum. 'Tis therefore demanded, how it happens, that even after all we retain a degree of belief, which is sufficient for our purpose, either in philosophy or common life.

但是，在这里，也许有人会问，即使根据我的假设，上面解释的这些论据怎么会不产生判断的完全悬念，以及在任何问题上，心灵是以何种方式保持一定程度的确信？因为这些新的可能性，由于它们的重复而不断减少原来的证据，无论是思想还是感觉，都是建立在与主要判断相同的原则之上的，所以似乎不可避免的是，在任何一种情况下，它们都必须同样地颠覆它，并通过相反的思想或感觉的对抗，使头脑完全陷入不确定状态。我假设，有一些问题向我提出，在我的记忆和感官的印象上转了一圈，并把我的想法从它们带到通常与它们联系在一起的对象上，我感到一边的概念比另一边的概念更强烈、更有说服力。这种强烈的概念形成了我的第一个决定。我假设，之后我检查我的判断本身，并从经验中观察到，它有时是公正的，有时是错误的，我认为它是由相反的原则或原因控制的，其中一些导致真理，一些导致错误；在平衡这些相反的原因时，我通过一个新的可能性减少了我第一个决定的确定性。这个新的可能性也会像前述那样被削弱，如此循环往复，无穷无尽。因此，有人问，即使在所有的事情之后，我们仍然保留一定程度的信念，这对我们的目的来说是足够的，无论是在哲学上还是在普通生活中。

I answer, that after the first and second decision; as the action of the mind becomes forc'd and unnatural, and the ideas faint and obscure; tho' the principles of judgment, and the balancing of opposite causes be the same as at the very beginning; yet their influence on the imagination, and the vigour they add to, or diminish from the thought, is by no means equal. Where the mind reaches not its objects with easiness and facility, the same principles have not the same effect as in a more natural conception of the ideas; nor does the imagination feel a sensation, which holds any proportion with that which arises from its common judgments and opinions. The attention is on the stretch: The posture of the mind is uneasy; and the spirits being diverted from their natural course, are not govern'd in their movements by the same laws, at least not to the same degree, as when they How in their usual channel.

我回答说，在第一次和第二次决定之后，由于心灵的行动变得强硬和不自然，思想变得模糊和晦涩；尽管判断的原则和相反原因的平衡与一开始一样；但它们对想象力的影响，以及它们对思想的增减，决不是平等的。在心灵不能轻松自如地达到其目标的地方，同样的原则就不能像在一个更自然的观念中那样产生影响；想象力也没有感觉，与从其共同的判断和意见中产生的感觉有任何比例。人们的注意力都集中在伸展上。心灵的姿态是不安的；精神偏离了它们的自然路线，它们的运动不受相同规律的支配，至少不受相同程度的支配，就像它们在通常的渠道中那样。

If we desire similar instances, 'twill not be very difficult to find them. The present subject of metaphysics will supply us abundantly. The same argument, which wou'd have been esteem'd convincing in a reasoning concerning history or politics, has little or no influence in these abstruser subjects, even tho' it be perfectly comprehended; and that because there is requir'd a study and an effort of thought, in order to its being comprehended: And this effort of thought disturbs the operation of our sentiments, on which the belief depends. The case is the same in other subjects. The straining of the imagination always hinders the regular flowing of the passions and sentiments. A tragic poet, that wou'd represent his heroes as very ingenious and witty in their misfortunes, wou'd never touch the passions. As the emotions of the soul prevent any subtile reasoning and reflection, so these latter actions of the mind are equally prejudicial to the former. The mind, as well as the body, seems to be endow'd with a certain precise degree of force and activity, which it never employs in one action, but at the expence of all the rest. This is more evidently true, where the actions are of quite different natures; since in that case the force of the mind is not only diverted, but even the disposition chang'd, so as to render us incapable of a sudden transition from one action to the other, and still more of performing both at once. No wonder, then, the conviction, which arises from a subtile reasoning, diminishes in proportion to the efforts, which the imagination makes to enter into the reasoning, and to conceive it in all its parts. Belief, being a lively conception, can never be entire, where it is not founded on something natural and easy.

如果我们想要类似的例子，就不难找到它们。目前的形而上学主题将为我们提供大量的内容。同样的论据，在有关历史或政治的推理中会被认为是有说服力的，但在这些深奥的主题中，即使它被完全理解，也没有什么影响；这是因为为了理解它，需要进行研究和思考的努力。而这种思考的努力扰乱了我们的情感的运作，而这正是信仰所依赖的。其他学科的情况也是如此。紧张的想象力总是阻碍激情和情感的正常流动。一个悲剧诗人，如果想把他的英雄表现为在他们的不幸中非常巧妙和机智，那么他就不会触及激情。由于灵魂的情感阻碍了任何微妙的推理和思考，所以心灵的这些后一种行为也同样不利于前者。心灵和身体一样，似乎被赋予了某种精确程度的力量和活动，它从不在一个行动中使用，而是以牺牲所有其他行动为代价。如果行动的性质完全不同，那就更明显了；因为在这种情况下，心灵的力量不仅被转移了，甚至连倾向也改变了，从而使我们无法从一个行动突然过渡到另一个行动，更无法同时完成这两个行动。因此，难怪从微妙的推理中产生的信念，会随着想象力为进入推理和想象它的所有部分所做的努力而减弱。信仰，作为一种生动的概念，如果不是建立在自然和容易的基础上，就不可能是完整的。

This I take to be the true state of the question, and cannot approve of that expeditious way, which some take with the sceptics, to reject at once all their arguments without enquiry or examination. If the sceptical reasonings be strong, say they, 'tis a proof, that reason may have some force and authority: if weak, they can never be sufficient to invalidate all the conclusions of our understanding. This argument is not just; because the sceptical reasonings, were it possible for them to exist, and were they not destroy'd by their subtility, wou'd be successively both strong and weak, according to the successive dispositions of the mind. Reason first appears in possession of the throne, prescribing laws, and imposing maxims, with an absolute sway and authority. Her enemy, therefore, is oblig'd to take shelter under her protection, and by making use of rational arguments to prove the fallaciousness and imbecility of reason, produces, in a manner, a patent under her hand and seal. This patent has at first an authority, proportion'd to the present and immediate authority of reason, from which it is deriv'd. But as it is suppos'd to be contradictory to reason, it gradually diminishes the force of that governing power, and its own at the same time; till at last they both vanish away into nothing, by a regular and just diminution. The sceptical and dogmatical reasons are of the same kind, tho' contrary in their operation and tendency; so that where the latter is strong, it has an enemy of equal force in the former to encounter; and as their forces were at first equal, they still continue so, as long as either of them subsists; nor does one of them lose any force in the contest, without taking as much from its antagonist. 'Tis happy, therefore, that nature breaks the force of all sceptical arguments in time, and keeps them from having any considerable influence on the understanding. Were we to trust entirely to their self-destruction, that can never take place, 'till they have first subverted all conviction, and have totally destroy'd human reason.

我认为这才是问题的真实情况，我不赞成有些人对怀疑论者采取的那种急功近利的做法，即不经询问或审查就立即拒绝他们的所有论据。他们说，如果怀疑论者的推理很强，那就证明理性可能有一定的力量和权威；如果很弱，它们就永远不足以使我们理解的所有结论失效。这个论点是不公正的；因为怀疑论的推理，如果有可能存在，如果没有被它们的微妙性所破坏，就会根据心灵的连续处置而先后变得既强又弱。理性首先出现在宝座上，规定法律，强加格言，具有绝对的支配力和权威。因此，她的敌人不得不躲在她的保护之下，并通过利用理性的论据来证明理性的谬误和无能，在某种程度上，产生了一个由她的手和印章的专利。这个专利起初有一个权威，与理性的当前和直接的权威相称，它是从理性派生出来的。但是，由于它被认为是与理性相矛盾的，所以它逐渐减少了支配力量的力量，同时也减少了它自己的力量；直到最后，它们都通过定期和公正的减少而消失得无影无踪。怀疑论和教条主义的理由也是如此，虽然它们的作用和趋势是相反的；因此，在后者强大的地方，它有一个与前者力量相等的敌人要对付；由于它们的力量最初是相等的，只要它们中的任何一个还存在，它们就仍然是这样；它们中的一个也不会在竞争中失去任何力量，而不从其对手那里得到同样的力量。因此，令人高兴的是，大自然及时打破了所有怀疑论点的力量，使它们无法对理解力产生任何重大影响。如果我们完全相信它们的自我毁灭，那是永远不可能的，"除非它们首先颠覆了所有的信念，并完全摧毁了人类的理性。

 

Section 2. Of Scepticism With Regard To The Senses

第 2 节。关于感官的怀疑论

 

Thus the sceptic still continues to reason and believe, even tho' he asserts, that he cannot defend his reason by reason; and by the same rule he must assent to the principle concerning the existence of body, tho' he cannot pretend by any arguments of philosophy to maintain its veracity. Nature has not left this to his choice, and has doubtless esteem'd it an affair of too great importance to be trusted to our uncertain reasonings and speculations. We may well ask, What causes induce us to believe in the existence of body? but 'tis in vain to ask, Whither there be body or not? That is a point, which we must take for granted in all our reasonings.

因此，怀疑论者仍然继续推理和相信，尽管他断言他不能用理性来捍卫他的理性；根据同样的规则，他必须同意关于身体存在的原则，尽管他不能假装用任何哲学论据来维护其真实性。大自然并没有把这个问题留给他选择，而且毫无疑问地认为这是一件非常重要的事情，不能把它交给我们不确定的推理和猜测。我们可以问，是什么原因促使我们相信身体的存在？但如果问，到底有没有身体，那是徒劳的。这是一个问题，我们在所有的推理中都必须把它视为理所当然。

The subject, then, of our present enquiry is concerning the causes which induce us to believe in the existence of body: And my reasonings on this head I shall begin with a distinction, which at first sight may seem superfluous, but which will contribute very much to the perfect understanding of what follows. We ought to examine apart those two questions, which are commonly confounded together, viz. Why we attribute a continu'd existence to objects, even when they are not present to the senses; and why we suppose them to have an existence distinct from the mind and perception. Under this last head I comprehend their situation as well as relations, their external position as well as the independence of their existence and operation. These two questions concerning the continu'd and distinct existence of body are intimately connected together. For if the objects of our senses continue to exist, even when they are not perceiv'd, their existence is of course independent of and distinct from the perception; and vice versa, if their existence be independent of the perception and distinct from it, they must continue to exist, even tho' they be not perceiv'd. But tho' the decision of the one question decides the other; yet that we may the more easily discover the principles of human nature, from whence the decision arises, we shall carry along with us this distinction, and shall consider, whether it be the senses, reason, or the imagination, that produces the opinion of a continu'd or of a distinct existence. These are the only questions, that are intelligible on the present subject. For as to the notion of external existence, when taken for something specifically different from our perceptions,  28we have already shewn its absurdity.

那么，我们现在询问的主题是关于诱使我们相信身体存在的原因。我在这个问题上的推理将从一个区别开始，这个区别乍一看可能是多余的，但它将非常有助于对下文的完美理解。我们应该分别研究这两个通常被混为一谈的问题，即：为什么我们把物体的持续存在归结为，即使它们不在感官上；以及为什么我们认为它们有一个不同于心灵和知觉的存在。在这最后一个标题下，我理解了它们的情况和关系，它们的外部位置以及它们的存在和运作的独立性。这两个关于身体的持续和独特存在的问题是密切相关的。因为如果我们感官的对象继续存在，即使它们没有被感知，它们的存在当然是独立于感知并与之不同的；反之亦然，如果它们的存在独立于感知并与之不同，它们必须继续存在，即使它们没有被感知。但是，尽管一个问题的决定决定了另一个问题；但为了我们能更容易地发现人性的原则，即决定产生的原因，我们将带着这种区别，并将考虑是感官、理性还是想象力产生了持续存在或独特存在的观点。这些是唯一的问题，在目前的问题上是可以理解的。至于外部存在的概念，如果被认为是与我们的感知特别不同的东西，我们已经证明了它的荒谬。 28我们已经证明了其荒谬性。

To begin with the senses, 'tis evident these faculties are incapable of giving rise to the notion of the continu'd existence of their objects, after they no longer appear to the senses. For that is a contradiction in terms, and supposes that the senses continue to operate, even after they have ceas'd all manner of operation. These faculties, therefore, if they have any influence in the present case, must produce the opinion of a distinct, not of a continu'd existence; and in order to that, must present their impressions either as images and representations, or as these very distinct and external existences.

从感官开始，很明显，这些能力不可能在它们的对象不再出现在感官面前时产生持续存在的概念。因为这是个矛盾的说法，它假定感官继续运作，甚至在它们停止了所有的运作方式之后。因此，这些能力，如果它们在目前的情况下有任何影响，就必须产生一个独特的，而不是持续存在的观点；为了达到这个目的，必须把它们的印象作为图像和代表，或者作为这些非常独特和外部的存在。

That our senses offer not their impressions as the images of something distinct, or independent, and external, is evident; because they convey to us nothing but a single perception, and never give us the least intimation of any thing beyond. A single perception can never produce the idea of a double existence, but by some inference either of the reason or imagination. When the mind looks farther than what immediately appears to it, its conclusions can never be put to the account of the senses; and it certainly looks farther, when from a single perception it infers a double existence, and supposes the relations of resemblance and causation betwixt them.

我们的感官提供的印象并不是独特的、独立的和外部的东西的形象，这是显而易见的；因为它们传达给我们的只是单一的感知，而从未给我们任何超越的东西的暗示。只有通过理性或想象力的某种推论，单一的感知才能产生双重存在的想法。当心灵看得比它立即出现的东西更远时，它的结论永远不能归结于感官；当它从单一感知中推断出双重存在，并假设它们之间的相似性和因果关系时，它当然看得更远。

If our senses, therefore, suggest any idea of distinct existences, they must convey the impressions as those very existences, by a kind of fallacy and illusion. Upon this head we may observe, that all sensations are felt by the mind, such as they really are, and that when we doubt, whether they present themselves as distinct objects, or as mere impressions, the difficulty is not concerning their nature, but concerning their relations and situation. Now if the senses presented our impressions as external to, and independent of ourselves, both the objects and ourselves must be obvious to our senses, otherwise they cou'd not be compar'd by these faculties. The difficulty, then, is how far we are ourselves the objects of our senses.

因此，如果我们的感官提出任何关于独特存在的想法，它们就必须通过一种谬误和幻觉，将印象传达为这些存在。在这个问题上，我们可以观察到，所有的感觉都是由心灵感受到的，就像它们真实存在的那样，而当我们怀疑它们是作为独特的对象呈现出来，还是作为单纯的印象呈现出来时，困难不在于它们的性质，而在于它们的关系和情况。现在，如果感官将我们的印象呈现为外部的、独立于我们自己的，那么，对于我们的感官来说，对象和我们自己都必须是显而易见的，否则它们就不能被这些能力所比较。那么，困难在于我们自己在多大程度上是我们感官的对象。

'Tis certain there is no question in philosophy more abstruse than that concerning identity, and the nature of the uniting principle, which constitutes a person. So far from being able by our senses merely to determine this question, we must have recourse to the most profound metaphysics to give a satisfactory answer to it; and in common life 'tis evident these ideas of self and person are never very fix'd nor determinate. 'Tis absurd, therefore, to imagine the senses can ever distinguish betwixt ourselves and external objects.

可以肯定的是，在哲学中，没有什么问题比关于身份和构成人的联合原则的性质的问题更深奥了。我们的感官远不能确定这个问题，我们必须求助于最深刻的形而上学，才能给出一个令人满意的答案；而在普通生活中，很明显，这些关于自我和人的想法从来都是固定的，也不是确定的。因此，想象感官能够区分我们和外部物体是很荒谬的。

Add to this, that every impression, external and internal, passions, affections, sensations, pains and pleasures, are originally on the same footing; and that whatever other differences we may observe among them, they appear, all of them, in their true colours, as impressions or perceptions. And indeed, if we consider the matter aright, 'tis scarce possible it shou'd be otherwise, nor is it conceivable that our senses shou'd be more capable of deceiving us in the situation and relations, than in the nature of our impressions. For since all actions and sensations of the mind are known to us by consciousness, they must necessarily appear in every particular what they are, and be what they appear. Every thing that enters the mind, being in reality as the perception, 'tis impossible any thing shou'd to feeling appear different. This were to suppose, that even where we are most intimately conscious, we might be mistaken.

此外，每一种印象，外部的和内部的，激情、情感、感觉、痛苦和快乐，最初都是在同一基础上的；无论我们在它们之间观察到什么样的差异，它们都以它们的真实面目出现，作为印象或感知。事实上，如果我们正确地考虑这个问题，几乎不可能出现其他情况，也不可能想象我们的感官在情况和关系上比在我们印象的性质上更能欺骗我们。因为既然心灵的所有行动和感觉都被我们的意识所了解，那么它们必然在每一个细节上表现为它们是什么，并且是它们所表现的。每件进入心灵的东西，在现实中都与感知一样，不可能有任何东西在感觉上出现不同。这是在假设，即使在我们最密切的意识中，我们也可能被误解。

But not to lose time in examining, whether 'tis possible for our senses to deceive us, and represent our perceptions as distinct from ourselves, that is as external to and independent of us; let us consider whether they really do so, and whether this error proceeds from an immediate sensation, or from some other causes.

但是，我们不要浪费时间去研究，我们的感官是否有可能欺骗我们，把我们的知觉表现为与我们自己不同，也就是与我们无关的外部知觉；让我们考虑它们是否真的这样做了，以及这种错误是来自直接的感觉，还是来自其他原因。

To begin with the question concerning external existence, it may perhaps be said, that setting aside the metaphysical question of the identity of a thinking substance, our own body evidently belongs to us; and as several impressions appear exterior to the body, we suppose them also exterior to ourselves. The paper, on which I write at present, is beyond my hand. The table is beyond the paper. The walls of the chamber beyond the table. And in casting my eye towards the window, I perceive a great extent of fields and buildings beyond my chamber. From all this it may be infer'd, that no other faculty is requir'd, beside the senses, to convince us of the external existence of body. But to prevent this inference, we need only weigh the three following considerations. First, That, properly speaking, 'tis not our body we perceive, when we regard our limbs and members, but certain impressions, which enter by the senses; so that the ascribing a real and corporeal existence to these impressions, or to their objects, is an act of the mind as difficult to explain, as that which we examine at present. Secondly, Sounds, and tastes, and smells, tho' commonly regarded by the mind as continu'd independent qualities, appear not to have any existence in extension, and consequently cannot appear to the senses as situated externally to the body. The reason, why we ascribe a place to them, shall be consider'd 29afterwards. Thirdly, Even our sight informs us not of distance or outness (so to speak) immediately and without a certain reasoning and experience, as is acknowledge'd by the most rational philosophers.

从有关外部存在的问题开始，也许可以说，抛开思维物质的身份这一形而上学问题，我们自己的身体显然属于我们；由于一些印象出现在身体外部，我们认为它们也在我们外部。我现在写的这张纸，在我的手之外。桌子是在纸的外面。桌子之外是房间的墙壁。当我把目光投向窗户时，我看到我的房间外有大片的田野和建筑。从这一切可以推断出，除了感官之外，不需要其他能力来说服我们相信身体的外部存在。但为了防止这种推论，我们只需要权衡以下三个方面的考虑。第一，正确地说，当我们看到我们的四肢和肢体时，我们感知的不是我们的身体，而是通过感官进入的某些印象；因此，将真实和肉体的存在赋予这些印象或其对象，是一种心灵的行为，就像我们现在所研究的那样，难以解释。第二，声音、味道和气味，虽然通常被头脑视为持续的独立品质，但似乎没有任何延伸的存在，因此不能在感官上显示为位于身体外部。我们为什么要给它们一个位置，原因将在后面考虑。29之后再考虑。第三，即使是我们的视觉，也不会立即告知我们距离或外在（可以说是），也不需要一定的推理和经验，正如最理性的哲学家们所承认的那样。

As to the independency of our perceptions on ourselves, this can never be an object of the senses; but any opinion we form concerning it, must be deriv'd from experience and observation: And we shall see afterwards, that our conclusions from experience are far from being favourable to the doctrine of the independency of our perceptions. Mean while we may observe that when we talk of real distinct existences, we have commonly more in our eye their in dependency than external situation in place, and think an object has a sufficient reality, when its Being is uninterrupted, and independent of the incessant revolutions, which we are conscious of in ourselves.

至于我们的知觉对我们自己的独立性，这永远不可能是感官的对象；但我们对它形成的任何意见，必须从经验和观察中得出。之后我们会看到，我们从经验中得出的结论远远不利于我们的知觉独立的学说。同时我们可以注意到，当我们谈论真正的独特存在时，我们通常更看重它们的依存性，而不是外部情况的位置，并且认为当一个物体的存在是不间断的，并且独立于我们自己意识到的不断旋转时，它就具有充分的真实性。

Thus to resume what I have said concerning the senses; they give us no notion of continu'd existence, because they cannot operate beyond the extent, in which they really operate. They as little produce the opinion of a distinct existence, because they neither can offer it to the mind as represented, nor as original. To offer it as represented, they must present both an object and an image. To make it appear as original, they must convey a falshood; and this falshood must lie in the relations and situation: In order to which they must be able to compare the object with ourselves; and even in that case they do not, nor is it possible they shou'd, deceive us. We may, therefore, conclude with certainty, that the opinion of a continu'd and of a distinct existence never arises from the senses.

因此，为了恢复我关于感官的说法；它们没有给我们提供持续存在的概念，因为它们不能在它们真正运作的范围之外运作。它们也很少产生独特存在的观点，因为它们既不能向心灵提供它的表象，也不能提供它的原始。为了把它作为代表提供给人们，它们必须同时提出一个对象和一个形象。为了使它作为原物出现，它们必须传达一种虚假性；而这种虚假性必须在于关系和情况。为了达到这个目的，他们必须能够将对象与我们自己进行比较；即使在这种情况下，他们也不会、也不可能欺骗我们。因此，我们可以肯定地得出结论，关于持续存在和独特存在的观点从未从感官中产生。

To confirm this we may observe, that there are three different kinds of impressions convey'd by the senses. The first are those of the figure, bulk, motion and solidity of bodies. The second those of colours, tastes, smells, sounds, heat and cold. The third are the pains and pleasures, that arise from the application of objects to our bodies, as by the cutting of our flesh with steel, and such like. Both philosophers and the vulgar suppose the first of these to have a distinct continu'd existence. The vulgar only regard the second as on the same footing. Both philosophers and the vulgar, again, esteem the third to be merely perceptions; and consequently interrupted and dependent beings.

为了证实这一点，我们可以观察到，感官所传达的印象有三种不同的类型。第一种是关于物体的形状、体积、运动和坚固性的印象。第二种是颜色、味道、气味、声音、热和冷。第三种是痛苦和快乐，这些痛苦和快乐是由物体作用于我们的身体而产生的，如用钢铁切割我们的肉体，以及诸如此类。哲学家和普通人都认为其中的第一种有一个独特的持续存在。俗人只认为第二种情况与之相同。哲学家和庸人都认为第三种仅仅是感知；因此是中断的和依赖性的存在。

Now 'tis evident, that, whatever may be our philosophical opinion, colours, sounds, heat and cold, as far as appears to the senses, exist after the same manner with motion and solidity, and that the difference we make betwixt them in this respect, arises not from the mere perception. So strong is the prejudice for the distinct continu'd existence of the former qualities, that when the contrary opinion is advanc'd by modern philosophers, people imagine they can almost refute it from their feeling and experience, and that their very senses contradict this philosophy. 'Tis also evident, that colours, sounds, &c. are originally on the same footing with the pain that arises from steel, and pleasure that proceeds from a fire; and that the difference betwixt them is founded neither on perception nor reason, but on the imagination. For as they are confest to be, both of them, nothing but perceptions arising from the particular configurations and motions of the parts of body, wherein possibly can their difference consist? Upon the whole, then, we may conclude, that as far as the senses are judges, all perceptions are the same in the manner of their existence.

现在很明显，无论我们的哲学观点如何，颜色、声音、热和冷，就感官而言，与运动和实体是以同样的方式存在的，我们在这方面对它们的区别，并不是来自单纯的感知。人们对前一种品质的持续存在有如此强烈的偏见，以至于当现代哲学家提出相反的观点时，人们认为他们几乎可以从他们的感觉和经验中反驳它，而且他们的感官与这种哲学相矛盾。同样明显的是，颜色、声音等与钢铁产生的疼痛和火产生的快感原本是一样的；它们之间的区别既不是建立在知觉或理性上，而是建立在想象上。因为既然它们都被认为是，只不过是由身体各部分的特殊构造和运动所产生的知觉，那么它们之间的差异可能会在哪里？因此，总的来说，我们可以得出结论，就感官而言，所有的感知在其存在方式上都是一样的。

We may also observe in this instance of sounds and colours, that we can attribute a distinct continu'd existence to objects without ever consulting Reason, or weighing our opinions by any philosophical principles. And indeed, whatever convincing arguments philosophers may fancy they can produce to establish the belief of objects independent of the mind, 'tis obvious these arguments are known but to very few, and that 'tis not by them, that children, peasants, and the greatest part of mankind are induc'd to attribute objects to some impressions, and deny them to others. Accordingly we find, that all the conclusions, which the vulgar form on this head, are directly contrary to those, which are confirm'd by philosophy. For philosophy informs us, that every thing, which appears to the mind, is nothing but a perception, and is interrupted, and dependent on the mind; whereas the vulgar confound perceptions and objects, and attribute a distinct continu'd existence to the very things they feel or see. This sentiment, then, as it is entirely unreasonable, must proceed from some other faculty than the understanding. To which we may add, that as long as we take our perceptions and objects to be the same, we can never infer the existence of the one from that of the other, nor form any argument from the relation of cause and effect; which is the only one that can assure us of matter of fact. Even after we distinguish our perceptions from our objects, 'twill appear presently, that we are still incapable of reasoning from the existence of one to that of the other: So that upon the whole our reason neither does, nor is it possible it ever shou'd, upon any supposition, give us an assurance of the continu'd and distinct existence of body. That opinion must be entirely owing to the imagination which must now be the subject of our enquiry.

在声音和颜色的例子中，我们也可以看到，我们可以把一个独特的持续存在归于物体，而不需要咨询理性，或用任何哲学原则来衡量我们的意见。事实上，无论哲学家们认为他们能提出什么令人信服的论据来确立独立于心灵的物体的信念，很明显，这些论据只有极少数人知道，而且儿童、农民和人类中的大多数人并不是靠它们来诱导将物体归于某些印象，而否认它们的。因此，我们发现，俗人在这个问题上形成的所有结论，都与哲学所确认的结论直接相反。因为哲学告诉我们，每一件出现在头脑中的事物，都不过是一种感知，而且是中断的，并依赖于头脑；而庸俗的人则把感知和物体混为一谈，并把一种独特的持续存在归于他们所感觉到或看到的事物。那么，这种情绪，由于它是完全不合理的，必须来自理解力以外的其他能力。对此，我们可以补充说，只要我们认为我们的感知和对象是相同的，我们就永远不能从另一个推断出一个的存在，也不能从因果关系中形成任何论据；这是唯一能向我们保证事实的因素。即使在我们把我们的感知与我们的对象区分开来之后，我们仍然无法从一个的存在推论到另一个的存在。因此，总的来说，我们的理性既不会，也不可能，在任何假设下，给我们一个身体持续和独特存在的保证。这种观点必须完全归功于想象力，而想象力必须是我们现在询问的主题。

Since all impressions are internal and perishing existences, and appear as such, the notion of their distinct and continu'd existence must arise from a concurrence of some of their qualities with the qualities of the imagination; and since this notion does not extend to all of them, it must arise from certain qualities peculiar to some impressions. 'Twill therefore be easy for us to discover these qualities by a comparison of the impressions, to which we attribute a distinct and continu'd existence, with those, which we regard as internal and perishing.

既然所有的印象都是内在的和消亡的存在，并以这种方式出现，那么它们独特和持续存在的概念必须来自于它们的某些品质与想象力的品质的一致；由于这种概念并不延伸到所有的印象，它必须来自于某些印象所特有的某些品质。因此，我们很容易通过比较我们认为具有独特和持续存在的印象与那些我们认为是内部和灭亡的印象来发现这些品质。

We may observe, then, that 'tis neither upon account of the involuntariness of certain impressions, as is commonly suppos'd, nor of their superior force and violence, that we attribute to them a reality, and continu'd existence, which we refuse to others, that are voluntary or feeble. For 'tis evident our pains and pleasures, our passions and affections, which we never suppose to have any existence beyond our perception, operate with greater violence, and are equally involuntary, as the impressions of figure and extension, colour and sound, which we suppose to be permanent beings. The heat of a fire, when moderate, is suppos'd to exist in the fire; but the pain, which it causes upon a near approach, is not taken to have any being except in the perception.

那么，我们可以看到，既不是因为某些印象的非自愿性，就像通常所认为的那样，也不是因为它们的力量和暴力，我们就把它们归于现实和持续的存在，而拒绝其他自愿或脆弱的印象。因为很明显，我们的痛苦和快乐，我们的激情和情感，我们从不认为它们在我们的感知之外有任何存在，它们以更大的暴力运作，而且同样是非自愿的，就像我们认为是永久存在的形状和延伸、颜色和声音的印象一样。火的热度，当适度时，被认为存在于火中；但它在接近时引起的疼痛，除了在知觉中，不被认为有任何存在。

These vulgar opinions, then, being rejected, we must search for some other hypothesis, by which we may discover those peculiar qualities in our impressions, which makes us attribute to them a distinct and continu'd existence.

那么，这些庸俗的观点既然被否定了，我们就必须寻找其他的假设，通过这些假设，我们可以在我们的印象中发现那些特殊的品质，从而使我们把它们归结为一种独特而持续的存在。

After a little examination, we shall find, that all those objects, to which we attribute a continu'd existence, have a peculiar constancy, which distinguishes them from the impressions, whose existence depends upon our perception. Those mountains, and houses, and trees, which lie at present under my eye, have always appear'd to me in the same order; and when I lose sight of them by shutting my eyes or turning my head, I soon after find them return upon me without the least alteration. My bed and table, my books and papers, present themselves in the same uniform manner, and change not upon account of any interruption in my seeing or perceiving them. This is the case with all the impressions, whose objects are suppos'd to have an external existence; and is the case with no other impressions, whether gentle or violent, voluntary or involuntary.

稍加研究，我们就会发现，所有那些我们认为持续存在的物体，都有一种特殊的不变性，这使它们与印象不同，后者的存在取决于我们的感知。目前在我眼皮底下的那些山峰、房屋和树木，总是以同样的顺序出现在我面前；当我因闭上眼睛或转过头去而看不到它们时，我很快就发现它们又出现在我面前，没有丝毫改变。我的床和桌子，我的书和文件，都以同样的方式出现，不会因为我看到或感知到它们的任何中断而改变。所有的印象都是这样，它们的对象被认为是有外部存在的；其他的印象也是如此，无论是温和的还是暴力的，自愿的还是不自愿的。

This constancy, however, is not so perfect as not to admit of very considerable exceptions. Bodies often change their position and qualities, and after a little absence or interruption may become hardly knowable. But here 'tis observable, that even in these changes they preserve a coherence, and have a regular dependence on each other; which is the foundation of a kind of reasoning from causation, and produces the opinion of their continu'd existence. When I return to my chamber after an hour's absence, I find not my fire in the same situation, in which I left it: But then I am accustom'd in other instances to see a like alteration produc'd in a like time, whether I am present or absent, near or remote. This coherence, therefore, in their changes is one of the characteristics of external objects, as well as their constancy.

然而，这种恒定性并不是那么完美，以至于不允许有非常大的例外。物体经常改变它们的位置和质量，而且在稍稍离开或中断后，可能变得难以辨认。但在这里可以看到，即使在这些变化中，它们也保持着一致性，并有规律地相互依赖；这是一种因果关系推理的基础，并产生了它们持续存在的观点。当我离开一小时后回到我的房间时，我发现我的火并不在我离开时的相同位置。但是，在其他情况下，我习惯于在类似的时间内看到类似的变化，无论我是在现场还是不在现场，是在附近还是在远处。因此，在它们的变化中的这种一致性是外部物体的特征之一，也是它们的不变性。

Having found that the opinion of the continu'd existence of body depends on the coherence and constancy of certain impressions, I now proceed to examine after what manner these qualities give rise to so extraordinary an opinion. To begin with the coherence; we may observe, that tho' those internal impressions, which we regard as fleeting and perishing, have also a certain coherence or regularity in their appearances, yet 'tis of somewhat a different nature, from that which we discover in bodies. Our passions are found by experience to have a mutual connexion with and dependence on each other; but on no occasion is it necessary to suppose, that they have existed and operated, when they were not perceiv'd, in order to preserve the same dependence and connexion, of which we have had experience. The case is not the same with relation to external objects. Those require a continu'd existence, or otherwise lose, in a great measure, the regularity of their operation. I am here seated in my chamber with my face to the fire; and all the objects, that strike my senses, are contain'd in a few yards around me. My memory, indeed, informs me of the existence of many objects; but then this information extends not beyond their past existence, nor do either my senses or memory give any testimony to the continuance of their being. When therefore I am thus seated, and revolve over these thoughts, I hear on a sudden a noise as of a door turning upon its hinges; and a little after see a porter, who advances towards me. This gives occasion to many new reflections and reasonings. First, I never have observ'd, that this noise cou'd proceed from any thing but the motion of a door; and therefore conclude, that the present phænomenon is a contradiction to all past experience, unless the door, which I remember on t'other side the chamber, be still in being. Again, I have always found, that a human body was possest of a quality, which I call gravity, and which hinders it from mounting in the air, as this porter must have done to arrive at my chamber, unless the stairs I remember be not annihilated by my absence. But this is not all. I receive a letter, which upon opening it I perceive by the hand-writing and subscription to have come from a friend, who says he is two hundred leagues distant. 'Tis evident I can never account for this phænomenon, conformable to my experience in other instances, without spreading out in my mind the whole sea and continent between us, and supposing the effects and continu'd existence of posts and ferries, according to my memory and observation. To consider these phænomena of the porter and letter in a certain light, they are contradictions to common experience, and may be regarded as objections to those maxims, which we form concerning the connexions of causes and effects. I am accustom'd to hear such a sound, and see such an object in motion at the same time. I have not receiv'd in this particular instance both these perceptions. These observations are contrary, unless I suppose that the door still remains, and that it was open'd without my perceiving it: And this supposition, which was at first entirely arbitrary and hypothetical, acquires a force and evidence by its being the only one, upon which I can reconcile these contradictions. There is scarce a moment of my life, wherein there is not a similar instance presented to me, and I have not occasion to suppose the continu'd existence of objects, in order to connect their past and present appearances, and give them such an union with each other, as I have found by experience to be suitable to their particular natures and circumstances. Here then I am naturally led to regard the world, as something real and durable, and as preserving its existence, even when it is no longer present to my perception.

在发现身体持续存在的观点取决于某些印象的连贯性和恒定性之后，我现在开始研究这些品质是如何引起这种特殊观点的。首先是连贯性；我们可以注意到，尽管那些被我们视为短暂和消亡的内部印象，在其外观上也有一定的连贯性或规律性，但其性质与我们在身体中发现的不同。我们的经验发现，我们的激情是相互联系和相互依赖的；但在任何情况下，都没有必要假设它们在没有被察觉的时候就已经存在和运作了，以便保持我们所经历的同样的依赖和联系。与外部物体有关的情况就不一样了。这些物体需要持续存在，否则就会在很大程度上失去其运作的规律性。我现在坐在我的房间里，面朝火堆；所有触动我感官的物体都在我周围几码的范围内。我的记忆的确告诉我许多物体的存在；但这种信息并没有超越它们过去的存在，我的感官和记忆也没有为它们的存在提供任何证明。因此，当我这样坐着，对这些想法进行思考时，我突然听到一种声音，就像门在铰链上转动一样；过了一会儿，我看到一个门房，他向我走来。这让我有了许多新的思考和推理。首先，我从来没有注意到，这种声音除了来自门的运动外，还可能来自其他任何东西；因此我得出结论，现在的现象与过去的所有经验都是矛盾的，除非我记得在房间另一边的门仍然存在。另外，我一直发现，人的身体有一种特性，我称之为重力，这种特性阻碍了它在空中飞行，就像这个搬运工到达我的房间时必须做的那样，除非我记得的楼梯没有因为我的离开而消失掉。但这还不是全部。我收到了一封信，打开后我发现这封信是一个朋友写来的，他说他在 200 里格以外的地方。显然，如果我不在脑海中展开我们之间的整个海洋和大陆，并根据我的记忆和观察，假设哨所和渡口的影响和持续存在，我就无法解释这种现象，这与我在其他情况下的经验是一致的。从某种角度来看，搬运工和信件的这些现象是与普通经验相矛盾的，可被视为对那些关于因果关系的格言的反对意见。我习惯于听到这样的声音，同时看到这样的物体在运动。在这个特殊的例子中，我没有收到这两种感知。这些观察是相反的，除非我假设那扇门仍然存在，而且它在我没有察觉的情况下被打开了。而这个起初完全是武断和假设的假设，由于是唯一的假设而获得了力量和证据，据此我可以调和这些矛盾。在我的生活中，几乎没有一刻没有类似的例子出现在我面前，我也没有机会假设物体的持续存在，以便将它们的过去和现在的表象联系起来，并使它们相互结合，因为我通过经验发现它们的特殊性质和情况是适合的。这样，我就自然而然地把世界看作是真实而持久的东西，而且即使它不再出现在我的感知中，也会保持其存在。

But tho' this conclusion from the coherence of appearances may seem to be of the same nature with our reasonings concerning causes and effects; as being deriv'd from custom, and regulated by past experience; we shall find upon examination, that they are at the bottom considerably different from each other, and that this inference arises from the understanding, and from custom in an indirect and oblique manner. For 'twill readily be allow'd, that since nothing is ever really present to the mind, besides its own perceptions, 'tis not only impossible, that any habit shou'd ever be acquir'd otherwise than by the regular succession of these perceptions, but also that any habit shou'd ever exceed that degree of regularity. Any degree, therefore, of regularity in our perceptions, can never be a foundation for us to infer a greater degree of regularity in some objects, which are not perceiv'd; since this supposes a contradiction, viz. a habit acquir'd by what was never present to the mind. But 'tis evident, that whenever we infer the continu'd existence of the objects of sense from their coherence, and the frequency of their union, 'tis in order to bestow on the objects a greater regularity than what is observ'd in our mere perceptions. We remark a connexion betwixt two kinds of objects in their past appearance to the senses, but are not able to observe this connexion to be perfectly constant, since the turning about of our head, or the shutting of our eyes is able to break it. What then do we suppose in this case, but that these objects still continue their usual connexion, notwithstanding their apparent interruption, and that the irregular appearances are join'd by something, of which we are insensible? But as all reasoning concerning matters of fact arises only from custom, and custom can only be the effect of repeated perceptions, the extending of custom and reasoning beyond the perceptions can never be the direct and natural effect of the constant repetition and connexion, but must arise from the co-operation of some other principles.

但是，尽管从表象的一致性得出的这一结论似乎与我们关于因果关系的推理具有相同的性质；因为它来自于习惯，并受过去经验的制约；我们在研究后会发现，它们在本质上有很大的不同，而且这种推理是以间接和斜向的方式从理解和习惯中产生的。因为我们很容易就会发现，既然除了自己的感知之外，没有任何东西真正存在于心灵之中，那么，任何习惯的养成都不可能不是通过这些感知的有规律的连续进行，而且任何习惯都不可能超过这种有规律的程度。因此，我们感知中任何程度的规律性，都不能成为我们推断某些未被感知的物体具有更大程度的规律性的基础；因为这假定了一个矛盾，即一个习惯是由头脑中从未出现过的东西获得的。但显而易见的是，每当我们从感官对象的一致性和它们结合的频率来推断它们的持续存在时，都是为了赋予这些对象比我们单纯的知觉中所观察到的更大的规律。我们注意到两种物体在过去出现在感官上时有一种联系，但不能观察到这种联系是完全恒定的，因为我们的头的转动或眼睛的闭合能够打破这种联系。那么，在这种情况下，我们该如何假设，这些物体仍然保持着它们通常的联系，尽管它们表面上被打断了，而这些不规则的表象是由某种东西连接起来的，而我们对这些东西一无所知？但是，由于所有关于事实问题的推理都只产生于习惯，而习惯只能是反复感知的结果，因此，习惯和推理的延伸超越了感知，永远不可能是不断重复和联系的直接和自然的效果，而必须产生于一些其他原则的合作。

I have already30 observ'd, in examining the foundation of mathematics, that the imagination, when set into any train of thinking, is apt to continue, even when its object fails it, and like a galley put in motion by the oars, carries on its course without any new impulse. This I have assign'd for the reason, why, after considering several loose standards of equality, and correcting them by each other, we proceed to imagine so correct and exact a standard of that relation, as is not liable to the least error or variation. The same principle makes us easily entertain this opinion of the continu'd existence of body. Objects have a certain coherence even as they appear to our senses; but this coherence is much greater and more uniform, if we suppose the objects to have a continu'd existence; and as the mind is once in the train of observing an uniformity among objects, it naturally continues, till it renders the uniformity as compleat as possible. The simple supposition of their continu'd existence suffices for this purpose, and gives us a notion of a much greater regularity among objects, than what they have when we look no farther than our senses.

我已经30在研究数学的基础时，我已经注意到，想象力在进入任何思路时，都会继续下去，即使它的目标已经失败，而且就像一艘被桨划动的船，在没有任何新的推动下继续前进。我认为这就是为什么在考虑了几个松散的平等标准，并通过相互纠正后，我们开始想象这种关系的正确和精确的标准，因为它不可能有丝毫错误或变化。同样的原则使我们很容易接受这种关于身体持续存在的观点。物体即使在我们的感官看来也有一定的一致性；但如果我们假设物体是持续存在的，这种一致性就会更大、更均匀；由于心灵一旦进入观察物体之间的一致性的轨道，它自然会继续下去，直到它使这种一致性尽可能地完整。简单地假设它们的持续存在就足以达到这个目的，并给我们一个关于物体之间的规律性的概念，比我们只看我们的感官时它们所具有的规律性大得多。

But whatever force we may ascribe to this principle, I am afraid 'tis too weak to support alone so vast an edifice, as is that of the continu'd existence of all external bodies; and we must join the constancy of their appearance to the coherence, in order to give a satisfactory account of opinion. As the explication of this will lead me into a considerable compass of very profound reasoning; I think it proper, in order to avoid confusion, to give a short sketch or abridgment of my system, and afterwards draw out all its parts in their full compass. This inference from the constancy of our perceptions, like the precedent from their coherence, gives rise to the opinion of the continu'd existence of body, which is prior to that of its distinct existence, and produces that latter principle.

但无论我们对这一原则赋予什么样的力量，我担心它太弱了，无法单独支持如此庞大的大厦，就像所有外部机构的持续存在一样；我们必须把它们的外观的恒定性与一致性结合起来，以便对意见做出令人满意的解释。由于对这一点的解释将使我进入一个相当大的范围内的非常深刻的推理；为了避免混乱，我认为应该对我的系统做一个简短的概述或节略，然后在其完整的范围内引出其所有部分。从我们感知的恒定性中得出的这一推论，就像从它们的一致性中得出的先例一样，产生了关于身体持续存在的观点，它先于其独特存在的观点，并产生了后一原则。

When we have been accustom'd to observe a constancy in certain impressions, and have found, that the perception of the sun or ocean, for instance, returns upon us after an absence or annihilation with like parts and in a like order, as at its first appearance, we are not apt to regard these interrupted perceptions as different, (which they really are) but on the contrary consider them as individually the same, upon account of their resemblance. But as this interruption of their existence is contrary to their perfect identity, and makes us regard the first impression as annihilated, and the second as newly created, we find ourselves somewhat at a loss, and are involv'd in a kind of contradiction. In order to free ourselves from this difficulty, we disguise, as much as possible, the interruption, or rather remove it entirely, by supposing that these interrupted perceptions are connected by a real existence, of which we are insensible. This supposition, or idea of continu'd existence, acquires a force and vivacity from the memory of these broken impressions, and from that propensity, which they give us, to suppose them the same; and according to the precedent reasoning, the very essence of belief consists in the force and vivacity of the conception.

当我们习惯于观察某些印象的恒定性，并且发现，例如对太阳或海洋的感知，在缺席或湮灭之后，会以类似的部分和类似的顺序回到我们面前，就不会把这些中断的感知看作是不同的，（它们确实是不同的），相反，由于它们的相似性，我们会认为它们各自是相同的。但是，由于它们存在的这种中断与它们完美的同一性相反，并使我们把第一个印象看作是湮灭的，而把第二个印象看作是新产生的，因此我们发现自己有些不知所措，并陷入了一种矛盾之中。为了使我们摆脱这种困难，我们尽可能地掩饰这种中断，或者说完全消除这种中断，办法是假设这些中断的知觉被一种真实的存在所连接，而我们对这种存在一无所知。这种假设，或持续存在的想法，从对这些中断的印象的记忆中获得了力量和活力，并从它们给我们带来的假设它们是相同的倾向中获得了力量和活力；根据前面的推理，信仰的本质包括概念的力量和活力。

In order to justify this system, there are four things requisite. First, To explain the principium individuationis, or principle of identity. Secondly, Give a reason, why the resemblance of our broken and interrupted perceptions induces us to attribute an identity to them. Thirdly, Account for that propensity, which this illusion gives, to unite these broken appearances by a continu'd existence. Fourthly and lastly, Explain that force and vivacity of conception, which arises from the propensity.

为了证明这一体系的合理性，有四点是必须的。第一，解释 “个体化原则”，或 “同一性原则”。第二，给出一个理由，为什么我们破碎和中断的知觉的相似性会诱使我们将它们归结为一种身份。第三，说明这种错觉所带来的倾向性，即通过持续的存在将这些破碎的表象结合起来。第四，也是最后一点，解释从这种倾向中产生的概念的力量和活力。

First, As to the principle of individuation; we may observe, that the view of any one object is not sufficient to convey the idea of identity. For in that proposition, an object is the same with itself, if the idea express'd by the word, object, were no ways distinguish'd from that meant by itself; we really shou'd mean nothing, nor wou'd the proposition contain a predicate and a subject, which however are imply'd in this affirmation. One single object conveys the idea of unity, not that of identity.

首先，关于个体化的原则；我们可以看到，对任何一个物体的看法都不足以表达同一性的概念。因为在这个命题中，一个物体与它本身是一样的，如果物体这个词所表达的思想与它本身的意思没有任何区别，我们就真的没有任何意思，这个命题也不会包含一个谓语和一个主语，但这在这个肯定中是隐含的。一个单一的对象传达的是统一性的概念，而不是同一性的概念。

On the other hand, a multiplicity of objects can never convey this idea, however resembling they may be suppos'd. The mind always pronounces the one not to be the other, and considers them as forming two, three, or any determinate number of objects, whose existences are entirely distinct and independent.

另一方面，多个物体永远无法传达这种想法，无论它们多么相似。心灵总是宣布一个不是另一个，并认为它们构成两个、三个或任何确定数量的物体，它们的存在是完全不同和独立的。

Since then both number and unity are incompatible with the relation of identity, it must lie in something that is neither of them. But to tell the truth, at first sight this seems utterly impossible. Betwixt unity and number there can be no medium; no more than betwixt existence and non-existence. After one object is suppos'd to exist, we must either suppose another also to exist; in which case we have the idea of number: Or we must suppose it not to exist; in which case the first object remains at unity.

既然数量和统一性都与同一性的关系不相容，那么它就必须存在于两者都不是的东西中。但说实话，乍一看，这似乎完全不可能。在统一性和数量之间，不可能有任何媒介；就像在存在和不存在之间一样。在一个物体被假定为存在之后，我们必须假定另一个物体也存在；在这种情况下，我们就有了数的概念。或者我们必须假设它不存在；在这种情况下，第一个物体仍然是统一的。

To remove this difficulty, let us have recourse to the idea of time or duration. I have already observ'd31, that time, in a strict sense, implies succession, and that when we apply its idea to any unchangeable object, 'tis only by a fiction of the imagination, by which the unchangeable object is suppos'd to participate of the changes of the co-existent objects, and in particular of that of our perceptions. This fiction of the imagination almost universally takes place; and 'tis by means of it, that a single object, plac'd before us, and survey'd for any time without our discovering in it any interruption or variation, is able to give us a notion of identity. For when we consider any two points of this time, we may place them in different lights: We may either survey them at the very same instant; in which case they give us the idea of number, both by themselves and by the object; which must be multiply'd, in order to be conceiv'd at once, as existent in these two different points of time: Or on the other hand, we may trace the succession of time by alike succession of ideas, and conceiving first one moment, along with the object then existent, imagine afterwards a change in the time without any variation or interruption in the object; in which case it gives us the idea of unity. Here then is an idea, which is a medium betwixt unity and number; or more properly speaking, is either of them, according to the view, in which we take it: And this idea we call that of identity. We cannot, in any propriety of speech, say, that an object is the same with itself, unless we mean, that the object existent at one time is the same with itself existent at another. By this means we make a difference, betwixt the idea meant by the word, object, and that meant by itself, without going the length of number, and at the same time without restraining ourselves to a strict and absolute unity.

为了消除这一困难，让我们求助于时间或期限的概念。我已经说过31当我们把时间的概念应用于任何不可改变的物体时，只是通过想象力的虚构，把不可改变的物体假设为参与了共同存在的物体的变化，特别是参与了我们的感知的变化。这种想象力的虚构几乎是普遍存在的；正是通过这种虚构，一个单一的物体，摆在我们面前，并且在我们没有发现它的任何中断或变化的情况下进行任何时间的观察，就能够给我们一个相同的概念。因为当我们考虑这个时间的任何两点时，我们可以把它们放在不同的光线下。我们可以在同一时刻对它们进行观察；在这种情况下，它们给我们提供了数字的概念，既包括它们本身，也包括对象；它们必须是乘法的，以便一下子就被设想为存在于这两个不同的时间点上。或者在另一方面，我们可以通过同样的观念继承来追踪时间的继承，首先设想一个时刻，连同当时存在的对象，然后想象时间的变化，而对象没有任何变化或中断；在这种情况下，它给了我们统一性的观念。因此，这里有一个概念，它是统一性和数量之间的媒介；或者更恰当地说，根据我们的观点，它是它们中的任何一个。这个概念我们称之为同一性的概念。我们不能以任何恰当的语言说，一个物体与它本身是相同的，除非我们的意思是，在一个时间存在的物体与另一个时间存在的物体是相同的。通过这种方式，我们在 “对象” 这个词所代表的概念和它本身所代表的概念之间做出了区别，而不至于像数字那样冗长，同时也不至于把自己限制在一个严格和绝对的统一体中。

Thus the principle of individuation is nothing but the invariableness and uninteruptedness of any object, thro' a suppos'd variation of time, by which the mind can trace it in the different periods of its existence, without any break of the view, and without being oblig'd to form the idea of multiplicity or number.

因此，个体化的原则不过是任何物体的不变性和不间断性，通过假定的时间变化，心灵可以在其存在的不同时期对其进行追踪，而没有任何观点的中断，也没有义务形成多重性或数量的概念。

I now proceed to explain the second part of my system, and shew why the constancy of our perceptions makes us ascribe to them a perfect numerical identity, tho' there be very long intervals betwixt their appearance, and they have only one of the essential qualities of identity, viz. invariableness. That I may avoid all ambiguity and confusion on this head, I shall observe, that I here account for the opinions and belief of the vulgar with regard to the existence of body; and therefore must entirely conform myself to their manner of thinking and of expressing themselves. Now we have already observ'd, that however philosophers may distinguish betwixt the objects and perceptions of the senses; which they suppose co-existent and resembling; yet this is a distinction, which is not comprehended by the generality of mankind, who as they perceive only one being, can never assent to the opinion of a double existence and representation. Those very sensations, which enter by the eye or ear, are with them the true objects, nor can they readily conceive that this pen or paper, which is immediately perceiv'd, represents another, which is different from, but resembling it. In order, therefore, to accommodate myself to their notions, I shall at first suppose; that there is only a single existence, which I shall call indifferently object or perception, according as it shall seem best to suit my purpose, understanding by both of them what any common man means by a hat, or shoe, or stone, or any other impression, convey'd to him by his senses. I shall be sure to give warning, when I return to a more philosophical way of speaking and thinking.

现在我开始解释我的体系的第二部分，并说明为什么我们的感知的恒定性使我们赋予它们一个完美的数字特性，尽管它们的出现之间有很长的间隔，而且它们只有一个基本的特性，即不变性 。为了避免在这个问题上的一切模糊和混乱，我将指出，我在这里说明了俗人对身体存在的看法和信念；因此，我必须完全顺应他们的思维方式和表达方式。现在我们已经注意到，无论哲学家如何区分感官的对象和感知；他们认为这些对象和感知是共存和相似的；但这是一种区别，是一般人所不能理解的，因为他们只感知到一个存在，所以永远无法同意双重存在和表现的观点。那些由眼睛或耳朵进入的感觉，对他们来说才是真正的对象，他们也不能轻易设想，这支立即被感知到的笔或纸，代表着另一个与之不同但又相似的东西。因此，为了适应他们的观念，我将首先假设；只有一个单一的存在，我将根据它似乎最适合我的目的，无所谓地称之为物体或感知，通过这两者理解任何普通人对帽子、鞋子、石头或任何其他印象的意思，由他的感官传达给他。当我回到一个更哲学化的说话和思考方式时，我一定会提出警告。

To enter, therefore, upon the question concerning the source of the error and deception with regard to identity, when we attribute it to our resembling perceptions, notwithstanding their interruption; I must here recal an observation, which I have already prov'd and explain'd32. Nothing is more apt to make us mistake one idea for another, than any relation betwixt them, which associates them together in the imagination, and makes it pass with facility from one to the other. Of all relations, that of resemblance is in this respect the most efficacious; and that because it not only causes an association of ideas, but also of dispositions, and makes us conceive the one idea by an act or operation of the mind, similar to that by which we conceive the other. This circumstance I have observ'd to be of great moment; and we may establish it for a general rule, that whatever ideas place the mind in the same disposition or in similar ones, are very apt to be confounded. The mind readily passes from one to the other, and perceives not the change without a strict attention, of which, generally speaking, 'tis wholly incapable.

因此，当我们把身份方面的错误和欺骗归因于我们相似的知觉时，尽管它们被打断了，但为了进入有关问题，我必须在此回顾我已经证明和解释过的一个观点32. 没有什么比它们之间的任何关系更容易使我们把一个概念误认为另一个概念，这种关系在想象中把它们联系在一起，并使它能顺利地从一个转移到另一个。在所有的关系中，相似的关系在这方面是最有效的；这是因为它不仅引起观念的联想，而且还引起处置的联想，使我们通过心灵的行动或操作来构思一个观念，与我们构思另一个观念的行动或操作类似。我认为这一情况非常重要；我们可以把它确立为一条普遍的规则，即无论什么想法都会使头脑处于相同或相似的处置中，都很容易被混淆起来。心灵很容易从一个转向另一个，如果没有严格的注意，就不会察觉到这种变化，而一般来说，这种变化是完全不可能的。

In order to apply this general maxim, we must first examine the disposition of the mind in viewing any object which preserves a perfect identity, and then find some other object, that is confounded with it, by causing a similar disposition. When we fix our thought on any object, and suppose it to continue the same for some time; 'tis evident we suppose the change to lie only in the time, and never exert ourselves to produce any new image or idea of the object. The faculties of the mind repose themselves in a manner, and take no more exercise, than what is necessary to continue that idea, of which we were formerly possest, and which subsists without variation or interruption. The passage from one moment to another is scarce felt, and distinguishes not itself by a different perception or idea, which may require a different direction of the spirits, in order to its conception.

为了应用这条一般的格言，我们必须首先检查在观看任何保持完全一致的物体时的心态，然后找到一些其他物体，通过引起类似的心态而与之相混淆。当我们把我们的思想固定在任何物体上，并假设它在一段时间内保持不变；很明显，我们认为变化只在于时间，而从未努力产生任何新的物体的形象或想法。心灵的能力在某种程度上是静止的，没有更多的锻炼，只是为了延续我们以前所拥有的那个想法，而且这个想法没有变化或中断。从一个时刻到另一个时刻，我们几乎感觉不到，也不会以不同的感知或想法来区分自己，这可能需要精神的不同方向，以实现其概念。

Now what other objects, beside identical ones, are capable of placing the mind in the same disposition, when it considers them, and of causing the same uninterrupted passage of the imagination from one idea to another? This question is of the last importance. For if we can find any such objects, we may certainly conclude, from the foregoing principle, that they are very naturally confounded with identical ones, and are taken for them in most of our reasonings. But tho' this question be very important, 'tis not very difficult nor doubtful. For I immediately reply, that a succession of related objects places the mind in this disposition, and is consider'd with the same smooth and uninterrupted progress of the imagination, as attends the view of the same invariable object. The very nature and essence of relation is to connect our ideas with each other, and upon the appearance of one, to facilitate the transition to its correlative. The passage betwixt related ideas is, therefore, so smooth and easy, that it produces little alteration on the mind, and seems like the continuation of the same action; and as the continuation of the same action is an effect of the continu'd view of the same object, 'tis for this reason we attribute sameness to every succession of related objects. The thought slides along the succession with equal facility, as if it consider'd only one object; and therefore confounds the succession with the identity.

现在，除了相同的对象之外，还有什么其他的对象能够使人在考虑这些对象时处于同样的状态，并使想象力同样不间断地从一个想法到另一个想法？这个问题是最重要的。因为如果我们能找到任何这样的对象，我们当然可以从前面的原则中得出结论，它们非常自然地与相同的对象相混淆，并在我们大多数的推理中被当作它们。但是，尽管这个问题非常重要，它并不十分困难，也不值得怀疑。因为我立即回答说，一连串有关系的物体使人的思想处于这种状态，并以想象力的同样顺利和不间断的进展来考虑，就像看待同一不变的物体一样。关系的本质是将我们的观念相互联系起来，当一个观念出现时，便于过渡到它的对应物。因此，相关概念之间的传递是如此顺利和容易，以至于它在头脑中产生的变化很小，看起来就像同一行动的延续；由于同一行动的延续是对同一对象的持续看法的结果，因此我们把同一性归于每一个相关对象的连续。思想以同样的方式沿着连续的物体滑动，就像它只考虑一个物体一样；因此把连续和同一混淆了。

We shall afterwards see many instances of this tendency of relation to make us ascribe an identity to different objects; but shall here confine ourselves to the present subject. We find by experience, that there is such a constancy in almost all the impressions of the senses, that their interruption produces no alteration on them, and hinders them not from returning the same in appearance and in situation as at their first existence. I survey the furniture of my chamber; I shut my eyes, and afterwards open them; and find the new perceptions to resemble perfectly those, which formerly struck my senses. This resemblance is observ'd in a thousand instances, and naturally connects together our ideas of these interrupted perceptions by the strongest relation, and conveys the mind with an easy transition from one to another. An easy transition or passage of the imagination, along the ideas of these different and interrupted perceptions, is almost the same disposition of mind with that in which we consider one constant and uninterrupted perception. 'Tis therefore very natural for us to mistake the one for the other33.

我们以后会看到许多例子，说明这种关系的趋势使我们对不同的对象归结为同一性；但在这里我们将把自己限制在目前的主题上。我们通过经验发现，几乎所有的感官印象都有这样的恒定性，它们的中断不会对它们产生任何改变，也不会妨碍它们在外观和状况上恢复到最初存在时的样子。我观察我房间里的家具；我闭上眼睛，然后睁开眼睛；发现新的感觉与以前冲击我的感官的那些感觉完全相似。这种相似性在无数的例子中被观察到，并且自然而然地将我们对这些被打断的感知的想法通过最强烈的关系连接在一起，并使心灵从一个过渡到另一个。想象力的轻松转换或通过，沿着这些不同的和中断的感知的想法，几乎是相同的心态，在其中我们认为一个恒定的和不间断的感知。因此，我们很自然地把一个误认为另一个。33.

The persons, who entertain this opinion concerning the identity of our resembling perceptions, are in general all the unthinking and unphilosophical part of mankind, (that is, all of us, at one time or other) and consequently such as suppose their perceptions to be their only objects, and never think of a double existence internal and external, representing and represented. The very image, which is present to the senses, is with us the real body; and 'tis to these interrupted images we ascribe a perfect identity. But as the interruption of the appearance seems contrary to the identity, and naturally leads us to regard these resembling perceptions as different from each other, we here find ourselves at a loss how to reconcile such opposite opinions. The smooth passage of the imagination along the ideas of the resembling perceptions makes us ascribe to them a perfect identity. The interrupted manner of their appearance makes us consider them as so many resembling, but still distinct beings, which appear after certain intervals. The perplexity arising from this contradiction produces a propension to unite these broken appearances by the fiction of a continu'd existence, which is the third part of that hypothesis I propos'd to explain.

对我们相似的知觉的同一性持有这种看法的人，一般都是人类中所有不思考和不懂哲学的人，（也就是我们所有人，在某个时候），因此，他们认为他们的知觉是他们唯一的对象，而从不认为有内部和外部、代表和被代表的双重存在。呈现在感官面前的形象，对我们来说就是真实的身体；对于这些中断的形象，我们赋予了完美的身份。但是，由于表象的中断似乎与同一性相反，并自然导致我们将这些相似的知觉视为彼此不同，我们在此发现自己不知道如何调和这种相反的观点。想象力沿着相似知觉的观念顺利通过，使我们把它们归于完美的同一性。它们出现的中断方式使我们认为它们是许多相似的、但仍然是不同的生命，在一定的间隔后出现。这种矛盾所产生的困惑产生了一种倾向，即通过连续存在的虚构来统一这些断裂的表象，这就是我提议解释的那个假设的第三部分。

Nothing is more certain from experience, than that any contradiction either to the sentiments or passions gives a sensible uneasiness, whether it proceeds from without or from within; from the opposition of external objects, or from the combat of internal principles. On the contrary, whatever strikes in with the natural propensities, and either externally forwards their satisfaction, or internally concurs with their movements, is sure to give a sensible pleasure. Now there being here an opposition betwixt the notion of the identity of resembling perceptions, and the interruption of their appearance, the mind must be uneasy in that situation, and will naturally seek relief from the uneasiness. Since the uneasiness arises from the opposition of two contrary principles, it must look for relief by sacrificing the one to the other. But as the smooth passage of our thought along our resembling perceptions makes us ascribe to them an identity, we can never without reluctance yield up that opinion. We must, therefore, turn to the other side, and suppose that our perceptions are no longer interrupted, but preserve a continu'd as well as an invariable existence, and are by that means entirely the same. But here the interruptions in the appearance of these perceptions are so long and frequent, that 'tis impossible to overlook them; and as the appearance of a perception in the mind and its existence seem at first sight entirely the same, it may be doubted, whether we can ever assent to so palpable a contradiction, and suppose a perception to exist without being present to the mind. In order to clear up this matter, and learn how the interruption in the appearance of a perception implies not necessarily an interruption in its existence, 'twill be proper to touch upon some principles, which we shall have occasion to explain more fully afterwards34.

根据经验，没有什么比任何与情感或激情的矛盾会给人带来明显的不安更确定的了，不管它是来自外部还是内部；来自外部物体的对抗，还是来自内部原则的斗争。相反，凡是与自然倾向相冲突的东西，无论是从外部促进它们的满足，还是从内部与它们的运动相一致，都肯定会给人以明显的快乐。现在，在这里，相似知觉的同一性概念与它们出现的中断之间存在着对立，心灵在这种情况下一定会感到不安，并会自然地从不安中寻求解脱。由于这种不安来自于两个相反的原则的对立，它必须通过牺牲一个原则来寻求缓解。但是，由于我们的思想沿着我们相似的知觉顺利通过，使我们把它们归结为同一性，我们永远不会不情愿地放弃这种观点。因此，我们必须转向另一面，并假设我们的感知不再是中断的，而是保持着持续的以及不变的存在，并且通过这种方式完全相同。但在这里，这些知觉的出现的中断是如此之长和频繁，以至于不可能忽视它们；由于知觉在头脑中的出现和它的存在乍一看完全一样，人们可能会怀疑，我们是否能同意如此明显的矛盾，并假设知觉存在而不存在于头脑中。为了澄清这个问题，并了解感知的外观中断如何意味着它的存在不一定中断，我们应该触及一些原则，我们将在以后有机会更充分地解释这些原则。34.

We may begin with observing, that the difficulty in the present case is not concerning the matter of fact, or whether the mind forms such a conclusion concerning the continu'd existence of its perceptions, but only concerning the manner in which the conclusion is form'd, and principles from which it is deriv'd. 'Tis certain, that almost all mankind, and even philosophers themselves, for the greatest part of their lives, take their perceptions to be their only objects, and suppose, that the very being, which is intimately present to the mind, is the real body or material existence. 'Tis also certain, that this very perception or object is suppos'd to have a continu'd uninterrupted being, and neither to be annihilated by our absence, nor to be brought into existence by our presence. When we are absent from it, we say it still exists, but that we do not feel, we do not see it. When we are present, we say we feel, or see it. Here then may arise two questions; First, How we can satisfy ourselves in supposing a perception to be absent from the mind without being annihilated. Secondly, After what manner we conceive an object to become present to the mind, without some new creation of a perception or image; and what we mean by this seeing, and feeling, and perceiving. a As to the first question; we may observe, that what we call a mind, is nothing but a heap or collection of different perceptions, united together by certain relations, and suppos'd, tho' falsely, to be endow'd with a perfect simplicity and identity. Now as every perception is distinguishable from another, and may be consider'd as separately existent; it evidently follows, that there is no absurdity in separating any particular perception from the mind; that is, in breaking off all its relations, with that connected mass of perceptions, which constitute a thinking being.

我们可以先观察一下，本案例中的困难不在于事实问题，也不在于心灵是否对其感知的持续存在形成这样的结论，而只在于形成结论的方式，以及推导结论的原则。可以肯定的是，几乎所有的人，甚至是哲学家自己，在他们生活的大部分时间里，都把他们的知觉当作他们唯一的对象，并且认为，与心灵密切相关的存在就是真正的身体或物质存在。同样可以肯定的是，这个感知或对象被认为有一个持续的、不间断的存在，既不会因为我们的离开而消失，也不会因为我们的存在而产生。当我们不在它身边时，我们说它仍然存在，但我们没有感觉，我们没有看到它。当我们在场时，我们说我们感觉到，或看到它。那么，这里可能会出现两个问题：第一，我们怎样才能使自己满意，假设一个感知不在头脑中而不被湮灭。至于第一个问题，我们可以看到，我们所谓的心灵，不过是一堆不同的知觉的集合，通过某些关系结合在一起，并被假定为具有完美的简单性和同一性，尽管这是错误的。现在，由于每一种感知都可以与另一种感知区分开来，并且可以被认为是单独存在的；显然，把任何特定的感知从心灵中分离出来并不荒谬；也就是说，把它的所有关系与构成一个有思想的生命的那批感知切断。

The same reasoning affords us an answer to the second question. If the name of perception renders not this separation from a mind absurd and contradictory, the name of object, standing for the very same thing, can never render their conjunction impossible. External objects are seen, and felt, and become present to the mind; that is, they acquire such a relation to a connected heap of perceptions, as to influence them very considerably in augmenting their number by present reflections and passions, and in storing the memory with ideas. The same continu'd and uninterrupted Being may, therefore, be sometimes present to the mind, and sometimes absent from it, without any real or essential change in the Being itself. An interrupted appearance to the senses implies not necessarily an interruption in the existence. The supposition of the continu'd existence of sensible objects or perceptions involves no contradiction. We may easily indulge our inclination to that supposition. When the exact resemblance of our perceptions makes us ascribe to them an identity, we may remove the seeming interruption by feigning a continu'd being, which may fill those intervals, and preserve a perfect and entire identity to our perceptions.

同样的推理为我们提供了第二个问题的答案。如果感知的名称不会使这种与心灵的分离变得荒谬和矛盾，那么代表同一事物的对象的名称就永远不会使它们的结合变得不可能。外部物体被看到，被感觉到，并成为心灵的存在；也就是说，它们获得了与一堆相连的感知的关系，以至于在通过当前的思考和激情来增加它们的数量，并在记忆中储存观念方面对它们产生了非常大的影响。因此，同一个连续的、不间断的存在，有时会出现在头脑中，有时又不在头脑中，而存在本身没有任何真实的或本质的变化。对感官来说，一个中断的外观不一定意味着存在的中断。假设感性对象或知觉的持续存在，并不涉及矛盾。我们可以轻易地放纵我们对这种假设的倾向。当我们的感知的确切相似性使我们归因于它们的同一性时，我们可以通过假装一个连续的存在来消除看似中断的现象，它可以填补这些间隔，并对我们的感知保持一个完美和完整的同一性。

But as we here not only feign but believe this continu'd existence, the question is, from whence arises such a belief; and this question leads us to the forth member of this system. It has been prov'd already, that belief in general consists in nothing, but the vivacity of an idea; and that an idea may acquire this vivacity by its relation to some present impression. Impressions are naturally the most vivid perceptions of the mind; and this quality is in part convey'd by the relation to every connected idea. The relation causes a smooth passage from the impression to the idea, and even gives a propensity to that passage. The mind falls so easily from the one perception to the other, that it scarce perceives the change, but retains in the second a considerable share of the vivacity of the first. It is excited by the lively impression; and this vivacity is convey'd to the related idea, without any great diminution in the passage, by reason of the smooth transition and the propensity of the imagination.

但是，由于我们在这里不仅佯装而且相信这种持续的存在，问题是，这种信念是从哪里产生的；这个问题把我们引向这个系统的第四个成员。我们已经证明，一般来说，信仰不在于什么，而在于一个观念的活力；而一个观念可以通过它与某些当前印象的关系获得这种活力。印象自然是头脑中最生动的知觉；而这种品质在一定程度上是通过与每一个相关概念的关系来传达的。这种关系导致了从印象到观念的顺利通过，甚至为这种通过提供了一种倾向。心灵如此轻易地从一种感知落到另一种感知，以至于它几乎察觉不到这种变化，而是在第二种感知中保留了第一种感知的相当份额的活力。它被活泼的印象所激发；这种活泼性被传达给了相关的想法，由于平稳的过渡和想象力的倾向，这段话没有任何大的减弱。

But suppose, that this propensity arises from some other principle, besides that of relation; 'tis evident it must still have the same effect, and convey the vivacity from the impression to the idea. Now this is exactly the present case. Our memory presents us with a vast number of instances of perceptions perfectly resembling each other, that return at different distances of time, and after considerable interruptions. This resemblance gives us a propension to consider these interrupted perceptions as the same; and also a propension to connect them by a continu'd existence, in order to justify this identity, and avoid the contradiction, in which the interrupted appearance of these perceptions seems necessarily to involve us. Here then we have a propensity to feign the continu'd existence of all sensible objects; and as this propensity arises from some lively impressions of the memory, it bestows a vivacity on that fiction; or in other words, makes us believe the continu'd existence of body. If sometimes we ascribe a continu'd existence to objects, which are perfectly new to us, and of whose constancy and coherence we have no experience, 'tis because the manner, in which they present themselves to our senses, resembles that of constant and coherent objects; and this resemblance is a source of reasoning and analogy, and leads us to attribute the same qualities to the similar objects.

但是，假设这种倾向是由关系以外的其他原则产生的；很明显，它仍然必须具有相同的效果，并将活力从印象传达给观念。现在，这正是目前的情况。我们的记忆为我们提供了大量的感知实例，它们彼此完全相似，在不同的时间距离和相当长的中断后返回。这种相似性使我们有一种倾向性，认为这些中断的知觉是相同的；也有一种倾向性，将它们通过持续的存在联系起来，以证明这种同一性，并避免矛盾，因为这些知觉的中断出现似乎必然使我们陷入其中。因此，我们有一种假装所有可感对象持续存在的倾向；由于这种倾向来自于记忆中一些生动的印象，它赋予了这种虚构以活力；或者换句话说，使我们相信身体的持续存在。如果有时我们把对我们来说完全陌生的物体归结为持续存在，而且我们对其恒定性和一致性没有经验，那是因为它们呈现在我们感官中的方式与恒定和一致的物体相似；这种相似性是推理和类比的来源，并导致我们把同样的品质归结为类似的物体。

I believe an intelligent reader will find less difficulty to assent to this system, than to comprehend it fully and distinctly, and will allow, after a little reelection, that every part carries its own proof along with it. 'Tis indeed evident, that as the vulgar suppose their perceptions to be their only objects, and at the same time believe the continu'd existence of matter, we must account for the origin of the belief upon that supposition. Now upon that supposition, 'tis a false opinion that any of our objects, or perceptions, are identically the same after an interruption; and consequently the opinion of their identity can never arise from reason, but must arise from the imagination. The imagination is seduc'd into such an opinion only by means of the resemblance of certain perceptions; since we find they are only our resembling perceptions, which we have a propension to suppose the same. This propension to bestow an identity on our resembling perceptions, produces the fiction of a continu'd existence; since that fiction, as well as the identity, is really false, as is acknowledge'd by all philosophers, and has no other effect than to remedy the interruption of our perceptions, which is the only circumstance that is contrary to their identity. In the last place this propension causes belief by means of the present impressions of the memory; since without the remembrance of former sensations, 'tis plain we never shou'd have any belief of the continu'd existence of body. Thus in examining all these parts, we find that each of them is supported by the strongest proofs; and that all of them together form a consistent system, which is perfectly convincing. A strong propensity or inclination alone, without any present impression, will sometimes cause a belief or opinion. How much more when aided by that circumstance?

我相信，聪明的读者会发现，同意这一体系的难度要小于充分和清晰地理解它，而且在稍加思考后，会发现每一部分都有它自己的证据。这的确很明显，因为庸人认为他们的感知是他们唯一的对象，同时又相信物质的持续存在，我们必须在这个假设的基础上说明信仰的起源。现在，根据这一假设，认为我们的任何对象或感知在中断后是相同的，这是一个错误的观点；因此，关于它们的同一性的观点永远不可能来自理性，而必须来自想象力。想象力只有通过某些知觉的相似性才会被引诱到这种观点中；因为我们发现它们只是我们相似的知觉，我们有一种假设相同的倾向。这种赋予我们相似的知觉以同一性的倾向，产生了持续存在的虚构；因为这种虚构以及同一性实际上是虚假的，正如所有哲学家所承认的那样，除了补救我们知觉的中断外，没有其他作用，而这是唯一与它们的同一性相反的情况。最后，这种悬念通过记忆中的现时印象而引起信仰；因为如果没有对以前感觉的记忆，我们就不可能对身体的持续存在产生任何信仰。因此，在研究所有这些部分时，我们发现每一个部分都有最有力的证据支持；而且所有这些部分共同构成了一个一致的系统，完全令人信服。仅仅是一种强烈的倾向性，而没有任何现时的印象，有时就会引起一种信仰或意见。如果有这种情况的帮助，那就更有可能了。

But tho' we are led after this manner, by the natural propensity of the imagination, to ascribe a continu'd existence to those sensible objects or perceptions, which we find to resemble each other in their interrupted appearance; yet a very little reflection and philosophy is sufficient to make us perceive the fallacy of that opinion. I have already observ'd, that there is an intimate connexion betwixt those two principles, of a continu'd and of a distinct or independent existence, and that we no sooner establish the one than the other follows, as a necessary consequence. 'Tis the opinion of a continu'd existence, which first takes place, and without much study or reflection draws the other along with it, wherever the mind follows its first and most natural tendency. But when we compare experiments, and reason a little upon them, we quickly perceive, that the doctrine of the independent existence of our sensible perceptions is contrary to the plainest experience. This leads us backward upon our footsteps to perceive our error in attributing a continu'd existence to our perceptions, and is the origin of many very curious opinions, which we shall here endeavour to account for.

但是，尽管我们在这种方式下，被想象力的自然倾向所引导，将持续的存在归于那些我们发现在其间断的外观中彼此相似的可感对象或感知；但是，稍加思考和哲学就足以使我们认识到这种观点的错误。我已经注意到，在这两个原则之间存在着密切的联系，一个是连续的存在，一个是独特的或独立的存在，我们刚确立了一个原则，另一个原则就作为一个必然的结果出现了。这就是连续存在的观点，它首先发生，并且不需要过多的研究或思考，就能把另一个观点吸引过来，只要头脑遵循其最初和最自然的趋向。但是，当我们对实验进行比较，并在此基础上稍作推理，我们很快就会发现，关于我们的感性认识独立存在的学说与最简单的经验相悖。这使我们向后看，认识到我们把持续存在归于我们的知觉的错误，这也是许多非常奇怪的观点的起源，我们将在此努力解释。

'Twill first be proper to observe a few of those experiments, which convince us, that our perceptions are not possest of any independent existence. When we press one eye with a finger, we immediately perceive all the objects to become double, and one half of them to be remov'd from their common and natural position. But as we do not attribute a continu'd existence to both these perceptions, and as they are both of the same nature, we clearly perceive, that all our perceptions are dependent on our organs, and the disposition of our nerves and animal spirits. This opinion is confirm'd by the seeming encrease and diminution of objects, according to their distance; by the apparent alterations in their figure; by the changes in their colour and other qualities from our sickness and distempers; and by an infinite number of other experiments of the same kind; from all which we learn, that our sensible perceptions are not possest of any distinct or independent existence.

首先应该观察一些实验，这些实验使我们相信，我们的知觉不具有任何独立的存在。当我们用手指按压一只眼睛时，我们立即感觉到所有的物体都变成了双倍，其中一半的物体从它们共同的和自然的位置移开了。但是，由于我们没有把持续的存在归于这两种知觉，而且它们都具有相同的性质，我们清楚地认识到，我们所有的知觉都依赖于我们的器官，以及我们的神经和动物精神的处置。这一观点被以下事实所证实：根据距离的远近，物体似乎在增加和减少；它们的形状有明显的变化；它们的颜色和其他质量因我们的疾病和痛苦而发生变化；以及其他无数的同类实验；从所有这些实验中我们了解到，我们的感官知觉并不拥有任何独特或独立的存在。

The natural consequence of this reasoning shou'd be, that our perceptions have no more a continu'd than an independent existence; and indeed philosophers have so far run into this opinion, that they change their system, and distinguish, (as we shall do for the future) betwixt perceptions and objects, of which the former are suppos'd to be interrupted, and perishing, and different at every different return; the latter to be uninterrupted, and to preserve a continu'd existence and identity.
