But however philosophical this new system may be esteem'd, I assert that 'tis only a palliative remedy, and that it contains all the difficulties of the vulgar system, with some others, that are peculiar to itself. There are no principles either of the understanding or fancy, which lead us directly to embrace this opinion of the double existence of perceptions and objects, nor can we arrive at it but by passing thro' the common hypothesis of the identity and continuance of our interrupted perceptions. Were we not first persuaded, that our perceptions are our only objects, and continue to exist even when they no longer make their appearance to the senses, we shou'd never be led to think, that our perceptions and objects are different, and that our objects alone preserve a continu'd existence. 'The latter hypothesis has no primary recommendation either to reason or the imagination, but acquires all its influence on the imagination from the former.' This proposition contains two parts, which we shall endeavour to prove as distinctly and clearly, as such abstruse subjects will permit.

这种推理的自然结果应该是，我们的知觉并不比独立的存在更有连续性；事实上，哲学家们已经远远陷入了这种观点，以至于他们改变了他们的体系，并将知觉和物体区分开来，（就像我们将来要做的那样），前者被认为是中断的、消亡的，并且在每次不同的返回时都是不同的；后者则是不间断的，并保持持续的存在和特性。但是，无论这个新体系多么具有哲学意义，我断言，它只是一个治标不治本的办法，它包含了庸俗体系的所有困难，以及其他一些自身所特有的困难。无论是理解力还是想象力，都没有任何原则可以直接引导我们接受这种关于知觉和物体双重存在的观点，我们也不可能通过对我们中断的知觉的同一性和持续性的共同假设来达到这一目的。如果我们不是首先被说服，认为我们的知觉是我们唯一的对象，而且即使它们不再出现在感官上也继续存在，我们就不会被引导去想，我们的知觉和对象是不同的，而且只有我们的对象保持持续的存在。后一种假设对理性或想象力都没有主要的建议，但它对想象力的影响都来自前者。这个命题包含两个部分，我们将努力在这种深奥的主题允许的范围内，尽可能清晰明确地证明这两个部分。

As to the first part of the proposition, that this philosophical hypotheses has no primary recommendation, either to reason or the imagination,, we may soon satisfy ourselves with regard to reason by the following reflections. The only existences, of which we are certain, are perceptions, which being immediately present to us by consciousness, command our strongest assent, and are the first foundation of all our conclusions. The only conclusion we can draw from the existence of one thing to that of another, is by means of the relation of cause and effect, which shews, that there is a connexion betwixt them, and that the existence of one is dependent on that of the other. The idea of this relation is deriv'd from past experience, by which we find, that two beings are constantly conjoin'd together, and are always present at once to the mind. But as no beings are ever present to the mind but perceptions; it follows that we may observe a conjunction or a relation of cause and effect between different perceptions, but can never observe it between perceptions and objects. 'Tis impossible, therefore, that from the existence or any of the qualities of the former, we can ever form any conclusion concerning the existence of the latter, or ever satisfy our reason in this particular.

至于命题的第一部分，即这一哲学假说对理性或想象力都没有主要的建议，我们可以通过以下的思考很快满足自己对理性的要求。我们唯一确定的存在是感知，它通过意识立即呈现在我们面前，得到我们最强烈的赞同，并且是我们所有结论的第一个基础。我们从一个事物的存在到另一个事物的存在所能得出的唯一结论是通过因果关系，这表明它们之间存在着一种联系，而且一个事物的存在取决于另一个事物的存在。这种关系的概念来自于过去的经验，通过这种经验我们发现，两个生命不断地结合在一起，并且总是同时存在于心灵中。但是，由于除了感知之外，没有任何生命存在于心灵中；因此，我们可以观察到不同感知之间的结合或因果关系，但永远无法观察到感知与物体之间的关系。因此，我们不可能从前者的存在或任何品质中得出关于后者存在的任何结论，也不可能在这一点上满足我们的理性。

'Tis no less certain, that this philosophical system has no primary recommendation to the imagination, and that that faculty wou'd never, of itself, and by its original tendency. have fallen upon such a principle. I confess it will be somewhat difficult to prove this to the full satisfaction of the reader; because it implies a negative, which in many cases will not admit of any positive proof. If any one wou'd take the pains to examine this question, and wou'd invent a system, to account for the direct origin of this opinion from the imagination, we shou'd be able, by the examination of that system, to pronounce a certain judgment in the present subject. Let it be taken for granted, that our perceptions are broken, and interrupted, and however like, are still different from each other; and let any one upon this supposition shew why the fancy, directly and immediately, proceeds to the belief of another existence, resembling these perceptions in their nature, but yet continu'd, and uninterrupted, and identical; and after he has done this to my satisfaction, I promise to renounce my present opinion. Mean while I cannot forbear concluding, from the very abstractedness and difficulty of the first supposition, that 'tis an improper subject for the fancy to work upon. Whoever wou'd explain the origin of the common opinion concerning the continu'd and distinct existence of body, must take the mind in its common situation, and must proceed upon the supposition, that our perceptions are our only objects, and continue to exist even when they are not perceiv'd. Tho' this opinion be false, 'tis the most natural of any, and has alone any primary recommendation to the fancy.

同样可以肯定的是，这个哲学体系对想象力没有任何主要的建议，而且这种能力本身和它的原始倾向绝不会落在这样的原则上。我承认，要证明这一点使读者完全满意是有些困难的；因为这意味着一种否定，而这种否定在许多情况下是不允许有任何正面证明的。如果有人愿意花心思研究这个问题，并发明一个系统，来解释这种观点直接来自想象力，我们就能通过对这个系统的研究，对这个问题作出一定的判断。让我们想当然地认为，我们的认识是断裂的、中断的，而且无论多么相似，都是彼此不同的；让任何一个人在这个假设下说明，为什么想象力会直接和立即开始相信另一种存在，与这些认识的性质相似，但又是持续的、不间断的和相同的；在他做到这一点使我满意之后，我保证会放弃我现在的观点。同时，我不能不得出结论，从第一个假设的抽象性和困难性来看，这是个不适合幻想的主题。无论谁想解释关于身体持续和独特存在的常见观点的起源，都必须把心灵放在其常见的情况下，并且必须在假设的基础上进行，即我们的感知是我们唯一的对象，并且即使在它们不被感知的时候也继续存在。尽管这种观点是错误的，但它是所有观点中最自然的，而且只有它才有对幻想的任何主要建议。

As to the second part of the proposition, that the philosophical system acquires all its influence on the imagination from the vulgar one; we may observe, that this is a natural and unavoidable consequence of the foregoing conclusion, that it has no primary recommendation to reason or the imagination. For as the philosophical system is found by experience to take hold of many minds, and in particular of all those, who reflect ever so little on this subject, it must derive all its authority from the vulgar system; since it has no original authority of its own. The manner, in which these two systems, tho' directly contrary, are connected together, may be explain'd, as follows.

至于命题的第二部分，即哲学体系对想象力的影响全部来自于庸俗体系；我们可以注意到，这是上述结论的一个自然和不可避免的结果，即它对理性或想象力没有主要的建议。因为根据经验，哲学体系被许多人所接受，特别是那些对这个问题思考不多的人，它必须从庸俗体系中获得所有的权威；因为它没有自己的原始权威。这两个系统虽然直接相反，但它们联系在一起的方式，可以解释如下。

The imagination naturally runs on in this train of thinking. Our perceptions are our only objects: Resembling perceptions are the same, however broken or uninterrupted in their appearance: This appearing interruption is contrary to the identity: The interruption consequently extends not beyond the appearance, and the perception or object really continues to exist, even when absent from us: Our sensible perceptions have, therefore, a continu'd and uninterrupted existence. But as a little reflection destroys this conclusion, that our perceptions have a continu'd existence, by shewing that they have a dependent one, 'twou'd naturally be expected, that we must altogether reject the opinion, that there is such a. thing in nature as a continu'd existence, which is preserv'd even when it no longer appears to the senses. The case, however, is otherwise. Philosophers are so far from rejecting the opinion of a continu'd existence upon rejecting that of the independence and continuance of our sensible perceptions, that tho' all sects agree in the latter sentiment, the former, which is, in a manner, its necessary consequence, has been peculiar to a few extravagant sceptics; who after all maintain'd that opinion in words only, and were never able to bring themselves sincerely to believe it.

想象力自然而然地在这一思路中运行。我们的知觉是我们唯一的对象。相似的知觉是相同的，无论它们的外观是破碎的还是不间断的。这种表面上的中断是与特性相反的。因此，这种中断并不超越表象，而感知或物体确实继续存在，即使不在我们身边。因此，我们的感性认识有一个持续的和不间断的存在。但是，由于稍加思考就会破坏这个结论，即我们的知觉有一个持续的存在，因为它显示出它们有一个依赖性的存在，所以我们自然会想到，我们必须完全拒绝这种观点，即自然界有这样一种持续的存在，即使它不再出现在感官上也会被保存下来。然而，情况并非如此。哲学家们远远没有在拒绝我们的感性认识的独立性和持续性的观点时拒绝持续存在的观点，尽管所有的教派都同意后一种观点，但前一种观点，也就是它的必然结果，一直是少数奢侈的怀疑论者所特有的；他们毕竟只是在口头上坚持这种观点，而从未能使自己真诚地相信它。

There is a great difference betwixt such opinions as we form after a calm and profound reflection, and such as we embrace by a kind of instinct or natural impulse, on account of their suitableness and conformity to the mind. If these opinions become contrary, 'tis not difficult to foresee which of them will have the advantage. As long as our attention is bent upon the subject, the philosophical and study'd principle may prevail; but the moment we relax our thoughts, nature will display herself, and draw us back to our former opinion. Nay she has sometimes such an influence, that she can stop our progress, even in the midst of our most profound reflections, and keep us from running on with all the consequences of any philosophical opinion. Thus tho' we clearly perceive the dependence and interruption of our perceptions, we stop short in our career, and never upon that account reject the notion of an independent and continu'd existence. That opinion has taken such deep root in the imagination, that 'tis impossible ever to eradicate it, nor will any strain'd metaphysical conviction of the dependence of our perceptions be sufficient for that purpose.

在我们经过冷静而深刻的思考后形成的观点与我们通过一种本能或自然冲动接受的观点之间存在着巨大的差异，因为它们适合并符合我们的思想。如果这些观点变得相反，就不难预料到哪一个会有优势。只要我们的注意力集中在这个问题上，哲学和研究的原则可能会占上风；但一旦我们放松思考，自然就会展示自己，把我们拉回到我们以前的观点。不，她有时会产生这样的影响，甚至在我们最深刻的思考中，也能阻止我们的进步，使我们不至于因任何哲学观点的所有后果而继续前进。因此，尽管我们清楚地意识到我们的感知的依赖性和中断，但我们在我们的职业生涯中停滞不前，而且从未因此而拒绝独立和持续存在的概念。这种观点已经在想象力中扎下了深深的根，以至于不可能将其根除，任何关于我们感知的依赖性的形而上学信念也不足以达到这个目的。

But tho' our natural and obvious principles here prevail above our study'd reflections, 'tis certain there must be some struggle and opposition in the case; at least so long as these reflections retain any force or vivacity. In order to set ourselves at ease in this particular, we contrive a new hypothesis, which seems to comprehend both these principles of reason and imagination. This hypothesis is the philosophical one of the double existence of perceptions and objects; which pleases our reason, in allowing, that our dependent perceptions are interrupted and different; and at the same time is agreeable to the imagination, in attributing a continu'd existence to something else, which we call objects. This philosophical system, therefore, is the monstrous offspring of two principles, which are contrary to each other, which are both at once embrac'd by the mind, and which are unable mutually to destroy each other. The imagination tells us, that our resembling perceptions have a continu'd and uninterrupted existence, and are not annihilated by their absence. Reflection tells us, that even our resembling perceptions are interrupted in their existence, and different from each other. The contradiction betwixt these opinions we elude by a new fiction, which is conformable to the hypotheses both of reflection and fancy, by ascribing these contrary qualities to different existences; the interruption to perceptions, and the continuance to objects. Nature is obstinate, and will not quit the field, however strongly attack'd by reason; and at the same time reason is so clear in the point, that there is no possibility of disguising her. Not being able to reconcile these two enemies, we endeavour to set ourselves at ease as much as possible, by successively granting to each whatever it demands, and by feigning a double existence, where each may find something, that has all the conditions it desires. Were we fully convinc'd, that our resembling perceptions are continu'd, and identical, and independent, we shou'd never run into this opinion of a double existence; since we shou'd find satisfaction in our first supposition, and wou'd not look beyond. Again, were we fully convinc'd, that our perceptions are dependent, and interrupted, and different, we shou'd be as little inclin'd to embrace the opinion of a double existence; since in that case we shou'd clearly perceive the error of our first supposition of a continu'd existence, and wou'd never regard it any farther. 'Tis therefore from the intermediate situation of the mind, that this opinion arises, and from such an adherence to these two contrary principles, as makes us seek some pretext to justify our receiving both; which happily at last is found in the system of a double existence.

但是，尽管我们的自然和明显的原则在这里凌驾于我们研究的思考之上，但可以肯定的是，在这种情况下必须有一些斗争和反对；至少只要这些思考还保留着任何力量或活力。为了在这个问题上让自己安心，我们设计了一个新的假设，它似乎同时包含了这些理性和想象力的原则。这个假说是哲学上的，即感知和物体的双重存在；这使我们的理性高兴，因为它允许我们的依赖性感知是中断的和不同的；同时也符合想象力，因为它把一种持续的存在归于其他东西，我们称之为物体。因此，这个哲学体系是两个原则的畸形后代，这两个原则是相互对立的，它们同时被思想所包容，而且它们无法相互摧毁对方。想象力告诉我们，我们相似的知觉有一个持续和不间断的存在，并不会因为它们的消失而消灭。反思告诉我们，即使是我们相似的知觉，在它们的存在中也是中断的，并且彼此不同。这些观点之间的矛盾，我们通过一种新的虚构来回避，这种虚构符合反思和幻想的假设，把这些相反的品质归结为不同的存在；感知的中断和物体的持续存在。自然是顽固的，无论理性如何强烈攻击，它都不会退出这个领域；同时，理性在这一点上又是如此明确，以至于没有可能掩饰她。由于无法调和这两个敌人，我们就努力使自己尽可能地安心，办法是先后给予每一个人它所要求的东西，并假装有一个双重的存在，在那里每一个人都可以找到具有它所希望的所有条件的东西。如果我们完全相信我们相似的知觉是连续的、相同的、独立的，我们就不会遇到这种双重存在的观点；因为我们会在我们的第一个假设中找到满足感，而不会去看别的。同样，如果我们完全相信我们的知觉是依赖的、中断的和不同的，我们就不会倾向于接受双重存在的观点；因为在这种情况下，我们会清楚地认识到我们关于连续存在的第一个假设的错误，并且永远不会再考虑它。因此，这种观点产生于心灵的中间状态，产生于对这两个相反的原则的坚持，使我们寻找某种借口来证明我们接受这两个原则是正确的；令人高兴的是，最后在双重存在的体系中找到了这种借口。

Another advantage of this philosophical system is its similarity to the vulgar one; by which means we can humour our reason for a moment, when it becomes troublesome and solicitous; and yet upon its least negligence or inattention, can easily return to our vulgar and natural notions. Accordingly we find, that philosophers neglect not this advantage; but immediately upon leaving their closets, mingle with the rest of mankind in those exploded opinions, that our perceptions are our only objects, and continue identically and uninterruptedly the same in all their interrupted appearances.

这种哲学体系的另一个优点是它与粗俗的体系相似；通过这种方式，当我们的理性变得麻烦和谨慎时，我们可以暂时消遣它；但在它最轻微的疏忽或不注意时，又可以轻易地回到我们粗俗和自然的观念中。因此，我们发现，哲学家们并没有忽视这一优势；而是在离开他们的衣橱后，立即与其他人类混在一起，发表那些爆炸性的观点，认为我们的知觉是我们唯一的对象，并在其所有中断的表象中保持相同和不间断的状态。

There are other particulars of this system, wherein we may remark its dependence on the fancy, in a very conspicuous manner. Of these, I shall observe the two following. First, We suppose external objects to resemble internal perceptions. I have already shewn, that the relation of cause and effect can never afford us any just conclusion from the existence or qualities of our perceptions to the existence of external continu'd objects: And I shall farther add, that even tho' they cou'd afford such a conclusion, we shou'd never have any reason to infer, that our objects resemble our perceptions. That opinion, therefore, is deriv'd from nothing but the quality of the fancy above-explain'd, that it borrows all its ideas from some precedent perception. We never can conceive any thing but perceptions, and therefore must make every thing resemble them.

在这个系统的其他细节中，我们可以注意到它以一种非常明显的方式对想象力的依赖。在这些方面，我将观察以下两点。第一，我们假设外部物体类似于内部感知。我已经证明，因果关系永远不会给我们提供任何公正的结论，从我们的感知的存在或质量到外部连续物体的存在。我还要补充说，即使它们能提供这样的结论，我们也没有任何理由推断出我们的物体与我们的感觉相似。因此，这种观点的产生，只是源于上面所解释的幻想的特性，即它的所有想法都来自于某种先验的感知。除了感知，我们永远无法设想任何东西，因此必须使每件东西都与它们相似。

Secondly, As we suppose our objects in general to resemble our perceptions, so we take it for granted, that every particular object resembles that perception, which it causes. The relation of cause and effect determines us to join the other of resemblance; and the ideas of these existences being already united together in the fancy by the former relation, we naturally add the latter to compleat the union. We have a strong propensity to compleat every union by joining new relations to those which we have before observ'd betwixt any ideas, as we shall have occasion to observe presently35.

第二，由于我们认为我们的物体一般都与我们的知觉相似，所以我们认为每个特定的物体都与它所引起的知觉相似，这是理所当然的。因果关系决定了我们要加入另一种相似性；而这些存在的观念已经通过前一种关系在幻想中结合在一起，我们自然会加入后一种关系来完成这种结合。我们有一种强烈的倾向，要把新的关系加入到我们以前观察到的任何观念之间的关系中去，从而完成每一种结合，正如我们现在有机会观察到的那样35.

Having thus given an account of all the systems both popular and philosophical, with regard to external existences, I cannot forbear giving vent to a certain sentiment, which arises upon reviewing those systems. I begun this subject with premising, that we ought to have an implicit faith in our senses, and that this wou'd be the conclusion, I shou'd draw from the whole of my reasoning. But to be ingenuous, I feel myself at present of a quite contrary sentiment, and am more inclin'd to repose no faith at all in my senses; or rather imagination, than to place in it such an implicit confidence. I cannot conceive how such trivial qualities of the fancy, conducted by such false suppositions, can ever lead to any solid and rational system. They are the coherence and constancy of our perceptions, which produce the opinion of their continu'd existence; tho' these qualities of perceptions have no perceivable connexion with such an existence. The constancy of our perceptions has the most considerable effect, and yet is attended with the greatest difficulties. 'Tis a gross illusion to suppose, that our resembling perceptions are numerically the same; and 'tis this illusion, which leads us into the opinion, that these perceptions are uninterrupted, and are still existent, even when they are not present to the senses. This is the case with our popular system. And as to our philosophical one, 'tis liable to the same difficulties; and is over-and-above loaded with this absurdity, that it at once denies and establishes the vulgar supposition. Philosophers deny our resembling perceptions to be identically the same, and uninterrupted; and yet have so great a propensity to believe them such, that they arbitrarily invent a new set of perceptions, to which they attribute these qualities. I say, a new set of perceptions: For we may well suppose in general, but 'tis impossible for us distinctly to conceive, objects to be in their nature any thing but exactly the same with perceptions. What then can we look for from this confusion of groundless and extraordinary opinions but error and falshood? And how can we justify to ourselves any belief we repose in them?

在对所有流行的和哲学的关于外部存在的体系进行了说明之后，我不能不对回顾这些体系时产生的某种情绪进行宣泄。我在开始讨论这个问题的时候，假定我们应该对我们的感官有一种隐秘的信任，而这将是我从整个推理过程中得出的结论。但说句实在话，我觉得自己目前的情绪完全相反，我更倾向于不相信我的感官；或者说是想象力，而不是对它抱有这样一种隐秘的信心。我无法想象，在这种错误的假设指导下，想象力的这种微不足道的品质如何能够导致任何坚实而合理的体系。它们是我们感知的连贯性和恒定性，产生了它们持续存在的观点；尽管这些感知的品质与这种存在没有可感知的联系。我们感知的恒定性具有最重要的作用，但也伴随着最大的困难。假设我们相似的知觉在数量上是相同的，这是一种严重的错觉；正是这种错觉导致我们认为，这些知觉是不间断的，即使它们不在感官上，也仍然存在着。这就是我们的流行体系的情况。至于我们的哲学体系，也有可能遇到同样的困难；而且还充满了这种荒诞性，即它同时否定并确立了庸俗的假设。哲学家们否认我们相似的知觉是完全相同的，而且是不间断的；但他们又如此倾向于相信它们是相同的，以至于他们任意发明了一套新的知觉，并将这些品质归于它们。我说，一套新的知觉。因为我们可以笼统地假设，但我们不可能明确地设想，物体在本质上与感知完全相同。那么，我们从这种毫无根据和非同寻常的观点的混乱中，除了错误和虚假，还能寻找到什么呢？我们又怎么能向自己证明我们对它们的任何信念呢？

This sceptical doubt, both with respect to reason and the senses, is a malady, which can never be radically cur'd, but must return upon us every moment, however we may chace it away, and sometimes may seem entirely free from it. 'Tis impossible upon any system to defend either our understanding or senses; and we but expose them farther when we endeavour to justify them in that manner. As the sceptical doubt arises naturally from a profound and intense reflection on those subjects, it always encreases, the farther we carry our reflections, whether in opposition or conformity to it. Carelessness and in-attention alone can afford us any remedy. For this reason I rely entirely upon them; and take it for granted, whatever may be the reader's opinion at this present moment, that an hour hence he will be persuaded there is both an external and internal world; and going upon that supposition, I intend to examine some general systems both ancient and modern, which have been propos'd of both, before I proceed to a more particular enquiry concerning our impressions. This will not, perhaps, in the end be found foreign to our present purpose.

这种对理性和感官的怀疑，是一种永远无法从根本上治愈的疾病，但每时每刻都会回到我们身上，无论我们如何驱赶它，有时似乎完全摆脱了它。任何系统都不可能为我们的理解力或感官辩护；当我们试图以这种方式为它们辩护时，我们只会使它们更加暴露。由于怀疑的疑虑是由对这些问题的深刻而强烈的思考自然产生的，它总是增加，我们的思考越远，无论是反对还是符合它。只有粗心和不注意才能为我们提供任何补救措施。因此，我完全依赖它们；并且认为，无论读者此时此刻的看法如何，一小时后他就会相信有一个外部和内部世界；根据这一假设，我打算在开始对我们的印象进行更具体的调查之前，先研究一些古代和现代的一般系统，这些系统都是关于这两者的建议。也许，这最终不会与我们目前的目的相悖。

 

Section 3. Of The Antient Philosophy

第三节。关于古代的哲学

 

Several moralists have recommended it as an excellent method of becoming acquainted with our own hearts, and knowing our progress in virtue, to recollect our dreams in a morning, and examine them with the same rigour, that we wou'd our most serious and most deliberate actions. Our character is the same throughout, say they, and appears best where artifice, fear, and policy have no place, and men can neither be hypocrites with themselves nor others. The generosity, or baseness of our temper, our meekness or cruelty, our courage or pusilanimity, influence the fictions of the imagination with the most unbounded liberty, and discover themselves in the most glaring colours. In like manner, I am persuaded, there might be several useful discoveries made from a criticism of the fictions of the antient philosophy, concerning substances, and substantial forms, and accidents, and occult qualities; which, however unreasonable and capricious, have a very intimate connexion with the principles of human nature.

有几位道德家建议，在一个早晨回忆我们的梦境，并以审视我们最严肃和最慎重的行为的同样严格的态度来审视它们，这是熟悉我们自己的内心，了解我们在美德方面的进展的一个很好的方法。他们说，我们的性格自始至终都是一样的，而且在没有欺骗、恐惧和政策的地方显得最好，人们既不能对自己也不能对别人虚情假意。我们脾气的慷慨或卑劣，我们的温顺或残忍，我们的勇气或懦弱，以最无限制的自由影响想象力的虚构，并以最耀眼的色彩发现自己。同样，我相信，通过对古代哲学的虚构进行批判，可能会有一些有益的发现，这些虚构涉及到物质、实质形式、意外和神秘的品质；无论这些虚构多么不合理和反复无常，都与人性的原则有着非常密切的联系。

'Tis confest by the most judicious philosophers, that our ideas of bodies are nothing but collections form'd by the mind of the ideas of the several distinct sensible qualities, of which objects are compos'd, and which we find to have a constant union with each other. But however these qualities may in themselves be entirely distinct, 'tis certain we commonly regard the compound, which they form, as One thing, and as continuing the Same under very considerable alterations. The acknowledge'd composition is evidently contrary to this suppos'd simplicity, and the variation to the identity. It may, therefore, be worth while to consider the causes, which make us almost universally fall into such evident contradictions, as well as the means by which we endeavour to conceal them.

最有判断力的哲学家都承认，我们对身体的观念只不过是由几个不同的感性品质的观念在头脑中形成的集合，物体是由这些品质组成的，而且我们发现它们彼此之间有持续的结合。但是，无论这些品质本身如何完全不同，可以肯定的是，我们通常把它们所形成的复合体视为一个东西，而且在非常大的变化下仍然是一样的。所承认的成分显然与这种假定的简单性相悖，而变化则与同一性相悖。因此，不妨考虑一下使我们几乎普遍陷入这种明显的矛盾的原因，以及我们努力掩盖这些矛盾的手段。

'Tis evident, that as the ideas of the several distinct successive qualities of objects are united together by a very close relation, the mind, in looking along the succession, must be carry'd from one part of it to another by an easy transition, and will no more perceive the change, than if it contemplated the same unchangeable object. This easy transition is the effect, or rather essence of relation; and as the imagination readily takes one idea for another, where their influence on the mind is similar; hence it proceeds, that any such succession of related qualities is readily consider'd as one continu'd object, existing without any variation. The smooth and uninterrupted progress of the thought, being alike in both cases, readily deceives the mind, and makes us ascribe an identity to the changeable succession of connected qualities. But when we alter our method of considering the succession, and instead of tracing it gradually thro' the successive points of time, survey at once any two distinct periods of its duration, and compare the different conditions of the successive qualities; in that case the variations, which were insensible when they arose gradually, do now appear of consequence, and seem entirely to destroy the identity. By this means there arises a kind of contrariety in our method of thinking, from the different points of view, in which we survey the object, and from the nearness or remoteness of those instants of time, which we compare together. When we gradually follow an object in its successive changes, the smooth progress of the thought makes us ascribe an identity to the succession; because 'tis by a similar act of the mind we consider an unchangeable object. When we compare its situation after a considerable change the progress of the thought is broke; and consequently we are presented with the idea of diversity: In order to reconcile which contradictions the imagination is apt to feign something unknown and invisible, which it supposes to continue the same under all these variations; and this unintelligible something it calls a substance, or original and first matter.

很明显，由于物体的几个不同的连续品质的观念是通过非常密切的关系结合在一起的，头脑在沿着这个连续的过程中，必须通过一个轻松的过渡从它的一个部分带到另一个部分，并且不会比考虑同一个不可改变的物体更能察觉到变化。这种轻松的过渡是关系的效果，或者说是关系的本质；由于想象力很容易把一个想法当作另一个想法，而它们对心灵的影响是相似的；因此，任何这种相关品质的连续都很容易被视为一个连续的物体，没有任何变化地存在。思想的顺利和不间断的进展，在两种情况下都是一样的，很容易欺骗心灵，并使我们把同一性归于相连的品质的变化的连续。但是，当我们改变考虑继承的方法，而不是通过连续的时间点逐渐追踪它，而是立即调查其持续时间的任何两个不同时期，并比较连续质量的不同条件；在这种情况下，变化，当它们逐渐产生时是不可见的，现在出现了后果，并似乎完全破坏了同一。通过这种方式，在我们的思维方法中出现了一种对比性，这种对比性来自于我们观察物体的不同角度，来自于我们一起比较的那些时间瞬间的远近。当我们逐渐跟踪一个物体的连续变化时，思维的顺利进行使我们对连续的变化归结为同一性；因为我们是通过类似的思维行为来考虑一个不可改变的物体。当我们比较它在一个相当大的变化之后的情况时，思想的进展就被打破了；因此，我们就出现了多样性的想法。为了调和这些矛盾，想象力很容易佯装出一些未知的和不可见的东西，它认为这些东西在所有这些变化中都是不变的；而这种不可理解的东西，它被称为物质，或者原始的和最初的物质。

We entertain a like notion with regard to the simplicity of substances, and from like causes. Suppose an object perfectly simple and indivisible to be presented, along with another object, whose co-existent parts are connected together by a strong relation, 'tis evident the actions of the mind, in considering these two objects, are not very different. The imagination conceives the simple object at once, with facility, by a single effort of thought, without change or variation. The connexion of parts in the compound object has almost the same effect, and so unites the object within itself, that the fancy feels not the transition in passing from one part to another. Hence the colour, taste, figure, solidity, and other qualities, combin'd in a peach or melon, are conceiv'd to form one thing; and that on account of their close relation, which makes them affect the thought in the same manner, as if perfectly uncompounded. But the mind rests not here. Whenever it views the object in another light, it finds that all these qualities are different, and distinguishable, and separable from each other; which view of things being destructive of its primary and more natural notions, obliges the imagination to feign an unknown something, or original substance and matter, as a principle of union or cohesion among these qualities, and as what may give the compound object a title to be call'd one thing, notwithstanding its diversity and composition.

对于物质的简单性，我们有一个类似的概念，也是出于类似的原因。假设一个完全简单和不可分割的物体与另一个物体一起出现，而后者的共存部分是通过一种强烈的关系连接在一起的，那么很明显，在考虑这两个物体时，心灵的行动并不十分不同。想象力通过单一的思想努力，立即轻松地构思出简单的物体，没有任何变化或改变。在复合物体中各部分的联系几乎具有相同的效果，并使物体在其内部结合起来，以至于想象力在从一个部分转到另一个部分时感觉不到过渡。因此，桃子或甜瓜的颜色、味道、形状、坚固性和其他品质结合在一起，被认为是一种东西；这是因为它们之间的密切关系，使它们以同样的方式影响思想，就像完全没有结合在一起。但是，思想并没有在这里休息。每当它从另一个角度看这个物体时，就会发现所有这些品质都是不同的，可以区分的，可以相互分离的；这种对事物的看法破坏了它的主要和更自然的概念，迫使想象力假装一个未知的东西，或者原始的物质和材料，作为这些品质之间的联合或凝聚的原则，并作为可能赋予复合物体一个名称的东西，尽管它的多样性和组成。

The peripatetic philosophy asserts the original matter to be perfectly homogeneous in all bodies, and considers fire, water, earth, and air, as of the very same substance; on account of their gradual revolutions and changes into each other. At the same time it assigns to each of these species of objects a distinct substantial form, which it supposes to be the source of all those different qualities they possess, and to be a new foundation of simplicity and identity to each particular species. All depends on our manner of viewing the objects. When we look along the insensible changes of bodies, we suppose all of them to be of the same substance or essence; When we consider their sensible differences, we attribute to each of them a substantial and essential difference. And in order to indulge ourselves in both these ways of considering our objects, we suppose all bodies to have at once a substance and a substantial form.

周易哲学认为，所有物体的原始物质都是完全同质的，并认为火、水、土和空气都是同一物质；因为它们是逐渐旋转和相互变化的。同时，它给这些物体的每一个种类分配了一个独特的实质形式，它认为这是它们拥有的所有这些不同品质的来源，并且是每个特定种类的简单性和同一性的新基础。一切都取决于我们观察物体的方式。当我们沿着身体的不可见的变化看时，我们认为它们都是相同的物质或本质；当我们考虑它们的感性差异时，我们把它们中的每一个都归结为实质性的和本质的差异。为了让自己沉浸在这两种考虑对象的方式中，我们假定所有的身体都同时具有一种物质和一种实质性的形式。

The notion of accidents is an unavoidable consequence of this method of thinking with regard to substances and substantial forms; nor can we forbear looking upon colours, sounds, tastes, figures, and other properties of bodies, as existences, which cannot subsist apart, but require a subject of inhesion to sustain and support them. For having never discover'd any of these sensible qualities, where, for the reasons above-mention'd, we did not likewise fancy a substance to exist; the same habit, which makes us infer a connexion betwixt cause and effect, makes us here infer a dependence of every quality on the unknown substance. The custom of imagining a dependence has the same effect as the custom of observing it wou'd have. This conceit, however, is no more reasonable than any of the foregoing. Every quality being a distinct thing from another, may be conceiv'd to exist apart, and may exist apart, not only from every other quality, but from that unintelligible chimera of a substance.

事故的概念是这种关于物质和实质形式的思考方法的一个不可避免的结果；我们也不能不把颜色、声音、味道、数字和身体的其他属性看作是存在，它们不能单独存在，而是需要一个内聚的主体来维持和支持它们。因为我们从来没有发现过这些可感的品质，由于上述原因，我们也没有想到有一种物质存在；同样的习惯，使我们推断出因果之间的联系，使我们在这里推断出每一种品质对未知物质的依赖。想象依赖关系的习惯与观察依赖关系的习惯具有同样的效果。然而，这种设想并不比前面的任何设想更合理。每一种质量都是与另一种质量不同的东西，可以被设想为单独存在，而且可以单独存在，不仅是与其他每一种质量，而且是与那种无法理解的物质的混合体。

But these philosophers carry their fictions still farther in their sentiments concerning occult qualities, and both suppose a substance supporting, which they do not understand, and an accident supported, of which they have as imperfect an idea. The whole system, therefore, is entirely incomprehensible, and yet is deriv'd from principles as natural as any of these above-explain'd.

但是，这些哲学家在他们关于神秘品质的情感中把他们的虚构带得更远，他们都假设有一个他们不理解的物质支持，以及一个他们对其有同样不完美的想法的意外支持。因此，整个系统是完全不可理解的，但它是由上述解释的任何原则自然衍生出来的。

In considering this subject we may observe a gradation of three opinions, that rise above each other, according as the persons, who form them, acquire new degrees of reason and knowledge. These opinions are that of the vulgar, that of a false philosophy, and that of the true; where we shall find upon enquiry, that the true philosophy approaches nearer to the sentiments of the vulgar, than to those of a mistaken knowledge. 'Tis natural for men, in their common and careless way of thinking, to imagine they perceive a connexion betwixt such objects as they have constantly found united together; and because custom has render'd it difficult to separate the ideas, they are apt to fancy such a separation to be in itself impossible and absurd. But philosophers, who abstract from the effects of custom, and compare the ideas of objects, immediately perceive the falshood of these vulgar sentiments, and discover that there is no known connexion among objects. Every different object appears to them entirely distinct and separate; and they perceive, that 'tis not from a view of the nature and qualities of objects we infer one from another, but only when in several instances we observe them to have been constantly conjoin'd. But these philosophers, instead of drawing a just inference from this observation, and concluding, that we have no idea of power or agency, separate from the mind, and belonging to causes; I say, instead of drawing this conclusion, they frequently search for the qualities, in which this agency consists, and are displeased with every system, which their reason suggests to them, in order to explain it. They have sufficient force of genius to free them from the vulgar error, that there is a natural and perceivable connexion betwixt the several sensible qualities and actions of matter; but not sufficient to keep them from ever seeking for this connexion in matter, or causes. Had they fallen upon the just conclusion, they wou'd have return'd back to the situation of the vulgar, and wou'd have regarded all these disquisitions with indolence and indifference. At present they seem to be in a very lamentable condition, and such as the poets have given us but a faint notion of in their descriptions of the punishment of Sisyphus and Tantalus. For what can be imagin'd more tormenting, than to seek with eagerness, what for ever flies us; and seek for it in a place, where 'tis impossible it can ever exist?

在考虑这个问题时，我们可以观察到三种观点的梯度，它们随着形成这些观点的人获得新的理性和知识程度而相互上升。这些观点是：庸俗的观点、错误的哲学观点和真正的观点；在这里我们会发现，真正的哲学比错误的知识更接近于庸俗的情感。人在普通和粗心的思考方式中，很自然地想象他们在经常发现结合在一起的物体之间发现了一种联系；由于习惯使人很难将这些想法分开，他们很容易认为这种分离本身是不可能和荒谬的。但是，哲学家们从习俗的影响中抽离出来，对物体的观念进行比较，就会立即察觉到这些庸俗情绪的虚假性，并发现物体之间没有已知的联系。在他们看来，每一个不同的物体都是完全不同的、独立的；他们还意识到，我们不是从物体的性质和质量的角度来推断一个物体，而是只有在我们观察到它们经常结合在一起的几个例子中才会这样做。但是，这些哲学家并没有从这种观察中得出公正的推论，并得出结论说，我们没有脱离心灵的、属于原因的力量或机构的概念；我说，他们并没有得出这个结论，而是经常寻找这种机构所包含的品质，并对他们的理性向他们建议的每一个系统感到不满意，以便解释它。他们有足够的天才力量把他们从庸俗的错误中解脱出来，即在物质的几种可感知的品质和行动之间存在着一种自然和可感知的联系；但还不足以使他们永远不在物质或原因中寻找这种联系。如果他们得出了正确的结论，他们就会回到庸人的境地，就会以懒惰和冷漠的态度看待所有这些讨论了。目前，他们似乎处于一种非常可悲的状态，就像诗人在描述西西弗斯和 坦塔罗斯的惩罚时，只给了我们一个模糊的概念。因为还有什么能比急切地寻找永远逃离我们的东西，并在一个它不可能存在的地方寻找它，更让人感到煎熬呢？

But as nature seems to have observ'd a kind of justice and compensation in every thing, she has not neglected philosophers more than the rest of the creation; but has reserv'd them a consolation amid all their disappointments and afflictions. This consolation principally consists in their invention of the words faculty and occult quality. For it being usual, after the frequent use of terms, which are really significant and intelligible, to omit the idea, which we wou'd express by them, and to preserve only the custom, by which we recal the idea at pleasure; so it naturally happens, that after the frequent use of terms, which are wholly insignificant and unintelligible, we fancy them to be on the same footing with the precedent, and to have a secret meaning, which we might discover by reflection. The resemblance of their appearance deceives the mind, as is usual, and makes us imagine a thorough resemblance and conformity. By this means these philosophers set themselves at ease, and arrive at last, by an illusion, at the same indifference, which the people attain by their stupidity, and true philosophers by their moderate scepticism. They need only say, that any phænomenon, which puzzles them, arises from a faculty or an occult quality, and there is an end of all dispute and enquiry upon the matter.

但是，由于大自然似乎在每件事情上都遵守一种公正和补偿，她对哲学家的忽视并不比其他受造物多；而是在他们所有的失望和痛苦中给他们保留了一种安慰。这种安慰主要包括他们发明的能力和神秘的品质这两个词。因为通常情况下，在经常使用真正有意义和可理解的术语之后，我们会省略我们想用它们表达的想法，而只保留我们乐意回忆这个想法的习惯；所以自然会发生这样的情况：在经常使用完全无意义和不可理解的术语之后，我们认为它们与前面的术语处于相同的地位，并且有一个秘密的含义，我们可以通过思考发现。它们外表的相似性欺骗了我们的心灵，就像往常一样，使我们想象出一种彻底的相似性和一致性。通过这种方式，这些哲学家让自己轻松起来，并通过一种幻觉最终达到了同样的冷漠，而这种冷漠是人们通过愚蠢达到的，是真正的哲学家通过温和的怀疑主义达到的。他们只需要说，任何令他们困惑的现象都是由一种能力或一种神秘的品质引起的，那么在这个问题上所有的争论和探究都将结束。

But among all the instances, wherein the Peripatetics have shewn they were guided by every trivial propensity of the imagination, no one is more remarkable than their sympathies, antipathies, and horrors of a vacuum. There is a very remarkable inclination in human nature, to bestow on external objects the same emotions, which it observes in itself; and to find every where those ideas, which are most present to it. This inclination, 'tis true, is suppress'd by a little reflection, and only takes place in children, poets, and the antient philosophers. It appears in children, by their desire of beating the stones, which hurt them: In poets, by their readiness to personify every thing: And in the antient philosophers, by these fictions of sympathy and antipathy. We must pardon children, because of their age; poets, because they profess to follow implicitly the suggestions of their fancy: But what excuse shall we find to justify our philosophers in so signal a weakness?

但是，在所有的例子中，Peripatetics 表明他们被每一个琐碎的想象力倾向所引导，没有一个例子比他们对真空的同情、反感和恐怖更引人注目。人性中有一种非常明显的倾向，就是把它在自己身上观察到的情绪赋予外部物体；并且在任何地方都能找到它最喜欢的想法。诚然，这种倾向只要稍加思考就会被抑制，而且只发生在儿童、诗人和古代的哲学家身上。它出现在儿童身上，因为他们想打石头，而石头会伤害他们。在诗人身上，他们愿意把每一件事都人格化；在古代的哲学家身上，他们虚构出同情和反感。我们必须原谅儿童，因为他们的年龄；原谅诗人，因为他们自称默默地听从他们幻想的建议。但我们能找到什么借口来为我们的哲学家们如此明显的弱点辩护呢？

 

Section 4. Of The Modern Philosophy

第 4 节。关于现代哲学

 

But here it may be objected, that the imagination, according to my own confession, being the ultimate judge of all systems of philosophy, I am unjust in blaming the antient philosophers for makeing use of that faculty, and allowing themselves to be entirely guided by it in their reasonings. In order to justify myself, I must distinguish in the imagination betwixt the principles which are permanent, irresistible, and universal; such as the customary tradition from causes to effects, and from effects to causes: And the principles, which are changeable, weak, and irregular; such as those I have just now taken notice of. The former are the foundation of all our thoughts and actions, so that upon their removal human nature must immediately perish and go to ruin. The latter are neither unavoidable to mankind, nor necessary, or so much as useful in the conduct of life; but on the contrary are observ'd only to take place in weak minds, and being opposite to the other principles of custom and reasoning, may easily be subverted by a due contrast and opposition. For this reason the former are received by philosophy, and the latter rejected. One who concludes somebody to be near him, when he hears an articulate voice in the dark, reasons justly and naturally; tho' that conclusion be deriv'd from nothing but custom, which infixes and inlivens the idea of a human creature, on account of his usual conjunction with the present impression. But one, who is tormented he knows not why, with the apprehension of spectres in the dark, may, perhaps, be said to reason, and to reason naturally too: But then it must be in the same sense, that a malady is said to be natural; as arising from natural causes, tho' it be contrary to health, the most agreeable and most natural situation of man. The opinions of the antient philosophers, their fictions of substance and accident, and their reasonings concerning substantial forms and occult qualities, are like the spectres in the dark, and are deriv'd from principles, which, however common, are neither universal nor unavoidable in human nature. The modern philosophy pretends to be entirely free from this defect, and to arise only from the solid, permanent, and consistent principles of the imagination. Upon what grounds this pretension is founded must now be the subject of our enquiry.

但在此可以反对，根据我自己的承认，想象力是所有哲学体系的最终评判者，我责备古代哲学家利用这种能力，并允许自己在推理中完全受其指导，是不公正的。为了自圆其说，我必须在想象中区分永久的、不可抗拒的和普遍的原则；比如从因到果、从果到因的习惯性传统。和那些易变的、软弱的、不规则的原则；比如我刚才提到的那些。前者是我们所有思想和行为的基础，因此，一旦它们被移除，人类的本性就必须立即灭亡，走向毁灭。后者既不是人类不可避免的，也不是必要的，更不是对生活有帮助的；相反，人们只注意到在软弱的头脑中发生，而且与习俗和推理的其他原则相反，很容易被适当的对比和反对所颠覆。因此，前者被哲学所接受，而后者被拒绝。当一个人在黑暗中听到一个清晰的声音时，他断定有人在他身边，他的理由是公正和自然的；尽管这个结论只是从习惯中推导出来的，因为习惯把人的概念加进去，因为他通常与现在的印象联系在一起。但是，一个不知道为什么被折磨着的人，在黑暗中对幽灵的担忧，也许可以说是在推理，而且是自然地推理。但是，必须在同样的意义上说，一种疾病被说成是自然的；因为它产生于自然的原因，尽管它违背了健康，人类最令人愉快和最自然的状况。古代哲学家的观点，他们对物质和意外的虚构，以及他们对实质形式和神秘品质的推理，就像黑暗中的幽灵，是由一些原则派生出来的，而这些原则无论多么常见，在人性中既不普遍也不可避免。现代哲学自称完全没有这种缺陷，而只是从想象力的坚实、永久和一致的原则中产生。现在，我们必须对这种说法的依据进行调查。

The fundamental principle of that philosophy is the opinion concerning colours, sounds, tastes, smells, heat and cold; which it asserts to be nothing but impressions in the mind, deriv'd from the operation of external objects, and without any resemblance to the qualities of the objects. Upon examination, I find only one of the reasons commonly produc'd for this opinion to be satisfactory, viz. that deriv'd from the variations of those impressions, even while the external object, to all appearance, continues the same. These variations depend upon several circumstances. Upon the different situations of our health: A man in a malady feels a disagreeable taste in meats, which before pleas'd him the most. Upon the different complexions and constitutions of men: That seems bitter to one, which is sweet to another. Upon the difference of their external situation and position: Colours reflected from the clouds change according to the distance of the clouds, and according to the angle they make with the eye and luminous body. Fire also communicates the sensation of pleasure at one distance, and that of pain at another. Instances of this kind are very numerous and frequent.

这种哲学的基本原则是关于颜色、声音、味道、气味、热度和冷度的观点；它断言，这些东西只不过是在头脑中的印象，是由外部物体的作用而产生的，与物体的品质没有任何相似之处。经过研究，我发现通常为这种观点提出的理由中只有一个是令人满意的，即从这些印象的变化中得出的，即使外部物体，在所有的外表下，仍然是一样的。这些变化取决于几种情况。在我们健康的不同情况下。一个患有疾病的人对肉食感到不舒服，而在以前他是最喜欢的。人的肤色和体质不同。对一个人来说是苦的，对另一个人来说是甜的。在他们外部情况和位置的不同上。从云层中反射出来的颜色会根据云层的距离以及它们与眼睛和发光体的角度而变化。火也会在某一距离传达快乐的感觉，而在另一距离传达痛苦的感觉。这样的例子非常多，也非常频繁。

The conclusion drawn from them, is likewise as satisfactory as can possibly be imagin'd. 'Tis certain, that when different impressions of the same sense arise from any object, every one of these impressions has not a resembling quality existent in the object. For as the same object cannot, at the same time, be endow'd with different qualities of the same sense, and as the same quality cannot resemble impressions entirely different; it evidently follows, that many of our impressions have no external model or archetype. Now from like effects we presume like causes. Many of the impressions of colour, sound, &c. are confest to he nothing but internal existences, and to arise from causes, which no ways resemble them. These impressions are in appearance nothing different from the other impressions of colour, sound, &c. We conclude, therefore, that they are, all of them, deriv'd from a like origin.

从它们得出的结论，也同样是可以想象的令人满意的。可以肯定的是，当同一感官的不同印象从任何物体中产生时，这些印象中的每一个都没有存在于物体中的相似品质。因为同一物体不可能同时被赋予同一感官的不同品质，而且同一品质不可能与完全不同的印象相似；显然，我们的许多印象没有外部模型或原型。现在，我们从相似的效果推测出相似的原因。许多颜色、声音等的印象被证实只是内部的存在，并来自于与它们毫不相像的原因。这些印象在外观上与其他颜色、声音等的印象没有什么不同。因此，我们的结论是，它们都是由一个类似的起源衍生出来的。

This principle being once admitted, all the other doctrines of that philosophy seem to follow by an easy consequence. For upon the removal of sounds, colours, heat, cold, and other sensible qualities, from the rank of continu'd independent existences, we are reduc'd merely to what are called primary qualities, as the only real ones, of which we have any adequate notion. These primary qualities are extension and solidity, with their different mixtures and modifications; figure, motion, gravity, and cohesion. The generation, encrease, decay, and corruption of animals and vegetables, are nothing but changes of figure and motion; as also the operations of all bodies on each other; of fire, of light, water, air, earth, and of all the elements and powers of nature. One figure and motion produces another figure and motion; nor does there remain in the material universe any other principle, either active or passive, of which we can form the most distant idea.

这个原则一旦被承认，该哲学的所有其他学说似乎都会因一个简单的结果而得到遵循。因为一旦把声音、颜色、热、冷和其他感性品质从持续的独立存在的等级中剔除，我们就只剩下所谓的初级品质了，因为这是唯一真实的品质，我们对它有充分的概念。这些主要的品质是延伸性和稳固性，以及它们不同的混合物和变体；形状、运动、重力和凝聚力。动物和蔬菜的生成、增加、衰亡和腐败，无非是形状和运动的变化；同样，所有物体的相互作用也是如此；火、光、水、空气、土以及自然界的所有元素和力量也是如此。一个图形和运动产生另一个图形和运动；在物质宇宙中也不存在任何其他原则，无论是主动的还是被动的，我们可以形成最遥远的概念。

I believe many objections might be made to this system: But at present I shall confine myself to one, which is in my opinion very decisive. I assert, that instead of explaining the operations of external objects by its means, we utterly annihilate all these objects, and reduce ourselves to the opinions of the most extravagant scepticism concerning them. If colours, sounds, tastes, and smells be merely perceptions, nothing we can conceive is possest of a real, continu'd, and independent existence; not even motion, extension and solidity, which are the primary qualities chiefly insisted on.

我相信对这一制度可以提出许多反对意见。但目前我只谈一个，在我看来是非常决定性的。我断言，我们不是用它来解释外部物体的作用，而是彻底消灭了所有这些物体，并使我们自己沦为对它们最奢侈的怀疑论的观点。如果颜色、声音、味道和气味仅仅是感知，那么我们所能想象的任何东西都不具备真实的、持续的和独立的存在；甚至连运动、延伸和坚固性也不具备，而这些是主要坚持的主要品质。

To begin with the examination of motion; 'tis evident this is a quality altogether inconceivable alone, and without a reference to some other object. The idea of motion necessarily supposes that of a body moving. Now what is our idea of the moving body, without which motion is incomprehensible? It must resolve itself into the idea of extension or of solidity; and consequently the reality of motion depends upon that of these other qualities.

首先是对运动的研究；很明显，这是一个单独的、不与其他物体相联系的、完全无法想象的品质。运动的概念必然假定有一个身体在运动。现在，我们对运动体的概念是什么，没有这个概念，运动是不可理解的？它必须转化为延伸性或稳固性的概念；因此，运动的现实性取决于这些其他品质的现实性。

This opinion, which is universally acknowledge'd concerning motion, I have prov'd to be true with regard to extension; and have shewn that 'tis impossible to conceive extension, but as compos'd of parts, endow'd with colour or solidity. The idea of extension is a compound idea; but as it is not compounded of an infinite number of parts or inferior ideas, it must at last resolve itself into such as are perfectly simple and indivisible. These simple and indivisible parts, not being ideas of extension, must be non-entities, unless conceiv'd as colour'd or solid. Colour is excluded from any real existence. The reality, therefore, of our idea of extension depends upon the reality of that of solidity, nor can the former be just while the latter is chimerical. Let us, then, lend our attention to the examination of the idea of solidity.

这个在运动方面被普遍承认的观点，我已经证明了在延伸方面的真实性；并且已经证明，除了由被赋予颜色或实体的部分组成之外，不可能想象出延伸。延展的概念是一个复合的概念；但由于它不是由无限多的部分或低级的概念组成的，它最后必须将自己分解为完全简单和不可分割的部分。这些简单而不可分割的部分，不属于延伸的观念，必须是非实体的，除非被设想为颜色或实体。颜色被排除在任何实际存在之外。因此，我们的延伸概念的真实性取决于实体概念的真实性，前者不可能是公正的，而后者则是虚构的。那么，让我们把注意力转移到对实体性概念的研究上。

The idea of solidity is that of two objects, which being impell'd by the utmost force, cannot penetrate each other; but still maintain a separate and distinct existence. Solidity, therefore, is perfectly incomprehensible alone, and without the conception of some bodies, which are solid, and maintain this separate and distinct existence. Now what idea have we of these bodies? The ideas of colours, sounds, and other secondary qualities are excluded. The idea of motion depends on that of extension, and the idea of extension on that of solidity. 'Tis impossible, therefore, that the idea of solidity can depend on either of them. For that wou'd be to run in a circle, and make one idea depend on another, while at the same time the latter depends on the former. Our modern philosophy, therefore, leaves us no just nor satisfactory idea of solidity; nor consequently of matter.

固体的概念是指两个物体，它们被最大的力量所推动，不能穿透对方；但仍然保持着独立和不同的存在。因此，如果没有一些物体的概念，实体性是完全无法理解的，这些物体是固体，并保持这种单独和独特的存在。现在我们对这些身体有什么概念呢？颜色、声音和其他次要品质的概念被排除在外。运动的概念取决于延伸的概念，而延伸的概念则取决于实体的概念。因此，实体性的概念不可能取决于其中任何一个。因为那将是在绕圈子，使一个概念依赖于另一个概念，而同时后者又依赖于前者。因此，我们的现代哲学没有给我们留下关于实体性的公正或令人满意的概念；因此，也没有留下关于物质的概念。

This argument will appear entirely conclusive to every one that comprehends it; but because it may seem abstruse and intricate to the generality of readers, I hope to be excus'd, if I endeavour to render it more obvious by some variation of the expression. In order to form an idea of solidity, we must conceive two bodies pressing on each other without any penetration; and 'tis impossible to arrive at this idea, when we confine ourselves to one object, much more without conceiving any. Two non-entities cannot exclude each other from their places; because they never possess any place, nor can be endow'd with any quality. Now I ask, what idea do we form of these bodies or objects, to which we suppose solidity to belong? To say, that we conceive them merely as solid, is to run on in infinitum. To affirm, that we paint them out to ourselves as extended, either resolves all into a false idea, or returns in a circle. Extension must necessarily be consider'd either as colour'd, which is a false idea; or as solid, which brings us back to the first question. We may make the same observation concerning mobility and figure; and upon the whole must conclude, that after the exclusion of colours, sounds, heat and cold from the rank of external existences, there remains nothing, which can afford us a just and consistent idea of body.

这个论点对每一个理解它的人来说都是完全结论性的；但由于它对广大读者来说可能显得深奥和错综复杂，如果我努力通过一些表达方式的变化使它更加明显，我希望能够得到原谅。为了形成稳固性的概念，我们必须设想两个物体在没有任何穿透力的情况下相互压迫；而当我们把自己局限于一个物体时，就不可能得出这个概念，更不用说没有任何设想了。两个非实体不能把对方排除在它们的位置之外；因为它们从不拥有任何位置，也不能被赋予任何质量。现在我问，我们对这些我们认为属于实体的身体或物体形成什么概念？如果说我们仅仅把它们想象成固体，那就是在无休止地进行下去。申明我们把它们描绘成延伸的，要么是把所有的东西都化为一个错误的概念，要么是在一个循环中返回。延伸必须被认为是彩色的，这是一个错误的概念；或者是固体的，这使我们回到了第一个问题。我们可以对移动性和形状做同样的观察；总的来说，我们必须得出结论，在把颜色、声音、热和冷从外部存在的等级中排除之后，就没有什么能给我们提供一个关于身体的公正和一致的概念。

Add to this, that, properly speaking, solidity or impenetrability is nothing, but an impossibility of annihilation, as36 has been already observ'd: For which reason 'tis the more necessary for us to form some distinct idea of that object, whose annihilation we suppose impossible. An impossibility of being annihilated cannot exist, and can never be conceived to exist, by itself; but necessarily requires some object or real existence, to which it may belong. Now the difficulty still remains, how to form an idea of this object or existence, without having recourse to the secondary and sensible qualities.

此外，正确地说，坚固性或不可渗透性只不过是一种不可能消灭的现象，正如36我们已经看到了。因此，我们更有必要对我们认为不可能湮灭的物体形成一些独特的概念。一个不可能被消灭的事物本身不可能存在，也不可能被设想为存在；而是必然需要一些对象或实际存在，它可能属于这些对象。现在，困难仍然存在，如何形成对这个对象或存在的概念，而不求助于次要的和可感的品质。

Nor must we omit on this occasion our accustom'd method of examining ideas by considering those impressions, from which they are deriv'd. The impressions, which enter by the sight and hearing, the smell and taste, are affirm'd by modern philosophy to be without any resembling objects; and consequently the idea of solidity, which is suppos'd to be real, can never be deriv'd from any of these senses. There remains, therefore, the feeling as the only sense, that can convey the impression, which is original to the idea of solidity; and indeed we naturally imagine, that we feel the solidity of bodies, and need but touch any object in order to perceive this quality. But this method of thinking is more popular than philosophical; as will appear from the following reflections.

在这种情况下，我们也不能省略我们习惯的方法，即通过考虑它们所衍生的那些印象来检验观念。通过视觉和听觉、嗅觉和味觉进入的印象，被现代哲学确认为没有任何类似的对象；因此，被认为是真实的实体性观念，永远不可能从这些感官中派生出来。因此，感觉是唯一能够传递印象的感官，而这种印象是实体性概念的原点；事实上，我们自然而然地想象，我们能感觉到身体的实体性，而且只需要触摸任何物体就能感知到这种品质。但这种思维方法是流行的，而不是哲学的；从下面的思考中可以看出。

First, 'Tis easy to observe, that tho' bodies are felt by means of their solidity, yet the feeling is a quite different thing from the solidity; and that they have not the least resemblance to each other. A man, who has the palsey in one hand, has as perfect an idea of impenetrability, when he observes that hand to be supported by the table, as when he feels the same table with the other hand. An object, that presses upon any of our members, meets with resistance; and that resistance, by the motion it gives to the nerves and animal spirits, conveys a certain sensation to the mind; but it does not follow, that the sensation, motion, and resistance are any ways resembling.

首先，我们很容易观察到，尽管身体是通过它们的坚固性来感受的，但这种感受与坚固性是完全不同的；它们之间没有丝毫的相似之处。一个人，如果一只手有麻痹，当他观察到那只手被桌子支撑着时，与他用另一只手感觉到同一张桌子时一样，有一种完美的不可穿透的想法。一个物体压在我们的任何部件上，都会遇到阻力；这种阻力通过它给神经和动物精神带来的运动，给心灵带来某种感觉；但这并不意味着，这种感觉、运动和阻力有任何相似之处。

Secondly, The impressions of touch are simple impressions, except when consider'd with regard to their extension; which makes nothing to the present purpose: And from this simplicity I infer, that they neither represent solidity, nor any, real object. For let us put two cases, viz. that of a man, who presses a stone, or any solid body, with his hand, and that of two stones, which press each other; 'twill readily be allow'd, that these two cases are not in every respect alike, but that in the former there is conjoin'd with the solidity, a feeling or sensation, of which there is no appearance in the latter. In order, therefore, to make these two cases alike, 'tis necessary to remove some part of the impression, which the man feels by his hand, or organ of sensation; and that being impossible in a simple impression, obliges us to remove the whole, and proves that this whole impression has no archetype or model in external objects. To which we may add, that solidity necessarily supposes two bodies, along with contiguity and impulse; which being a compound object, can never be represented by a simple impression. Not to mention, that tho' solidity continues always invariably the same, the impressions of touch change every moment upon us; which is a clear proof that the latter are not representations of the former.

第二，触摸的印象是简单的印象，除非考虑到它们的延伸；这对目前的目的没有任何意义：从这种简单性我推断，它们既不代表实体，也不代表任何真实的物体。因为让我们举两个例子，即一个人用手按压石头或任何固体物体，以及两块石头互相按压；我们很容易就会发现，这两种情况在各方面都不一样，但在前者中，有一种感觉或感受与固体结合在一起，而在后者中却没有出现。因此，为了使这两种情况相同，有必要去除印象的某些部分，即人通过他的手或感觉器官感受到的部分；而这在一个简单的印象中是不可能的，因此我们必须去除整个印象，并证明整个印象在外部物体中没有原型或模式。对此，我们可以补充说，实体性必然假定有两个身体，以及毗连性和冲力；作为一个复合物体，它永远不可能被一个简单的印象所代表。更不用说，尽管实体性总是不变的，但触摸的印象在我们身上每时每刻都在变化；这清楚地证明了后者不是前者的代表。

Thus there is a direct and total opposition betwixt our reason and our senses; or more properly speaking, betwixt those conclusions we form from cause and effect, and those that persuade us of the continu'd and independent existence of body. When we reason from cause and effect, we conclude, that neither colour, sound, taste, nor smell have a continu'd and independent existence. When we exclude these sensible qualities there remains nothing in the universe, which has such an existence.

因此，在我们的理性和我们的感官之间存在着直接和完全的对立；或者更恰当地说，在我们从因果关系形成的结论和那些说服我们身体的持续和独立存在的结论之间存在着对立。当我们从因果关系中推理时，我们的结论是：颜色、声音、味道或气味都没有持续和独立的存在。当我们排除了这些感性的品质，宇宙中就没有任何东西具有这样的存在。

 

Section 5. Of The Immateriality Of The Soul

第 5 节。关于灵魂的非物质性

 

Having found such contradictions and difficulties in every system concerning external objects, and in the idea of matter, which we fancy so clear and determinate, we shall naturally expect still greater difficulties and contradiction in every hypothesis concerning our internal perceptions, and the nature of the mind, which we are apt to imagine so much more obscure, and uncertain. But in this we shou'd deceive ourselves. The intellectual world, tho' involv'd in infinite obscurities, is not perplex'd with any such contradictions, as those we have discover'd in the natural. What is known concerning it, agrees with itself; and what is unknown, we must be contented to leave so.

既然在每一个关于外部物体的系统中，以及在我们认为如此清晰和确定的物质概念中，都发现了这样的矛盾和困难，我们自然会期待在每一个关于我们内部感知和心灵本质的假设中，出现更大的困难和矛盾，我们很可能会认为这些假设更加模糊和不确定。但在这一点上，我们应该自欺欺人。智力世界虽然有无限的模糊性，但并不像我们在自然界发现的那样，被任何这样的矛盾所困扰。关于它，已知的东西与它本身一致；而未知的东西，我们必须满足于让它这样。

'Tis true, wou'd we hearken to certain philosophers, they promise to diminish our ignorance; but I am afraid 'tis at the hazard of running us into contradictions, from which the subject is of itself exempted. These philosophers are the curious reasoners concerning the material or immaterial substances, in which they suppose our perceptions to inhere. In order to put a stop to these endless cavils on both sides, I know no better method, than to ask these philosophers in a few words, What they mean by substance and inhesion? And after they have answer'd this question, 'twill then be reasonable, and not till then, to enter seriously into the dispute.

诚然，如果我们听从某些哲学家的意见，他们承诺会减少我们的无知；但我担心这是在让我们陷入矛盾的危险中，而这个问题本身是可以避免的。这些哲学家是关于物质或非物质的奇怪推理者，他们认为我们的知觉存在于其中。为了制止双方这些无休止的争论，我不知道有什么更好的方法，只能用几句话问这些哲学家，他们所说的物质和内涵是什么意思？在他们回答了这个问题之后，就可以合理地，而不是在那之前，认真地进入这个争论。

This question we have found impossible to be answer'd with regard to matter and body: But besides that in the case of the mind, it labours under all the same difficulties, 'tis burthen'd with some additional ones, which are peculiar to that subject. As every idea is deriv'd from a precedent impression, had we any idea of the substance of our minds, we must also have an impression of it; which is very difficult, if not impossible, to be conceiv'd. For how can an impression represent a substance, otherwise than by resembling it? And how can an impression resemble a substance, since, according to this philosophy, it is not substance, and has none of the peculiar qualities or characteristics of a substance?

我们发现这个问题在物质和身体方面是无法回答的。但是，除了在心灵的情况下，它在所有相同的困难下挣扎，它还被一些额外的困难所困扰，这些困难是该主题所特有的。由于每一个观念都是由先前的印象派生出来的，如果我们对我们思想的实质有任何观念，我们也必须对它有一个印象；这是很困难的，如果不是不可能的话，可以想象。因为印象除了与物质相似外，怎么能代表它呢？既然根据这种哲学，印象不是物质，也没有物质的特殊品质或特征，那么，印象怎么可能与物质相似？

But leaving the question of what may or may not be, for that other what actually is, I desire those philosophers, who pretend that we have an idea of the substance of our minds, to point out the impression that produces it, and tell distinctly after what manner that impression operates, and from what object it is deriv'd. Is it an impression of sensation or of redaction? Is it pleasant, or painful, or indifferent? Does it attend us at all times, or does it only return at intervals? If at intervals, at what times principally does it return, and by what causes is it produc'd?

但是，把 “可能” 或 “不可能” 的问题留给 “实际是什么” 的问题，我希望那些假装我们有一个关于我们心灵实质的想法的哲学家指出产生这种想法的印象，并清楚地告诉我们这种印象是以什么方式运作的，以及它是从什么对象衍生出来的。它是一种感觉的印象还是节制的印象？它是愉快的，还是痛苦的，还是无所谓的？它是一直伴随着我们，还是只在一段时间内回来？如果是间歇性的，它主要是在什么时候回来的，它是由什么原因产生的？

If instead of answering these questions, any one shou'd evade the difficulty, by saying, that the definition of a substance is something which may exist by itself; and that this definition ought to satisfy us: Shou'd this be said, I shou'd observe, that this definition agrees to every thing, that can possibly be conceiv'd; and never will serve to distinguish substance from accident, or the soul from its perceptions. For thus I reason. Whatever is clearly conceiv'd may exist; and whatever is clearly conceiv'd, after any manner, may exist after the same manner. This is one principle, which has been already acknowledg'd. Again, every thing, which is different, is distinguishable, and every thing which is distinguishable, is separable by the imagination. This is another principle. My conclusion from both is, that since all our perceptions are different from each other, and from every thing else in the universe, they are also distinct and separable, and may be consider'd as separately existent, and may exist separately, and have no need of any thing else to support their existence. They are, therefore, substances, as far as this definition explains a substance.

如果有人不回答这些问题，而是回避困难，说物质的定义是可以自行存在的东西；而且这个定义应该让我们满意。如果这样说，我就会说，这个定义符合每一件可能被设想的事情；而且永远不会用于区分物质和意外，或者灵魂和它的感知。因为我是这样推理的。凡是明确设想的，都可以存在；凡是明确设想的，以任何方式，都可以以同样的方式存在。这是一个原则，已经被承认了。另外，每件不同的东西都是可以区分的，每件可以区分的东西都是可以通过想象力分离的。这是另一个原则。我从这两方面得出的结论是，既然我们所有的感知都是彼此不同的，也是与宇宙中的其他事物不同的，那么它们也是有区别的、可分离的，可以被认为是单独存在的，可以单独存在，不需要任何其他东西来支持它们的存在。因此，就这个定义对物质的解释而言，它们是物质。

Thus neither by considering the first origin of ideas, nor by means of a definition are we able to arrive at any satisfactory notion of substance; which seems to me a sufficient reason for abandoning utterly that dispute concerning the materiality and immateriality of the soul, and makes me absolutely condemn even the question itself. We have no perfect idea of any thing but of a perception. A substance is entirely different from a perception. We have, therefore, no idea of a substance. Inhesion in something is suppos'd to be requisite to support the existence of our perceptions. Nothing appears requisite to support the existence of a perception. We have, therefore, no idea of inhesion. What possibility then of answering that question, Whether perception inhere in a material or immaterial substance, when we do not so much as understand the meaning of the question?

因此，无论是通过考虑观念的最初起源，还是通过定义，我们都无法得出任何令人满意的物质概念；在我看来，这似乎是彻底放弃关于灵魂的物质性和非物质性的争论的充分理由，并使我甚至对这个问题本身也予以绝对谴责。我们对任何事物都没有完美的概念，只有感知的概念。物质与感知完全不同。因此，我们没有关于物质的概念。某种东西的内聚力被认为是支持我们的感知存在的必要条件。似乎没有什么是支持知觉的存在所必需的。因此，我们没有关于内聚的概念。那么，当我们连这个问题的含义都不明白的时候，还有什么可能回答这个问题，即感知是存在于物质还是非物质中呢？

There is one argument commonly employ'd for the immateriality of the soul, which seems to me remarkable. Whatever is extended consists of parts; and whatever consists of parts is divisible, if not in reality, at least in the imagination. But 'tis impossible any thing divisible can be conjoin'd to a thought or perception, which is a being altogether inseparable and indivisible. For supposing such a conjunction, wou'd the indivisible thought exist on the left or on the right hand of this extended divisible body? On the surface or in the middle? On the back- or fore-side of it? If it be conjoin'd with the extension, it must exist somewhere within its dimensions. If it exist within its dimensions, it must either exist in one particular part; and then that particular part is indivisible, and the perception is conjoin'd only with it, not with the extension: Or if the thought exists in every part, it must also be extended, and separable, and divisible, as well as the body; which is utterly absurd and contradictory. For can any one conceive a passion of a yard in length, a foot in breadth, and an inch in thickness? Thought, therefore, and extension are qualities wholly incompatible, and never can incorporate together into one subject.

对于灵魂的非物质性，有一个通常采用的论据，在我看来是非常重要的。凡是延伸的东西都由部分组成；凡是由部分组成的东西都是可分割的，如果不是在现实中，至少是在想象中。但是，任何可分割的东西都不可能与思想或感知结合在一起，而思想或感知是一个完全不可分割的存在。因为假设有这样的结合，不可分割的思想会不会存在于这个扩展的可分割体的左手或右手？在表面还是在中间？在它的背面还是正面？如果它与扩展体相连，它就必须存在于它的某处。如果它存在于它的尺寸之内，那么它必须存在于一个特定的部分；然后那个特定的部分是不可分割的，而感知只与它相连，而不是与延伸部分相连。或者，如果思想存在于每一个部分，它也必须像身体一样是延伸的、可分离的和可分割的；这完全是荒谬的和矛盾的。因为有人能想象出一码的长度、一英尺的宽度和一英寸的厚度的激情吗？因此，思想和延伸是完全不相容的品质，而且永远不可能结合在一起成为一个主体。

This argument affects not the question concerning the substance of the soul, but only that concerning its local conjunction with matter; and therefore it may not be improper to consider in general what objects are, or are not susceptible of a local conjunction. This is a curious question, and may lead us to some discoveries of considerable moment.

这个论点不影响关于灵魂的实质的问题，而只影响关于它与物质的局部结合的问题；因此，一般地考虑什么物体是，或不可能是局部结合的，也许并无不妥。这是一个奇怪的问题，可能会导致我们有一些相当重要的发现。

The first notion of space and extension is deriv'd solely from the senses of sight and feeling; nor is there any thing, but what is colour'd or tangible, that has parts dispos'd after such a manner, as to convey that idea. When we diminish or encrease a relish, 'tis not after the same manner that we diminish or increase any visible object; and when several sounds strike our hearing at once, custom and reflection alone make us form an idea of the degrees of the distance and contiguity of those bodies, from which they are deriv'd. Whatever marks the place of its existence either must be extended, or must be a mathematical point, without parts or composition. What is extended must have a particular figure, as square, round, triangular; none of which will agree to a desire, or indeed to any impression or idea, except of these two senses above-mention'd. Neither ought a desire, tho' indivisible, to be consider'd as a mathematical point. For in that case 'twou'd be possible, by the addition of others, to make two, three, four desires, and these dispos'd and situated in such a manner, as to have a determinate length, breadth and thickness; which is evidently absurd.

空间和延伸的第一个概念完全来自视觉和感觉的感官；除了有颜色或有形的东西，也没有任何东西的部件是按照这样的方式配置的，以传达这一概念。当我们减少或增加一种味道时，并不是以同样的方式减少或增加任何可见的物体；当几种声音同时冲击我们的听觉时，只有习惯和思考才能使我们对这些物体的距离和毗连程度形成一个概念，而这些声音就是从这些物体中产生的。凡是标志着其存在的地方，要么必须是延伸的，要么必须是一个数学上的点，没有部分或组成。延伸的东西必须有一个特定的图形，如方形、圆形、三角形；除了上面提到的这两种意义外，这些都不会与欲望相一致，也不会与任何印象或想法相一致。尽管欲望是不可分割的，但也不应该被视为一个数学上的点。因为在这种情况下，通过增加其他的欲望，就有可能形成两个、三个、四个欲望，而这些欲望的分布和位置是这样的，即具有确定的长度、宽度和厚度；这显然是荒谬的。

'Twill not be surprising after this, if I deliver a maxim, which is condemn'd by several metaphysicians, and is esteem'd contrary to the most certain principles of human reason. This maxim is that an object may exist, and yet be no where: and I assert, that this is not only possible, but that the greatest part of beings do and must exist after this manner. An object may be said to be no where, when its parts are not so situated with respect to each other, as to form any figure or quantity; nor the whole with respect to other bodies so as to answer to our notions of contiguity or distance. Now this is evidently the case with all our perceptions and objects, except those of the sight and feeling. A moral reflection cannot be plac'd on the right or on the left hand of a passion, nor can a smell or sound be either of a circular or a square figure. These objects and perceptions, so far from requiring any particular place, are absolutely incompatible with it, and even the imagination cannot attribute it to them. And as to the absurdity of supposing them to be no where, we may consider, that if the passions and sentiments appear to the perception to have any particular place, the idea of extension might be deriv'd from them, as well as from the sight and touch; contrary to what we have already establish'd. If they appear not to have any particular place, they may possibly exist in the same manner; since whatever we conceive is possible.

在这之后，如果我提出一条格言，也就不足为奇了，这条格言受到几位形而上学家的谴责，并被认为是与人类理性的最确定原则相违背的。这句格言是，一个物体可以存在，但却不在任何地方：我断言，这不仅是可能的，而且大部分的生命确实也必须以这种方式存在。当一个物体的各个部分相互之间没有形成任何图形或数量时，就可以说它不在任何地方；当整个物体相对于其他物体而言，也不符合我们关于毗连或距离的概念时，就可以说它不在任何地方。现在，除了视觉和感觉之外，我们所有的知觉和对象显然都是这样。道德上的反思不能放在激情的右边或左边，气味或声音也不能是圆形或方形的。这些物体和感觉，远远不需要任何特定的位置，而是与之绝对不相容的，甚至想象力也不能把它归于它们。至于认为它们不在任何地方的荒谬性，我们可以考虑，如果激情和情感在知觉中看起来有任何特定的地方，那么延伸的概念可能会从它们那里衍生出来，就像从视觉和触觉一样；这与我们已经确定的情况相反。如果它们看起来没有任何特定的位置，它们就可能以同样的方式存在；因为我们所设想的都是可能的。

'Twill not now be necessary to prove, that those perceptions, which are simple, and exist no where, are incapable of any conjunction in place with matter or body, which is extended and divisible; since 'tis impossible to found a relation37 but on some common quality. It may be better worth our while to remark, that this question of the local conjunction of objects does not only occur in metaphysical disputes concerning the nature of the soul, but that even in common life we have every moment occasion to examine it. Thus supposing we consider a fig at one end of the table, and an olive at the other, 'tis evident, that in forming the complex ideas of these substances, one of the most obvious is that of their different relishes; and 'tis as evident, that we incorporate and conjoin these qualities with such as are colour'd and tangible. The bitter taste of the one, and sweet of the other are suppos'd to lie in the very visible body, and to be separated from each other by the whole length of the table. This is so notable and so natural an illusion, that it may be proper to consider the principles, from which it is deriv'd.

现在不需要证明，那些简单的、不存在于任何地方的知觉，不可能与物质或身体结合在一起，而物质或身体是扩展的、可分割的；因为不可能找到一种关系37因为除了某种共同的质量之外，不可能找到一种关系。也许更值得我们注意的是，物体的局部结合问题不仅发生在关于灵魂本质的形而上学争论中，而且甚至在普通生活中我们也随时有机会研究它。因此，假设我们把无花果放在桌子的一端，把橄榄放在另一端，很明显，在形成这些物质的复杂概念时，最明显的一点是它们不同的味道；同样明显的是，我们把这些品质与那些有颜色和有形的品质结合起来。一个人的苦味和另一个人的甜味被认为就在可见的身体里，并通过整个桌子的长度相互分离。这种错觉是如此明显和自然，以至于我们应该考虑其产生的原理。

Tho' an extended object be incapable of a conjunction in place with another, that exists without any place or extension, yet are they susceptible of many other relations. Thus the taste and smell of any fruit are inseparable from its other qualities of colour and tangibility; and which-ever of them be the cause or effect, 'tis certain they are always co-existent. Nor are they only co-existent in general, but also co-temporary in their appearance in the mind; and 'tis upon the application of the extended body to our senses we perceive its particular taste and smell. These relations, then, of causation, and contiguity in the time of their appearance, betwixt the extended object and the quality, which exists without any particular place, must have such an effect on the mind, that upon the appearance of one it will immediately turn its thought to the conception of the other. Nor is this all. We not only turn our thought from one to the other upon account of their relation, but likewise endeavour to give them a new relation, viz. that of a conjunction in place, that we may render the transition more easy and natural. For 'tis a quality, which I shall often have occasion to remark in human nature, and shall explain more fully in its proper place, that when objects are united by any relation, we have a strong propensity to add some new relation to them, in order to compleat the union. In our arrangement of bodies we never fail to place such as are resembling, in contiguity to each other, or at least in correspondent points of view: Why? but because we feel a satisfaction in joining the relation of contiguity to that of resemblance, or the resemblance of situation to that of qualities. The effects of this propensity have been 38already observ'd in that resemblance, which we so readily suppose betwixt particular impressions and their external causes: But we shall not find a more evident effect of it, than in the present instance, where from the relations of causation and contiguity in time betwixt two objects, we feign likewise that of a conjunction in place, in order to strengthen the connexion.

尽管一个延伸的物体不能与另一个没有任何位置或延伸的物体结合在一起，但它们却能产生许多其他关系。因此，任何水果的味道和气味都与它的颜色和触感等其他品质密不可分；无论它们中的哪一个是原因或结果，可以肯定的是它们总是共存的。它们不仅在一般情况下是共存的，而且在它们出现在头脑中的时候也是共存的；正是在把扩展的身体应用于我们的感官时，我们才感知到了它的特殊味道和气味。那么，这些因果关系，以及它们出现时的相邻性，在扩展的物体和质量之间，没有任何特定的地方存在，必须对心灵产生这样的影响，即当一个出现时，它将立即把它的思想转向另一个的概念。这也不是全部。我们不仅根据它们之间的关系将我们的思想从一个转向另一个，而且还努力赋予它们一种新的关系，即 在位置上的结合，以便我们可以使过渡更加容易和自然。因为这是我在人性中经常要提到的一种品质，我将在适当的地方更充分地解释，当物体通过任何关系结合在一起时，我们有一种强烈的倾向，要给它们增加一些新的关系，以完成这种结合。在我们对物体的安排中，我们从来都会把那些相似的物体放在彼此相邻的地方，或者至少放在相应的角度。因为我们在把毗连关系和相似关系结合起来时感到满意，或者把情况的相似性和品质的相似性结合起来。这种倾向的影响已经在 38这种倾向的效果已经在这种相似性中观察到了，我们如此轻易地假设特定的印象和它们的外部原因之间的相似性。但我们找不到比现在更明显的效果了，在这个例子中，我们从两个物体之间的因果关系和时间上的毗连关系中，同样假装出地方上的结合，以加强这种联系。

But whatever confus'd notions we may form of an union in place betwixt an extended body, as a fig, and its particular taste, 'tis certain that upon reflection we must observe in this union something altogether unintelligible and contradictory. For shou'd we ask ourselves one obvious question, viz. if the taste, which we conceive to be contain'd in the circumference of the body, is in every part of it or in one only, we must quickly find ourselves at a loss, and perceive the impossibility of ever giving a satisfactory answer. We cannot reply, that 'tis only in one part: For experience convinces us, that every part has the same relish. We can as little reply, that it exists in every part: For then we must suppose it figur'd and extended; which is absurd and incomprehensible. Here then we are influenc'd by two principles directly contrary to each other, viz. that inclination of our fancy by which we are determin'd to incorporate the taste with the extended object, and our reason, which shows us the impossibility of such an union. Being divided betwixt these opposite principles, we renounce neither one nor the other, but involve the subject in such confusion and obscurity, that we no longer perceive the opposition. We suppose, that the taste exists within the circumference of the body, but in such a manner, that it fills the whole without extension, and exists entire in every part without separation. In short, we use in our most familiar way of thinking, that scholastic principle, which, when crudely propos'd, appears so shocking, of totem in toto & totum in qualibel parte: Which is much the same, as if we shou'd say, that a thing is in a certain place, and yet is not there.

但是，无论我们对无花果这样一个扩展的身体与它的特殊味道之间的结合形成什么样的混乱概念，可以肯定的是，经过思考，我们必须在这种结合中看到一些完全无法理解和相互矛盾的东西。因为如果我们问自己一个明显的问题，即我们认为包含在身体周围的味道是在身体的每个部分还是只在一个部分，我们一定会很快发现自己无所适从，并意识到不可能给出一个满意的答案。我们不能回答说 “只在一个部位”。因为经验告诉我们，每一部分都有同样的味道。我们也不能回答说，它存在于每个部分。因为那样的话，我们必须假定它是形象化的和扩展的；这是很荒谬的和不可理解的。在这里，我们受到两个直接相反的原则的影响，即我们的幻想的倾向，根据这种倾向，我们决定把味道和扩展的物体结合起来，而我们的理性则告诉我们这种结合是不可能的。在这些相反的原则之间，我们既不放弃一个，也不放弃另一个，而是把这个问题卷入如此混乱和晦涩之中，以至于我们不再察觉到对立。我们认为，味觉存在于身体的圆周内，但它是以这样一种方式存在的，即它充满了整个身体而没有延伸，并且完整地存在于每个部分而没有分离。简而言之，我们用我们最熟悉的方式来思考，那条学术原则，当它被粗略地提出来时，显得如此令人震惊，即totem in toto & totum in qualibel parte。这就好比我们说，一个东西在某个地方，但又不在那里，是一样的。

All this absurdity proceeds from our endeavouring to bestow a place on what is utterly incapable of it; and that endeavour again arises from our inclination to compleat an union, which is founded on causation, and a contiguity of time, by attributing to the objects a conjunction in place. But if ever reason be of sufficient force to overcome prejudice, 'tis certain, that in the present case it must prevail. For we have only this choice left, either to suppose that some beings exist without any place; or that they are figur'd and extended; or that when they are incorporated with extended objects, the whole is in the whole, and the whole in every part. The absurdity of the two last suppositions proves sufficiently the veracity of the first. Nor is there any fourth opinion. For as to the supposition of their existence in the manner of mathematical points, it resolves itself into the second opinion, and supposes, that several passions may be plac'd in a circular figure, and that a certain number of smells, conjoin'd with a certain number of sounds, may make a body of twelve cubic inches; which appears ridiculous upon the bare mentioning of it.

所有这些荒谬都来自于我们试图给完全不可能有的东西赋予一个位置；而这种努力又来自于我们的倾向，即通过将对象在位置上的结合归因于因果关系和时间上的连续性，来完成一种结合。但是，如果理性有足够的力量来克服偏见，那么可以肯定的是，在目前的情况下，它必须占上风。因为我们只剩下这样的选择，要么假设某些生命存在而没有任何地方；要么假设它们是具象的和延伸的；要么假设当它们与延伸的物体结合时，整体在整体中，而整体在每个部分中。最后两个假设的荒谬性充分证明了第一个假设的真实性。也没有任何第四种观点。因为关于它们以数学点的方式存在的假设，它自己就变成了第二种意见，并假设几个激情可以放在一个圆形中，一定数量的气味与一定数量的声音结合在一起，可以组成一个 12 立方英寸的身体；一提到这一点就显得很荒谬。

But tho' in this view of things we cannot refuse to condemn the materialists, who conjoin all thought with extension; yet a little reflection will show us equal reason for blaming their antagonists, who conjoin all thought with a simple and indivisible substance. The most vulgar philosophy informs us, that no external object can make itself known to the mind immediately, and without the interposition of an image or perception. That table, which just now appears to me, is only a perception, and all its qualities are qualities of a perception. Now the most obvious of all its qualities is extension. The perception consists of parts. These parts are so situated, as to afford us the notion of distance and contiguity; of length, breadth, and thickness. The termination of these three dimensions is what we call figure. This figure is moveable, separable, and divisible. Mobility, and separability are the distinguishing properties of extended objects. And to cut short all disputes, the very idea of extension is copy'd from nothing but an impression, and consequently must perfectly agree to it, To say the idea of extension agrees to any thing, is to say it is extended. The free-thinker may now triumph in his turn; and having found there are impressions and ideas really extended, may ask his antagonists, how they can incorporate a simple and indivisible subject with an extended perception? All the arguments of Theologians may here be retorted upon them. Is the indivisible subject, or immaterial substance, if you will, on the left or on the right hand of the perception? Is it in this particular part, or in that other? Is it in every part without being extended? Or is it entire in any one part without deserting the rest? 'Tis impossible to give any answer to these questions, but what will both be absurd in itself, and will account for the union of our indivisible perceptions with an extended substance.

但是，尽管从这个角度来看，我们不能拒绝谴责唯物主义者，因为他们把所有的思想都与扩展联系在一起；但稍加思考就会发现，我们有同样的理由责备他们的对立面，因为他们把所有的思想都与一个简单而不可分割的物质联系在一起。最庸俗的哲学告诉我们，没有任何外部物体能够在没有图像或感知的干扰下立即让心灵了解自己。刚才出现在我面前的那张桌子，只是一种感知，它的所有品质都是一种感知的品质。现在，它的所有品质中最明显的是延伸。感知是由部分组成的。这些部分的位置是这样的，以便为我们提供距离和毗连的概念；长度、宽度和厚度的概念。这三个维度的终端就是我们所说的数字。这个图形是可移动的、可分离的和可分割的。可移动性和可分离性是扩展物体的区别属性。为了缩短所有的争论，延伸的概念是由印象复制而来的，因此必须完全同意它，说延伸的概念同意任何事物，就是说它是延伸的。自由思想家现在可以取得胜利了；在发现有印象和观念真正的延伸之后，他可以问他的对手，他们怎么能把一个简单而不可分割的主体与一个延伸的感知结合起来？神学家们的所有论据都可以在此反驳他们。不可分割的主体，或者非物质的物质，如果你愿意，是在感知的左手还是右手？它是在这个特定的部分，还是在另一个部分？它是在每一个部分都没有被扩展吗？或者说，它在任何一个部分都是完整的，而没有遗弃其他部分？对于这些问题，不可能给出任何答案，只能给出本身就很荒谬的答案，并说明我们不可分割的知觉与一个扩展的物质的结合。

This gives me an occasion to take a-new into consideration the question concerning the substance of the soul; and tho' I have condemn'd that question as utterly unintelligible, yet I cannot forbear proposing some farther reflections concerning it. I assert, that the doctrine of the immateriality, simplicity, and indivisibility of a thinking substance is a true atheism, and will serve to justify all those sentiments, for which Spinoza is so universally infamous. From this topic, I hope at least to reap one advantage, that my adversaries will not have any pretext to render the present doctrine odious by their declamations, when they see that they can be so easily retorted on them.

这使我有机会重新考虑关于灵魂物质的问题；虽然我已经谴责这个问题完全不可理解，但我还是忍不住提出一些关于它的进一步思考。我断言，关于思想物质的非物质性、简单性和不可分割性的学说是真正的无神论，并将有助于证明斯宾诺莎如此普遍地臭名昭著的所有那些情绪。从这个话题中，我希望至少能收获一个好处，那就是我的对手看到他们可以如此轻易地反驳他们，就不会有任何借口通过他们的声明使目前的学说变得可憎。

The fundamental principle of the atheism of Spinoza is the doctrine of the simplicity of the universe, and the unity of that substance, in which he supposes both thought and matter to inhere. There is only one substance, says he, in the world; and that substance is perfectly simple and indivisible, and exists every where, without any local presence. Whatever we discover externally by sensation; whatever we feel internally by reflection; all these are nothing but modifications of that one, simple, and necessarily existent being, and are not possest of any separate or distinct existence. Every passion of the soul; every configuration of matter, however different and various, inhere in the same substance, and preserve in themselves their characters of distinction, without communicating them to that subject, in which they inhere. The same substratum, if I may so speak, supports the most different modifications, without any difference in itself; and varies them, without any variation. Neither time, nor place, nor all the diversity of nature are able to produce any composition or change in its perfect simplicity and identity.

斯宾诺莎无神论的基本原则是宇宙的简单性和物质的统一性的学说，他认为思想和物质都在其中。他说，世界上只有一种物质；这种物质是完全简单和不可分割的，它存在于任何地方，没有任何局部存在。无论我们在外部通过感觉发现什么；无论我们在内部通过思考感受到什么；所有这些都不过是那个唯一的、简单的、必然存在的存在物的修饰，并不拥有任何单独或不同的存在。灵魂的每一种激情；物质的每一种构造，无论多么不同和多样，都存在于同一物质中，并在自身中保持着它们的区别特征，而不把它们传给它们所存在的那个主体。如果我可以这样说的话，同一个基质支持最不同的修饰，而本身没有任何差异；并且改变它们，没有任何变化。无论是时间、地点，还是自然界的所有多样性，都不能在其完美的简单性和同一性中产生任何构成或变化。

I believe this brief exposition of the principles of that famous atheist will be sufficient for the present purpose, and that without entering farther into these gloomy and obscure regions, I shall be able to shew, that this hideous hypothesis is almost the same with that of the immateriality of the soul, which has become so popular. To make this evident, let us 39remember, that as every idea is deriv'd from a preceding perception, 'tis impossible our idea of a perception, and that of an object or external existence can ever represent what are specifically different from each other. Whatever difference we may suppose betwixt them, 'tis still incomprehensible to us; and we are oblig'd either to conceive an external object merely as a relation without a relative, or to make it the very same with a perception or impression.

我相信，对这位著名的无神论者的原则的这一简要阐述就足以达到目前的目的，而且，在不进一步进入这些阴暗和晦涩的区域的情况下，我将能够证明，这个可怕的假设与已经变得如此流行的灵魂非物质性的假设几乎相同。为了证明这一点，让我们 39为了证明这一点，让我们记住，由于每一个概念都是由前面的感知派生出来的，所以我们对感知的概念和对物体或外部存在的概念不可能代表彼此之间的具体差异。无论我们认为它们之间有什么区别，对我们来说都是不可理解的；我们不得不把一个外部物体仅仅设想为一种没有相对性的关系，或者把它与一个感知或印象看作是一样的。

The consequence I shall draw from this may, at first sight, appear a mere sophism; but upon the least examination will be found solid and satisfactory. I say then, that since we may suppose, but never can conceive a specific difference betwixt an object and impression; any conclusion we form concerning the connexion and repugnance of impressions, will not be known certainly to be applicable to objects; but that on the other hand, whatever conclusions of this kind we form concerning objects, will most certainly be applicable to impressions. The reason is not difficult.
